webTitle: England fix trip to France and try for Italy

fields.headline: England fix trip to France and try for Italy
fields.trailText: England will face France in a friendly during the run-up to the World Cup qualifiers with Germany and Finland, and are also negotiating for a subsequent game in Italy.
fields.body:
England will face France in a friendly during the run-up to the World Cup qualifiers with Germany and Finland, and are also negotiating for a subsequent game in Italy.

The World Cup holders will provide the opposition for Kevin Keegan's squad at Stade de France on September 2, then Germany come to Wembley on October 7, the stadium's last match, and four days later England face the Finns in Helsinki. The Football Association expects to arrange a match with Italy for November.

Liverpool's Michael Owen, 20, will not be asked to play for England Under-21 in their European Championship play-off against Yugoslavia in Barcelona on Wednesday week, but his club-mate Emile Heskey and West Ham's Rio Ferdinand are almost certain to be included.

"Kevin [Keegan] and I have discussed this squad a lot and our priority is to ensure that the Under-21 team qualifies for the finals," said Howard Wilkinson, the Football Association's technical director.

The FA is to introduce an advanced coaching course which conforms to Uefa standards to try to reduce the failure rate of first-time managers such as John Barnes (Celtic), Chris Waddle (Burnley) and Adrian Heath (Sheffield United). In mainland Europe qualifications are required to work as a coach; the FA is expected to introduce the same criteria in three years.

 An Alessandro Del Piero penalty gave Juventus a 3-2 victory against their city rivals Torino and took them nine points clear in Serie A. Second-placed Lazio, who visit Chelsea on Wednesday, lost 1-0 at Verona, Leonardo missed a penalty for fourth-placed Milan as they went down 1-0 at Venezia, and Roma were beaten 2-0 by visiting Reggina. Internazionale were held 1-1 by Bologna on Saturday.

 In Spain Miguel Angel Angulo scored two for Valencia, who host Manchester United tomorrow, but they were held 2-2 at home by Malaga.

webTitle: Beckham barnet steals the show on Thatch of the Day

fields.headline: Beckham barnet steals the show on Thatch of the Day
fields.trailText: These are exciting times for BBC Sport. The Boat Race, the climax to the Six Nations, and the Grand National are all among Grandstand's forthcoming attractions, and on Saturday they had the big one: first pictures of David Beckham's new haircut.
fields.body:
These are exciting times for BBC Sport. The Boat Race, the climax to the Six Nations, and the Grand National are all among Grandstand's forthcoming attractions, and on Saturday they had the big one: first pictures of David Beckham's new haircut.

Barry Davies, whose interest in hairdressing has hitherto been kept under wraps, was bubbling over with excitement. "The haircut may be worthy of a US marine, but the free-kick was no howitzer," he said in his half-time report, proving that a sound knowledge of the effete world of hairdressing and a manly interest in military hardware are not necessarily mutually exclusive.

I could hardly wait for Match of the Day for further and deeper analysis. According to my morning paper Beckham had paid £300 for his haircut, and on the evidence of the fleeting glimpse we were allowed on Grandstand it did not look like 300 quid's worth to me. When my son had something similar done I handed over a fiver - including tip - so I was busting to take a closer look at what a nurse's weekly wage could buy you in the home counties.

At that price, I figured, you would want your hairdo topped off with something more exotic than Brylcreem. Beluga caviar, perhaps, or finest Colombian cocaine - "God's way of telling you you have too much money," as Robin Williams once described it, although that was obviously before he had seen Beckham's haircut.

"That's a close-up of the Beckham barnet," announced Bazza when the big moment arrived. "Yes, that is David Beckham." The camera sought out the newly shorn midfielder at every opportunity. "The new-style David Beckham just like the old-style," said Bazza when the free-kick went in, and as Ryan Giggs ruffled what was left of the midfielder's hair he warned: "Careful not to cut your fingers."

As the teams left the field there was time for one last reference to the most famous haircut since Samson: "The scorer was this man David Beckham, his contribution not only the haircut but the goal that settled the match."

Interestingly Matt Elliott, interviewed after the match, favoured a similarly close-cropped style and, although I am no expert, it did not look half as good as Beckham's. I should say the hairdressers of Leicestershire need to sharpen up their act. Dwight Yorke, quizzed on the all- important issue, was also impressed with his team-mate's new look. "The haircut of Becks certainly suited him," he said. "There has been a bit of banter in the dressing room but he has taken it on the chin."

"I thought it was on his head," said Gary Lineker, whose years working with Nick Hancock and Rory McGrath on They Think It's All Over have clearly not been wasted. Actually, that rather dismal line notwithstanding, Lineker is looking much happier on Match of the Day these days, possibly buoyed by reports that the show is to get an earlier start time, and certainly encouraged by the growing confidence of Mark Lawrenson, who has hit a rich vein of form in recent weeks.

Lawrenson, whose primary material used to be semi-humorous historical references to Trevor and Gary's playing careers, now appears unafraid to be more forthright on the subject of the modern game, and to have some fun with it in a way that was formerly the exclusive province of Ron Atkinson.

"The ball came across and Eustace was useless in that position," he said of the Coventry midfielder. He was similarly scathing about Tahar El Khalej's dive in the box - the Moroccan roll, as the caption dubbed it - but without taking the outrage too seriously.

I had been hoping Match of the Day might dispatch Bazza to the Dell to see if he could come up with any exciting and innovative pronunciations for South-ampton's new Moroccan, but I fully accept that his services were needed for the important matter of the haircut, and he did not let us down.

For the cost of five visits to Becks's barber you could buy yourself into Channel 4's Friday-night poker game, a bizarre addition to the roster of televised sport. Seven players chip in £1,500 each and the last one standing goes through to Binion's Horseshoe in Las Vegas, home of the World Series of Poker.

Poker has apparently become the cult success of Channel 4's post-pub schedule, but I can only assume that is because the alternative is yet another programme in which pink and drunken young people disport themselves in a Mediterranean holiday resort, or a revival of Confessions of a Window Cleaner.

T he brand of poker played in the World Series is called "No Limit Texas Hold 'em", which I found particularly inscrutable. The "unique under-the-table camera" reveals to us the cards the players are holding, which is supposed to elucidate the play, but I remained none the wiser. Still, now that the technology is available I should like to see the under-the-table camera used more widely, at awards dinners for instance.

The big problem with poker on TV, which I cannot see them overcoming, is that what the casual viewer really wants to see is the expressions on the players' faces. But since they are masters of concealment in that area, you rarely see any. Perhaps if some of them had a haircut?

webTitle: Home and away: a tale of the divide between rich and poor

fields.headline: Home and away: a tale of the divide between rich and poor
fields.trailText: The routine manner in which Manchester United strolled to victory in a potentially difficult fixture at Leicester seemed to add firm evidence to the impression that the Premiership is becoming easier to win.
fields.body:
The routine manner in which Manchester United strolled to victory in a potentially difficult fixture at Leicester seemed to add firm evidence to the impression that the Premiership is becoming easier to win.

United, after all, have drawn clear of all but one of their rivals while effortlessly switching their attention between the Premiership, the Champions League and assorted Mickey Mouse cup competitions.

One bookmaker has already emptied his satchel to punters who backed Man U to retain their title, and even Leeds's 4-1 win over Wimbledon yesterday to close the gap to four points will not persuade him that he paid out prematurely.

If he were to look more closely at the statistics, however, he might at least take the precaution of retaining the names and addresses of those who have banked his cheques. Leeds, if they continue to gather points at the same rate, will equal Man U's haul of 79 points last term, the highest since the Premiership was reduced to 20 clubs in 1996-97.

So Manchester United will probably need a record points total to retain their crown. They are, though, on course to finish with a remarkable 84 points; on a points-to-games ratio, that would be superior even to their performance of 1993-94, when they won a 22-club league with 92 points.

Depressingly for those who believe that in football, as in life, the rift between rich and poor continues to grow wider each year, the figures are also quite damning. Watford, on current form, will finish last with a record low 23 points, eclipsing what was regarded as an abysmal return of 30 by Nottingham Forest last year.

And whether it is Bradford City or Derby who join Watford and Sheffield Wednesday in the Nationwide next season, they will do well to beat the 36 points gathered by Charlton, who finished 18th last season.

So the good news for those coming up from the Nationwide League is that fewer points are needed for Premiership survival. The bad news is that they are harder to come by than a decent hairdresser.

The battle between Brad ford and Derby for survival may rest on their game at Valley Parade on April 23. That is disturbing news for Rodney Marsh, the former England striker turned television critic, who has promised to go even further in the drastic haircut department than David Beckham if Bradford stay up, since the latter seem to understand that gaining points at home is the secret of survival.

Whereas the key to winning the title, as the two Uniteds in first and second place have once again demonstrated, is in consistent success away from home, at the bottom it is all about home comforts. So if Bradford, beaten only three times in 14 home matches, maintain that kind of form while scraping a couple of draws away, they may yet reduce Marsh to a slaphead come the middle of May.

The perennial strugglers Coventry long ago learned about the importance of home form, so much so that their manager Gordon Strachan almost crowed about how bad they were at Leeds a fortnight ago, telling reporters it would have been better to view the game on Ceefax.

Coventry's 4-0 win over Bradford on Saturday was, astonishingly, their 10th from 16 home games, which for 24 hours was equal to the home successes of Leeds and Arsenal. Coventry, in fact, could field their reserves in away matches and still expect to gain enough points at Highfield Road to secure safety.

Southampton are much the same, virtually securing safety again with a 2-0 win over Aston Villa, who had not lost in their previous 12 games. It was another example of the benefits of playing at a tight, awkward ground such as the Dell, which used even to be a graveyard for Manchester United, who famously blamed their defeat there a couple of years ago on a grey away strip. One fears for Southampton when they move to their proposed new stadium.

But the biggest indictment of Premiership standards is that Villa remain in sixth place, 21 points off the leaders yet only 17 ahead of Bradford in 18th spot. Such is the gap between the leading clubs and the rest, which may also explain why Manchester United and Chelsea are in the last eight of the Champions League and Arsenal and Leeds seem set to reach the last four of the Uefa Cup. They are, despite appearances, in a different league.

webTitle: The Bhoys are back with a cautious victory

fields.headline: The Bhoys are back with a cautious victory
fields.trailText: Celtic, by the use of perspiration rather than imagination, won the League Cup yesterday by comfortably seeing off the challenge of Aberdeen as every bit of statistical evidence said they would.
fields.body:
Celtic, by the use of perspiration rather than imagination, won the League Cup yesterday by comfortably seeing off the challenge of Aberdeen as every bit of statistical evidence said they would.

In what may still end up as an unsatisfactory season, they at least have a trophy to show off. "I was getting fed up looking at team groups and all there was in front of the players in the picture were a couple of balls and the physio's bag," said one fan.

The goals from Vidar Riseth and Tommy Johnson were nicely timed and the manager Kenny Dalglish took no risks after that as Celtic played the rest of the game cautiously. The departed John Barnes, it should be added in fairness, had a hand in this small triumph for a club that has been used to slender pickings recently.

There was little of the swagger that had been seen when the Bhoys planted 18 goals past Aberdeen in three league matches this season, but the business still had to be done. The Dons may have shaken off the tag of Europe's worst first division team but they are hardly the finished article and Jonathan Gould was completely untroubled in the Celtic goal.

Dalglish was in his taciturn mode at the end. "I've only won a couple of matches. John Barnes did the rest and the players worked really hard," he said. "It will allow our supporters to go to work in a good mood in the morning."

Celtic were largely in control throughout with Tom Boyd marshalling the defence and Morten Wieghorst and Lubomir Moravcik setting out their midfield stalls. Only up front, where Mark Viduka was strangely subdued, could any weakness be found.

But their lead in the 15th minute rather confounded the bright start Aberdeen had made to the match. The goal was another small indication of the defensive frailties that have blighted the Dons since the start of the season.

Moravcik, probing away on the left, held up the ball just long enough for Wieghorst to make his forward run and he delivered the ball around Mark Perry's feet. The Dane found Riseth, of all people, standing alone on the six-yard line and, after a rather inelegant swing, the ball ended up in the back of the net.

Aberdeen continued to prove through the first half that they had brought some vibrancy to the occasion - Hicham Zerouali's wasted volley from an Arild Stavrum cross showing a willingness to attack opponents still struggling to string passes together.

But the Dons could do only so much and no more. Their chances collapsed in an eight-minute period after the interval in which one of their players was carried off, another sent off, and in which they conceded a second goal.

The Moroccan Zerouali looked in considerable pain after an awkward but scarcely malevolent challenge on Jackie McNamara. Five minutes later, Celtic had the game wrapped up when McNamara, Moravcik and Viduka all combined down the middle to allow Johnson to draw Jim Leighton and beat him with a cross shot.

As Celtic went for the jugular, Thomas Solberg's desperate and illegal tackle on Stilian Petrov saw him dismissed for a second bookable offence.

Moravcik later saw his chip cannon back off the bar, but it mattered not. Aberdeen supporters were left only to contemplate a long and largely silent journey home.

webTitle: Taylor sanguine as he hatches two-year plan

fields.headline: Taylor sanguine as he hatches two-year plan
fields.trailText: Graham Taylor clasped his hands and looked to the heavens. "Please, please," he cried, "are you listening to what I'm saying?" The smile, though, was a giveaway. The Watford manager may be praying for a miracle but he is not counting on one.
fields.body:
Graham Taylor clasped his hands and looked to the heavens. "Please, please," he cried, "are you listening to what I'm saying?" The smile, though, was a giveaway. The Watford manager may be praying for a miracle but he is not counting on one.

"If the next stage for this club is that they're a yo-yo club that's great news given where we've come from and what we're doing," Taylor said. "That's the reality. If we do go down my reaction is we have two years to get back up." The two years of Premiership parachute payments, that is.

Defeatism? Realism more like. Taylor has not given up but these two sides looked as likely to survive as David Beckham is to be searching for a hairbrush this morning.

The win will bolster Watford's confidence - "You wonder where your next draw will come from," Taylor said - but even if they discover the self-belief of Naseem Hamed, making up 10 points would be a tall order. Arsenal, Manchester United and Leeds await.

Soon it may be Crewe and Stockport, yet Taylor is understandably jolly. Watford were in the Second Division in 1997-98. They, like Charlton, have budgeted carefully, will stick by their manager and should hold on to most of their players. Only the skilful but unproductive Nordin Wooter has made noises about leaving.

Relegation seems bleaker for Wednesday, dispirited, hugely in debt and certain to lose key men. Wim Jonk in the First Division? Gilles de Bilde and Niclas Alexandersson sticking around? And despite rebuilding, there will not be patience. It is hard to imagine Hillsborough fans saying: "We have two years to get back up."

This defeat proved not only that Wednesday lack the quality and guts to survive but also that Danny Wilson is not related to Nostradamus after all. "I don't expect the lads to lose again," the manager had said. Near the end of a dreadful game Allan Smart knocked in Tommy Smith's cross.

Results elsewhere mean Wednesday are no worse off but it was a measure of their poverty that Watford kept their first clean sheet in 24 matches. For Wilson this was the end of the so-called beginning. Taylor is sleeping easy knowing relegation would not be the beginning of the end.

This defeat proved not only that Wednesday lack the quality and guts to survive but also that Danny Wilson is not related to Nostradamus after all. "I don't expect the lads to lose again," the manager had said. Near the end of a dreadful game Allan Smart knocked in Tommy Smith's cross. Results elsewhere mean Wednesday are no worse off but it was a measure of their poverty that Watford kept their first clean sheet in 24 matches. For Wilson this was the end of the so-called beginning. Taylor is sleeping easy knowing relegation would not be the beginning of the end.

fields.headline: Smith's timing keeps Huddersfield ticking
fields.trailText: At least Martin Smith was confident. Four goals in four games is not to be sniffed at by any striker and, with Wolves winning at Swindon, the centre-forward's early breakthrough was all that kept Huddersfield Town in a play-off position.
fields.body:
At least Martin Smith was confident. Four goals in four games is not to be sniffed at by any striker and, with Wolves winning at Swindon, the centre-forward's early breakthrough was all that kept Huddersfield Town in a play-off position.

"We've got as good a chance of promotion as anyone," Smith said. "Just so long as we're up there anything can happen."

He spoke with the assurance of someone who has already tasted promotion, as a member of the Sunderland squad who went up to the Premiership last time around, but his words rather put a gloss on what was a scrappy display.

This was only Huddersfield's third win in 14 games and they do beg the question: who outside Charlton in the First Division is going to have a snowflake's chance in hell of making an impression on the top flight? The answer is that whoever accompanies the Addicks into the Premiership might as well have next year's bottom two slots assigned to them now.

Huddersfield could yet be one of them. They have none too daunting a run-in, which continues tomorrow night when they play Nottingham Forest at home, and their final game away to Fulham could prove the clincher for a play-off place.

Smith will be expected to keep scoring. He was bought for £300,000 from Sheffield United in February and this was his 14th league goal of the campaign. "The season's gone ever so well," he said. "It was just what I needed, a decent run in the side." He took his chance coolly, slotting the ball past Brian Jensen from Clyde Wijnhard's pass.

It was cruel luck for West Bromwich Albion, who battled hard all the way in their second game under Gary Megson but ended up one place off the relegation zone.

Tomorrow night they go to Portsmouth, and Megson admitted: "We're in a position where we need other results to go for us." Sooner rather than later: their last game is home to Charlton.

fields.headline: No way Sauzée
fields.trailText: Franck Sauzée must rather like playing matches for Hibernian at the weekend. During the rest of the week he tries to turn a deaf ear to all the pleading that he should stay in Scotland next season.
fields.body:
Franck Sauzée must rather like playing matches for Hibernian at the weekend. During the rest of the week he tries to turn a deaf ear to all the pleading that he should stay in Scotland next season.

The 34-year-old Frenchman scored the critical second goal in Hibs' 3-1 derby win over Hearts and lost four teeth in the process. He toured the ground at the final whistle to an emotional standing ovation.

Sauzée has already told his manager Alex McLeish that business matters and his family will take him away from Edinburgh. But Hibs captain John Hughes revealed after the game that the dressing-room is now playing its part in the persuasion process. "We've told him we all want him to stay but we're not making much progress", he said.

McLeish added: "He's still a bit worried about his legs standing up for another season and he doesn't want to be sitting on the bench. I can understand that. But it would take millions to find a younger player with similar ability and we don't have millions."

fields.headline: Reds sail through calm waters
fields.trailText: Before long Manchester United's sixth Premiership title in eight seasons will surely be taken as red. Their rivals are running out of points of order and United just keep on winning.
fields.body:
Before long Manchester United's sixth Premiership title in eight seasons will surely be taken as red. Their rivals are running out of points of order and United just keep on winning.

Week by week it becomes harder to envisage just where Sir Alex Ferguson's team could come unstuck. Leicester City, beaten 6-2 on their own ground by United last season, might have been expected to give them a hard game at Filbert Street on Saturday if only for the sake of self-esteem, but it did not happen.

United lolloped through a low-key match won by a free-kick from David Beckham and a neat finish by Dwight Yorke. Ferguson fielded the side that three nights earlier had ensured a place in the quarter-finals of the Champions League with an inspired, passionate performance against Fiorentina, but against Leicester his team merely unwound.

To be caught this season United would have to lose probably three of their remaining nine Premiership matches. Given the remainder of their programme this is hard to envisage. Of the four teams due to visit Old Trafford only Chelsea are likely to cause the champions problems. The others, West Ham, Sunderland and Tottenham, will need to catch them on off days. Away from home United have to travel to Bradford City, Middlesbrough, Southampton, Watford and, on the last weekend, Aston Villa. As run-ins go this one looks a doddle.

Ferguson has given every indication that from now on he will field his strongest side in most matches. "At this stage of the season there comes a time when we have to play the same team in every game," he explained on Saturday. "With Leeds chasing us we can't afford to make mistakes."

Tomorrow United complete the second phase of the Champions League in Valencia where they will need to avoid being defeated by three goals or more to stay top of Group B and steer clear of Bayern Munich and Barcelona, who have already won their groups, in Friday's quarter-final draw.

Though Ferguson can afford to rest Yorke or Andy Cole, or perhaps both, in this game he will want to revert to his first-choice side at Valley Parade at the weekend. At least Bradford City, unlike Leicester on Saturday, will surely force United to raise a sweat.

Leicester's vapid performance was thoroughly untypical of a team who have made tenacity and aggression articles of faith. Martin O'Neill's players seemed mesmerised by the gentle ebb and flow of United's football.

Or perhaps it was more a matter of not wanting to be routed on their own ground for a second successive season. As O'Neil pointed out: "In that match, when we were 4-2 down we kept on attacking and they just picked us off on the break to win 6-2. If we'd kept on playing it could have ended up 19-2."

So a certain wariness in Leicester's football was understandable, although O'Neill was disappointed that his players failed to increase the tempo in the second half. Leicester have now lost twice since the departure of Emile Heskey to Liverpool and their attack has still to readjust. Playing the ball over the top of opposing defenders does not carry the same threat now that Heskey's power and speed are not there.

Beckham's hair is now styled after the US marines and just past the half-hour he dipped a free-kick inside the near post helped by a Leicester wall built after the style of Jericho. Seven minutes from the end Matt Elliott failed to intercept a low centre from Ryan Giggs and Yorke completed a victory which had long looked inevitable.

webTitle: Pulis primes Pompey for the great escape

fields.headline: Pulis primes Pompey for the great escape
fields.trailText: The caller to the BBC's radio phone-in Six-O-Six, his vision apparently clouded by the euphoria of an away win, missed the point completely.
fields.body:
The caller to the BBC's radio phone-in Six-O-Six, his vision apparently clouded by the euphoria of an away win, missed the point completely.

He suggested that Portsmouth do not deserve to be relegated because they are the club who have held the FA Cup for the longest time, thanks to war breaking out shortly after their sole success in 1939.

A more accurate prognosis is that Portsmouth do not deserve to go down because, on this evidence at least, they possess several players of genuine pedigree as well as a manager who is slowly gaining a reputation as one of the game's more progressive thinkers.

Further reason for optimism comes with growing historical evidence that Pompey, in common with daffodils, the Six Nations tournament and their distinguished alumnus Darren Anderton, appear to come to life only once we are well into the month of March. This win, their second in a week, looks to have put them on course for a third great escape in three seasons.

Their manager Tony Pulis counselled caution, saying victory here will mean nothing unless it is followed by a similar display at home to West Bromwich Albion in another six-pointer tomorrow night. "Between now and the end of the season it's going to be very difficult," he said. "We've got two massive games at Fratton Park now and this result on its own changes nothing for me."

Crewe may have peaked too soon. This was an abject display, particularly as it followed four consecutive wins. Compared to the visitors' powerful spine of Darren Moore, Shaun Derry and Lee Bradbury, Dario Gradi's team were woefully lacking in presence.

Indeed, it was a major surprise when the Crewe midfielder Colin Cramb cancelled out Steve Claridge's opener just before the hour, rather less so when goals from Thomas Thorgersen and the impressive Kevin Harper sealed victory for Portsmouth and prompted that delirious, if misguided, telephone call to Charlie Whelan.

webTitle: Peacock roasted on return of the prodigal

fields.headline: Peacock roasted on return of the prodigal
fields.trailText: "This is a new me; I'm not taking the game home with me," said Graeme Souness after his first match in charge of Blackburn, as if no one knew how volcanoes work. He took a point home, though, that Rovers had no right to, thanks to Maik Taylor's second gaffe.
fields.body:
"This is a new me; I'm not taking the game home with me," said Graeme Souness after his first match in charge of Blackburn, as if no one knew how volcanoes work. He took a point home, though, that Rovers had no right to, thanks to Maik Taylor's second gaffe.

In fact the two keepers kept them in the game. Alan Kelly held or tipped over four point-blank shots and saved Karlheinz Riedle's early penalty (Germans are not infallible). Taylor dived over David Dunn's half-hit shot and, far from goal, punched a late cross to Keith Gillespie, who chipped in.

"Ten seconds before the goal I had said to Tony Parkes [now assistant manager] we've not got Gary Gillespie into the game," said Souness. Perhaps he should at least take home and learn his charges' names.

Apart from Kelly they got no one into the game, which was a mess of midfield congestion and poor first touches. Both sides needed someone with an enlarged hippocampus. Before the match Souness spoke of winning all 10 games left, which would probably take them to the play-offs. He then played a 4-1-4-1 formation.

He also promised to give everyone a chance to prove himself in the 10 games. Darren Peacock must have blown his in one. The game's only footballing pleasure lay in Riedle, initially overborne by the defender, pulling away and beating him consistently in the air with run and jump. It would have been fitting if his header, nipping in front of Peacock, had decided the game. Peacock had conceded the penalty, beaten by the speed of Riedle's turn, and was at fault before Barry Hayles's acute blast for the first goal. He could not look more foolish if he saw Beckham's barber and sorted out a disguise while he is still on Blackburn wages.

"I want to be fair to people," said Souness. It would have been kind and sensible to replace Peacock with Christian Dailly.

Souness accepts that self-belief is low. His own is not in doubt. "This is just the sort of challenge I relish," he said, though he has met his previous ones with little success - what challenge is Rangers? - and at Anfield he destroyed all that was most precious. He is unlikely to touch Jack Walker's promised £20m until the close season.

This was tame for a tycoon-weight title fight, the battle of the big-spenders. Fulham were at it again last week. The American midfielder Eddie Lewis, signed for £1.2m on video evidence, was on the bench. But to the owners players are merely a means; promotion is all.

Through the afternoon the PA warned of an evacuation exercise at the whistle. When the time came, it was cancelled. Too many had left to make it worthwhile. Fulham's manager Paul Bracewell may follow at the end of the season. Souness may have a little longer to feel the pressure.

webTitle: Negative forces rule on derby day

fields.headline: Negative forces rule on derby day
fields.trailText: At its worst this was more like a bad game of Pokemon than a football match: both sides intent upon destruction, nobody much concerned with attempting anything creative.
fields.byline: David Hopps at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
At its worst this was more like a bad game of Pokemon than a football match: both sides intent upon destruction, nobody much concerned with attempting anything creative.

Even Brian Clough, appearing at half-time, could not resist a playful hack at Kevin Phillips's shins as the England striker presented him with a Sunderland No9 shirt.

Sunderland will draw encouragement from the fact that they have now played four games against Middlesbrough and Newcastle without being beaten. But there is scant encouragement elsewhere. Third in mid-December, they have now gone 11 Premiership matches without victory and are fortunate that Phillips has maintained faith by signing a new contract. Peter Reid has much to remedy in the summer.

With limited resources at his disposal Reid's supposed rift with Nicky Summerbee can only be counterproductive. Only when the forward came on as a substitute 11 minutes into the second half and Sunderland reverted to 4-4-2 did they summon any attacking zest. Summerbee immediately sparked a move from which Phillips should have scored but struck a post.

Phillips then provided the cross from which Sunderland went ahead, a deep ball from the left which was finished off by Niall Quinn's towering header. Quinn's aerial qualities are so well known that they might as well be printed on his personal Pokemon card, but that does not necessarily mean anyone can stop him.

Christian Ziege is not a Pokemon. Put him in a Pokemon game and he would try to persuade all the others to sign a peace treaty. But Bryan Robson, Boro's manager, made much of the bravery of Ziege's equaliser, a collision with the Sunderland goalkeeper Thomas Sorensen being the price of his sprint on to Brian Deane's loft forward.

Much of a dreadful first half was passed wondering why Ziege's team-mates never passed to him. He danced around a tackle or two, took the occasional free-kick and was even allowed a corner, but only from the right. One of the most clinical left feet in the land was left underemployed.

Then, in the last minute of the half, someone passed to him and he was flattened by Darren Holloway. The defender was booked but the Sunderland supporters, in what had to be a contender for the One-Eyed Crowd of the Season award, howled at Ziege for diving. Ziege's eye, though, proved to be the meanest of all.

fields.headline: Nationwide Third Division
fields.trailText: When, with third-placed Darlington already 1-0 up against Swansea at Feethams on Saturday, their record signing Nick Cusack scored four minutes into the second half, you might have thought the hosts were on their way to three vital points against their promotion rivals.
fields.body:
When, with third-placed Darlington already 1-0 up against Swansea at Feethams on Saturday, their record signing Nick Cusack scored four minutes into the second half, you might have thought the hosts were on their way to three vital points against their promotion rivals.

Sadly for them Cusack now plays for Swansea and his goal, cancelling out Peter Duffield's first-half strike for the Quakers, was enough to take Swansea top after Rotherham's surprise defeat at home to Mansfield the previous evening.

 Barnet lost ground in the race for play-off places by losing 3-1 at Carlisle, for whom the former Motherwell striker Steve Halliday struck twice. Carlisle's sixth victory of the season consigned Chester, 3-1 losers at Southend, to bottom spot in their place.

 Peterborough's recent good run, which has seen them reach fourth place, was checked with a 1-1 draw at Macclesfield, while Hartlepool and Northampton kept their play-off hopes alive with home wins over Torquay (2-0) and Exeter (2-1) respectively.

 Ten-man York City held out at Shrewsbury for a 1-0 win and three valuable points in the fight to avoid dropping out of the league. Having taken the lead in the 14th minute through their top scorer Barry Conlon, they had to hang on against their fellow strugglers when the former Hull and Leeds utility man Peter Swan was dismissed for his second bookable offence just before half-time.

fields.headline: Nationwide Second Division
fields.trailText: Despite a faltering display punctuated only by an eighth-minute goal from the on-loan winger Iain Anderson, Preston retained top spot by beating Luton 1-0 at Deepdale. The Luton substitute Liam George's 86th-minute penalty miss confirmed that North End's luck is well and truly in.
fields.body:
Despite a faltering display punctuated only by an eighth-minute goal from the on-loan winger Iain Anderson, Preston retained top spot by beating Luton 1-0 at Deepdale. The Luton substitute Liam George's 86th-minute penalty miss confirmed that North End's luck is well and truly in.

Anderson has joined from the French Second Division club Toulouse until the end of the season and hopes to make the move permanent. "It was so frustrating for me in France," he said. "The coach didn't speak a word of English. That shouldn't be a problem here with David Moyes, who's a fellow Scot."

 Bristol Rovers kept on Preston's tails by beating Chesterfield, the bottom club, 3-1 at the Memorial Ground. But it needed second-half goals in quick succession from Jamie Cureton and Vitalijs Astafjevs to seal the win.

 Ian Wright scored his second late goal in successive games to keep Burnley in the hunt. The veteran striker came off the bench to convert the Clarets' third goal in their 3-0 win at home to Reading.

 Millwall were the only side in the top seven not to win. The Londoners fell behind to lowly Blackpool when Wayne Gill opened the scoring, but Neil Harris's penalty just before half-time earned the Lions a point.

 Wigan emerged victorious from their derby against Bury thanks to Andy Liddell's goal with 15 minutes to go at the JJB Stadium.

fields.headline: Leeds keep up title chase
fields.trailText: If the Premiership title can be won by lopping the heads off dandelions, Leeds United should not be lacking when it comes to horticultural decapitation. Though Wimbledon, woeful away from home this season, scored first yesterday they were quickly weeded out by David O'Leary's enduringly confident young side.
fields.body:
If the Premiership title can be won by lopping the heads off dandelions, Leeds United should not be lacking when it comes to horticultural decapitation. Though Wimbledon, woeful away from home this season, scored first yesterday they were quickly weeded out by David O'Leary's enduringly confident young side.

The victory keeps Leeds four points behind the leaders Manchester United and, with Chelsea held at West Ham on Saturday, has consolidated their chances of a Champions League place through a top-three finish. In fact it looks as if Leeds will finish runners-up and avoid having to qualify for the first group phase.

Certainly they looked well worth second place yesterday, recovering briskly after falling behind in the second minute with Eirik Bakke scoring twice, Ian Harte putting away a penalty in between and Harry Kewell rounding off another high-quality performance.

"I don't know how we'll do at the end of the season," O'Leary insisted afterwards. "We'll just try to win every game and see where that takes us. That's all we can do."

The Leeds manager was equally guarded about his side's championship chances when, apart from a fortnight in November, they led the Premiership from the beginning of October until the end of January. Such comments, however, were purely for media consumption and the Leeds players showed little sign of believing them.

In the unlikely event of Manchester United dropping a basketful of points Leeds will surely be the team to benefit most. They have a healthy, positive attitude and are not yet quite good enough to loaf around and still win, as Sir Alex Ferguson's team did at Leicester on Saturday.

Last November Leeds lost 2-0 at Wimbledon three days after the first of their wearisome treks to Moscow in the Uefa Cup. The way the match started yesterday a sense of deja vu must have swept through their supporters as Jason Euell ducked between the centre-backs, Alf-Inge Haaland and Lucas Radebe, to meet Marcus Gayle's centre and head Wimbledon in front in the second minute.

However, those who know their Wimbledon knew better. Egil Olsen's side will probably win enough home games to stay up but on their travels they have lost too many games too easily. They remain sprightly up front but defensively they often look vulnerable and lack concentration. Yesterday Bakke and Stephen McPhail found a lot of space between Wimbledon's midfield and their back four. In consequence Kewell and Jason Wilcox were given plenty of possession and it seemed only a matter of time before Leeds eased themselves into the contest and went on to win it.

Indeed they as good as won it from midfield. Neil Sullivan had already saved smartly from Michael Bridges and Kewell as Wimbledon began to defend deep, but midway through the first half the scores were level and by half-time Leeds were 3-1 ahead.

An inspired pass through the inside-left space from McPhail found Bakke haring through a gap to flick the ball into the far corner with the outside of his right foot. Then Carl Cort, under pressure from Haaland at a corner, reached up to handle the ball and Harte's penalty put Leeds ahead. Olsen argued that the penalty should not have been given because Haaland had pushed Cort, but it did look a clear enough instance of deliberate handball. And as the Wimbledon manager admitted: "We would probably have lost anyway."

Olsen has spent £6.8m bringing five fellow Norwegians to Selhurst Park. O'Leary, on the other hand, paid Sogndal an initial fee of £1m for Bakke which, even when it rises to £1.75m after an agreed number of appearances, should still leave him one of the season's bargains.

Just to emphasise the point Bakke, tall, powerful and possessing an assured first touch, increased the lead, gathering another astute McPhail pass and again guiding the ball neatly past Sullivan. Bakke, of course, may have benefited from inside information on Wimbledon's frailities since his father Svein, like him a player with Sogndal, had been sent in at Wimbledon last year as a trouble-shooter as their new owners checked out their financial viablility prior to the takeover.

At the start of the second half Andreas Lund and Euell drew urgent saves from Nigel Martyn, just to show that Wimbledon had not gone home. But Leeds continued to dominate and two minutes after hitting a post Kewell completed the scoring after being sent clear by Alan Smith, one of the Leeds substitutes.

fields.headline: Ipswich switch off automatic pilot
fields.trailText: Ipswich, it appears, will again be looking for manual rather than automatic promotion to the Premiership this season.
fields.body:
Ipswich, it appears, will again be looking for manual rather than automatic promotion to the Premiership this season.

Having been subjected to the protracted misery of three semi-final play-off failures in the last three seasons, George Burley's side are particularly anxious to finish in the top two this time round.

But their form has faltered at a critical stage and after this derby defeat they dropped to third in the table, level on points with Manchester City, who have a game in hand, and Barnsley.

They have now taken two points from a possible 15 and those five games have yielded only two goals. On that form they could be pipped even for a play-off place.

Norwich, for whom this was only a second win in 12 games, have been downright unneighbourly in recent times. They won 1-0 here last season and have not conceded a goal in their last four matches against Ipswich.

Yesterday's game, though, was about figures of another sort. The Norwich victory was orchestrated by the caretaker manager Bryan Hamilton, who until Bruce Rioch's walkout a week ago was working as the director of football at Carrow Road.

He also once played with style in Ipswich's midfield and two years ago worked alongside Burley to shape the modern Ipswich side.

Yesterday his recent handiwork gave him more pleasure than his old. Ipswich were outplayed. Norwich outnumbered them five against four in midfield and Iwan Roberts, as lonely as a missionary up front, also looked like one struggling to convert a primitive people to footballing ways.

He scored both goals and created havoc with his selfless strength. When he had the ball, however, he was quickly supported from midfield, particularly by Darel Russell's spritely runs and Lee Marshall's impressive poise.

In this kind of form Norwich hardly need Ruel Fox, who they hope will return from Spurs today. Hamilton also hopes to secure the signature of another player before the day is through, a Premiership midfielder.

"I am an Ipswich fan and I hope they go up," he said. "But today I was delighted with the way we played. This is a young side but they passed well and I was pleased to see them respond to one or two things I put to them this week."

Burley looked far less happy. "This was our worst performance of the season. It was a very disappointing way to respond to a full house and to being second in the table."

Roberts scored the first in the 19th minute, though Richard Wright would have saved but for a generous deflection by Manuel Thetis. The second came on half-time when Roberts beat Fabian Wilnis to Paul Dalglish's cross.

fields.headline: Hoddle's burden easier to bear
fields.trailText: Aston Villa were the answer to Saints' prayers. After this form-confounding afternoon, Glenn Hoddle looked like a master coach in defensive security and Kevin Davies like the young, rampaging striker who once commanded a £7.25m fee.
fields.body:
Aston Villa were the answer to Saints' prayers. After this form-confounding afternoon, Glenn Hoddle looked like a master coach in defensive security and Kevin Davies like the young, rampaging striker who once commanded a £7.25m fee.

Seldom have reputations, individual and collective, been so quickly repaired. Southampton's defence, under the week-long tutelage of Hoddle, ironed out the "schoolboy errors" of their seven-goal mauling by Tottenham, and Davies twice struck impressively, his first goal drawing the commendation "great technique" from his manager.

The upshot is that Southampton are contemplating another extension to their Premiership tenure. Other relegation candidates obliged but no one was more responsible for the mood swing than Villa.

John Gregory, denying the distraction of the FA Cup semi-final against Bolton on Sunday week, could not find an easy explanation for a "very flat performance, the first bad one I've had in about 19 games". Hence Villa's manager spared his team a rollicking which would have been justified on the damning statistic alone of their failure to produce a shot or header on goal.

Hoddle takes much credit for that, only modifying his four-man defence by moving the versatile Moroccan Tahar El Khalej to centre-back on his home debut. The former England coach appears to be meeting head-on the new realities of managing a struggling club.

"We've learned a lot of things this week," he said. "It wasn't classical today, indeed it's the worst we've passed the ball since I've been here. But we needed to churn that out."

Nevertheless there was little to suggest such a happy outcome until Davies scored with Southampton's second shot. It was worth the wait: Gareth Barry's loose header was neatly controlled and then dispatched on the volley from just outside the area.

Southampton grew in confidence, graphically illustrated when Matthew Oakley cleverly put Davies away for a calm, crisp finish. "The frustration was beginning to creep in," Davies said after not scoring since early January. "The two goals are a weight off my shoulders." Suddenly, too, Southampton's burden is not too great to bear.

webTitle: Gold stars for Houllier's mean machine

fields.headline: Gold stars for Houllier's mean machine
fields.trailText: Back in the autumn, when some Liverpool fans took to washing down their half-time Bovril with antidepressants, the prospect of Gérard Houllier's side boasting the country's meanest defence was as likely as Gary Neville being invited to the club's end-of-season dinner as guest of honour.
fields.body:
Back in the autumn, when some Liverpool fans took to washing down their half-time Bovril with antidepressants, the prospect of Gérard Houllier's side boasting the country's meanest defence was as likely as Gary Neville being invited to the club's end-of-season dinner as guest of honour.

The peasants were revolting, the white flag seemed to have been hoisted and the telephone lines to David Mellor bristled with scouse indignation. Six months on and the amateur psychologists who questioned the wisdom of appointing a former French teacher to oversee the biggest image overhaul on Merseyside since Sporty Spice swapped her shellsuit for Prada have been bludgeoned into submission.

Some minor tweaking is still needed here and there. But the rehabilitation programme is well ahead of schedule and Houllier's spring-term report will incorporate gold stars for the graduates of a footballing academy whose learning curve had been warped by the effects of negligent tutoring in recent unfulfilled years.

Since mid-November his charges have been second only to Manchester United in terms of Premiership points secured. Furthermore, and arguably most crucially, they have been transformed from a side that sieved goals to one with the best goals-against column around, having conceded 12 fewer than their old adversaries from Old Trafford.

Without a single player over the age of 27 they chugged away in second gear for much of the match here and spluttered into life only in fits and starts. But such was their composure in defence that the goalkeeper Sander Westerveld scarcely needed to muddy his knees all afternoon.

"It took Alex Ferguson four or five years to do anything at United so it is still early days, but you have to praise our manager," said the colossal Sami Hyypia. "At the start of the season he had the courage to bring in players, myself included, who no one in England had heard of. It shows his knowledge of the game."

Emile Heskey does not fit into that bracket. The £11m signing will come good but this was a day when he took more tumbles than shots, hitting the deck with a regularity more in keeping with the authentic "Bruno".

Fortunately for Liverpool, Michael Owen and the substitute Titi Camara seemed far more au fait with the centre-forward's traditional job description. Owen's 17th-minute gambit, controlling Hyypia's long ball before flummoxing Jacob Laursen with a sway of the hips and shooting across the Derby goalkeeper Mart Poom, was the injury-troubled striker at his predatory best. Camara's poised, precise finish late in the second half gave the scoreline a more apt appearance.

A place in the Champions League has swayed from the boundaries of optimism to realism. "We will die for third position," offered Houllier.

For Derby the inquest continues. This was their 11th home defeat of the season, nine coming in the Premiership. "If we carried our away form into our home form we'd be in the top 10," said their manager Jim Smith. Their season ticket holders should study the small print to see if it carries a health warning.

webTitle: Francis's turnabout offers a direct route

fields.headline: Francis's turnabout offers a direct route
fields.trailText: There was a time when talk of automatic promotion within Trevor Francis's earshot brought to mind Basil Fawlty and his German paying guests: "I mentioned the war once but I think I got away with it."
fields.body:
There was a time when talk of automatic promotion within Trevor Francis's earshot brought to mind Basil Fawlty and his German paying guests: "I mentioned the war once but I think I got away with it."

Now Birmingham have won 10 of their last 13 games to move to within two points of second place it is an option he can no longer ignore.

"The win over Barnsley was our best performance of the season," he said. "It was the start of a vital period of five matches for us: all are against teams with hopes of reaching the play-offs.

"And, if we don't do well in our next two games and results elsewhere go against us, then we could have slipped to seventh by this time next week. So I'll be more prepared to pass judgment after another four games."

It is a remarkable turn-around from when Francis trudged out of the City Ground in Nottingham, his Christmas ruined by a third successive defeat which left his team 13th.

At least five key players were sidelined by long-term injuries at that time but, perversely, those enforced midwinter breaks may now work in his favour. Stan Lazaridis, backafter an absence of three months, terrorised Barnsley with his pace and Isiah Rankin, who arrived on loan from Bradford in January, improves with every game.

It all proved too much for a Barnsley side who had gone ahead through Craig Hignett. Rankin, who has agreed to spend another month at St Andrews, equalised 12 minutes later before delivering the coup de grace midway through the second half. In between David Holdsworth headed Birmingham in front seconds before the interval.

"We were always chasing the game after that" said the Barnsley manager Dave Bassett, whose side still lie fourth. "I was disappointed we didn't impose ourselves on them after scoring first. Instead we were totally negative. To be perfectly brutal about it, we were absolutely brain-dead."

"I was disappointed we didn't impose ourselves on them after scoring first. Instead we were totally negative. To be perfectly brutal about it, we were absolutely brain-dead."

webTitle: EastEnders with a cast but no plot

fields.headline: EastEnders with a cast but no plot
fields.trailText: People had arrived expecting to savour the delights of a fine champagne but were left only with heartburn. This game was more crude than cru, lacking sparkle and subtlety and failing miserably to intoxicate. What a shame.
fields.body:
People had arrived expecting to savour the delights of a fine champagne but were left only with heartburn. This game was more crude than cru, lacking sparkle and subtlety and failing miserably to intoxicate. What a shame.

When two sides meet who so encouragingly embrace the principles of an inventive, passing game, one naturally expects to witness a free-flowing cut-and-thrust exhibition of attacking swordplay. But all that was on offer was a blunt-edged stand-off.

Perhaps this should have been no surprise given that exactly the same tactical stalemate had occurred when the two teams drew 0-0 at Stamford Bridge in November. Here West Ham seemed so fearful of Chelsea's armoury that they turned into Leicester for the day, making containment their priority to the detriment of anything creative.

Under the watchful eye of Milan's vice-president Franco Baresi, Chelsea did their best to break free of the shackles but, tired perhaps after their win in Rotterdam and with Lazio to contemplate on Wednesday, they struggled.

The result was a hectic, bitty game littered with misplaced passes and pub-team errors, sparking marginal interest only when Igor Stimac was controversially sent off and Steve Lomas later accused Gus Poyet of elbowing him in the face.

From the point of view of the league table the outcome was equally unsatisfying for each team. Chelsea extended their unbeaten Premiership run to 13 games but this was another point dropped, after last weekend's home draw with Everton, as they slip behind in the race to secure a Champions League spot for next season.

West Ham increasingly look like pinning their European hopes on another marathon run in the InterToto Cup, for their inconsistency is worse than Chelsea's, which is saying something. Even Harry Redknapp admitted he needs to sign "one or two quality players" next season and surely one of those must be a new striker to link with the superb skills of Paolo di Canio. Paulo Wanchope's confidence is shot.

Stimac was sent off by mistake. He rightly received a second yellow for a rash challenge on Dennis Wise on 70 minutes but should not have been shown the first. Late in the first half the Croatian was wrongly identified by the linesman as the player who pushed Tore Andre Flo to the ground in retaliation for the Norwegian remonstrating with John Moncur about being kicked off the ball.

Redknapp said he would study the video before deciding whether to appeal over Stimac, but he will have to be careful. The replay will exonerate Stimac but identify Rio Ferdinand as Flo's assailant. It will also highlight Moncur's kick at Flo, which was missed by the match officials, luckily for Moncur, who himself was already on a yellow card.

fields.headline: Dyer brightens a dire encounter
fields.trailText: The name Ferguson may have been emblazoned across a thousand and one fading blue shirts but it was a dreaded day that finally dawned on Merseyside. There he was, the big man himself, trotting out to champion someone else's cause, in someone else's shirt.
fields.body:
The name Ferguson may have been emblazoned across a thousand and one fading blue shirts but it was a dreaded day that finally dawned on Merseyside. There he was, the big man himself, trotting out to champion someone else's cause, in someone else's shirt.

The departure of Duncan Ferguson from Everton 16 months ago was a watershed in the club's chequered recent history for it precipitated not only necessary changes at boardroom level but, more significantly, a discernible change of emphasis and style on the pitch.

Having abandoned what was no more than a long-ball game dressed up as something more laudable, the Merseysiders have prospered and they entered yesterday's game unencumbered by thoughts of relegation.

However, with so little to play for between now and season's end, Everton are finding motivation a problem; they are going through the motions and the process is neither pretty nor entertaining.

By contrast, with an FA Cup semi-final on the horizon Newcastle United's campaign is still very much alive. In this match their football always boasted the greater sense of urgency, particularly in a first half that was witless and clueless.

Although the dovetailing of Ferguson and Alan Shearer was reasonably watchable, the game limped to half-time without offering even the semblance of a chance. It was unspeakably dull.

As the hour mark was reached there was a collective sharp intake of breath as Nolberto Solano steered a shot across the face of the Everton goal. It fell many yards wide but at least there was a whiff of enterprise about the effort.

The first shot on target was to go in and thus separate two sides whose afternoon-long ineptitude, despite the appearance of 20 full internationals, had been such that they did not deserve to be separated.

With 11 minutes remaining David Weir foolishly attempted to dribble his way out of trouble deep inside his own penalty area. It was a bold gamble and it went horribly wrong. As the Everton defender attempted to move the ball from one foot to the other he was dispossessed by Aaron Hughes, who clipped a firm shot just inside a post.

The game's one moment of genuine class came with three minutes remaining, the Newcastle substitute Kieron Dyer collecting the ball near the halfway line, running round two defenders and lobbing the ball into the net to confirm Everton's first home league defeat of the season.

"I have been getting in some great positions of late but missing the target, so it was extra sweet when it hit the back of the net," said Dyer. "Apart from Manchester United at home, this is the best result of the season for us."

webTitle: City rue Newton's law of rebound

fields.headline: City rue Newton's law of rebound
fields.trailText: Manchester City, never a club to take more than one step forward without the likelihood of a major pratfall, found themselves back in second place in the table yesterday, but more by default than any grand surge of inspiration.
fields.body:
Manchester City, never a club to take more than one step forward without the likelihood of a major pratfall, found themselves back in second place in the table yesterday, but more by default than any grand surge of inspiration.

This was their sixth match without a win, which hardly warranted the huge cheer that went up when the home supporters discovered that Ipswich Town had lost at home to Norwich City. With Barnsley, Birmingham City and Huddersfield Town all crowding in behind, both Manchester City and Ipswich fans face an anxious time up to and including Easter.

Charlton, by some way the best team in the division this season, will surely go up as champions, and they had the more clearcut chances to have won yesterday, although with 20 minutes left their manager Alan Curbishley would have settled for the point.

But with a crowd of more than 32,000 again at Maine Road, and with the match being shown live on Sky, neither team was in a mood for expediency. "Both sides wanted to win, whereas in recent times the teams coming here have put everybody behind the ball," said City's manager Joe Royle, who believes his side have come out of a lull and now need "a kiss from Lady Luck".

Both goals certainly enjoyed a huge slice of fortune. Dean Kiely had made a brilliant save from a Jamie Pollock header before Charlton believed they had taken the lead when Andy Hunt headed in Shaun Newton's cross, only for John Robinson to be adjudged offside.

With Charlton still cursing, City pounced when Shaun Goater swung a boot at Ian Bishop's parabolic through-ball, arrived a touch early and shinned a lob beyond Kiely, who was prepared for something faster and lower.

It was imperative that City did not concede a goal before half-time, thereby increasing the certainty that they would; such are the laws of physics peculiar to Maine Road.

Robinson's shot was going to some remote area, harmless to Nick Weaver, when it struck Newton somewhere in the region of his shoulder to take an immense diversion which left the City goalkeeper, as one music hall comedian used to say, "stood standing".

Charlton, whose run of 12 consecutive First Division victories ended against the bottom side Swindon Town in their previous match, looked rather more vulnerable at the beginning of the second half.

Both Jim Whitley and Robert Taylor, the latter returning after injury, should have scored. Whitley made the wrong decision to try one extra pass to Goater, while Taylor's lack of match sharpness saw him scuff a shot with the goal gaping.

Thereafter it was Charlton, who have a 13-point lead over City, who created the better openings. Newton tried a shot when the better option was a pass to Mathias Svensson, and then Martin Pringle, on for Svensson, wasted two more openings.

There was no doubting the raw excitement of chances made and chances squandered, and both managers were pleased with their respective sides' efforts. But there really was not much in the way of quality - certainly not the sort of quality that would sustain either team for longer than one season in the Premiership.

webTitle: Blunt words after Sharpe summing up

fields.headline: Blunt words after Sharpe summing up
fields.trailText: After Lee Sharpe had first muffed his clearance and then clumsily brought down Ysrael Zuniga, he greeted the penalty award by angrily lashing the ball into his own net. It was exactly the right thing to do: Bradford had been scoring own-goals all afternoon.
fields.body:
After Lee Sharpe had first muffed his clearance and then clumsily brought down Ysrael Zuniga, he greeted the penalty award by angrily lashing the ball into his own net. It was exactly the right thing to do: Bradford had been scoring own-goals all afternoon.

Quite what this crushing defeat will do to their hopes of remaining in the Premiership will probably not become apparent for a couple of weeks. Their next opponents are Manchester United and on this evidence the champions can parade their Second String Band and still win with something in hand.

For this examination Bradford seemed to have left at home precisely the quality that had given them a chance of escaping relegation: their fighting spirit. This was a meek surrender as Coventry were allowed time and space to do exactly as they wished. When Bradford have no appetite to hustle and harry they do not have much to offer, their manager Paul Jewell admitted.

"Our spirit and togetherness has been our strength this season but today every player tried to do their own thing and that will get you punished in the Premier League," said Jewell, who had been proud of the way they had fought when conceding three goals to Leeds last Sunday. But this was "dreadful; if I tried to analyse what went wrong I'd be here all night".

Now it looks like developing into a straight scrap between Bradford and Derby as to who accompanies Watford and Sheffield Wednesday on the downward slide. There is little to choose between the two clubs in terms of the difficulty of their remaining fixtures and the defining moment may come when they meet at Valley Parade at the end of April.

It is a scramble for survival which Coventry, this time round at least, can happily leave to others. A second win in four days after a goalless losing streak of four games lifts them to 11th, although Coventry being Coventry they cannot enjoy such rarefied heights without glancing over their shoulders.

Gordon Strachan can feel rightly proud of the youngsters who are gaining experience because of a lengthy injury list. No one had more influence than John Eustace, who set up Noel Whelan for the shot that gave Cédric Roussel a tap-in to put Coventry on their way.

After Whelan had fired in the second it was Eustace who insisted on taking the penalty and the chance to score his first goal for the club. Zuniga, the Peruvian substitute, then dispatched an eye-catching volley, success with his third attempt at goal in the same move.

webTitle: Arsenal weary but still the wiser

fields.headline: Arsenal weary but still the wiser
fields.trailText: Arsenal maintained their challenge for a Champions League place yesterday with a victory over their fiercest rivals which exposed Tottenham's lack of quality and the Gunners' lack of rest.
fields.body:
Arsenal maintained their challenge for a Champions League place yesterday with a victory over their fiercest rivals which exposed Tottenham's lack of quality and the Gunners' lack of rest.

Despite taking a firm grip of a lively game, albeit through an own goal and a penalty, Arsenal's Uefa Cup excursions took their toll towards the end as Spurs were allowed to surge forward in search of their sixth draw in the last seven visits to their old enemy's lair.

Gilles Grimandi did not help Arsenal's cause by getting sent off four minutes from time for a second yellow-card offence at the height of the siege. But even against 10 men Tottenham lacked the wit and imagination to offer George Graham further satisfaction on his return to the club he guided to two league titles.

What Arsenal's players lost to tired limbs they made up for with strength of character, holding on for only their second win in the last seven Premiership games and avenging Spurs' 2-1 win in November.

Arsène Wenger was also relieved to see them follow up a tiring Uefa Cup tie - Thursday's 2-0 win over Werder Bremen - with a Premiership victory. In the previous round, games against Deportivo La Coruna had been followed by flat league performances. The fact that the next match on the conveyor belt is Thursday's second leg highlights exactly why Wenger has been so critical of the fixture demands on his players.

To cope, he knows he must strengthen his squad even further for next season, and one player in his thoughts is the £14m-rated Tottenham defender Sol Campbell, who is rumoured to have already agreed to join Manchester United but whom Wenger still hopes to lure across north London.

That is the last thing Spurs want. They desperately need to hold on to their better players and, as Graham says, add four or five more in the summer. The sorry state of his current options were writ large in his assessment of yesterday's game. "Arsenal looked very tired after playing so many games," Graham said. "This was a day when they were there for the taking. But we just didn't have enough quality when we had the ball."

This was not only evident as Spurs pushed forward towards the end but in the 15-minute spell they dominated at the start. Alex Manninger, replacing the injured David Seaman in Arsenal's goal, hardly had a save to make in either period as, in total, Spurs produced three shots on target to Arsenal's nine.

Arsenal, without the injured Emmanuel Petit and Martin Keown, took a while to stir but went into the lead on 18 minutes. Nwankwo Kanu had already gone close when Marc Overmars broke down the left and won a corner. Silvinho swung the ball in at pace to the near post, where Chris Armstrong managed to glance it into his own net.

But Spurs under Graham are nothing if not fighters. Silvinho earned more Brownie points by clearing off the line from Steffen Iversen's header before they found an equaliser on the half-hour. David Ginola, switched to the right wing, fired in a swinging cross and Armstrong, atoning for his earlier error, glanced it past the correct goalkeeper.

But then Arsenal took control. Ian Walker saved well from Thierry Henry and Overmars shot just wide before, in first-half injury time, they restored their lead. Kanu fed Ray Parlour in the area, where he was upended by Mauricio Taricco. Eight different players have missed penalties for Arsenal this season, but Henry made no mistake.

It was a bad time for Spurs to concede a goal but in the second half, as Arsenal tired and the substitute Les Ferdinand brought some power to their front line, they gamely fought back despite losing Campbell to a knee injury. Yet they still struggled to trouble Manninger.

Such are the ups and downs of football. On 61 minutes the sight of Iversen being substituted reminded everyone that a week ago he had scored a hat-trick and Spurs had been in seventh heaven. Yesterday they had to suffer seeing Arsenal on cloud nine.

webTitle: Voters want more spent on NHS, poll shows

fields.headline: Voters want more spent on NHS, poll shows
fields.trailText: The majority of voters want to see chancellor Gordon Brown give the NHS priority by granting it the biggest increase in spending when he unveils his budget, according to an exclusive Guardian ICM opinion poll.
fields.body:
The majority of voters want to see chancellor Gordon Brown give the NHS priority by granting it the biggest increase in spending when he unveils his budget, according to an exclusive Guardian ICM opinion poll.

At the same time, nearly half would not mind paying more income tax to fund the increased spending.

Mr Brown has come under mounting pressure to address the perceived crises in health, education and treatment of the elderly.

This is borne out in the Guardian poll with 58% calling for the NHS to be treated as the main priority, followed by pensioners at 18% and education at 15%. The nearest priority to these was tax cuts at 6%.

Asked what extra taxes would be acceptable to raise expenditure, 40% said they were ready to pay more income tax. That will be a boost for the Liberal Democrats who say the government should try and win people over to paying more tax for better services.

A bigger number, 75%, say it would be acceptable to increase duty on tobacco whereas only 22% would see petrol duty increases as acceptable.

As Mr Brown put the finishing touches to his fourth budget, the Guardian poll showed that a third of people would disapprove if he announced cuts in income against 59% approving.

Less surprisingly, 90% of voters would approve of more money being spent on pensioners, 96% on health and 94% on schools.

Only 24% of voters believe cutting income tax will win the next election, while 68% say spending more on the NHS will be the vote winner.

Mr Brown's approval rating in the poll remains relatively high compared to his cabinet colleagues. A total of 45% of voters remain satisfied with his performance - down eight points on last year.

But the chancellor will be concerned to see that 40% of people think they are worse off financially than 12 months ago. Only 15% think their finances have improved because of last year's budget.

Feelings are mixed about the impact of this year's budget statement, with 21% believing their fortunes will improve as a result of it, 34% think they will get worse and 37% say they will stay the same.

On voting intentions, the Conservatives have seen a three-point rise in their fortunes since the last ICM poll. They stand at 32%, Labour sees no change at 44%, the Liberal Democrats are at 16% and others at 8%.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,207 adults aged over 18 by telephone between March 17-19, 2000. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

A bigger number, 75%, say it would be acceptable to increase duty on tobacco whereas only 22% would see petrol duty increases as acceptable. As Mr Brown put the finishing touches to his fourth budget, the Guardian poll showed that a third of people would disapprove if he announced cuts in income against 59% approving. Less surprisingly, 90% of voters would approve of more money being spent on pensioners, 96% on health and 94% on schools. Only 24% of voters believe cutting income tax will win the next election, while 68% say spending more on the NHS will be the vote winner. Mr Brown's approval rating in the poll remains relatively high compared to his cabinet colleagues. A total of 45% of voters remain satisfied with his performance - down eight points on last year. But the chancellor will be concerned to see that 40% of people think they are worse off financially than 12 months ago. Only 15% think their finances have improved because of last year's budget. Feelings are mixed about the impact of this year's budget statement, with 21% believing their fortunes will improve as a result of it, 34% think they will get worse and 37% say they will stay the same. On voting intentions, the Conservatives have seen a three-point rise in their fortunes since the last ICM poll. They stand at 32%, Labour sees no change at 44%, the Liberal Democrats are at 16% and others at 8%.  ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,207 adults aged over 18 by telephone between March 17-19, 2000. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Students given star role in TV quiz

fields.headline: Students given star role in TV quiz
fields.trailText: The ultimate university challenge, as any impoverished student knows, is no longer a starter for 10 from Jeremy Paxman but the ability to pay off student loans.
fields.body:
The ultimate university challenge, as any impoverished student knows, is no longer a starter for 10 from Jeremy Paxman but the ability to pay off student loans.

With this in mind, a new Channel 4 quiz show called Dicing with Debt plans to offer hard-up undergraduates the opportunity to battle their way out of the red and into the black, with a star prize of thousands of pounds to write off the winner's debts.

It may not offer the financial potential of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? or the intellectual cachet of University Challenge, but financially stricken students are expected to be queueing up to wipe out three years of debt in half an hour.

The show, hosted by the comedian Paul Tonkinson, is scheduled for the autumn and will be produced by Hat Trick, the television production company behind numerous award-winning shows, including Have I Got News For You.

Other prizes, such as the contestant's height in pizza and a year's subscription to the Radio Times - and other items of use to the average undergraduate - will be offered.

But it is the star prize that most contestants will be hoping to win, with the average student expected to leave university with debts of £12,000 thanks to rising tuition fees, inadequate grants and soaring living expenses.

Dicing with Debt will see six students fight to clear their debts by rolling the dice and answering questions about popular culture. So while their brainier classmates appearing on University Challenge rote-learn the finer points of molecular biology, Dicing with Debt contestants need only brush up on the traditional student interests of drinking, daytime television and casual sex.

A Channel 4 spokeswoman said: "Only legitimate student loans will be paid off and the students have to give the precise amount of their debts, down to the nearest pound."
