fields.headline: Racism 'rife in justice system'
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Every key stage of the criminal justice system is riddled with racism, leaving black people with a greater prospect of being arrested and jailed than whites, according to a study by a penal reform group.
fields.body:
Every key stage of the criminal justice system is riddled with racism, leaving black people with a greater prospect of being arrested and jailed than whites, according to a study by a penal reform group.

British Afro-Caribbean people are seven times more likely to be in jail despite being no more likely to commit crimes, says the Howard League.

Its analysis of official figures throughout the criminal justice system, from arrest to incarceration, is due to be published on Wednesday.

The report suggests that the unequal treatment suffered by black people at the hands of the police, identified by the Macpherson report, is practised by all parts of the criminal justice system.

The study shows the discrimination occurs despite people in ethnic minorities being in greatest need of protection by the criminal justice system as they are more likely to be victims of crime. Data from the British Crime Survey shows that Pakistanis and Bangladeshis are worst affected.

Furthermore, no evidence exists to suggest the disparities are due to greater lawlessness by Afro-Caribbeans. An official study of 18- to 24-year-olds who had admitted crimes found 43% of Afro-Caribbeans and 44% of whites had confessed to law breaking, compared with 30% of British Indians and 28% of British Pakistanis.

Afro-Caribbean people are six times more likely than whites to be stopped and searched by the police and more likely to be arrested.

Of 1.3m arrests in 1998-99, 7% were of Afro-Caribbean people, who make up 2% of the population, 4% were of Asian people, who comprise 3% of the nation, with 1% of other ethnic minority groups.

But after arrest the same amount of ethnic minority people as whites were charged - 59%.

Afro-Caribbean and Asian suspects were more likely than whites to be remanded in custody after being charged - 35% of Afro-Caribbean people and 34% of Asians had bail requests refused, compared with 26% for whites.

Some evidence on sentencing suggests it is carried out fairly, while the study says other research has found "significant discrepancies in the use of imprisonment and the length of sentences".

Afro-Caribbeans are far more likely than any other ethnic group to be imprisoned. In June 1998 the rate of incarceration per 100,000 of the general population was 1,245 for black people, 185 for whites and 168 for Asians.

White people, who are 94% of the British population, made up 82% of male prison inmates, Afro-Caribbeans were 12% of those imprisoned, Asians 3%, and other ethnic minorities 3%.

The Howard League study noted that ethnic minorities were under-represented in the criminal justice system as employees, in posts such as police and prison officers, lay magistrates and at all senior levels.

Frances Crook, director of the Howard League, said: "The number of black people in our prisons is out of all proportion to the size of the black community, yet there is no evidence to suggest that people from ethnic minority groups commit more crime.

"The reasons for this are complex. It is partly a matter of social deprivation.

"But it is also clear that discrimination operates at every stage in the criminal justice system, from the chances of being arrested to the decision of the court and the length of the sentence.

"These individuals must then endure the culture of racism which still operates in many of our prisons."

webTitle: Forever, For now and Forward thinking

fields.headline: Forever, For now and Forward thinking
fields.trailText: I WANT THAT MAN
fields.body:
I WANT THAT MAN

If the manager of your team pulled over a school bus to deliver a beneficial lecture to kids who were flicking Vs at him and his wife, would you still want him in charge? If he took in your star striker as a lodger after he accidentally 'caught' his foot in the window of a local fast-food restaurant, would you want him to stay? And if he got himself sent off for using foul and abusive language at the referee in a reserve game, would you love him forever?

Of course you would - and that's why Coventry manager Gordon Strachan has been offered a new five-year deal by chairman Bryan Richardson. Wee Gord is expected to put pen to paper in the next couple of days. "Everything has been agreed and we are delighted. When you get something that is good you want to do your best to hold on to it," simpered Richardson today. "We wanted to do everything we could to hold on to him," he continued, to the music from Simon Bates' Our Tune.

For a while, Richardson continued to make a surprising amount of sense. "It is absolutely vital to a club like ours that we have stability with a long-term manager in charge." But then he remembered himself in time to make one ridiculous quote. According to Bryan, wee Gord will become "the best manager in the club's history". Ha! You mean better than Terry Butcher? Or Don Howe? We'd like to see it!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CORT IN THE ACT

You don't have to be mad to play for Wimbledon, but it helps. Known everywhere as the Crazy Gang, this bunch of cockney wideboys is managed by a Norwegian with an interest in political philosophy. A few weeks ago they bade farewell to the owner who brought the club up from non-league, only to find him trying to help through the transfer of their star striker a few days later. No wonder Carl Cort doesn't seem to know whether he's coming or going.

The highly-rated striker was the subject of a £5m transfer bid from Leeds a few weeks ago, a bid that was turned down by the struggling Dons. After resurgent rumours that David O'Leary O'Leeds is to make another attempt to sign the England Under-21 player before Thursday's transfer deadline, Cort today came out and committed himself to the Dons unconditionally. We think.

"With some new faces we could have a very good side," said Cort, at the same time as confessing, "It's difficult to say in which direction the club is going at the moment." While he feels that "next season will be important" at Selhurst Park, he also thinks it might be nice at Leeds: "It's certainly an exciting place to be". So what exactly are the 15-goal striker's thoughts on the future? "Leaving is not something I've really thought about," ok, "but then Leeds are a massive side and any player would love to come to a club like this." Perhaps the Norwegian translation might be clearer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Over in Brazil I've already linked up with another footballer and we've got a third division team with a lot of players. I'm sure that one day a star player will emerge." Rivaldo announcing his intention to become an agent when he retires. Sounds like you've got the patter already mate.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

JOB REF: NU FERG

"How about Terry Venables?" "Too cockney." "Barry Venison?" "Too high profile." "Michael Barrymore?" "No experience of football management." As we speak, discussions over the successor to Alex Ferguson PHD are taking place at the highest level within Manchester United. Why officials would want to hold them on the top of the Stretford End remains unclear. Perhaps they'd rather Ol' Red Face didn't hear.

To quickly recap, Ferg is to retire at the end of the season after next. But rather than having the old lag riding around the corridors of Old Trafford on a horse chastising youth team players, the United hierarchy want the issue sorted now. Which would explain the slight change of emphasis in yesterday's David O'Leary O'Leeds's post-match boreathon, from "They're too young to catch Manchester United," to "I'm too young to boss Manchester United."

O'Leary had (rather cheekily we suspect) been mooted by Ferg himself as a possible candidate for his job. Money Martin Edwards meanwhile has yet to comment on the discussions, perhaps because he is said to prefer a Van Gaal over an O'Leary or, er, a Robson. According to the Manchester Evening News, Barca boss Van Gaal has already been sounded out by United, although this story may go the way of the Rivaldo rumours (this week he's staying at the Nou Camp forever). And what's wrong with Brian Kidd for heaven's sake?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Gerard Houllier has denied that Liverpool are on the verge of signing the 'new Maradona' Andres D'Alessandro. Reports suggested that Liverpool had officials in Buenos Aires ready to tie up a deal for the 18-year-old River Plate starlet but, according to Houllier, "It is completely wrong to say we are about to sign him." Which is, of course, pretty much what he said about Emile Heskey.

Bobby Robson is now said to be chasing four players from his former club Barcelona. Josep Guardiola, Luis Enrique, Sergi and Ronald de Boer are all reportedly on Robson's summer shopping list, and the Toon boss said "I'll have to see who is going to be available once I've got funds in place during the summer."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Ryan Giggs wants to sign a new contract at Manchester United. His current deal does not expire until 2002, but the winger is ready to agree new terms. "I'm similar to Becks in that I want to stay. I have always maintained that I am a Manchester United fan first and foremost and I have always just wanted to play for United," he told the Manchester Evening News.

Darren Anderton will sign a £24,000-a-week one-year extension to his Spurs contract. "The new contract should be signed by Thursday and there should be no problems," said director of football David Pleat.

Ian Wright has been banned for two matches by SFA for pushing fourth official Willie Young after the Kilmarnock v Celtic game. The striker's ban will affect him playing for Burnley and starts this weekend.

Ticket prices have been reduced for England's final international at Wembley before Euro 2000. Anyone aged 16 or under who is accompanied by an adult will be able to watch the game for half price. Children's prices will be reduced to £7.50 in some parts of the stadium.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Sports Show (11.30pm)

Like a Sports Bar, the Sports Show is ersatz and full of vacant idiots.

Uefa Champions League Weekly (12.35am)

If you ask us, they'd get better viewing figures if they just concentrated on Big Cup.

Football Extra (1.05am)

"Tee hee! If we keep this form up we'll bag a play-off place for sure!" laughs George Burley as he loops a length of rope around a Portman Road light fitting.

Channel 5: Dutch Football (4.45am)

English too much? Try a bit of Dutch.

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (7pm, 11pm SS2)

Graeme Souness examines the relationship between actor Klaus Kinski and director Werner Herzog. "You won't catch me losing my temper like that!" quips Blackburn's level-headed new boss.

***'** ** *** ******! (10.15pm, repeated 1.45am)

Another reader's message, this time from a Mr R McCaffrey. "It has come to my attention that you are no longer reviewing ***'** ** *** ******! and are instead using the space as some sort of message posting service. I cannot and will not stand for this. You must spread word of my existence, for I am your Overlord! Comply with my commandment or suffer my wrath! Now, if you'll excuse me I've got some folding to do." World Football Show (11pm)

Showing world football.

fields.headline: We hate you
fields.standfirst:
It's open season on asylum-seekers (again). Roy Greenslade wades through two weeks of xenophobic tabloid bile

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: It's open season on asylum-seekers (again). Roy Greenslade wades through two weeks of xenophobic tabloid bile
fields.body:
Let's play that simple psychological test known as word association. I'll save you the trouble of replying by supplying the answers, imagining I am a Daily Mail or Sun reader. Asylum-seekers: scroungers. Gypsies: wily scroungers. Romanians: ungrateful scroungers. Albanians: dirty scroungers. Beggars: rich scroungers.

Of course, there will be Mail and Sun readers who think otherwise. But not too many, to judge by the readers' letters pages. These, and other newspapers, are evidently pressing just the right buttons with their audiences in their increasingly hysterical daily assaults on East European beggars.

The past fortnight's headlines on "the curse" (the Mail) of Romanian gypsies have not come out of the blue. There have been many manifestations of overtly racist material about all manner of asylum-seekers, such as the infamous coverage of immigrants into Dover and the Afghan airline hijack last month.

The first wave of headlines about "the mounting menace of gipsy spongers" (the Sun) appeared after several women appeared in court for begging, usually with their babies, on London's tube trains and stations.

Then papers latched on to a report by Lord Gardiner about the "hidden economy" to suggest - improbably, and without any evidence - that this was linked to the sudden arrival of people from central Europe.

Both the Sun and the Times presented their front page articles on the Gardiner report next to pictures of gypsy beggars and the Sun's splash was unequivocal: "Crooks, dole cheats and illegal immigrants pocket £80 billion a year through the black economy."

The fact that most of the report dealt largely with the activities of people born or long settled in Britain was irrelevant to papers which had set their sights on fomenting prejudice in general against "the asylum flood" (the Mail) and specifically against "cadgers" (the Times).

The next twist came with some typical stunts. After days of stories in which beggars were fined, and admonished in suitably patronising - and quotable - terms by magistrates, the Mail on Sunday sent a female writer on to the streets with a fake baby and "Eastern European disguise". The result was predictable: though she had understood that "£20 an hour is the going rate for any experienced Romanian beggar" the best she could muster after two-and-a-half hours was £10.67. She also found it "grubby and undignified work".

The following day a Sun reporter, indulging in a crass exercise, discovered the amazing fact that begging in Bucharest is unprofitable, managing to get only one penny in her bowl. Why does the Sun think people trek across Europe in the first place?

But the Sun's excursion to Romania opened the next phase of press propaganda. Reporters from the Daily Mail and its stablemate, the London Evening Standard, were dis patched to the country too. The result was the discovery of "gipsy palaces" (the Sun) and the "town that lives off London's beggars" (the Standard). It was claimed in both reports, and supported by the Mail man a day later, that families had been sent to Britain to beg and to collect welfare state "hand-outs" which were being used to live in "palaces festooned with marble and gold" in an area "dubbed Beverly Hills by locals" (the Sun).

It was odd that both the Standard's Keith Dovkants and the Mail's Nick Craven should have lighted on exactly the same family, the Constantins. Was it coincidence? Or could it have been the fact that there were too few example of "organised begging" (the Sun) to find others?

There have also been more sympathetic reports, such as that from the Times's Roger Boyes telling of the "brutish life" suffered in many central European countries and explaining why Romania was "exporting its Roma problem". But these have been largely ignored in the frenzy to "prove" that Romanian gypsies "are taking us for a ride".

Whatever the truth, and the discovery of a small group of boastful Roma is hardly proof when we know the anti-immigrant agenda of the tabloids, the eruption of the campaign has proved difficult for people and papers trying to take an unhysterical view.

Any sign of tolerance towards asylum-seekers was stamped on. When the Guardian reported that Milwall football club had offered 25 Kosovan refugees the chance to enjoy matches and even coaching sessions, the Sun was beside itself with rage. fields.headline: Warning: culture clash ahead
fields.trailText: Scene: the House of Commons. "The secretary of state for trade and industry." "Madam Speaker, I should like to set out the government's new approach to the regulation of telecommunications ...
fields.body:
Scene: the House of Commons. "The secretary of state for trade and industry." "Madam Speaker, I should like to set out the government's new approach to the regulation of telecommunications ...

"For two decades Britain has strived to create a competitive market; now we intend to improve the content of telephone calls. All domestic subscribers will have to talk about religion on the telephone for at least one hour a week. All 0898 numbers, the so-called 'sex-lines', must remain within the boundaries of taste and decency. And anyone who goes online to access an internet news service must do so at precisely 10pm - members of the house are unanimous that we must have a 'news at-ten' slot. We are going to quadruple the size of GCHQ and give it unfettered powers to tap any line for monitoring and enforcement purposes. I commend this white paper to the house." (Fade to the the usual shouts of "hear hear" and "resign").

OK, this is not exactly what we expect to hear when the white paper covering telecoms and broadcasting is published in October. But the exercise represents a complete clash of cultures. Since BT was privatised in the early 80s, Oftel has worked hard to achieve one of the world's most competitive telecommunications markets. By contrast the regulators of television have concerned themselves largely with content. The Independent Television Commission handed out the massive privilege of a network to companies from whom they (quite rightly) demanded a lot in return in terms of programming. The Broadcasting Standards Commission's brief on taste and decency was another restriction on content.

Meanwhile, British broadcasters were allowed to vertically integrate their businesses unchallenged. Show me the ITC paper which seriously considered why the owner of a government-given channel should also be a producer and a programme distributor. Show me the ITC proposals as to how broadcasters should share their new online businesses fairly with programme creators. They don't exist.

What does exist, significantly, is a new set of proposals from the ITC as to how to control the content of television-related interactive services. They recommend what they call "a light touch". But once more they are looking at the content and not the market. Contrast this with a report from the Creative Industries Task Force about the internet published at the same time. It makes seven recommendations about regulation. But its authors are active members of the new economy. So the proposals cover competition, equal access and intellectual property protection. And the only one about content recommends self-regulation!

Now the government has to prepare for television becoming - in essence - a telecommunications signal. This clash of regulatory cultures has to be reconciled by October's white paper. Oftel reports to the department of trade and industry. The ITC and BSC report to the department of culture, media and sport. Will the DTI competition culture have the upper hand? Will all these factions unite to make television properly competitive and, at the same time, accept that it is not possible to control the content of the multi-channel, online world in the way we have been used to?

The behaviour of our politicians makes me wonder. So far this year we have heard a plea from Tony Blair, no less, for ITV to put News at Ten back in the schedule. Then we had the spectacle of the culture, media and sport select committee devoting a whole hearing (and a report to come) to the subject.

This is so far out of touch with the way our media is developing as to be both comical and alarming at the same time. But it is a fine example of what I have decided to call Davies' Law. This is a principle inspired by the team appointed to advise on BBC funding. Its chairman, Gavyn Davies, discovered early on that although he watched quite a lot of television, his colleagues watched very little. So the law is expressed as follows: those who legislate for television don't watch it and those who watch television don't legislate for it. Have there been spontaneous public demonstrations about News at Ten? Riots in Trafalgar Square, rallies on village greens? I think not. Most of the heat has been generated in Westminster's talking shop.

When it comes to October I dearly hope the white paper manages to bridge the culture gap between telecommunications and broadcasting. While a few channels still dominate, there are arguments for regulations about such things as diversity and watersheds. This is particularly so where public money is involved, as it is with the BBC. But first and foremost we need a new market-led approach. Who knows, the white paper's authors may even disprove Davies' Law.

 Peter Bazalgette is creative director of GMG Endemol Entertainment, an independent production company part-owned by the Guardian Media Group.

webTitle: Livingstone apologises to Commons over undeclared interests

fields.headline: Livingstone apologises to Commons over undeclared interests
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone, the frontrunning London mayoral candidate, today apologised to the Commons for failing to make a comprehensive declaration of his income to the register of members' interests.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone, the frontrunning London mayoral candidate, today apologised to the Commons for failing to make a comprehensive declaration of his income to the register of members' interests.

The Brent East MP was rebuked last week for failing to declare more than £158,000 made from after-dinner speaking and journalism.

A packed Commons chamber listened as Mr Livingstone made his one minute statement.

He said: "In accordance with the report of the Committee on Standards and Privileges I wish to apologise to the House for breaching the rules on registration of interest and for not observing the principle of openness which the code of conduct requires."

Mr Livingstone, who is standing as an independent candidate in the London mayoral race, had claimed that he was following advice he was given four years ago about what to declare. Parliament's standards commissioner Elizabeth Filkin said the rules had been tightened since then and the MP should have declared the income.

Mr Livingstone's statement continued: "When I was first elected to the House in 1987, I checked with the authorities that income from earnings paid into my firm Localaction Ltd did not need to be individually declared in the register. "Following the new code of practice, I wrote in 1996 to the parliamentary commissioner for standards to clarify the position.

"My outside earnings then developed in such a way that my registered entry was no longer adequate.

"I ought to have made a comprehensive entry covering all the services I provide through Localaction, but I did not in fact do so.

"As soon as possible after the issue was raised with me by the present parliamentary commissioner [Elizabeth Filkin], I amended my entry in the register in accordance with the rules."

After his speech, the house immediately moved on to next business. By convention, MPs do not question members making personal statements.

Mr Livingstone, while accepting Ms Filkin's ruling, called for an inquiry into how the complaint was made. The complainant, a Loughborough University student called John Jones, initially denied any involvement. It later emerged that he had signed the complaint on behalf of a London lawyer who had previously been involved in the campaign of Trevor Phillips, Labour's candidate for deputy mayor.

Since he announced his intention to split from the Labour party Mr Livingstone has ridden high in the polls, enjoying more than 60% support in the latest Evening Standard poll - well above Labour's Frank Dobson on 16%, the Conservatives' Steven Norris on 13% and Susan Kramer of the Liberal Democrats on 8%.

fields.headline: The German job
fields.standfirst: BMW is abandoning Rover, but not the Mini - hardly surprising, given the car's timeless appeal. Simon Hacker wonders whether the new model will be so coolRover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: BMW is abandoning Rover, but not the Mini - hardly surprising, given the car's timeless appeal.  Simon Hacker  wonders whether the new model will be so cool.
fields.body:
Like James Bond emerging from a fight, the Mini has come out of the wreckage of BMW's Rover sell-off looking pretty calm. The final orders for the current Mini will be fulfilled in Longbridge by Alchemy, while plans for the next version will steam ahead under BMW at its retained works in Cowley.

It might not be an entirely seamless operation. BMW has already indicated that the planned introduction of the all-new replacement, scheduled for this autumn, will now be delayed until July or August 2001, while speculation is rife that Alchemy will not wait until then before pulling the plug on the existing car.

There is a plan under way for British Motor Heritage, at Witney, to continue to build the original car on the old production line, though no one knows whether Alchemy, BMH's new boss, will let that happen. Whatever happens, while the future of cars called Rover looks uncertain, the 41-year-old best-selling British car of all time will live on.

Fashion guru Paul Smith, who recently put his couture badge to a special edition of the car, knows why: "It's like a pair of Levi's, or the original Beetle; the Mini has a wonderful simplicity that gives it a timeless appeal." He's not entirely convinced by the replacement. "From what I have seen of the design, I have to admit that I'd rather stay with the Mini as it is."

But the car is no stranger to controversy. Conceived as a reaction to fuel shortages after the Suez oil crisis, Alec Issigonis's £497 front-wheel drive box delivered affordable motoring and stunned the public. The engine was lodged sideways and the wheels were tiny, which meant there was far more room inside than in an A35 or Morris Minor. Suddenly, less was more and three wins in the Monte Carlo Rally proved that a pipsqueak could out-handle many supercars. For the self-preservation society, the Mini was the only choice.

Soon it was seen hanging around in the company of the rich and famous: John Lennon, Lord Snowdon, Peter Sellers, Twiggy and Britt Ekland queued up for their Mini keys. Marc Bolan dramatically died in his but, while all sorts of shenanigans were practised by celebs, the Mini only served to prove that cost-effective cars can also be cool. So when Christine Keeler caused a scandal, her choice of car showed she was still a sensible girl at heart.

By the 1980s, the cult of the Mini was a hard-wired fact. Steve Kirk, writer for MiniWorld magazine, which sells to Mini drivers in 92 countries, knows why: "The car was originally marketed as a woman's choice of transport and it wasn't until the mid 60s, after John Cooper had got hold of it, that people realised it was a small sports car. Men started to get interested too, and that's what made it. All the famous people who wanted to be seen with it just reinforced the cool image."

Kirk says the cult status is as strong as ever today. "This is what BMW will maximise and this is why they will sell the new car as a distinct brand - it was never a Rover product."

The key to that success, however, would be BMW keeping its badge off the bonnet. The relatively small number of new Minis it hopes to sell in the UK will shift readily from BMW dealerships, which is where the car now looks most likely to be displayed, but buyers would never accept a "BMW Mini".

Dave Hollis, of the British Mini Club, says the new car's success is intrinsic to it being seen as British. "Mini is a British icon and a British way of life. A German showroom is just not in keeping. We're upset that there is no clear news of what will happen, and this can only damage the Mini - both old and new."

For hardcore fans, however, reservations over the next incarnation run deeper still. "We've been running a global poll on our website and the most significant reaction to the new car is that 52% of fans feel that no matter how cool the new car looks, the real test comes with a drive," says Kirk. "The fact that we've been waiting since 1997 - when the first working design was revealed - to get behind the wheel, hardly helps."

This scepticism he says, is reflected in a huge groundswell of support for keeping the old car running alongside the new. "The majority of fans are against the new model because they feel there's no need for a new car - after all, it's not really a Mini, it's a hatchback."

But in the hard world of commercial sales, industry analysts say the old car is well past its drive-by date. Adrian Rushmore, who edits Glass's car guide, sees it as an automotive Queen Mum. "It's an evergreen that has grown old gracefully, but it trades more on its reputation than any real technical prowess. An aura surrounds it, but despite some updates, it's not much short of a disaster."

BMW's aim to sell the new model in very small numbers (the global sales estimate is for about 200,000 cars a year) will spell huge demand. Rushmore says it will be just as cherished as its predecessor because the new car is instantly recognisable as a Mini. "The price, however, will be crucial. The maker initially said it would sell from £11,995 - so it will definitely be perceived as a premium product."

Perhaps not by chance that leaves the Mini fitting rather neatly into BMW's own car range. As any disgruntled Rover dealer will tell you, with Mercedes and Audi all downsizing to offer premium small cars, the Mini makes sense as the new entry-level BMW. Rushmore agrees: "But if the car did go directly under BMW's badge, it would take something away. The world market may not think it matters, but in Britain, a BMW Mini would destroy the Mini for good."

Even if the sales target is modest, everyone agrees that the new car has a tough act to follow. No model has forced its way into popular culture so effectively. Owners clubs in Britain alone total more than 100, including the Christian Mini Club, Mini Erotica, the Gay Mini Owners Club and SMUG - the Solihull Mini Users Group. Among their rank and file, hopes are high that BMW will go on to revive such derivatives as the Moke, the Riley, the Elf, the Wolseley Hornet and even the wood-clad Countryman.

"When BMW first arrived on the scene and Bernd Pischetsreider took over at Rover, we were relieved that he was a Mini lover," says Bristol fan Alex Stanley, who has owned six Minis. "After he went the Mini was left in the hands of a bunch of heartless suits from Munich. It was like asking Hannibal Lecter to pick up your kids from school. We still retain some hope though and we can't wait for the next Cooper, which is supposed to follow soon after the main launch." The Cooper will, of course, be the Mini to buy when it arrives, but a new Mini Elf? Most insiders don't believe it will happen, though who would have predicted the Ford Land Rover?

An aura surrounds it, but despite some updates, it's not much short of a disaster." BMW's aim to sell the new model in very small numbers (the global sales estimate is for about 200,000 cars a year) will spell huge demand. Rushmore says it will be just as cherished as its predecessor because the new car is instantly recognisable as a Mini. "The price, however, will be crucial. The maker initially said it would sell from £11,995 - so it will definitely be perceived as a premium product." Perhaps not by chance that leaves the Mini fitting rather neatly into BMW's own car range. As any disgruntled Rover dealer will tell you, with Mercedes and Audi all downsizing to offer premium small cars, the Mini makes sense as the new entry-level BMW. Rushmore agrees: "But if the car did go directly under BMW's badge, it would take something away. The world market may not think it matters, but in Britain, a BMW Mini would destroy the Mini for good." Even if the sales target is modest, everyone agrees that the new car has a tough act to follow. No model has forced its way into popular culture so effectively. Owners clubs in Britain alone total more than 100, including the Christian Mini Club, Mini Erotica, the Gay Mini Owners Club and SMUG - the Solihull Mini Users Group. Among their rank and file, hopes are high that BMW will go on to revive such derivatives as the Moke, the Riley, the Elf, the Wolseley Hornet and even the wood-clad Countryman. "When BMW first arrived on the scene and Bernd Pischetsreider took over at Rover, we were relieved that he was a Mini lover," says Bristol fan Alex Stanley, who has owned six Minis. "After he went the Mini was left in the hands of a bunch of heartless suits from Munich. It was like asking Hannibal Lecter to pick up your kids from school. We still retain some hope though and we can't wait for the next Cooper, which is supposed to follow soon after the main launch." The Cooper will, of course, be the Mini to buy when it arrives, but a new Mini Elf? Most insiders don't believe it will happen, though who would have predicted the Ford Land Rover?

fields.headline: Test drive
fields.standfirst: Nissan Almera
fields.trailText: Nissan Almera.
fields.body:
No one expects small family cars to look like Ferraris, but it seems that even practical middle-Englanders drew the line at the original Nissan Almera. Despite being robust, roomy and reliable it didn't sell - it was just too ugly.

Whether the new Almera can match the VW Golf's elegant conservatism or the Ford Focus's wilful wackiness is a matter of taste. Nissan make much of what they call their "super-utility" interior concept, which in practice adds up to endless cubby holes, cup holders and other plastic addenda. It's an anal retentive's delight. There's a special place for your sunglasses, your tissues, your briefcase and even your takeaway - although I've always found that the passenger's footwell suits all of the above.

Nissan have also made the Almera's interior much posher than before, but the plush new armchairs take up rear legroom. The old Almera was really roomy in the back, but our 11-year-old daughter was complaining bitterly before we'd even left the drive - a new family record - because I had the driver's seat right back and didn't realise just how short of space she was.

However, I soon found that the new Almera is as enjoyable to drive as the old one. And despite having less room in the back than the old one, it certainly isn't cramped when compared with the other cars in its class - although it's no longer a class leader. I would pay the extra £500 for the 1.8 over the 1.5, because it is still good for almost 38mpg on the combined cycle. And if you cover a high annual mileage then the 2.2 litre diesel will be well worth another £800 over the 1.8.

When it comes to equipment levels, if you want a full suite of airbags and ABS brakes - not to mention air-con for comfort - then you'll have to go for the "SE" trim level. The pick-of-the-range is the 1.8 SE 5-door, listed at £13,900, and in comparison with the competition that's really excellent value - with Nissan's watertight three year warranty.

If the new Almera wasn't such good value I'd have to conclude that while it's better than before it's still not good enough to dethrone VW Golf or Ford Focus. But at such competitive prices the Almera has to be a real contender, and if you're buying a car with your own money then you really should put it on your shopping list.

fields.headline: Me and my motor
fields.standfirst: Elizabeth Wright
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Wright.
fields.body:
What is your car?

It's a sculpture called Mini, Escort that features a Mini magnified by 30% parked next to a normal sized Escort.

How did the idea come about?

I wanted to swap the scales of two objects. A car has a standard shape but with lots of variables to play with. I wanted people to recognise the shape but also realise that something has changed. You've got to decide if it's the Mini that's different or the Escort.

Why did you choose these cars?

I was interested in archetypal English cars. The mini is an icon of the 20th century and the Escort is the 80s boy racer.

What is your Mini made of?

Aluminium, Perspex, steel and some real car parts.

Does it work?

No, although everyone wants it to - but it's just an image. You can push it forward and back on its wheels. Inside it has a steering wheel, mirror and a magic tree that illuminates at night.

How long did it take to make?

Eight weeks. It was made by Mick from MC Hammering in Kent. I completed the finishing of dirt and rust. I didn't want it to look like a prototype, but rather as if it had been used. It's weathered - like it's been round the block.

What reaction have you had to it?

People say dumb things like "That's a big mini"or "Is it on steroids?"

Where is it?

It's in London for two months then goes on tour to Ipswich and then the Norwich.

How much did it cost to make?

£8,000 - co-funded by two galleries.

What will happen to it after the tour?

I'm hoping to sell it to a car collector so the galleries can get some of their money back.

Have you worked with cars before?

My next piece, opening in April, is a van parked in a living room. With this work I'll be challenging the idea of placement and context.

Do you have a roadworthy car?

I had to get rid of my last car - some sort of Renault - because the engine was falling inwards. It was completely lethal.

What would be your dream car to own?

A new Volkswagen Beetle because of its amazing design.

Who would be the perfect passenger for the Mini, Escort?

Someone 30% bigger than the average person.

 Elizabeth Wright's Mini, Escort has been shortlisted for the Beck's Futures 2000 prize and can currently be seen at the ICA. Details: 0171 930 3647

fields.headline: Auto parts
fields.trailText: Quote of the week
fields.body:
Quote of the week

"The first time I drove a supercar - a Porsche 928 - I managed to go just a mile before ramming it into some crash barriers at a place with no vowels in Wales."

Jeremy Clarkson, The Sun

Out of Focus

Ford is recalling 100,000 new Focus models over possible engine faults, it announced on Friday. The problem - on Zetec models fitted with 1.8 and 2 litre petrol engines, and 20,000 of the 1.6 litre engine model - causes oil leaks and temporary power loss. Not a great week for British motor manufacturing then.

Jam tomorrow

By 2005 the average driver is in this country is going to be spending over a fortnight a year stuck in traffic jams, says the RAC. Increasing congestion means we're spending more time behind the wheel - and that's not good for the nation's health. Long periods of driving can cause stress, road rage and high blood pressure. And it also means more pigging out on junk food snacks. Scary.

fields.headline: Do the bag test
fields.standfirst: Justin Urquhart Stewart, Corporate Development Director, Barclays Stockbrokers
fields.trailText: Justin Urquhart Stewart, Corporate Development Director, Barclays Stockbrokers. For most of us, personal finance and money is frightening and fundamentally dull. It's this thing that you do need to do something about, but you want someone else to do it. When it comes to money, most of us want loads of it, provided on a plate.
fields.body:
For most of us, personal finance and money is frightening and fundamentally dull. It's this thing that you do need to do something about, but you want someone else to do it. When it comes to money, most of us want loads of it, provided on a plate.

One thing I think is so important is to make money and finance into something that's entertaining and fun. Not something that means you have to talk to pretentious gits like me with double-barrelled names and red braces.

My advice is to get together with your chums and form an investment club. Make sure you have sufficient drink to make sure you cannot remember exactly what was said at each meeting. Each member need only contribute between £20 and £50 each month (aside from the drinks bill) to be set aside in a communal account. Then decide together where you want to invest your fund. You can't have more than 20 people or you run into problems with partnership law. Fifteen is a good number.

If you have people from different professions, you'll find that before you know it you have a wealth of knowledge. Lo and behold, you have all this information which you can start using when the club buys shares. If it all goes horribly wrong, then you have only lost about £40. But you'll find you can quite easily cut through all the rhubarb spouted by people like me if you just use your common sense.

Did you notice that a couple of years ago, no one you knew was shopping at M & S, they were all going to Tesco. It's the same with Storehouse (otherwise known as Poorhouse), which owns things like Mothercare and Bhs. You can do the bag test: you wouldn't wander around with a Bhs bag would you? You'd put it inside a Tesco bag.

Or look at Russia. Now that you have a leader who is more interested in his political cabinet than his drinks cabinet, it is a better bet to invest there. When you think this way, suddenly you find the mist being lifted.

If you look at the growth of the internet, you then realise that all these messages require some kind of communication mechanism. Whether it is BT or mobile phone companies, they are better investments than all these dot.com companies, which may well end up being Dot Con. Telecommunications stock might not be something you can retire on, but you might get a decent car out of it.

fields.headline: Fighting dirty
fields.standfirst: Phillip Knightley changed our view of war and the media with his book The First Casualty. To mark its updating, he argues that the war correspondent has an easy choice: become part of the military's propaganda machine - or quit.
fields.trailText: Phillip Knightley changed our view of war and the media with his book The First Casualty. To mark its updating, he argues that the war correspondent has an easy choice: become part of the military's propaganda machine - or quit.
fields.body:
When groups of old war correspondents gather in a bar - as they have been known to do - they shed a nostalgic tear for Vietnam, the days when they were heroes, famous and important.

In Vietnam, the United States military accepted them, called on all ranks to give them full cooperation and assistance, transported them, fed them on a reimbursable basis, briefed them, armed them when necessary, defended them, drank with them, and treated them like members of the team. Free from any censorship, the war correspondents went where they chose, reported the truth as they saw it and, according to the military establishment, thus lost the United States the war.

Robert Elegant, a long-serving Asia expert, wrote later: "For the first time in modern history the outcome of war was determined not on the battlefield but on the printed page and, above all, on the television screen."

The military was bitter. War correspondents had been patriotic in the second world war and on side in Korea. What was wrong in Vietnam? "So you're Malcolm Browne," said Admiral Harry D Felt when he met the legendary Associated Press journalist. "Why the hell don't you get on the team?"

Now fast-forward 25 years to Kosovo in March last year. More correspondents than ever were all set to cover the conflict - an astonishing 2,700 media people accompanied Nato forces when they entered the province at the end of the bombing campaign.

Official arrangements for them were awe-inspiring. There was a daily briefing at Nato's headquarters in Brussels, a series of briefings at the Ministry of Defence in London, media meetings at the Pentagon, press conferences at the White House and statement after statement from President Clinton, Prime Minister Blair, and numerous other Allied ministers. Nato generals lined up to be interviewed and armchair strategists jostled for air time. There were even Allied correspondents in the enemy capital, Belgrade, and Serbian journalists attended Nato briefings in Brussels.

The revolution in communications technology; the satellite phone - the star of the war; instant TV links from the front to the studio and between correspondents in the field; electronic transmission of still photographs; and - the latest arrival at the front - the internet; all were available to provide the public with an unprecedented overview of the war. The ordinary, literate citizen would be able to know more about the conflict than any war in history.

Instead, we drowned in wave after wave of words and images that added up to nothing. "Kosovo ... turned out to be the most secret campaign in living memory," wrote the British war historian Alistair Horne. "We were given lots of material but no information," says Sky war correspondent Jake Lynch. British journalist Peter Dunn wrote that it was "the first international conflict fought by press officers." General Sir Michael Rose, former commander of the UN force in Bosnia, said that at Nato "rhetoric has taken over from reality".

What had changed between Vietnam and Kosovo? Basically, the military has won its 150-year battle with war correspondents: journalists want to tell the public everything; the military's attitude is: "Tell them nothing till the war's over, then tell them who won." Defeated by the military, governments and spin doctors, war correspondents now face an agonising choice. If they can no longer be heroes, do they want to continue as propagandists and myth makers, subservient to those who wage the wars?

The turning point in the battle was the Falklands. The nature of the campaign - a seaborne task force sailing to invade a group of islands 8,000 miles from Britain and 400 miles from the nearest land mass - meant that correspondents could not get to the war unless the Ministry of Defence took them. In return for access to the action the correspondents had to accept the MoD rules.

These were crippling. British correspondents only; no impartial neutrals. The British applicants were vetted - no room, for example, for veteran photographer Don McCullin, because his photographs tended to be too realistic.

The 17 correspondents eventually accredited had to sign forms agreeing to accept censorship at source by six MoD "public relations officers". And they were told that it was their duty to "help in leading and steadying public opinion in times of national stress or crisis". The result was that the war was reported exactly how the military wanted it to be.

From this success, a theory developed. If you confronted the media groups and told them that, unlike Vietnam, this was a war that they would not be allowed to cover, they would become so desperate and divided that you could do a deal - they would be allowed war coverage but only on the military's terms.

This theory was tested in the American invasions of Grenada and Panama, and worked brilliantly in the Gulf war. There the United States and Britain operated a "pool system". Only a limited number of journalists would be allowed near the battlefield; they would be escorted by officers who would decide what they would see; and the journalists would have to make their reports available to everyone.

Although media organisations complained that this amounted to censorship more dangerous than "blue-pencil editing", they ended up accepting it because they had no choice. They also accepted the "advice" of their MoD minders on what they could write because, as the Economist put it, "the truth about the Gulf war ... must await the end of the fighting".

So by the time Kosovo came around, the lies, manipulation, news management, propaganda, spin, distortion, omission, slant and gullibility involved in trying to report the conflict brought war correspondents to the current crisis point in their short history. Their role has never been more insecure.

The most shameful event for the media during the Kosovo war was a United States Congressional fact-finding mission to Yugoslavia between April 18 and 21. Congressmen felt they could trust neither the administration nor the media to tell them what was really happening - what an indictment of war correspondents. How did they allow this sorry state of affairs to come about?

One difficulty is that the media have little or no memory. War correspondents have short working lives and there is no tradition or means for passing on their knowledge and experience. The military, on the other hand, is an institution and goes on forever. The military learned a lot from Vietnam and these days plans its media strategy with as much attention as its military strategy.

The Pentagon and the MoD have manuals, updated after every war, which serve to guide the way they will manage the media - as does every other major military power. What media organisation has anything similar?

All these military manuals follow basic principles - appear open, transparent and eager to help; never go in for summary repression or direct control; nullify rather than conceal undesirable news; control emphasis rather than facts; balance bad news with good; and lie directly only when certain that the lie will not be found out during the course of the war.

We are learning only now what lies we were told and what secrets were kept from us during the war in Kosovo. We were not told that the CIA helped train the Kosovo Liberation Army before the bombing began. We were not told that the KLA realised its attacks on Serb policemen would bring retaliation on ethnic Albanian civilians but it went ahead anyway because it hoped that Serbian atrocities would bring in the west - as they did.

We did not realise at the time that Nato was lying when it said it did not deliberately attack civilian targets. It was not until June that Nato's commander, General Wesley Clark, admitted to the BBC's Mark Urban that Nato planes were targeting "phase 3" [civilian] targets.

We believed Nato when it said that after the war it would disarm and disband the KLA. But Jonathan Dimbleby wrote in January that the KLA remained in control of the streets, Nato had delivered Kosovo from one catastrophe straight into another and western leaders had stayed shockingly silent about outrages taking place there. "So much for moral crusades," said Dimbleby.

We believed Nato when it said it was systematically destroying the Serbian army in Kosovo, only to learn after the war that this was simply not so. We believed the figures the State Department and Pentagon released for the number of ethnic Albanians murdered by Serbs, only to see them come tumbling down - 500,000, then 100,000, then 10,000 - when Nato entered Kosovo and sufficient mass graves failed to materialise.

True, the nature of the war played into the military's hands in keeping the true face of battle from the public. It was fought entirely from the air by means of a high-altitude bombing campaign, so no one - except the victims - really knew what was happening on the ground.

Since they could not go to the fighting, correspondents either gathered at Nato headquarters in Brussels or clustered along the borders of those coun tries surrounding Kosovo and tried to peer over. There they were interviewed on television by fellow journalists in studios in Europe and the United States - who often had to brief them about the latest news before the interview started because the reporter on the spot usually knew nothing.

According to veteran correspondent Robert Fisk, one of the few heroes left, this lack of access to the war produced two types of journalists - the "frothers" who had "convinced themselves of the justice of the war and the wickedness of the other side" - and the "sheep" who blindly followed Nato's word.

The Russians watched and learned. When Moscow began its campaign against Chechnya, it used a system of news management based on Nato's. An information centre in Moscow offered Nato-style briefings which had to be accepted at face value, while at the front everything possible was done to hinder war correspondents and exclude them from battle zones. They were denied accreditation, detained, searched, intimidated. "How can you cover a war you can't get to?" one foreign journalist asked the Moscow Times.

The sad truth is that today government propaganda prepares its citizens for war so skilfully that it is quite likely that they do not want the truthful, objective and balanced reporting that hero war correspondents once did their best to provide.

Studies carried out after the Gulf war by Dr David Morrison, of the University of Leeds, showed that if there were a British mistake that caused a war to go badly, most people in the study felt that this mistake should never be reported, or only after the war was over.

Further, where reporting in the Gulf was dominated by television as in no other war, most viewers were quite content with the reporting and considered it to be accurate and fair. If viewers had any complaint at all, it was that TV stations devoted too much time to the war and that this disrupted their favourite programmes.

Armed with information like this, the likelihood is that governments will find further justification for managing the media in wartime. In fact, I predict that control of war correspondents - both open and covert - will be even tighter, and that this will be accepted by most media groups because in wartime they consider their best commercial and political interests lie in supporting the government of the day.

 Phillip Knightley's book, The First Casualty: the War Correspondent as Hero and Myth Maker from the Crimea to Kosovo, is published by Prion Books, price £12

And they were told that it was their duty to "help in leading and steadying public opinion in times of national stress or crisis". The result was that the war was reported exactly how the military wanted it to be. From this success, a theory developed. If you confronted the media groups and told them that, unlike Vietnam, this was a war that they would not be allowed to cover, they would become so desperate and divided that you could do a deal - they would be allowed war coverage but only on the military's terms. This theory was tested in the American invasions of Grenada and Panama, and worked brilliantly in the Gulf war. There the United States and Britain operated a "pool system". Only a limited number of journalists would be allowed near the battlefield; they would be escorted by officers who would decide what they would see; and the journalists would have to make their reports available to everyone. Although media organisations complained that this amounted to censorship more dangerous than "blue-pencil editing", they ended up accepting it because they had no choice. They also accepted the "advice" of their MoD minders on what they could write because, as the Economist put it, "the truth about the Gulf war ... must await the end of the fighting". So by the time Kosovo came around, the lies, manipulation, news management, propaganda, spin, distortion, omission, slant and gullibility involved in trying to report the conflict brought war correspondents to the current crisis point in their short history. Their role has never been more insecure. The most shameful event for the media during the Kosovo war was a United States Congressional fact-finding mission to Yugoslavia between April 18 and 21. Congressmen felt they could trust neither the administration nor the media to tell them what was really happening - what an indictment of war correspondents. How did they allow this sorry state of affairs to come about? One difficulty is that the media have little or no memory. War correspondents have short working lives and there is no tradition or means for passing on their knowledge and experience. The military, on the other hand, is an institution and goes on forever. The military learned a lot from Vietnam and these days plans its media strategy with as much attention as its military strategy. The Pentagon and the MoD have manuals, updated after every war, which serve to guide the way they will manage the media - as does every other major military power. What media organisation has anything similar? All these military manuals follow basic principles - appear open, transparent and eager to help; never go in for summary repression or direct control; nullify rather than conceal undesirable news; control emphasis rather than facts; balance bad news with good; and lie directly only when certain that the lie will not be found out during the course of the war. We are learning only now what lies we were told and what secrets were kept from us during the war in Kosovo. We were not told that the CIA helped train the Kosovo Liberation Army before the bombing began. We were not told that the KLA realised its attacks on Serb policemen would bring retaliation on ethnic Albanian civilians but it went ahead anyway because it hoped that Serbian atrocities would bring in the west - as they did. We did not realise at the time that Nato was lying when it said it did not deliberately attack civilian targets. It was not until June that Nato's commander, General Wesley Clark, admitted to the BBC's Mark Urban that Nato planes were targeting "phase 3" [civilian] targets. We believed Nato when it said that after the war it would disarm and disband the KLA. But Jonathan Dimbleby wrote in January that the KLA remained in control of the streets, Nato had delivered Kosovo from one catastrophe straight into another and western leaders had stayed shockingly silent about outrages taking place there. "So much for moral crusades," said Dimbleby. We believed Nato when it said it was systematically destroying the Serbian army in Kosovo, only to learn after the war that this was simply not so. We believed the figures the State Department and Pentagon released for the number of ethnic Albanians murdered by Serbs, only to see them come tumbling down - 500,000, then 100,000, then 10,000 - when Nato entered Kosovo and sufficient mass graves failed to materialise. True, the nature of the war played into the military's hands in keeping the true face of battle from the public. It was fought entirely from the air by means of a high-altitude bombing campaign, so no one - except the victims - really knew what was happening on the ground. Since they could not go to the fighting, correspondents either gathered at Nato headquarters in Brussels or clustered along the borders of those coun tries surrounding Kosovo and tried to peer over. There they were interviewed on television by fellow journalists in studios in Europe and the United States - who often had to brief them about the latest news before the interview started because the reporter on the spot usually knew nothing. According to veteran correspondent Robert Fisk, one of the few heroes left, this lack of access to the war produced two types of journalists - the "frothers" who had "convinced themselves of the justice of the war and the wickedness of the other side" - and the "sheep" who blindly followed Nato's word. The Russians watched and learned. When Moscow began its campaign against Chechnya, it used a system of news management based on Nato's. An information centre in Moscow offered Nato-style briefings which had to be accepted at face value, while at the front everything possible was done to hinder war correspondents and exclude them from battle zones. They were denied accreditation, detained, searched, intimidated. "How can you cover a war you can't get to?" one foreign journalist asked the Moscow Times. The sad truth is that today government propaganda prepares its citizens for war so skilfully that it is quite likely that they do not want the truthful, objective and balanced reporting that hero war correspondents once did their best to provide. Studies carried out after the Gulf war by Dr David Morrison, of the University of Leeds, showed that if there were a British mistake that caused a war to go badly, most people in the study felt that this mistake should never be reported, or only after the war was over. Further, where reporting in the Gulf was dominated by television as in no other war, most viewers were quite content with the reporting and considered it to be accurate and fair. If viewers had any complaint at all, it was that TV stations devoted too much time to the war and that this disrupted their favourite programmes. Armed with information like this, the likelihood is that governments will find further justification for managing the media in wartime. In fact, I predict that control of war correspondents - both open and covert - will be even tighter, and that this will be accepted by most media groups because in wartime they consider their best commercial and political interests lie in supporting the government of the day.  Phillip Knightley's book, The First Casualty: the War Correspondent as Hero and Myth Maker from the Crimea to Kosovo, is published by Prion Books, price £12

fields.headline: No one asked us
fields.standfirst: Why did the Sunday Times reveal confidential sources to the Bloody Sunday inquiry?  John Mullin reports
fields.trailText: Why did the Sunday Times reveal confidential sources to the Bloody Sunday inquiry? John Mullin reports
fields.body:
Former Sunday Times reporters Peter Pringle and Philip Jacobson look on with some bemusement as Lord Saville of Newdigate issues tough rules limiting journalists' rights to protect sources during his Bloody Sunday inquiry, which opens next Monday. Neither of the ex-Insight investigators much relishes a taste of porridge or a hefty fine for contempt of court. They would, though, have liked to have been able to make their own decisions on the confidential material they amassed almost three decades ago.

Pringle and Jacobson, now freelancers, were aghast to learn that their interview notes, memos and other sensitive papers relating to Bloody Sunday had been handed over to Lord Saville two years ago. No one had asked them.

The Sunday Times passed over material kept in its archives since 1972. The reporters, who have been legally advised they own copyright, say that they would have refused permission. The Sunday Times admits it made a mistake. Its lawyers are trying to mitigate the damage caused.

Pringle and Jacobson were sent to Londonderry on January 31 1972, the day after paratroopers opened fire on a civil rights demonstration. The army killed 13 unarmed Catholics.

When Lord Chief Justice Lord Widgery's inquiry was announced the following day, many media outlets backed off from further investigations of Bloody Sunday. But Harold Evans, then editor of the Sunday Times, insisted that the Insight team remained to conduct their own reconstruction of events.

Pringle and Jacobson traipsed through the Bogside for two months. They interviewed members of the Provisional and Official IRA, and hundreds of eyewitnesses. So, while Lord Widgery exonerated the army, Insight presented a different picture in its 12,000 word piece.

After the reporters came home, Sunday Times bosses insisted they placed their material in the newspaper's archives. It filled seven boxes, including many crucial photographs of a key flashpoint which Lord Widgery was confident never even existed.

Pringle was first told that the Sunday Times had handed over the material when he received a call from Lord Saville's inquiry in New York in May 1998. He met the inquiry's then solicitor Philip Ridd at an anonymous office block in London two months later.

There he was confronted with five small, brightly coloured note books he had last seen more than a quarter of a century ago. Although he was outraged, the damage was not as bad as it could have been. He had been careful not to record the identities of people who had spoken on condition of anonymity.

But the difficulty is where sources prepared to be named have gone off the record during an interview to be distanced from the information they are imparting. There are half a dozen instances, potentially creating terrible problems for each of the sources.

Richard Caseby, managing editor of the Sunday Times, refuses to comment on who was to blame, saying that the matter was being dealt with internally. "The Insight papers should not have been handed over by News International," Caseby says. "And the journalists involved should have been consulted. As soon as I learned what had happened, I instructed our lawyers to contact the Saville inquiry over its right to retain and circulate the material. That matter is still ongoing, but we are doing our best to mitigate the error."

As well as Pringle and Jacobson, Tony Harnden, the Daily Telegraph's former Ireland correspondent, has been ordered to hand over material, while others - including Channel 4's Alex Lena Ferguson and Alex Thomson - must wait and see.

Meanwhile, Pringle and Jacobson, shortly to publish their book on Bloody Sunday, Those Are Real Bullets, Aren't They?, are deeply disappointed by the fiasco.

fields.headline: Irish troubles
fields.trailText: It is difficult not to smile at the antics of those Ulster Unionists who have tried to prevent Tony O'Reilly's Independent Newspapers from buying the Belfast Telegraph group. David Trimble has complained to the department of trade and industry that the deal would give O'Reilly monopoly powers across the island of Ireland.
fields.body:
It is difficult not to smile at the antics of those Ulster Unionists who have tried to prevent Tony O'Reilly's Independent Newspapers from buying the Belfast Telegraph group. David Trimble has complained to the department of trade and industry that the deal would give O'Reilly monopoly powers across the island of Ireland.

But the irony is that the fight by Unionists to maintain the six northern counties as a separate jurisdiction has helped to win the day for O'Reilly's bid. His lawyers, and those of the seller, Trinity-Mirror, are evidently agreed: the sale will pass the automatic competition commission inquiry.

Sabre-rattling by Unionists is bound to continue. Trimble's deputy, John Taylor, himself an owner of a small newspaper group in Co Armagh, has opposed virtually every press takeover in recent times. This is unlikely to move the government to block O'Reilly.

One major Unionist complaint, that the Belfast Telegraph's editorial policy might change, is clearly nonsense. O'Reilly's main Dublin-based titles, the Irish Independent and especially the Sunday Independent, have been trenchantly anti-republican throughout the troubles and, if anything, more pro-Unionist than the Belfast Telegraph.

That is one of the reasons O'Reilly was able to attract the Unionist party chairman, Lord Rogan, to join the board he has set up specifically to oversee his new northern Irish group. Another director will be Lady (Moyra) Quigley, a former chair of the Northern Ireland Livestock Commission, and the wife of Sir George Quigley, chairman of Ulster Bank and Short Brothers. The so-called "moderate Unionist" stance of the Belfast Telegraph is therefore bound to continue.

In truth, this purchase is not about politics but economics. If a newspaper business with the same characteristics had turned up in Wagga Wagga or Windhoek, anywhere in the world, O'Reilly's team would have been interested. Consider the figures: the Belfast Telegraph has a £54m turnover and makes £22m profit, one of highest margins in regional papers in Britain and Ireland. It has lucrative printing deals. It has a flourishing online operation, boasting one of the most used websites of any regional paper. So the future looks bright.

Though Independent has paid £300m for the pleasure of ownership, it makes commercial sense and raises the UK-based sector of the company into the big league at last. Until last week it was 19th in the list of regional publishers. If this deal is approved it will move up to 12th.

The competition commission will doubtless be asked to consider the Sunday market closely because Independent already owns the Sunday World, which sells more than 70,000 in the six counties and will now have the hugely successful Sunday Life in its stable with a circulation of more than 90,000. Even that is unlikely to prove a problem because the Sunday World isn't viewed as a northern Irish title and, most significantly, it sells almost no advertising in the north.

One of the attractions of the Belfast Telegraph is its dominance of the advertising market. With a circulation approaching 120,000, it has a solid classified advertising base, especially for jobs. Under fair employment legislation, it has to target both communities and that may well have helped it gradually increase its Catholic readership, which now accounts for about 30% of the total.

In journalistic terms, the Telegraph could well benefit from new ownership. It hasn't been noticeably bad under Trinity-Mirror, but there is no doubt it could be so much better. There is still too little editorial content (and too few journalists) and the paper's latest revamp, putting the accent on features rather than news, is not as impressive as it might be. The Irish News, the nationalist daily which sells 50,000 and has also undergone a redesign, is more serious than the Belfast Telegraph and, when news breaks, has shown itself far better able to handle it.

Finally, again on a political note, Trimble and Taylor would do well to consider the pressures on O'Reilly once he controls the Belfast Telegraph group. If Ireland were to be reunited, Independent Newspapers & Media would hold such an overwhelming newspaper monopoly across the 32 counties it would be inconceivable that he could hold on to all his papers. He would be forced to divest. It therefore makes more sense for the commercial future of O'Reilly's company to keep the border in place. Seen in that context, Trimble's hostility to the deal makes no sense at all.

* The sale of the Belfast Telegraph group came about as a condition of Trinity's takeover of the Mirror group. It was a bitter pill for the merged company's chief executive, Philip Graf, to swallow. He has a great affection for the Belfast Telegraph, having started his career there, and would rather not have sold it. But he had reason to smile on Friday: Trinity-Mirror announced profits of £168m, just ahead of forecasts. A licence to print papers nowadays is also a licence to print money, it seems.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Richard Johnson
fields.trailText: Newspapers: I read the Racing Post and usually the Sun. Also, the Mail on Sunday. I like most of them, unless they write anything bad. Jonathan Powell in the Racing Post writes very good articles. He writes in a couple of Sunday papers as well. He tends to take things from a different angle and puts them over very well.
fields.body:
Newspapers: I read the Racing Post and usually the Sun. Also, the Mail on Sunday. I like most of them, unless they write anything bad. Jonathan Powell in the Racing Post writes very good articles. He writes in a couple of Sunday papers as well. He tends to take things from a different angle and puts them over very well.

Magazines: Nothing really. I suppose I'd look at Loaded if I was going on a very long journey. I don't read magazines.

Film: Nothing really. I don't go to the cinema either. Tommy Lee Jones is brilliant - whatever movie he's in. And I'll always watch any James Bond film that's on.

Television: I don't really watch television either. Except I suppose EastEnders. Just for entertainment. I would switch the television off if I saw someone like Julian Clary on it. I'm hardly ever at home. I don't usually get home until 9 or 10 o'clock at night.

Radio: Radio 1, just because it's entertaining and modern. I listen to all of it. It's just very easy to listen to when you're driving. Zoë Ball in the morning was good, but she's obviously finished now.

Books: I don't read books. Can't read. Put it this way, I've never ever read a book in my life. I wouldn't have time anyway.

Ads: Don't mind them. I like the Fiat car ads on telly now - the Punto ones I think. They're quite entertaining, taking the mickey out of people.

Multimedia: I've got a mobile phone. It's the only piece of electronic equipment I need really, just because it's the only way people can contact me direct. I don't really need things like computers and the rest. I have an agent to do everything like that.

 Richard Johnson rode Looks Like Trouble to victory in last week's Gold Cup at Cheltenham.

fields.headline: Kids' stuff
fields.standfirst: It is the future of broadcasting, 15-minute programmes that don't demand so much of our time. As the BBC launches into micro-TV,  Maggie Brown  reveals the driving force - channel-hopping children
fields.trailText: It is the future of broadcasting, 15-minute programmes that don't demand so much of our time. As the BBC launches into micro-TV, Maggie Brown reveals the driving force - channel-hopping children
fields.body:
So you've crumbled. You've installed digital television, become part of a trend. But what will happen to your viewing habits now that you have nearly 200 channels to choose from?

Around 3m homes have signed up to digital television over the past 18 months and research suggests that in digital-homes people are viewing differently, displaying a new impatience, dodging adverts and demanding instant gratification. The term used is "grazing".

Further, according to a study by Nickelodeon, children and teenagers have cottoned on fastest to the power of the electronic programme guide (EPG) - the big difference between analogue and digital television - which calls up networks by scrolling through the choices, as with a computer. Or, as children observe, it's like playing a computer game.

Janey Grace, managing director of Nickelodeon, says: "Audiences seem much less tolerant of the bits in between. They won't watch any clutter, won't watch the adverts. Content is important. If they want Rugrats, they want Rugrats now, and they will scroll down the EPG until they find it."

"This is an audience closest to video," says Kathryn Mitchell, programming head of the UKTV channels, including the successful UK Gold. As many of the minor channels, such as National Geographic or the BBC's relaunching Arena net work, feature way down the pecking order on the EPG, they have to be content with hauling in tiny numbers of casual viewers. If they get 20 minutes or so per week, they are ecstatic, says Ian Lewis, Sky's director of programme and promotional strategy.

The more minor channels also attract peak audiences at different times - perhaps 10.30pm, if aimed at adults, or 5pm if, like MTV, they are aimed at teenagers - because the main terrestrial channels throw resources at the hours between 7pm and 10.30pm.

Even the BBC is recognising this, by quietly changing its clumsy digital strategy. On April 3, the little-watched but much-criticised BBC Choice relaunches. Central to the new schedule devised by its head, Stuart Murphy, is that it will invest its limited funds for new output on bite-size programmes, 15-minutes long but in an hour-long strand, appealing to 25- to 44-year-olds.

BBC News 24 has already bowed to the inevitable and become a more conventional news service, for people wanting a quick news fix, while the third, well-nigh "invisible" digital channel, BBC Knowledge, originally aimed at a youth audience, is to switch its focus towards viewers aged 35-55, interested in informative factual programmes.

The joy of micro TV, as Murphy describes his 15-minuters, is that budgets equivalent to £160,000 per hour - divided among brief but relatively timeless programmes - will repay the original investment. They can be repeated perhaps eight times over two years, without blushing, because only a few people will have seen them the first time. The subjects and strands already commissioned give a flavour of what he means: profiles of Zoë Ball, Prince Naseem, Ulrika Jonsson, Jason Donovan; Rock Shrines, including reports from the graves of such stars as John Lennon and Bob Marley on the anniversaries of their deaths; Great Speeches, including Jonathan Aitken's "sword of truth" outburst; and Screw-ups, the art of messing up.

"It's a fact that people graze on cable and satellite, while wedded to videos of old Have I Got News For You shows," argues Murphy. "Quality is a big issue. We're making a fundamental shift of emphasis. Trying to become more attuned to digital audiences."

As for encouraging grazing, Murphy says: "I don't think it's a bad habit. On BBC Choice, within one hour you'll get the essence of the BBC. We don't take an idea and dilute it," he adds, referring to the alternative theme-night strategy of digital channels, exemplified by Discovery's shark or hurricane nights.

David Peter, broadcast planning director of media agency Carat, cautions that while grazing is on the increase, and people's choice is obviously that much greater, the typical viewer tends to settle down after a period of surfing and experimentation and stick with 12-15 favourite networks. Many of the small niche services, he says, "don't get on people's radar. In reality, people can't deal with 240 channels. All new subscribers scan through, but they soon settle on a manageable repertoire."

This problem of attracting attention despite increasing competition lies at the heart of Nickelodeon's study Youth Power, How to Connect? conducted by Shari Donnenfeld, its director of research. It says the 1998 launch of Sky Digital has revolutionised the way its target audience of children view TV, changing both what and how kids in digi-homes watch. They develop their own "tricks" to memorise the time, date and location of favourite channels, and bypass menus. "They are advanced users of the EPG, prolific surfers."

Even pre-school children unable to read can recognise the channel they want to call up. "Kids naturally have short attention-spans and the EPG is a tool which helps them gain instant gratification." In homes with fewer choices, it adds, kids may sit through a less than thrilling programme, whereas kids in digital homes will not tolerate anything "boring".

Grace says the research hasn't changed schedules, "but it makes you focus on the breaks, and the live bits. Every word has to have its place, every frame on TV has to have its place." She adds that it is an argument for more investment in programmes, not less, that programming is crucial - "the EPG changed it all again".

Lewis believes that "to some extent, access to TV via an EPG begins to equalise the playing field. It puts Sky 1 close to BBC1, and BBC2 and Channel 4. Equally, UK Gold or Paramount are also on a par with Sky 1. Schedules need to be strong, programme titles become ever more important. And the more memorable they are the better." With up to 75,000 new digital subscribers each month, he argues, hard and fast rules about TV viewing habits are difficult to make, and certainly not set in stone.
