Further, according to a study by Nickelodeon, children and teenagers have cottoned on fastest to the power of the electronic programme guide (EPG) - the big difference between analogue and digital television - which calls up networks by scrolling through the choices, as with a computer. Or, as children observe, it's like playing a computer game. Janey Grace, managing director of Nickelodeon, says: "Audiences seem much less tolerant of the bits in between. They won't watch any clutter, won't watch the adverts. Content is important. If they want Rugrats, they want Rugrats now, and they will scroll down the EPG until they find it." "This is an audience closest to video," says Kathryn Mitchell, programming head of the UKTV channels, including the successful UK Gold. As many of the minor channels, such as National Geographic or the BBC's relaunching Arena net work, feature way down the pecking order on the EPG, they have to be content with hauling in tiny numbers of casual viewers. If they get 20 minutes or so per week, they are ecstatic, says Ian Lewis, Sky's director of programme and promotional strategy. The more minor channels also attract peak audiences at different times - perhaps 10.30pm, if aimed at adults, or 5pm if, like MTV, they are aimed at teenagers - because the main terrestrial channels throw resources at the hours between 7pm and 10.30pm. Even the BBC is recognising this, by quietly changing its clumsy digital strategy. On April 3, the little-watched but much-criticised BBC Choice relaunches. Central to the new schedule devised by its head, Stuart Murphy, is that it will invest its limited funds for new output on bite-size programmes, 15-minutes long but in an hour-long strand, appealing to 25- to 44-year-olds. BBC News 24 has already bowed to the inevitable and become a more conventional news service, for people wanting a quick news fix, while the third, well-nigh "invisible" digital channel, BBC Knowledge, originally aimed at a youth audience, is to switch its focus towards viewers aged 35-55, interested in informative factual programmes. The joy of micro TV, as Murphy describes his 15-minuters, is that budgets equivalent to £160,000 per hour - divided among brief but relatively timeless programmes - will repay the original investment. They can be repeated perhaps eight times over two years, without blushing, because only a few people will have seen them the first time. The subjects and strands already commissioned give a flavour of what he means: profiles of Zoë Ball, Prince Naseem, Ulrika Jonsson, Jason Donovan; Rock Shrines, including reports from the graves of such stars as John Lennon and Bob Marley on the anniversaries of their deaths; Great Speeches, including Jonathan Aitken's "sword of truth" outburst; and Screw-ups, the art of messing up. "It's a fact that people graze on cable and satellite, while wedded to videos of old Have I Got News For You shows," argues Murphy. "Quality is a big issue. We're making a fundamental shift of emphasis. Trying to become more attuned to digital audiences." As for encouraging grazing, Murphy says: "I don't think it's a bad habit. On BBC Choice, within one hour you'll get the essence of the BBC. We don't take an idea and dilute it," he adds, referring to the alternative theme-night strategy of digital channels, exemplified by Discovery's shark or hurricane nights. David Peter, broadcast planning director of media agency Carat, cautions that while grazing is on the increase, and people's choice is obviously that much greater, the typical viewer tends to settle down after a period of surfing and experimentation and stick with 12-15 favourite networks. Many of the small niche services, he says, "don't get on people's radar. In reality, people can't deal with 240 channels. All new subscribers scan through, but they soon settle on a manageable repertoire." This problem of attracting attention despite increasing competition lies at the heart of Nickelodeon's study Youth Power, How to Connect? conducted by Shari Donnenfeld, its director of research. It says the 1998 launch of Sky Digital has revolutionised the way its target audience of children view TV, changing both what and how kids in digi-homes watch. They develop their own "tricks" to memorise the time, date and location of favourite channels, and bypass menus. "They are advanced users of the EPG, prolific surfers." Even pre-school children unable to read can recognise the channel they want to call up. "Kids naturally have short attention-spans and the EPG is a tool which helps them gain instant gratification." In homes with fewer choices, it adds, kids may sit through a less than thrilling programme, whereas kids in digital homes will not tolerate anything "boring". Grace says the research hasn't changed schedules, "but it makes you focus on the breaks, and the live bits. Every word has to have its place, every frame on TV has to have its place." She adds that it is an argument for more investment in programmes, not less, that programming is crucial - "the EPG changed it all again". Lewis believes that "to some extent, access to TV via an EPG begins to equalise the playing field. It puts Sky 1 close to BBC1, and BBC2 and Channel 4. Equally, UK Gold or Paramount are also on a par with Sky 1. Schedules need to be strong, programme titles become ever more important. And the more memorable they are the better." With up to 75,000 new digital subscribers each month, he argues, hard and fast rules about TV viewing habits are difficult to make, and certainly not set in stone.

webTitle: The report that shocked the suits

fields.headline: The report that shocked the suits
fields.standfirst:
Gathering dust in a Harvard archive is a document every BBC employee should read. Because Greg Dyke loves it. Janine Gibson and Maggie Brown reveal its mystery author, a man at the DG's right hand with job losses on his mind

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The most remarkable thing about the leaks of Greg Dyke's blueprint for the new BBC last week was not the headline figure - 1,000 jobs to go - nor the news that some of the corporation's longest-serving executives might soon be getting their coats. The truly amazing thing was that the BBC, one of the leakiest organisations ever, had managed to keep it quiet for so long.
fields.body:
The most remarkable thing about the leaks of Greg Dyke's blueprint for the new BBC last week was not the headline figure - 1,000 jobs to go - nor the news that some of the corporation's longest-serving executives might soon be getting their coats. The truly amazing thing was that the BBC, one of the leakiest organisations ever, had managed to keep it quiet for so long.

So why did some of the greatest gossips in a notoriously gossipy industry fail to reveal the secret plan emerging from Dyke's review of the corporation, which began when he joined in the autumn? Simple: they didn't know. In fact, no one knew. They still don't.

It didn't stop them speculating. "Isn't it incredible," gasped one of the BBC's most acclaimed programme makers, "how everything that Birt has done is being swept away? It's as if he's never been."

A note from Dyke, sent to every member of staff on Thursday after the trade magazine Broadcast splashed on the story, was confiding and reassuring, while still failing either to deny the reports or unveil the plan. Affectionately signed "yours, Greg" it described the story as speculation and reminded staff that he would announce his plans in a couple of weeks.

So with staff none the wiser, the rumour mill went into overdrive. And the name on the lips of those who know enough to know how little they know was Gareth Jones, the BBC's new director of human resources and legal affairs. Professor Jones, who joined the corporation in November to replace Margaret Salmon, was Dyke's first senior appointment. A former colleague of the new DG, he is something of a mystery to the broadcasting types. Aged 39, he was professor of organisational development at Henley Management college, where he was known for his skills in helping managers effect wide-scale cultural change in their organisations.

This is his speciality, honed with companies including Polygram International and at academic institutions including the University of East Anglia, the London Business school and the voguish French business school, Insead.

Happily, there is an insight into Jones's thinking on the difficulties of changing a company's culture. Gathering dust in the archive of the Harvard Business Review, an illustrious publication, is an article authored by the mastermind behind Dyke's plans. In 1996, along with Rob Goffee - then an LBS professor - Jones wrote What Holds the Modern Company Together. It is a key report.

The article shows the influences behind Dyke's plan - the massive cultural sea change he wants to effect, removing the endless managers and helping BBC staff to have fun again. It also shows the motivation behind his "put up or shut up" speech to staff when he formally took over, when he told them to leave if they didn't like it. Jones's model would not tolerate creative types bitching about the job instead of doing it.

Jones's theory is built on the twin virtues of "sociability" and "solidarity", which can be combined in varying ratios to achieve various ends. There is no single ideal, according to this theory, and different models can work in different areas. A "mercenary" culture can work for a highly competitive, sales-driven organisation where employees expect to work very hard for vast rewards and early retirement. However, for the BBC, it seems the "communal" model, where sociability and solidarity meet harmoniously, would be the ideal.

Four years ago, Jones and Goffee described the BBC as undergoing an "uncomfortable transition". As Birt tried to focus the corporation on efficiency and productivity - dividing producers from broadcasters and establishing the internal market - the BBC became fragmented, they wrote.

"With its communal culture heading toward a fragmented one, the BBC faces no alternative but to invent itself," they concluded. How does an organisation change its culture? Jones and Goffee offered a series of steps: promote the sharing of ideas, arrange casual gatherings, reduce formality, limit hierarchical differences, "act like a friend", create a sense of urgency and stimulate the will to win.

But, they warned, "before attempting to change levels of sociability or solidarity, a manager needs to think a bit like a doctor taking on a new patient. The patient's past and current condition are not only relevant but also critically important to assessing the best future treatment". A questionnaire is provided, with which to assess your organisation's culture, with statements such as "people here do favours for one other because they like one another" to which the responses are either "low, medium or high". One BBC staffer simply burst out laughing in response to that question last week.

Some degree of choosiness will no doubt be appropriate when selecting the BBC's future tactics from the list. Limiting hierarchical differences and redesigning the organisational chart - one of the five recommendations for increasing sociability - is clearly well under way. Introducing an annual company picnic might not be wholly welcomed.

So far, Dyke's grand plan to turn the BBC into a more productive and happy place has been painted as a slaughter of hundreds of top and middle managers, who will find themselves competing for a vastly reduced number of posts. And that slaughter will happen - it will be vital to meet the promised target of reducing spending on administration from 24% of the BBC's total income to a justifiable 15%.

But the real shock to the BBC system will not be the erasure of the current divisions between producers and broadcasters, nor the redistribution of budgets, nor even the rumoured move of Alan Yentob from director of television. According to those who have spoken to Jones, whose touchy-feely style involves chats with key executives over pints of beer, it will be the culture change that is intended to create an effective atmosphere.

The Dyke team want to create a fast-reacting organisation, where programme makers feel valued, and where ideas and creative juices flow freely. They want the new departments to be "small and specialist", reasoning that this is how programme makers work best.

It's no accident that one of the few decisions made in the period of wait ing for the blueprint has been an acceptance that the new digital channels BBC Choice and BBC Knowledge can move into a loft-style office in Mortimer Street, central London, far from the tentacles of the "big brother" BBC Television Centre, in White City, west London.

A further symptom of the new style is Dyke's much commented-upon dislike of lengthy paper policy documents - he refuses to read them - and a desire for a much better system of internal communication. Nothing is sacred - even the role of Ariel, the BBC's Pravda-like internal weekly newspaper, previously deemed essential for the dissemination of Birtspeak, is up for debate.

For many programme makers, the term BBC was associated with Birt and the corporate centre: it was an institution they might have belonged to, but from which they felt alienated. The policy of sending favoured managers off to expensive business school courses at Wharton in the US or Insead is being stopped. So, probably, is the exclusive link with the University of Bradford, which runs a BBC management scheme. The aim is to create a BBC scheme, drawing on the best of business courses.

Dyke's team have also been appalled by the civil service feel of the BBC, evidenced by fusty old-fashioned practices such as "boarding" applicants for "posts" rather than holding interviews for jobs. The new brooms shake their heads at the quaint idea that staff "go on annual leave" instead of holidays.

One trusted aide last week said the bottom line was simple. "What does all this mean for Mrs Smith on her sofa? More money to be spent on better programmes. That's it." Or as another remarks: "The key thing is for the BBC to deliver stonking good programmes to the public, and everything else stands in the way of that."

But the hushed tones and enforced secrecy surrounding Dyke's blueprint cause some old hands to cite the mark of Birt. Carolyn Reynolds, one of the executives trusted to write the plan, is a former McKinsey consultant who joined BBC Worldwide. Robin Foster, who assisted, went on extended leave the moment the blueprint was handed over. "I'm surprised Dyke hasn't issued a consultation plan. That's what ought to happen," said a critic.

The expressed fear is that the change will be so sharp and swift that a further shakedown will be needed in 18 months. The great variation in the predictions of job losses comes from the estimates made by those informed of the outline plan. Though several hundred will go at first, Dyke will not immediately lay down targets for further restructuring within the 16 new departments. That will be left to their new heads.

The programme makers should have nothing to worry about - save any personal aversion to company picnics and the like, but of course the waiting seems endless. As one key senior executive said last week, "I've put all my plans on hold until I know what the final version is."

For, in a period of great change, there are countless tales of people rushing to grab territory and rubbish old rivals or enemies. Some of the governors are thought to be unnerved by the thought of their director-general line-managing 16 separate departments. Some staff are running a book on who will be the first senior manager to go. Whatever Dyke promises about his all-new BBC, it's not all sweetness and light.

fields.headline: Bank charges
fields.standfirst: Banks are under fire after a wide-ranging review into how they operate accused them of making excess profits at customers' expense. Mark Brown analyses the latest findings
fields.trailText:
What is the review and how did it come about?
Chancellor Gordon Brown announced in November 1998 that he was setting up an independent review of banking services. Don Cruickshank, then chairman of the Action 2000 millennium bug campaign, was asked to lead the review, working with officials in the Treasury. Formally launching the review in January 1999, Mr Cruickshank promised to keep an open mind. Consumer groups, though, hoped it would help end practices which they had complained about for years.
fields.body:
What is the review and how did it come about?
Chancellor Gordon Brown announced in November 1998 that he was setting up an independent review of banking services. Don Cruickshank, then chairman of the Action 2000 millennium bug campaign, was asked to lead the review, working with officials in the Treasury. Formally launching the review in January 1999, Mr Cruickshank promised to keep an open mind. Consumer groups, though, hoped it would help end practices which they had complained about for years.

Like what?
Charging customers to withdraw money at other banks' cashpoints. Not making explicit when and why charges were being made. Slow response to complaints. The difficulties banks put in the way of customers trying to change their accounts. Basically, banks were accused of being greedy (Lloyds TSB announced record profits last month of £3.62bn) and ripping off customers at any opportunity.

So what does the report say?
The most shocking finding is that customers are being overcharged by £3-5bn a year - that is between £40 and £400 per individual customer. The main reason, according to Mr Cruickshank, is a lack of competition.

How do you mean?
It may seem that there is more on offer from the banks and more of them - telephone only banks, online banking etc - but the fact is that 80% of current accounts are with the big four high-street banks: Barclays, Lloyds TSB, HSBC and NatWest. You're more likely to get divorced than change your bank account - yet you could save a lot of money if you did.

What other criticisms does the report make?
Banks do charge too much for using cash machines. They don't serve low-income families or small businesses properly. Retailers pay too much for the facility of accepting credit card payments. The banks were expecting a bashing - and they got it.

What does the report recommend?
It calls for a new regulator, called PayCom, to watch over things such as cheque clearing and ATM charging; increased transparency and competition; better complaints handling; an obligation for banks to create basic "no frills" accounts which cannot go into debit for people who do not currently have accounts. And, controversially, the report calls for an end to the domination of the market by so few banks - there needs to be greater competition.

What do the banks have to say?
They don't like the report. They defend their high profits, claiming that these are cyclical - when times are good profits are very good, when bad they are very bad. The banks also say they only charge when they have to. And they also reject absolutely the suggestion that there is not enough competition. They argue that making it too easy for other companies to start new banks would pose a threat to customers, who could not be sure their money was safely looked after. Tim Sweeney, director-general of the British Bankers' Association, called for a calm and measured response, saying: "Do not allow all the miasma of small criticisms to distract attention from the larger picture."

So what happens next?
Over to Gordon Brown. The chancellor is expected to use his budget tomorrow to address the points raised by the report. Meanwhile the big four banks - whose share prices have already been hit by news of Mr Cruickshank's reaport - are putting on a brave face. They say they want to look at the fine detail of the report before they make any big announcements.

fields.headline: Labour counting on Brown's clout
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Labour MPs are banking on Gordon Brown doing for them what Achilles did for the Greeks.
fields.body:
There was a time during the Trojan war when things were going badly for the Greeks. Achilles had got the hump and was sulking in his tent; while he was out of action, the emboldened Trojans were threatening to drive the Greeks back into the sea.

In the nick of time, Achilles re-entered the fray. He donned his gleaming golden armour and rode out on to the battlefield, where his very presence was enough to raise the flagging spirits of the Greeks and strike terror into the hearts of the Trojans. He then proceeded to slaughter everybody in sight.

Labour MPs are banking on Gordon Brown doing for them what Achilles did for the Greeks. While the chancellor has been away from the battlefield preparing his budget, the government has been having a thoroughly rotten time of it, culminating in last week's decision by BMW to give up on Longbridge. There is a sullen mood out in the heartlands, while for the first time since their trouncing almost three years ago the Conservatives have rediscovered some of their old swagger.

Brown has not exactly been sulking in his tent, but his low profile since the turn of the year has meant that not only has he escaped any blame for the government's current woes but is seen as the only man who can turn the tide back in the government's favour. If the chancellor can put the Tories to flight tomorrow and garner the right sort of headlines in Wednesday's papers, Labour MPs will forget that Brown has been responsible for the government's perceived failures - the cash crisis in the NHS, for example - as well as its successes.

Hard cash

And, on the face of it, the chancellor has everything in his favour. The economy did better than expected last year, allowing the treasury to build up a hefty fiscal surplus. There is money in the bank - so much money that Brown is able to do what Nigel Lawson did in the late 80s - cut taxes, raise spending and pay off debt all at the same time. Given the current gloom and despondency in Labour's ranks, it would be the simplest thing in the world for the chancellor to hand out a few lollipops tomorrow, but the budget is likely to be a bit more complex than that.

Brown's first consideration is the need to dovetail fiscal policy with monetary policy. In theory, he could blow the entire surplus on tax cuts or higher spending, but the Bank of England would almost certainly respond by banging up interest rates to compensate for the boost to demand. At a time when there is justifiable concern about the strength of the pound, this would not be the wisest course of action and, in terms of macro-economic management, there is a case for even tougher fiscal policy so that monetary policy takes less of the strain in holding inflation to the government's 2.5% target.

However, tightening fiscal policy is tricky when the government is already running a whopping surplus, the voters are spitting blood about the state of schools and hospitals, and the Conservatives are banging on day after day about how the tax burden has increased under Labour.

So how does the treasury cope with this dilemma? The macro-economic assumption will be that the effects of higher interest rates and the strong pound will start to slow the economy down during the course of this year, making a modest relaxation of fiscal policy acceptable. However, this will probably be limited to the minimum necessary to prevent the tax burden from rising due to the effects of fiscal drag, whereby people pay more to the inland revenue as their incomes rise. In hard cash, this means that Brown would have to cut taxes by around £2bn to keep the tax burden where it is, £3bn to reduce it.

If anything, the willingness of Downing Street to admit for the first time last week that the tax burden has gone up under Labour suggests that it might be the higher of the two figures, and that the Conservatives are being lured on to a sucker punch.

Missing link

All the indications are that the beneficiaries of the chancellor's largesse will be those he considers the deserving rich and the deserving poor. The budget's theme is the need to raise Britain's economic performance to close the productivity gap with Germany, France and the United States, so there will be tax breaks on share options for the new breed of entrepreneurs starting up their own companies, together with tax credits for spending on research and development. At the other end of the scale, Brown is likely to increase the generosity of the working families tax credit and levy the 10p starting rate of tax on a higher slice of taxable income.

Some of the other likely measures have already been well trailed. There will be measures designed to bring a halt to the housing boom in the south, while the rise in global oil prices means that the policy of increasing petrol duties by well in excess of inflation has been junked.

But there is still something missing. Brown loves to plan for the long term, but as the prime minister has no doubt reminded his chancellor, the long term is a series of short terms. And in the short term, the government is in trouble and needs a political boost from the budget. So what is it to be? Another cut in the basic rate of income tax? A reduction in duties on booze and fags? Or something else?

Squaring circles

Let us look at it from the government's point of view. Despite all the recent fuss, there has been quite substantial redistribution over the past three years but in two key areas it is felt that Labour has not delivered. The first is the provision of public services - particularly health and education. The second is pensions.

On spending, Labour's parsimony in its first two years has now come back to haunt it. Budgets for health and education are now increasing by 5% in real terms, but it will take time to make good the effects of the earlier freeze, let alone deliver the improvements the electorate thought it was voting for in 1997. Up until now, the strategy has been to announce a new three-year spending deal in the summer, promising at least the same inflation-busting deal for health and education until well into the next parliament. That would allow Alan Milburn and David Blunkett to hand out all sorts of goodies during the autumn, softening up voters for an election next spring.

Brown may now be forced to rethink the timing of this approach. Assumptions have to be made in the budget about spending, and the chancellor could make a virtue of necessity by announcing that public spending can rise by at least as much in the second three-year spending round as it did in the first, with the government again focussing on its priorities of health and education. Specific commitments for individual departments look less likely at this stage because the treasury wants to ensure, particularly in health, that extra cash is accompanied by reform.

One group that has not featured in the pre-budget speculation has been pensioners, which is strange given that pensioners are well organised, vociferous and extremely unhappy with the government. Rather than restore the link between the universal state pension and earnings, Brown has plumped for a means-testing approach, arguing that he wants to focus support on the poorest pensioners.

Squaring this circle is not going to be easy. Unless the chancellor is prepared to abandon his whole approach to the welfare state, he is not going to announce a big increase in the state pension. But he is a strong believer in tax credits, and there is nothing to stop him extending the principle to pensioners, many of whom pay tax on savings. A properly tapered pensioners tax credit would allow those on modest income to escape tax altogether without applying to wealthy pensioners.

While this will not go far enough for pensioners groups, my guess is that the chancellor will once again be the darling of Labour MPs come tomorrow night. Whether the budget is a long-term solution to the government's travails remains to be seen. Achilles, it should be remembered, did not win the Trojan war, he merely saved the Greeks from defeat. In the end, he had a weak spot. So, too, does Mr Brown: the strength of the pound.

webTitle: We're not blind to the need to create some real value

fields.headline: We're not blind to the need to create some real value
fields.standfirst:
In their co-written diary our heroes examine business motives
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: We thought we had an idea for an internet business that could really fly - a service that enabled young people to shop independently and securely online without having to hassle parents for a credit card.
fields.body:
We thought we had an idea for an internet business that could really fly - a service that enabled young people to shop independently and securely online without having to hassle parents for a credit card.

We needed to create a business plan that would lay the appropriate foundations for a concrete business, not a castle made of sand that would be swept away by a rising competitive tide. Most research we were able to do quickly and easily online because of the vast amount of information available now on the net. The market was certainly big enough to be attractive - teenagers in Britain spend at least £3bn each year, mostly on fun stuff (music and videos rather than mortgages) which is ripe for online purchases. Teenagers we spoke to were also very enthusiastic about the service.

The US is often the lead for internet activity and the discovery that there were similar services operating there gave us heart, suggesting as it did that the core business model was sound. Although there appeared to be no direct competition in Europe, it would be dangerously naive to assume that others would not also be attracted to this valuable market.

Things do move incredibly fast and markets become crowded very quickly - a review of recent American company flotations revealed hundreds of copycat versions of well known brands such as Amazon andYahoo, all entering already highly competitive sectors with no discernable unique proposition or innovative technology.

We looked into the technology that would be required (it could be done but we would have to invest a lot in security processes and systems) and our legal position, where we took guidance from the financial services authority.

Despite the popular media perception (only slightly tongue-in-cheek) that internet businesses are valued more highly the greater the losses they make, it is vitally important for us to identify a realistic route to profitability. We believe that online businesses which aim to attract large numbers of customers but which have no clarity about how to make money are not going to survive in the medium to long term. (We were amazed to read only recently of an online business launched last year which was still looking at revenue streams to determine a potential profit.)

If our numbers are correct (and we ran through a number of extremely pessimistic scenarios) we would become profitable within a relatively short period of time, possibly even by year two.

Our initial investment in a week of heavy research and planning has paid dividends throughout the subsequent months. We had to build a company with a "unique proposition" - and a long term future. Our business has to "create value".

It also has to have the room to grow so geographic expansion (Europe and beyond) and alternative platforms (Wap, digital TV and the Next Big Thing) are core components of our plans.

However, we are acutely aware that our idea is worthless until we convert it effectively (and very quickly) into a real business. There is widely held view in the industry that there is no shortage of ideas but that it is the ability to execute that differentiates a successful business from those that fall away. After all, there is only so much planning you can do...

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools.com

webTitle: Whoever loses out, it won't be BMW

fields.headline: Whoever loses out, it won't be BMW
fields.standfirst: Boycott or no, the BMW brand will survive the Rover carve-up
fields.trailText: Like all patriot Brits I went to work armed today: with a knife, coins, and a sack of rocks. The first victim was the silver convertible 3 Series outside. The fact that this particular BMW belongs to my friend Andy and that I'm looking after it for him while he's away didn't spare it. Out came the knife - first the roof, then the tyres. Andy will understand, I'm doing it for the Midlands.
fields.body:
Like all patriot Brits I went to work armed today: with a knife, coins, and a sack of rocks. The first victim was the silver convertible 3 Series outside. The fact that this particular BMW belongs to my friend Andy and that I'm looking after it for him while he's away didn't spare it. Out came the knife - first the roof, then the tyres. Andy will understand, I'm doing it for the Midlands.

Then, on the way to the tube, any car sporting the famous blue and white logo got a coin scraped down the side and its aerial snapped off, and any moving Beemer purring past got a rock though the windscreen. "Lying bastards. This one's for Longbridge, and this one's for those 'English Patient' jibes."

Passing the BMW dealership, I spat and looked the other way, making a special point of not going in and buying a car. Hah! that'll teach you to mess with our workers...

OK, so I'm lying. I didn't smash up any cars, and I'm slightly ashamed to say that I'm not suggesting you should. Smashing up cars, while obviously enormously entertaining, doesn't help and won't affect BMW. But the bit about me not going into that showroom to buy a new 7 Series was true (although to be honest I wasn't really in the market for one). That's what the union leaders are calling for; a boycott. Even Jeremy Clarkson has decided against getting one of those tasty new Z8s, and has decided to go to work on a pogo stick instead.

But, apart from dear old Jeremy's generous gesture, will BMW's shocking behaviour really make any difference? Martin Ward at CAP, the car price specialists, thinks not.

"People who buy BMWs are not the sort of people who are interested in what's going on with Rover," he said. "If they were interested, they would have bought a Rover in the first place."

So who does buy BMWs? "People who want a bit of respect from neighbours and colleagues They're premium cars, sought after both new and used. In fact the brand might be stronger now it won't be linked to Rover."

That's the key word: brand. The strength of the brand, Ward thinks, will easily carry it through. Stephen Bayley, design guru and one-time dome consultant, thinks there could be repercussions for BMW, albeit short term. "For 40 years, BMW has made superb cars and stood for success; now they have a short-term image problem. Usually when this happens it's because of the product, but BMW has an excellent product; their tarnished reputation is in the moral and philosophical departments.

"I wouldn't want to be the person who walks into a wine bar with a set of keys to a brand new 3 Series. Especially if the wine bar was in Birmingham."

I think they're both right. People may not want to be flashing the keys to a new 3 Series around any wine bars for a while. But like Bayley says, the image problem is short term. When there are neighbours and colleagues to impress, people will soon forget about all those job losses. It won't be long before we barely recall the Rover incident - a small blip in the BMW brand's smooth cruise through time.

Except for the people who are losing their jobs who, I suspect, will never forget. I'm with Clarkson on this one; even if one day I can afford it, I won't be going anywhere near that showroom.

fields.headline: Cults
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about new religions on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about new religions on the net
fields.body:
1. Up to 470 men, women and children are feared dead in an apparent mass suicide in Kanugu, Uganda.

2. Devotees of the Church of the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God locked themselves in their church, doused themselves in petrol and then set themselves ablaze.

3. It is the second largest cult-inspired mass suicide of recent times.

4. In November 1978, 914 people died at Jim Jones' People's Temple in Jonestown, Guyana, after drinking a grape punch laced with cyanide. Those who refused to drink it were shot.

5. More recently, in March 1997, 39 members of the Higher Source cult committed suicide hoping to meet comet Hale-Bopp in the sky and rise to a new evolutionary level.

6. Their website, still around today, says: "By the time you receive this, we'll be gone."

7. At the time, the relatively novel internet was blamed for the suicide - detractors said that users were vulnerable loners who could be easily targeted by the charismatic cult leaders.

8. Cults are new religions that deviate from, or deny, orthodox teachings or practices. Their detractors say they are destructive groups hell-bent on mind control.

9. Modern cults do not have the monopoly on religious suicide: in 73AD around 1,000 Jewish zealots in the fortress of Masada chose death instead of submitting to Roman rule.

10. The millennium, and the years that preceded it, were expected to bring a rash of doomsday cults. The 90s saw Aum Shinrikyo kill 12 people with sarin gas on the Tokyo underground, repeated suicides of members of the Solar Temple and the infamous stand-off between the FBI and David Koresh's Branch Davidians at Waco, Texas.

fields.headline: I'm off
fields.standfirst: When new media boss, Martin Dunn, quit his job at Associated Newspapers last week it sparked another bout of industry navel-gazing.  Patrick Barkham  on the tension between old and new media
fields.trailText: The online media future tends to be talked of in terms of Wap, personal digital assistants and all those other bleeding-edge technologies charged with distributing old media content. Staffing this revolution is discussed less. Finding and keeping good journalists is an age-old problem, but in the world of new media it could prove a bigger headache than ever for bosses.
fields.body:
The online media future tends to be talked of in terms of Wap, personal digital assistants and all those other bleeding-edge technologies charged with distributing old media content. Staffing this revolution is discussed less. Finding and keeping good journalists is an age-old problem, but in the world of new media it could prove a bigger headache than ever for bosses.

At the top, as last week's departure of Associated Newspapers' new media editor-in-chief Martin Dunn shows, the online branches of traditional media companies often find their brightest brains poached by sleek new start-ups offering a level of personal autonomy or stock options that they cannot match.

With online news sites expected to increase their staff by 40% this year, according to Interactive Publishing Surveys, many new media bosses are also struggling to recruit middle-ranking staff who possess the requisite experience in traditional journalism with a smidgen of online acumen. And at the bottom, online operations have to pacify trained journalists who become disillusioned with the menial production tasks that can take up much of their day.

Losses at the top have been coming thick and fast. IPC Electric's acting MD and commercial director Julian Hardy left in November after only three months in the job. Two months later, new chief René Carayol also quit the company. Ellis Watson at the Sun's currantbun.com and Guardian Unlimited's Justin Walters both left their top jobs recently, the latter to pursue his own start-up project. After three-and-a-half years at Associated, Dunn has done the same.

He calls it a "half-departure". Associated is funding the initial costs of his start-up and has first refusal on its products in an arrangement that Dunn calls a "Hollywood producer model". It is an innovative option that he believes other traditional media companies may take up to keep new media talent on board. "A lot of the ideas you see for great opportunities on the internet are totally unrelated to the traditional media company's core business, so you need to make that autonomy [between new and old media] even greater," he says.

"It is difficult for traditional media companies at the moment because there are many start-ups ploughing into this market which offer seemingly lucrative share packages," Dunn says. "However, looking at the way some of the share prices have fallen recently, I wonder if that is going to continue. The stability that a traditional, solid media company can offer may become more attractive again."

But industry insiders speculate that the sometimes fraught relationship between new media spin-offs and the core business within a traditional media company often forces people out. "What often drives out heads of new media [in traditional media companies] is that they get insufficient support from the newspaper," says one. "Dunn's biggest gripe is that it took three years to put This Is London's URL on the cover of the Evening Standard."

The Financial Times has also been hit by defections to start-ups. The departure of Lex columnist Hugo Dixon and his colleague Jonathan Ford to Breakingviews.com, helped push Pearson to consider an options package for its web journalists to block the brain drain.

But FT.com's editor, Paul Maidment - one of the few at the top of traditional media's online offerings not to move on in the past year - is now finding it easier to attract credible candidates for middle-ranking positions, having recruited 100 editorial staff in the past 12 months. Boosted by Pearson's January share issue, which raised a further £250m for FT's internet projects, more recruitment is sure to follow.

"There was a concern before the last recruitment drive that we would not be able to find people with adequate experience and quality," says Maidment. "But that's not actually proved to be the case. We have got past the black-hole generation of people who didn't have enough experience editorially but had a little bit of web experience. We now have people with a fair chunk of both and we've deepened our gene pool as a news organisation as a result."

Keeping middle-ranking staff can also be difficult. Dunn says Associated was "remarkably resilient" in terms of staff stability. "But if you have long-serving staff, their skill set becomes enormously valuable so you become a prime target for any start-ups entering the UK market."

Traditional media reporters may enviously believe that new media journalists are constantly in demand and swimming in stock options. However, some online journalists are less than content, complaining that any chance to do "proper" journalism is squeezed out by understaffed operations simply charged with repackaging newspaper or broadcasting content for the internet.

"If we want to call ourselves real reporters we will only be considered so when we start breaking stories and coming up with original material," says one unhappy online hack, whose day is often spent wrestling with the labour-intensive production system used to publish internet content.

While most online journalists who work for established news organisations' online offshoots rarely leave their desks, Roisin Heycock, who moved from an FT.com production job to Complinet, an online news service for business subscribers, reports a happier experience. She uses the internet to find stories, but says she "still does what traditional journalists do, ringing round, going to conferences, and going to court".

Working in a dedicated online environment, she says she does not suffer from the inferiority complex that many online journalists in traditional news organisations report. Lowly status is the inevitable result of an unequal relationship between new internet divisions with young employees and established news operations, which see their online set-up simply as a way of publishing their content on a different platform.

"The only way organisations will have their online and print journalists considered the same in terms of status will be if they share common terms and conditions," says Maidment, whose latest recruitment round shunned short-term contracts and offered the FT's internet journalists "staff jobs which have the opportunity for long-term careers on the FT.

"We've created a completely integrated newsroom that works across print and online, so we don't have FT.com journalists and we don't have newspaper journalists. We just have FT journalists. We believe very strongly that what we produce every day is FT journalism," he says.

It is this integration of online and offline operations in traditional media companies that many bosses hope will solve some of the problems of staffing the new media revolution.

The first likely consequence of integration is that traditional journalists will become "online" journalists, honing their internet research skills. "I think all journalists need to develop online skills because that is where information now flows from," says one online financial journalist. "I don't think all will. Some will have to change and develop new skills, some will retire."

The second consequence of integration is that as the internet is colonised by print and broadcast journalists, some online journalists will be sidelined into the mouse-clicking monotony that is "producing" others' content for internet publication. And this could recreate many of the staffing problems that integration is supposed to solve.

As one online journalist says: "If you reduce the people who work on the web to mere robots and production machines I don't think they'd be happy or stay around for long. You have got to make sure your online journalists have something to write about."

fields.headline: Banks overcharging customers 'billions of pounds'
fields.standfirst:
Each house in Britain is paying up to £400 a year too much, report finds

The Cruickshank report
fields.trailText: Banks are charging personal customers and small businesses a total of between £3bn and £5bn a year too much for their services, an inquiry has found.
fields.body:
Banks are charging personal customers and small businesses a total of between £3bn and £5bn a year too much for their services, an inquiry has found.

The charges are the equivalent of each household in the country paying from £40 to £400 too much for banking services, the report says.

The inquiry team investigating the banking industry, headed by former telecommunications regulator Don Cruickshank, called for a radical shake-up of the sector.

Mr Cruickshank said of his report: "It says that if there was effective competition in banking, prices would be between £3bn and £5bn less than they are now And you would get better service.

"What I'm saying is government [should] act on one of the root causes, which is the way the payments system is run and managed by the banks.

"There are real problems with the way banks control the networks which allow money to flow around the economy, whether it be cheques, credit and debit cards or electronic transfers, big and small.

"Cash machines are just the tip of that iceberg."

The Cruickshank report recommends that the handling of small business accounts should be referred to the competition commission - "which should bring with it the threat of the break-up of the big four's business in that area".

The British bankers' association said it needed time to study the report, but a spokesman insisted banks were competitive.

"Nothing in this report shakes our belief that this is a highly competitive industry," he said.

"This is a very effective, important industry which is one of Britain's market leaders."

Key recommendations of the Cruickshank report


 A new payments regulator (PayCom) to supervise a licensing regime for banks' cash and payments networks - including cheque clearance and automatic cash machines


 Better information to help those currently excluded from banking services to find the best banking deal


 Measures to end banks' monopolies on services to small and medium-sized firms.


 Creating a basic bank account for the many people who do not have one


 Introducing better complaint-handling procedures for personal customers and small and medium-sized businesses


 Developing benchmarks for banking services to help consumers make informed choices.

Useful links

Competition commission

fields.headline: Orange Prize longlist announced
fields.trailText: The longlist for this year's Orange Prize for fiction, awarded to a novel by a woman writer, has been announced. High-profile choices include Booker unofficial runner-up Fasting, Feasting by Anita Desai and the pyrotechnic debut White Teeth by Zadie Smith
fields.body:
The longlist for this year's Orange Prize for fiction, awarded to a novel by a woman writer, has been announced. High-profile choices include Booker unofficial runner-up Fasting, Feasting by Anita Desai and the pyrotechnic debut White Teeth by Zadie Smith.

The judges will be Polly Toynbee, Claire Beaumont, Amanda Foreman, Bonnie Greer and Ffion Hague. The shortlist will be announced on 8 May 2000.

The £30,000 prize, inaugurated in 1996, was sparked off by the 1991 all-male Booker shortlist. Further research into literary prestige revealed that only 10 women had been awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in its 100-year history - and not one woman had ever been judged the author of a 'Thumping Good Read' by WH Smith.

In the past four years the Orange Prize has honoured Helen Dunmore for A Spell of Winter, Anne Michaels for Fugitive Pieces, Carol Shields for Larry's Party and Suzanne Berne for A Crime in the Neighbourhood.

The longlist in full:

The Translator by Leila Aboulela

If I Told You Once by Judy Budnitz

Girl With a Pearl Earring by Tracy Chevalier

Fasting, Feasting by Anita Desai

A Dangerous Vine by Barbara Ewing

fields.headline: Primary dolours
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The man in the grass hut on Bora Bora was boiling and it wasn't the heat. It was the message on the fax machine. John McCain was supposed to be resting from his valiant efforts to wring the Republican nomination from the party's crown prince, Texas governor George W Bush. The Bush campaign was supposed to be tip-toeing through the sand bearing hibiscus blossoms and soft words of reconciliation: John, our hearts really weren't in it, when we spent a few million on TV in the primaries to say that you're in favour of breast cancer and dirty air and virtually in the pocket of the Vatican. It was just politics, so let's make up.
fields.body:
The man in the grass hut on Bora Bora was boiling and it wasn't the heat. It was the message on the fax machine. John McCain was supposed to be resting from his valiant efforts to wring the Republican nomination from the party's crown prince, Texas governor George W Bush. The Bush campaign was supposed to be tip-toeing through the sand bearing hibiscus blossoms and soft words of reconciliation: John, our hearts really weren't in it, when we spent a few million on TV in the primaries to say that you're in favour of breast cancer and dirty air and virtually in the pocket of the Vatican. It was just politics, so let's make up.

McCain's aides, seething back at base, had expected to be reporting the bribes they were being offered to secure McCain's endorsement of Bush. The Democratic nominee, Al Gore, has wiped out the 20 point lead Bush had last autumn and where the McCain voters go will decide whether the Republicans can relive the glory of 1980 when Ronald Reagan recaptured the White House from the Democrats.

George W is no Ronald R. He wanders off script. The sting in the fax to the bush hut reported the content of an interview with the New York Times, in which Bush dismissed the idea that anything McCain had said might have made an impact on him. "No, he didn't change my views." All McCain did was "force me to play to my better strengths". As for the curious idea that he might offer concessions to McCain's favourite causes, Bush was downright patronising. "No, I think what I need to do is explain to John that we agree a lot more than we disagree..."

Explain again to John, while you're about it, Governor, why the huge surge in turnout in the Republican primaries had nothing to do with the enthusiasm McCain aroused. When that point was put to Bush by the Times reporters, he responded cockily, "Well, how come he didn't win?" None of this played big in Bora Bora. The official line is that Bush's feelings - not his words - have been misrepresented. Privately there is recrimination. The way one eminent Republican put it to me was: "What the hell were our guys doing leaving him alone with the Times for an hour - with the Times for Godssake!"

The trouble now for the Republican machine is that Bush's responses betray the reality of deep differences. The little outbreak of nomination hubris reminds everyone that the bigger picture is of a party with a split personality. The personal affront may be appeased with a little dextrous grovelling, proud and prickly though McCain is. Today he can carry his suntan into the Senate on the prostrate forms of Bush apologists. And a one-on-one meeting with Bush, coupled with the promise of the defense secretary's job, may yet produce the much desired photo-op of John and George displaying a comradely rictus. The bigger question is not so susceptible. It is how the Republican elephant can be put together again so that trunk and tail proceed in the same direction.

Millions of restive Republicans, and potential party members, have voted for McCain's vow to drive the money men from the temple. They have the fervour of Teddy Roosevelt's Bull Moosers, who broke from the Republican party in 1912 when Teddy failed to win the nomination from his "reactionary" protege William Howard Taft. Rather more millions of regular Republican voters have taken Bush's view that cash is a form of free speech, in particular that they must have the right to take as much of it as they can get from the lobbies to offset the Democratic contributions from the unions. And McCain's reformists recoil from the pressure of the Christian right on a range of social issues; the Bush people embrace the evangelicals. And the Bush Republicans promise $483bn of tax cuts over five years which the new Bull Moosers regard as reckless and a sop to the rich.

It is hard to see how the elephant can be put together again this year without resembling a mouse. If Bush were to compromise on his big tax cut, say, he would lose the central issue of his campaign which is to give the budget surplus "back to the people" and not spend it on programmes devised in Washington. If McCain accepts a fudge on any of the issues, he will lose Honest John's levitating halo of high principle. He has sworn he will not use his delegates to split the party at the convention.

The third clear option for McCain and his followers is to sit this one out, campaigning for their causes but not committing to Bush. If Bush wins in November, they become a footnote to history. But if he loses badly, the new Bull Moosers could be the foundation of a reconstructed party in 2004. It would be four years of torment for McCain. He would be accused of handing the election to Gore (for whom he has no time). Sort of what he endured while a prisoner of the North Vietnamese.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: The English Patient cast wait patiently for payment, Queen Amidala is not a draft-dodger, plus F Murray Abraham, Anna Paquin, the Rock and Spike Jonze on the casting couch
fields.body:
 The filmmakers and cast of 1997 Oscar winner The English Patient are yet to be paid, reveals the Hollywood Reporter. "Right after the Academy Awards, Harvey (Weinstein) gave a $5m advance (to be divvied up amongst everyone), but no one's gotten a nickel since," said one source involved. Producer Saul Zaentz confirmed to the paper that the creative team, who deferred payment to get the picture made, are still waiting for an audit, set in motion last June, to end. Said one source: "There is this ongoing audit that never ends. They are very slow in producing documents. Meanwhile, we keep getting statements from (Miramax) showing us that the movie is in the red. It just doesn't make any sense."

 Queen Amidala is not a draft dodger. Representatives for Natalie Portman have denied reports that the Star Wars actress "passed on" a call-up to national service the Israeli army sent to her last year. "They made up the quotes", Portman's publicist Kelly Bush tells the New York Post. "She was never notified by the army for service". According to Bush, in fact, Portman is "exempt" from the army: Israelis do not have to serve in the army if, like Portman, they leave the country before the age of 16.

 Oscar winners F. Murray Abraham and Anna Paquin have joined Sean Connery in the cast of Gus Van Sant's Finding Forrester. The film centres on a young black athlete struggling to fit in at his all-white prep school, and befriended by a reclusive novelist. Connery plays the novelist, Abraham a professor, and Paquin the athlete's girlfriend.

 Dwayne Johnson, otherwise known as the Rock - one of the World Wrestling Federation's biggest stars - is joining the cast of the sequel to last year's hit The Mummy. Johnson is in final negotiations to play "the ruler of all evil who is brought forth from the undead", according to the trade press. Brendan Fraser, Rachel Weisz and John Hannah will reprise their roles from the first movie.

 Being John Malkovich director Spike Jonze is rumoured to have approached George Lucas about directing the next instalment of Star Wars. Spurning the maverick director's offer, Lucas is reported to have offered Jonze a role as an Imperial Storm Trooper in the prequel's sequel. His wife, Sofia Coppola, played a handmaiden to Queen Amidala in The Phantom Menace.

fields.headline: Where now for the Windies?
fields.standfirst: Softly spoken Jimmy Adams was about to be named West Indies captain. Tanya Aldred managed to catch up with him at his mother's house on March 2 for a little chat
fields.trailText: How long have you been captain of Jamaica?
fields.body:
How long have you been captain of Jamaica?

This is my second full season.

Do you think you are a good captain?

That's a difficult question. I think if I'm truthful, once you've been playing for a fairly long time people seem to think that you are qualified to be captain. It's not something I've given much thought to.

Are you happy with your form at the moment?

Over the last two games I have felt pretty good, and I hope it continues to get much better as the season goes on.

What is the answer to rejuvenating West Indies cricket?

I don't know if there is one answer. There are quite a few areas that need looking at, but I'm confident it is something the team will get right.

Were you surprised by Brian Lara's decision to step down?

Yes, he hadn't hinted at it at all.

How well do you know Roger Harper [37-year-old former West Indies offspinner, controversially preferred to Vic Richards as the team's new coach]?

I've played with him and against him for a few years and have worked with him as a coach. I think he is well qualified and will do a good job. He is young but I don't think it is a problem: we have quite a few young coaches over here.

Who is the best captain you have ever played under?

That is reserved for a gentleman called Marlon Tucker who captained Jamaica [from 1988 to '90]. Marlon was never going to be a Test player but he made all of us - and we were a mixed team - believe that we could walk on water.

Who are the most promising young players coming through?

There is a young fast bowler called Reon King who is on the doorstep of really great things. There is also a young left-handed batsman, Christopher Gayle of Jamaica. I believe that if we play as well as we can play, we can beat anyone. The bottom line is we have to play good cricket.

webTitle: Roberts' out front at US box office

fields.headline: Roberts' out front at US box office
fields.trailText: Julia Roberts' latest picture, the Steven Soderbergh-directed legal drama Erin Brockovich, topped the US box office this weekend with a take of $28.2m - making it the years second biggest opening so far
fields.body:
Julia Roberts' latest picture, the Steven Soderbergh-directed legal drama Erin Brockovich, topped the US box office this weekend with a take of $28.2m - making it the years second biggest opening so far.

But American media attention has focused less on the film's assets than on those of its suddenly inflated star. In Roberts' own much-quoted words: "I'd gone 30 years without cleavage and suddenly, pow!"

"She deserves a new Oscar category: best-supported actress", contends one critic of the toothy star's "cantilevered cleavage". According to the Chicago Sun-Times, "The serious buzz about Erin Brockovich is about the serious cleavage suddenly sported by Julia Roberts". Pouncing on the publicity coup, Soderbergh defended his movie's upholstery. "When Erin saw the movie", comments the director of the film's crusading real-life heroine, "she said, 'The only thing that was inaccurate is that the skirts weren't short enough'".

 Erin Brockovich, headline-grabbing bust and all, is released in the UK on April 7.

webTitle: A city too rude for the web

fields.headline: A city too rude for the web
fields.standfirst: Edward Helmore on why the residents of Los Angeles lost their newspaper chat rooms.
fields.trailText: Last week, just two days before it was acquired by the parent company of the Chicago Tribune, the Los Angeles Times abruptly closed the message boards and discussion groups on its internet site. The paper found that the guidelines users agreed to follow when they registered for the service were being broken by widespread use of swearing and threats, statements designed to injure or defame, and postings that amounted to trading of services.
fields.body:
Last week, just two days before it was acquired by the parent company of the Chicago Tribune, the Los Angeles Times abruptly closed the message boards and discussion groups on its internet site. The paper found that the guidelines users agreed to follow when they registered for the service were being broken by widespread use of swearing and threats, statements designed to injure or defame, and postings that amounted to trading of services.

Many newspapers consider their chat rooms to be a principal element of their internet presence. When it chose to close them down, the Times warned users they could be held legally responsible for any libellous remarks and reminded participants that discussion boards are intended to encourage healthy public debate and to act as a virtual town square.

"The abuse of the discussion boards doesn't place the paper in legal jeopardy but does jeopardise our relationship with our users," explains Mike Lang, a spokesman for the paper. "In the same way, some papers might run adult entertainment ads and the LA Times doesn't."

While revealing the often undig nified nature of public exchange online, the decision to shut down the discussions groups also highlights the different ways in which news organisations are forming new bonds with their readers.

When they were first established, chat rooms were considered a step forward in allowing the readership to participate rather than simply being passive recipients of information. The underlying thinking has not changed, but larger US newspapers, including the New York Times and Washington Post, have moved away from the free-for-all that caused the LA Times problems. Instead, they exercise editorial control over their sites by offering discussion groups moderated by an editor, columnist or reporter.

"Newspapers are looking to develop more items and services that involve the reader, but they may not be chat rooms," says Ross Settles of Times Mirror Interactive, the parent of the LA Times online operation.

But as chat rooms lose favour among online newspaper strategists, efforts to turn their sites into hubs for information have continued undiminished. Both the Washington Post - currently the newspaper site with the greatest traffic - and the New York Times are aggressively trying to turn themselves into providers of information and consumer services.

The theory is this: if you offer enough services in a single place, your online audience will grow. The New York Times, with 10m registered users, has consolidated more than 50 online holdings into Times Company Digital, including the paper itself, Boston.com, WineToday.com and a local information service called New York Today.

In January, the division launched Abuzz, a free service that provides space where users can ask questions on a topic and be routed to other knowledgeable users for an answer. Drawing on the intellectual capital of the New York Times, its architects hope to establish "new social networks" that will "humanise" the internet and revolutionise how web users find information.

"It's a whole new animal," says Jed Miller, interactive editor of the New York Times on the web. "Rather than firing a note off into the dark and hoping someone will comment, you're submitting your thoughts to a system that looks for the best people to respond to you."

Links to Abuzz are posted within Times articles to encourage feedback and discussion on current events and themes. "Rather than just throwing a bunch of people in a room and saying talk amongst yourselves, what a good online community does is offer a context, and the content of the Times is an amazing context for discussion," says Miller. The overarching purpose of the system is to return users to the sense of community for which the internet was celebrated before the arrival of the wider public and business interests.

The Washington Post, in addition to moderated discussions, now offers a range of services from local news and guides to job searches, shopping, property, education, auctions, entertainment and health. But these online ventures are haemorrhaging money. Last year, the Post spent $85m (£53m) on its internet arm, yet revenues were just $17m (£11m).

But the primary purpose of newspaper sites, says Settles, must be to deliver news. "While there are other features and functions such as shopping, classifieds and auctions, it leads with news and sports. Consumers don't expect to go to a newspaper site for all things but they'd like it to be more personalisable, more interactive and more current."

Efforts to convert newspaper companies into deliverers of information electronically was given a big jolt by last week's $5.9bn (£3.7bn) sale of Times Mirror to Tribune Co. The Chicago-based buyer has an established online presence that includes 60 sites, including those of the Chicago Tribune and the Orlando Sentinel, as well as television and radio holdings. Tribune Co has already installed television, internet and radio outlets in its newspaper newsrooms and requires its journalists to work across all media.

The purpose is to create a new type of media and entertainment conglomerate that can get stories and services out in every medium and to as many people as possible. And, of course, there is the hope of increasing revenue by offering "cross-media packages" to advertisers.

But as the future of newspapers takes shape, unregulated chat rooms and message boards, once heralded as a way to get readers involved and keep them brand-loyal, are fading into internet history.

"The community will behave as purposefully and intelligently as you invite it to," says Miller. "But you do want to keep some editorial awareness of what appears on your sites and to keep ahead of the people who want to create trouble."

fields.standfirst: All today's paper talk, in handy digest form
fields.trailText: Optasoccer Wimbledon striker Carl Cort has upped the ante before this week's transfer deadline and declared his desire to play for Leeds. Cort, who was the subject of a bid from the Yorkshire club only a fortnight ago, revealed, "Leeds are an exciting young team making moves in the Premiership and in Europe. I've not thought about a move, but any young player in their career would love to move to a club like Leeds."
fields.body:
Optasoccer Wimbledon striker Carl Cort has upped the ante before this week's transfer deadline and declared his desire to play for Leeds. Cort, who was the subject of a bid from the Yorkshire club only a fortnight ago, revealed, "Leeds are an exciting young team making moves in the Premiership and in Europe. I've not thought about a move, but any young player in their career would love to move to a club like Leeds."

Newcastle and Manchester United are preparing to make a move for Atletico Bilbao midfielder Txomin Nagore. Currently on loan at Numancia, Nagore has had a great season but may be hard to tempt away from the Basque club on a permanent basis.

The Express Spurs boss George Graham remains confident that skipper Sol Campbell will still be at White Hart Lane next season, despite being a target for Manchester United and Arsenal. "I am hopeful he will be a Spurs player for the next couple of seasons," said Graham. Graham also confided that Darren Anderton is expected to sign a new contract with the club soon.

Teamtalk Spurs are ready to sell Chris Armstrong and have put a £6m price on the striker's head. Graham wants to bring three new strikers to the club this summer and will have to find money to fund new purchases. "I want up to five new players, with three of them being strikers", said Graham. "If you bring in new people, you must make room for them. There will clearly be a few players leaving."

webTitle: Lucasfilm closes the net around angry fans

fields.headline: Lucasfilm closes the net around angry fans
fields.trailText: A row has broken out over Lucasfilm's efforts to commandeer the sprawling world of Star Wars fansites
fields.body:
A row has broken out over Lucasfilm's efforts to commandeer the sprawling world of Star Wars fansites. A new feature on the sci-fi saga's official site, starwars.com, which allows users to construct their own fansites, has been condemned by fans for insisting that all images and storylines created using the facility are the sole property of the film's producers.

"This action by Lucasfilm does not connote respect", argues www.miscellanies.net, a site set up to oppose Lucasfilm's action, "because it empowers Lucasfilm to more effectively regulate what fans can and cannot do, particularly if they have their sites on 'fan.starwars.com'".

The issue embroils Star Wars in a sticky debate over intellectual property limits on the web, a grey area unlikely to be clarified by Lucafilm spokeswoman Lynn Hale's pronouncements on the subject. "We want fans to be able to use all of our images", Hale said. "But if they do a drawing of what (they think) Boba Fett is going to look like, and there's any similarity, we need to be guaranteed that we own the copyright, because they're all derivative of our original design". Campaigning fans have since rebutted Hale's argument; and the world waits for George Lucas's empire to strike back.

fields.headline: Missing Oscars found in bin
fields.trailText: Satisfying tidings for all those who believe the Oscars to be rubbish: the missing statuettes have shown up in a trash can
fields.body:
Satisfying tidings for all those who believe the Oscars to be rubbish: the missing statuettes have shown up in a trash can.

Fifty-five of the golden fellas disappeared last week from a loading bay in Los Angeles and had been presumed stolen. It remains unclear how many statuettes have now been recovered. In reports on American television, Willie Fullgear said he found the Oscar statues on Sunday evening, still wrapped in plastic and in individual white boxes. He filled the trunk of his car with the boxes and alerted the media and the police. "I found a lot of white stuff out there which were a lot of Styrofoam boxes and I picked one up and busted it open " Fullgear told CBS TV. When invited to consider his likely $50,000 reward for recovering the statuettes, Fullgear commented: "I'm gonna buy a house. I'm gonna get out of one room and buy a house".

Last week's embarrassing loss came after the Academy had earlier misplaced 4,000 Oscar ballot papers. The ballots were eventually found, but not before new ones were printed and the voting deadline extended by two days.

 The Oscars take place on March 26
