fields.headline: The agonies of Doctor Love
fields.standfirst: Alain de Botton propelled a book about Proust to the top of the US bestseller list, he boasts a devoted throng of thoughtful women but he is very nervous about the future
fields.trailText: Alain de Botton propelled a book about Proust to the top of the US bestseller list, he boasts a devoted throng of thoughtful women but he is very nervous about the future.
fields.body:
Alain de Botton, the 30-year-old literary philosopher, the man with all the answers, has an old head on his young shoulders, a head from which even a central strip of hair has been expelled as if its growth was a distraction to thought. His angular face, the bones like tent poles beneath his skin, is earnest, his light grey eyes intense. We meet to discuss his latest book (and television series), The Consolations of Philosophy. His last book was about Proust. This one is about Seneca and Schopenhauer, Socrates and Nietzsche, Epicurus and Montaigne.

He is sitting across the table from me in a central London cafe. He is sipping hot chocolate. He is saying: "You know it was that kind of transition thing. I was 23 when I met her and then suddenly you're 27... and there's that terrible thing when you're 23 that no one tells you that a woman you're going to be with is going to be thinking very seriously about marriage, so you'd better watch out. So when you do realise, you walk. I mean, she was right, but not right forever. So then I was single for a while." He's talking faster and faster, pausing only for his tongue to dab at the stray globs of foam which keep adhering to his upper lip.

"I couldn't even manage meaningless affairs, they were too meaningful. There's no such thing really as casual sex. It's always heavy and complicated. And then we were filming this series and we were looking for someone to illustrate the ideas of Schopenhauer, we needed someone with a broken heart and we were desperate" - dab at glob - "and I was talking to my editor at Penguin and I said, 'It's a real crisis, we can't find anyone,' and he said, 'Well actually there is someone here, in another department, recently dumped by her boyfriend.' So then that afternoon, there she was, her heart freshly broken and it's terrible for her and I was interviewing her and I thought, 'This is nice.' She was looking melancholic which is always very attractive - the unhappiness of women: exciting. So then at the end of the interview I said, 'Do you want to come out to dinner?' and we started going out. And that was last summer."

He breaks off. His large lips break into a broad smile. She is very sporty, he tells me. She wears a Baby-G watch. She goes rollerblading, "which makes me feel threatened". But he looks very happy about it.

De Botton, or Dr Love as he's known to the throngs of thoughtful girls with waistlength hair who attend his bookshop readings (and who may be disappointed to hear of the latest moves in his romantic life), doesn't hold with the separation of grand ideas and small everyday concerns. The three novels he wrote in his precocious mid-20s were as much about relativism, naturalism, pessimism as about the dating game.

How Proust Can Change Your Life, which jostled in the US bestseller lists alongside the Chicken Soup self-help manuals, sought out advice for unhappy lovers along with the hints for catching up on lost time. And The Consolations of Philosophy applies ancient ideas to, among things, not having enough money, not doing as well as you think you ought to be, and not getting it up.

"Most modern philosophy is about mathematics, moving very carefully through an argument," says de Botton, frowning. "The guys I've chosen are interested in wisdom, in how you live your life."

The book contains some personal details, the unsatisfied desire for a house in Kensington's Campden Hill Road (see Happiness: An Acquisition List), an incident of impotence on holiday in Portugal with a girl called L ("Oh L?" he says. "L is a long time ago. L is in fact A, for what it's worth"). But for the most part, you can't help wondering how much consolation de Botton can need himself. He comes from a wealthy family. Swiss upbringing, houses in Chelsea, father in banking, mother in Washington. His stepmother is the art collector and benefactress Janet de Botton. Usually voluble, he talks about his provenance in staccato bites ("Weird background. Strange name. Outsider/insider all that. Stepmother, yup, fantastically rich").

He went to Harrow, where he was miserable and didn't meet any girls ("If you're a certain kind of boy you don't fare well in adolescence"), and Cambridge, where he wasn't and did. Then he began a PhD in French 17th-century philosophy, and wrote Essays in Love, his first novel. It earned him £50,000 for the German rights alone, so he never had to get a proper job.

The Proust book was a bit of a wobble - his publisher was uneasy about it from the beginning - but then, boom, John Updike gave it a rave in the New Yorker and sales rocketed. Bestseller city. He's just bought his first home, a house in Hammersmith. Alone for now, but things are "on the horizon". Money, property, success, and now love. Quite consoling, all in all?

"No, no," he says. "Anxiety, God. I have anxiety about the future. Always the panic. Am I going to write again? It's horrible. I see my talent as a flickering flame that's always in danger of going out forever. We're nervous Jews, my whole family. We're jittery. We're all -" He waggles his shoulders and shakes his hands in the air. "Completely hysterical. A door slams and -" He mimes freezing in terror.

"We all think everything's going to go wrong. From the age of one, my father always thought he was going to go bankrupt - his parents had gone bankrupt several times - so he has that immigrant destitute mentality which is: 'This is not going to last', and I think you pass it on to your children. My father, who was born in Egypt, was always like: 'You're an outsider, you may be put in a ghetto at any time and be killed.' It was always: 'Don't take anything for granted.' Also," he adds, "very demanding parents. Coming back from school. Ten A grades. 'Why not 15?' Always disapproving."

The disapproval gene has not been entirely passed over. De Botton may chat happily, like a close girlfriend, about the problems of moving to the country ("What happens if someone says, 'Come to lunch', and I'm three hours away by train?"), of the urge for the mini-break ("Stage one is: 'We're so in love we're not going out"; and then stage two is: "Let's try and take our love to Brussels"). But there are moments of icy superiority.

Of John Updike's career-making review, he says: "I don't know John Updike. I don't even like John Updike." Of the television series to accompany his book (called Philosophy: A Guide to Happiness), he says disloyally, "It's quite a crappy programme. It's divided into half hours and it's dumbed down."

He spends his money on books, he says. "But weird things, psychology. Not novels. Most novels just tell you a story and then they stop. I get bored of stories." He likes art, but not his stepmother's sort of art: "She likes canvasses with 'Fuck' written all over them. I don't. I like small pictures of a jug and an apple and some sunlight coming in."

He hates noise. On this, he is more Schopenhauer (only brutes don't notice noise) than Seneca (rise above it). He wrote his last book in "a family house" in Chelsea and "the whole street was being redone, every house, monstrous noise, banging from morning to night, drilling the road . . . And I've got this noisy neighbour. It can drive you to crime it really can. He says he hopes that "in my advancing years I'll get more relaxed about things and take a more fatalistic attitude and not care so much". I think Nietzsche's brilliant, but one wouldn't want to be him. Must have been a nightmare. My mother thinks I'm like Schopenhauer because he had a dreadful relationship with his mother. He laughs cheerily. Even yours? I venture. "I think it's very very tricky to get right," he says. "Like finding a house. webTitle: EM.TV to buy big formula one stake

fields.headline: EM.TV to buy big formula one stake
fields.trailText: German TV and marketing group EM.TV is understood to be ready to pay £1.3bn for a 50% stake in Bernie Ecclestone's formula one grand prix empire, which began its new season with a win for Michael Schumacher last week.
fields.body:
German TV and marketing group EM.TV is understood to be ready to pay £1.3bn for a 50% stake in Bernie Ecclestone's formula one grand prix empire, which began its new season with a win for Michael Schumacher last week.

The deal would mean Mr Ecclestone sharing control of the sport. And it would hand two private equity companies a 100% profit.

EM.TV grabbed the headlines last month when it paid £425m for the Jim Henson Company. Now it is said to be ready to pay £1.3bn for the 37.5% of F1 owned by US group Hellman and Friedman and the 12.5% owned by Britain's Morgan Grenfell Private Equity.

The American financiers bought their F1 stake from Mr Ecclestone a month ago and if the deal goes through would bank almost £500m profit. Morgan Grenfell bought its 12.5% last autumn for £245m.

EM.TV is a private family company which specialises in family viewing and is particularly strong in merchandising its products. It is thought that F1 could make much more from its name and image.

Mr Ecclestone, 69, and his wife Slavica, whose wealth was estimated at £2bn by the annual Sunday Times Rich List over the weekend, has long been trying to extract some of the wealth built up in his glamourous empire and the EM.TV deal would value his business at £2.6bn.

Two years ago he attempted to float the business on the stock exchange, but an EU competition investigation into F1 meant that had to be abandoned.

Mr Ecclestone has been incensed by the EU inquiry and has threatened to take grand prix away from Europe if the commission forces him to make changes to the way he runs the business, but he has recently voluntarily changed some of the broadcasting contracts which were the main cause for concern and now expects the empire to be given a green light.

Earlier this month reports in the German press suggested that a stock market float on Germany's Neuer Markt was under discussion.

fields.headline: Funny place for a landmark...
fields.standfirst: Salford's gleaming new £70m Lowry Centre is a bold piece of architecture - but the setting could hardly be worse, says  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: Salford's gleaming new £70m Lowry Centre is a bold piece of architecture - but the setting could hardly be worse, says Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
There is something unsettling about the route that links Manchester and its siamese twin Salford. The two cities are connected to each other and the much-hyped new Lowry Centre by smooth, reliable and fast trams - as good as you'll find in most major European cities - and an all but disused canal that connects the landlocked pair to Liverpool and thus the oceans of the world.

Follow the towpath and you'll be gobsmacked by the sheer banality of the mismatching rows of vaguely postmodern offices and apartment blocks that have been rushed up here over the past decade in the name of urban regeneration. They barely deserve to be called "architecture".

Take a tram from central Manchester, in front of the sadly neglected Piccadilly Hotel, and soak up the terracotta, marble and harsh brick braggadocio of the Victorian city. The tram gathers speed down wide boulevards, roars over a former Midland Railway bridge and begins its rollercoaster journey along the canal. Now look out of the window. What do you see? Gimcrack office blocks and housing that makes the meretricious architecture of London's docklands seem the stuff of Italian renaissance cities. These cynical new buildings (buy one, someone said to me, and you get two free), continue to the point where Manchester becomes Salford and the canal opens up.

Here, a giant new shopping complex, a grim new multi-storey car park (nearly complete) and a bridge to bring the tram from Piccadilly will eventually rub shoulders with the Lowry Centre, which opens next month. This massive arts complex is at the heart of a dream to bring a cultural renaissance and new prosperity to Manchester and Salford.

Photographs of the £70m Lowry Centre, a multi-purpose "landmark" cultural venue and one of the many architectural projects supported by the Millennium Commission and National Lottery money, are taken almost exclusively from a viewpoint denied to visitors arriving by tram or car from central Manchester. From this perspective it recalls Frank Gehry's Guggenheim museum in Bilbao, but surrounded by a plethora of other, lesser buildings. Most visitors, meanwhile, first see it through the concrete grid of the new 670-space multi-storey car park. Subtle.

The Lowry Centre is just one link in a chain of arts and sports buildings that, in theory, should make Salford an unmissable leisure destination. There's Old Trafford, Man United's lucrative ground, the northern outpost of the Imperial War Museum - an explosion of a building by Daniel Libeskind - and other potential crowd-pleasers. Will they draw the millions of visitors they are expected to? Can their lively architecture make up for the sorry stuff that lines the old canal? Maybe. Certainly the Libeskind building will be a draw in its own right. As with the same architect's Jewish Museum in Berlin, many people will want to see this megablast of a building for its own sake.

And the Lowry? Maybe. But, just as the regeneration of canalside Manchester is confusing, so is this cultural castle. What looks like a book of architectural quotations drawn up on a heroic scale by Michael Wilford and Partners is, between its stainless steel covers, an exhausting read. Gehry's Guggenheim it ain't. There are two theatres, a round tower and long gallery for artworks (including LS Lowry's depressing paintings of depressed matchbox people), a labyrinth of display areas, an "inter active" children's gallery, rooms with the best views set aside for private functions just like a billion-pound football club, and what feels to be miles of ramps, stairs and corridors, some set under wave-like ceilings weaving around the stainless steel-clad structure and holding the whole caboodle together.

This is an exhausting building to look at - too many notes, as Emperor Joseph II says to the prodigious Mozart in Amadeus - and no less tiring inside. So much packed in. So much to do. So many choices. Buildings within buildings like a Russian doll. Garish colours. No punctuation. No space to pause and rest. An architectural rattle box designed as if this was the architect's one big moment and he was going to stir every idea into the mix in case the next major commission was a long time coming. Still, if the shows in the theatres are good and the art exhibitions well done - which they should be - this monument to England's curious obsession with the millennium may meet with the success that its bravura, flag-waving architecture works so hard to signal.

But there are two questions that no one - least of all architects - wants or dares to ask. First, how far can art and culture regenerate an out-of-town area, especially if has been blighted by unattractive new development over the past few years? Second, should we have abandoned multi-purpose civic buildings of this scale - brainchildren of the 60s and 70s - some while back?

It's a tricky one, the arts and culture bit. Central Manchester is far more lively today than it was 15 or 20 years ago, but still needs major investment to pull it together as the grand European city it wants to be. Its hotels, museums and art galleries all need a shot in the arm. Its many empty and boarded-up buildings - many of them impressive structures - need new uses and imaginative refurbishment. There are far too many holes in the city, like the missing bits of a jigsaw puzzle.

It seems a shame that the centre of the city is so flawed, despite the bold efforts that have been made to repair it since the IRA ripped a part of its heart out. Investment along the canal might have been better delayed until the centre was sorted out and a proper plan put in hand for the long stretches of urban wasteland between here and Salford. An arts renaissance might have been best concentrated in the city centre, helping to give Manchester the cultural concentration and creative energy that make a city premier league rather than first division. This is where Milan wins over Manchester, Barcelona over Birmingham. Sort out the centre first. Work your way out into the edges with a plan in mind and not on a developer's wing and a millennial prayer.

The second question is about planning. Perhaps what Salford needs is not a multi-storey car park with a multiplex arts centre attached, but a new city square reached by the tram from Piccadilly, with a stunning new theatre, museum, art gallery, cinema, restaurant, cafes set around it. Market stalls on weekends. Live music. A real place that everyone might enjoy even if they don't go to concerts or plays. Urban regeneration does not come about by car parks, tramless spaces and multi-purpose arts complexes. It needs more subtle planning than this, particularly in such a wind-swept spot: planning that allows natural growth. Every day.

webTitle: Adams does a Brearley as Zims do a Greg Norman

fields.headline: Adams does a Brearley as Zims do a Greg Norman
fields.trailText: Everybody was expecting a famous victory in Port-of-Spain today. Nobody could possibly have guessed that it would be a West Indian one. Somehow, out of the jaws of humiliation, Curtly and Co grabbed a win that, in the end, was almost comfortable.
fields.body:
Everybody was expecting a famous victory in Port-of-Spain today. Nobody could possibly have guessed that it would be a West Indian one. Somehow, out of the jaws of humiliation, Curtly and Co grabbed a win that, in the end, was almost comfortable.

The poor Zimbabweans suffered a collapse that was beyond even England's wildest nightmares. Other Test teams, notably England at the same ground only six years ago, have been all out for less than 63. But the whole 20th century went by without a Test team falling short of a two-figure target. I had to Ask Steven when it last happened: he reckoned it was in 1882, at The Oval, when Australia set a target of 85, England were all out for 77, and the home supporters were so traumatised that a bunch of them got together to place a mock-obituary saying "In affectionate remembrance of English cricket, which died at The Oval É"

The rest, of course, is history. And so is this. West Indies' obituary can now be put on hold - or rather hastily pulled from tomorrow's first editions. Their home record, which has remained excellent while their away form has gone to pieces, is not to be besmirched with a series defeat by the team ranked bottom in the Wisden World Championship. And Zimbabwe have not won their first Test in the Caribbean. More than that, they join the list of great sporting chokes, somewhere between Greg Norman and Bayern Munich. You have to feel for Andy Flower, who is lumbered with the triple burden that did for Alec Stewart - captain, wicketkeeper, and key batsman. In this match, helped by a poor umpiring decision and a few dropped catches, he was the only man to pass 50, and went on to a hundred.

The only consolation for him is that South Africa did something similar in their only Test in the West Indies, in 1991-92. So did India four years ago (all out for 81), and so have England, at regular intervals. The Caribbean is still, after all these years of decline, a very hard place to win a Test match, and harder still if you are batting last, because the pitches are so uneven. Andy Flower's good fortune was cancelled out today by the fate of his brother Grant. He was the one man who could have won it, the only one, in 60-something overs, who managed a boundary. And he got a shocker of a shooter. For Port-of-Spain, read sport of pain.

For Jimmy Adams, it was an astonishing start to his career as West Indies captain. Even Mike Brearley didn't conjure victories like this until his second stint in charge of England. Adams has embarked on probably the most difficult job in cricket at the trickiest time imaginable, and in the wrong place - Trinidad, where Brian Lara is king and no other current player is good enough to make the Test team. Adams is one of the brightest, most level-headed men in the game. Today, he needed to be.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly. Click here to read our pre-Test chat with Jimmy Adams.

In this match, helped by a poor umpiring decision and a few dropped catches, he was the only man to pass 50, and went on to a hundred. The only consolation for him is that South Africa did something similar in their only Test in the West Indies, in 1991-92. So did India four years ago (all out for 81), and so have England, at regular intervals. The Caribbean is still, after all these years of decline, a very hard place to win a Test match, and harder still if you are batting last, because the pitches are so uneven. Andy Flower's good fortune was cancelled out today by the fate of his brother Grant. He was the one man who could have won it, the only one, in 60-something overs, who managed a boundary. And he got a shocker of a shooter. For Port-of-Spain, read sport of pain. For Jimmy Adams, it was an astonishing start to his career as West Indies captain. Even Mike Brearley didn't conjure victories like this until his second stint in charge of England. Adams has embarked on probably the most difficult job in cricket at the trickiest time imaginable, and in the wrong place - Trinidad, where Brian Lara is king and no other current player is good enough to make the Test team. Adams is one of the brightest, most level-headed men in the game. Today, he needed to be. Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly. fields.headline: Gordon the seducer
fields.standfirst:
Brown's subtle mastery of the media shows great political skill. He gets all the praise and none of the blame

Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Brown's subtle mastery of the media shows great political skill. He gets all the praise and none of the blame.
fields.body:
As Gordon Brown dangles his red box in front of the photographers tomorrow, he can be confident that its contents will reap accolades on all sides. This paper will probably heap praise on him for his brave commitment to protecting the most vulnerable (children and the elderly); rightwing tabloids will laud his plans to crack down on a "hard core" of benefit scroungers while financial commentators will praise his fiscal prudence, his plans to taper capital gains tax and his self-proclaimed "mission" to make Britain the most competitive business environment anywhere in the world. He will pull off that difficult political trick at which he is adept - being all things to (almost) all men.

Meanwhile, the machinations to salvage something from the Rover meltdown will continue, but it will be Stephen Byers and Tony Blair who have to carry that can. Brown may be responsible for running the economy but he has, so far, brilliantly managed to dodge BMW's repeated assertions that Rover is paying the price for high sterling. Brown is not getting slammed for the severe beating the manufacturing sector has suffered under his aegis, of which Rover and Harland & Wolff are only the most high-profile cases.

It is a measure of how much we have all imbibed Baroness Thatcher's adage ("you can't buck the market"), that few are questioning the role of Brown's prudence and gung-ho espousal of the competitive global market in the destruction of communities in the West Midlands and Northern Ireland. However, knowing Brown, he will get plenty of credit for the generous regeneration grants and ingenious welfare to work policies will soon be unveiled to revive them.

Much is made of Brown's mastery of this government, but what about his mastery of the media? He has most newspapers eating out of his hand. Looking back at the coverage of Brown since the election, a pattern emerges; prior to any of his major statements, there is a run-up period in which exclusives (usually so accurate, they cannot but be leaks) are carefully placed in whichever newspaper they are likely to garner the most sympathy. While most of his cabinet colleagues have had their share of controversy to battle through, Brown has sailed on without a significant challenge. When the mud is flying, he knows to duck, and the person who usually catches it as a result is his old mate, Tony Blair. It has been Blair who has had to field the fury over the failure of public services such as health and education to deliver significant improvement, yet it was Brown's draconian spending straitjacket in the first two years of this government which is largely to blame.

Strong sterling doesn't come home to roost because interest rates are now set by the independent Bank of England. But it was Brown who appointed the membership of the monetary policy committee (which includes negligible industrial experience) and instructed their narrow remit to be the control of inflation. Interest rates are raised to curb dangers of the south-east overheating, at a punishing cost to the rest of the country. Meanwhile Brown gathers in the bouquets at home and abroad, for Britain becoming the fourth biggest economy in the world and a record budget surplus.

So why have we all fallen in love with Gordon? Part of the reason is obvious yet true: everyone loves a chancellor in good times, it could all be very different if the economy came unstuck. But even more important is that he is a very clever politician; he has a big armoury of political skills and judges astutely when to use which one. For example, on the media: while commentators bemoan his neighbour's preoccupation with spin, the media and focus groups, Brown and his team discreetly employ exactly the same techniques without incurring any of the cynicism.

It was Brown who introduced the idea of "test running" the Budget through focus groups in 1998, and the skill with which this significant break with Budget secrecy was spun was breathtaking. It was reported as "removing a veil of secrecy from the Budget-making process and opening it up to wider consultation" and a Treasury source was quoted as saying, "we would rather make sure that we get changes right". So while Blair is lambasted for his dependence on focus groups and the lack of principle that that reveals, using them in the Treasury becomes an advance in democratic policy making.

More sinisterly, the spin often gives Brown credit at Blair's expense. On the minimum wage a few weeks ago, the story out of Brown's office was that he had managed to convince Number 10 to increase it; what later emerged was that Blair had overruled Brown's reluctance. Brown is cast as the beleaguered socialist in Downing Street: for example, earlier this month the Sunday Express quoted a minister in a story about child poverty saying that there will be an "element of the R-word that New Labour does not dare speak, redistribution". In the Guardian in February 1999, a pre-Budget leak on Brown's plans to switch resources to the poor described the chancellor "locked in conflict" with colleagues... tensions between the Treasury and Number 10 "which is anxious not to alienate middle England voters".

One explanation for Brown's flattering coverage is that he puts a lot of effort and time into getting it. Particularly with the Guardian. He knows it is one of the conduits to the party and its sympathisers, so he goes to considerable lengths to make sure we understand what he is doing. He asks to come and talk to us, and he is remarkably available for us to come and talk to him. He is charming, flattering - columnists are often surprised by his ability to recall and comment on several of their recent articles. He genuinely has a wide range of intellectual interests which enables him to engage with lots of commentators and journalists on their preoccupations: national identity? Morality and global inter-dependence? Community solidarity, micro-economic policy to crack the poverty trap or fiscal policy? Whatever it is, he has a real appetite for new, original ideas and seduces journalists with brilliant effect by listening to us as if we had any.

But the real craft is that none of this comes across as media manipulation, which is precisely why it is so successful. No one throws the "it's all spin" line at Brown. He manages to convey a moral integrity and purpose to his politics, thanks to his manse boy's crusade against poverty and bid for global leadership on debt cancellation.

And this is the most striking paradox about Gordon. By sheer sleight of hand, he convincingly positions himself as Red Gordon whose heart beats at one with the party's socialist core, while enthusiastically promoting (in this country and in the developing world) a model of Anglo-American global capitalism which has delivered unprecedented economic inequality both within and between countries over the last two decades. When he does go so far as to acknowledge the contradiction, his defence is dangerously close to a Thatcherite trickle down.

His work on debt relief helps paper over the contradiction; admirable it has been, but it has also been politically useful, enabling him to argue that all he needs is time - be patient - the global financial system can deliver for everyone not just the corporate capitalists on top of the heap. This laudable ambition may well prove to be one beyond even Gordon Brown's remarkable gifts.

webTitle: You decide when monarchy goes, Queen tells Australians

fields.headline: You decide when monarchy goes, Queen tells Australians
fields.standfirst: Knifeman arrested in security scare ahead of keynote constitutional speech
fields.trailText: The Queen today reaffirmed her pledge to serve as the monarch of Australia for as long as the  Australians want her, and no longer.
fields.body:
The Queen today reaffirmed her pledge to serve as the monarch of Australia for as long as the Australians want her, and no longer.

In a major constitutional speech at Sydney convention centre, amid a security alert involving the arrest of a mentally ill man with a knife, the Queen said she respected and accepted the outcome of last November's referendum in which Australians voted to retain the monarchy.

"I have always made it clear that the future of the monarchy in Australia is an issue for you, the Australian people, and you alone, to decide by democratic and constitutional means. It should not be otherwise."

On the first day of her first visit to Australia for eight years, the Queen said: "In the light of the result last November, I shall continue faithfully to serve as Queen of Australia under the constitution to the very best of my ability, as I have tried to do for these past 48 years.

"That is my duty. It is also my privilege and my pleasure.

"It is my duty to seek to remain true to the interests of Australia and all Australians as we enter the 21st century."

Earlier, the Queen had been given an enthusiastic reception by an estimated 3,000 well-wishers on the steps of Sydney opera house, although the crowds were small compared with the millions who turned out to greet the young Queen on her first visit in 1954.

"Since I first stepped ashore here in Sydney in February 1954, I have felt part of this rugged, honest, creative land," she said.

"I have shared in the joys and the sorrows, the challenges and the changes that have shaped this country's history over these past 50 years.

"But we must look forward as well as back. Australia has always been a country on the move and will go on being so - it is not for nothing that the anthem is 'Advance Australia Fair'.

"Whatever the future may bring, my lasting respect and deep affection for Australia and Australians everywhere will remain as strong as ever.

"That is what I have come here to say; that is why I am pleased to be back; and that is why I am looking forward to these next two weeks amongst you in this great country."

A security alert erupted earlier when Australian police arrested a man armed with a knife and a suspected bomb as he tried to talk his way into the conference centre shortly before the Queen was due to arrive.

Gregory Philip Pailthorpe, an unemployed Sydney man with a history of mental illness, later appeared in court and was ordered to be held overnight for assessment in a psychiatric unit. His lawyer told Sydney's central local court that Mr Pailthorpe, 39, admitted having the knife but "had the intention of protecting the Queen and not harming her in any way".

Detectives had earlier suspected that he had a home-made bomb in his rucksack, but forensic experts found later that a box containing wires and batteries was harmless.

Australian government officials said that when challenged Mr Pailthorpe had said: "Don't worry, I'm a member of the SAS."

Although the pro-monarchists won November's vote by 54.22% to 44.87%, with majorities in favour of retaining the monarchy in all but one of Australia's six states, recent polls indicate that a majority of Australians now favour a homegrown head of state but they disagree about how to choose one.

On this theory, the referendum only failed to produce a majority in favour of a republic because of the controversy surrounding the proposed new constitutional model.

webTitle: £40 a week to stay at school

fields.headline: £40 a week to stay at school
fields.standfirst: Budget cash boost to pay over-16s to stay at school
fields.trailText: A major expansion of state payments of up to £40 a week to encourage youngsters in Britain's run-down urban areas to stay on at school after the age of 16 will be announced by the chancellor in tomorrow's Budget.
fields.body:
A major expansion of state payments of up to £40 a week to encourage youngsters in Britain's run-down urban areas to stay on at school after the age of 16 will be announced by the chancellor in tomorrow's Budget.

In a move certain to reopen the debate about the future of child benefit for 16 to 18-year-olds, Gordon Brown is to earmark tens of millions of pounds to increase the number of areas piloting educational maintenance allowances (Emas).

With the chancellor putting the finishing touches to his fourth Budget, government sources yesterday shrugged off as "total rubbish" reports that he was at loggerheads with the prime minister over April's planned 1p cut in income tax.

"There has been no row about the basic rate of income tax," one Whitehall insider said, stressing that the government's priority was to increase the amount of money available to improve public services, particularly health and education, rather than a further reduction in the basic rate from 22%.

In what is being billed as a tight package overall, Mr Brown is to target tax cuts selectively, with more generous tax breaks for the working poor and budding entrepreneurs high on his list of priorities. Sources said that the chancellor and the education secretary, David Blunkett, had been so impressed by the instant impact of Emas in 15 pilot areas that they have fast-tracked plans to widen the scope of the experiment from the start of the next academic year.

Early evidence from the pilots launched last September shows that the payments of up to £40 a week for the poorest families have had a marked effect on the numbers staying on at school and that they could raise the national staying-on rate of 80% by up to 6 percentage points.

In opposition, Labour floated the idea of abolishing child benefit for those over 16 who stay on at school and replacing it by means-tested Emas. Fears that it would antagonise middle-class voters meant that the idea was put on ice before the election, with Labour's manifesto committing the party to a review of educational support for the over-16s.

However, Mr Brown remains a keen supporter of the idea, believing that it would help to tackle educational underperformance in poor areas, where staying-on rates average only 35%. Government sources said last night that the future of child benefit was still an open question, but added that if Emas proved to be a success there would be renewed impetus for a radical overhaul of the current system.

Mr Brown and Mr Blunkett are keen to see which form of Ema works best, since in some pilots the allowance is paid to the mother rather than the student. The speed at which the benefit is phased out and the cut-off point where families are no longer eligible also varies.

The new pilots in September will test whether the payment of transport costs has any impact on staying-on rates.

Mr Brown believes that the payments will have a marked impact on educational attainment, giving youngsters a better chance of escaping from poverty.

With the Conservatives yesterday stepping up their recent attacks on the government's record on tax, sources said there was no split between the chancellor and the prime minister on whether government help should be focused on eradicating poverty or boosting health spending.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, said the average working family was paying an extra £600 a year more in tax under Labour.

Using figures prepared by the House of Commons library, Mr Portillo said that the average family was losing £400 a year on pension tax; £175 on petrol; £139 on tobacco; £98.50 as a result of the abolition of the married couples tax allowance; and £100 resulting from council tax rises.

"Labour would like us to believe that they have only raised tax on fat cats and the super rich," Mr Portillo said.

"These figures show that it is actually ordinary hard-working families who are being hit."

The chief secretary to the treasury, Andrew Smith, insisted that the tax burden on the average family was falling, adding that Mr Portillo was launching a "desperate attempt" to hide the fact that his policy of cutting tax while increasing public spending did not add up.

Mr Smith said that the tax burden on the average family was falling to its lowest level since 1972. "Households on average will be £380 a year better off and the average family will be £740 a year better off," he said.

webTitle: 'Free and easy' Summerhill goes on trial

fields.headline: 'Free and easy' Summerhill goes on trial
fields.standfirst:
Tribunal to hear appeal against closure of internationally-renowned independent school that lets pupils study when they want
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The right of a school to adopt an unorthodox style of teaching will go on trial at the high court today to decide whether the government can force the closure of Summerhill, a progressive coeducational boarding school in Leiston, Suffolk.
fields.body:
The right of a school to adopt an unorthodox style of teaching will go on trial at the high court today to decide whether the government can force the closure of Summerhill, a progressive coeducational boarding school in Leiston, Suffolk.

Zoe Readhead, the headteacher, is appealing against a notice of complaint issued by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, after Ofsted inspectors said the internationally-renowned independent school was failing to maintain proper standards.

Summerhill was founded 78 years ago by Ms Readhead's father, A.S. Neill, to let children "develop free from fear", choosing when to attend classes and agreeing school laws in weekly meetings with staff.

In a series of critical reports, Ofsted drew attention to "unconventional extra-curricular activities", including nude bathing, and questioned whether the principle of allowing pupils discretion when to learn was interfering with their progress.

Last summer Mr Blunkett gave Summerhill six months to improve its premises and standards, or face closure. He is understood to have told officials to concentrate on health and safety problems at the school and avoid getting embroiled in arguments of educational philosophy.

But Ms Readhead will today appeal to an independent schools tribunal, chaired by a retired circuit court judge, alleging that parts of the government order are a direct challenge to the school's concept of education. The tribunal can quash the notice of closure or uphold it by striking the school immediately from the register of independent schools.

"This will be the first time that an educational philosophy has gone on trial," said the school's solicitor, Mark Stephens. "The question is whether there is room for a plurality of different types of education in a democratic society."

The fee-paying school for children aged six to 16 has 63 pupils, mostly from overseas, and is being supported by the parents.

When inspectors visited the school last year, they said pupils were allowed to "mistake idleness for the exercise of personal liberty". Ofsted accepted that pupils were generally "well-behaved and courteous, if often foul-mouthed". But it warned of serious weaknesses in children's learning. "The root cause of the defects is non-attendance at lessons. Some pupils abandon mathematics for up to two years on end," it said.

As a result, the curriculum for most pupils was "fragmented, dispirited, narrow and likely adversely to affect their future options". Pupils responded by voting for compulsory lessons in the afternoons as well as mornings.

In January, an independent inquiry team of heads, inspectors and businessmen said there was no evidence to support Ofsted's finding that the school was drifting. GCSE results were improving and former pupils' success in higher education showed their prospects were not narrowed as the inspectors suggested.

After spending 17 days at the school, they said the freedom enjoyed by Summerhill pupils did not mean it was "anarchic, ill-organised and unstructured". On the contrary, there were more than 200 rules and tribunals to deal with those who broke them.

The team, headed by Ian Cunningham, a management consultant and professor, said the government would contravene the European convention on human rights if it closed the school.

The tribunal is scheduled to last for eight days and judgment is expected to be reserved.

Zoe Readhead, the headteacher, is appealing against a notice of complaint issued by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, after Ofsted inspectors said the internationally-renowned independent school was failing to maintain proper standards. Summerhill was founded 78 years ago by Ms Readhead's father, A.S. Neill, to let children "develop free from fear", choosing when to attend classes and agreeing school laws in weekly meetings with staff. In a series of critical reports, Ofsted drew attention to "unconventional extra-curricular activities", including nude bathing, and questioned whether the principle of allowing pupils discretion when to learn was interfering with their progress. Last summer Mr Blunkett gave Summerhill six months to improve its premises and standards, or face closure. He is understood to have told officials to concentrate on health and safety problems at the school and avoid getting embroiled in arguments of educational philosophy. But Ms Readhead will today appeal to an independent schools tribunal, chaired by a retired circuit court judge, alleging that parts of the government order are a direct challenge to the school's concept of education. The tribunal can quash the notice of closure or uphold it by striking the school immediately from the register of independent schools. "This will be the first time that an educational philosophy has gone on trial," said the school's solicitor, Mark Stephens. "The question is whether there is room for a plurality of different types of education in a democratic society." The fee-paying school for children aged six to 16 has 63 pupils, mostly from overseas, and is being supported by the parents. When inspectors visited the school last year, they said pupils were allowed to "mistake idleness for the exercise of personal liberty". "The root cause of the defects is non-attendance at lessons. Some pupils abandon mathematics for up to two years on end," it said. fields.headline: Byers wins extra BMW cash
fields.standfirst:
Carmaker's concession as unions call for boycott

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The German car giant BMW will try to restore its reputation in Britain by offering a multimillion pound contribution towards the cost of regenerating the Longbridge Rover plant, in Birmingham.
fields.body:
The German car giant BMW will try to restore its reputation in Britain by offering a multimillion pound contribution towards the cost of regenerating the Longbridge Rover plant, in Birmingham.

As ministers accused BMW of telling lies over its plans to sell Rover, the government said it had persuaded the company to make a substantial contribution on top of big redundancy packages.

The move by BMW, following intense pressure from the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will be designed to dampen criticism from union leaders who last night backed a boycott of BMW.

Bill Morris and Sir Ken Jackson, the leaders of the T&G and the AEEU, yesterday signalled support for a "showroom stayaway".

Sir Ken said: "Britain has been stabbed in the back. Many people want to hit a firm they no longer trust where it hurts - in the pocket."

Tony Blair is said to "understand" the unions' frustration, a point he will make plain to the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, at this weekend's EU summit in Portugal.

Mr Byers yesterday underlined the government's anger when he said BMW had lied to him at a meeting earlier this month at which it gave no hint of its sell-off plans.

The trade and industry secretary, who is to visit BMW's Munich headquarters this week, said: "We've got to pick up the pieces [but] it won't get away from the anger people feel about the way BMW have conducted themselves."

Mr Byers has been politically hurt by the affair. A Blairite who put his faith in business, he has been seen as powerless in the face of BMW's decision.

At the end of last week he went some way to restoring his reputation when he set up an emergency aid package for the thousands of workers threatened with redundancy.

Last night DTI sources said BMW had agreed to contribute to the economic regeneration plan for Longbridge.

Werner Saman, Rover's German boss, has told Mr Byers he is prepared to hand over large parts of the Longbridge plant to the government, possibly for use as enterprise parks.

Meanwhile, union leaders have asked lawyers to study the prospects of legal action against BMW and Alchemy Partners, the venture capital firm which has made it clear that it will sack most of Longbridge's 8,500 workers.

A union source said: "This could be about getting the best redundancy terms, not avoiding the redundancies."

The Rover row has reignited a cabinet debate on the euro. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, made it clear yesterday that the cabinet's pro-euro wing would renew its fight to persuade Mr Blair to make a decision on the single currency after BMW blamed its decision on the high value of sterling.

Both the government and unions, however, last night played down the threat of closure at Ford's complex at Dagenham, in east London.

fields.headline: Rover's open and shut case
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The fate of the Rover plant at Longbridge is a graphic illustration of one of the big dilemmas in a modern economy. For a government committed to high employment, plant closures are a potential disaster. But, for a government committed to high productivity, closing poorly performing plants is precisely what is required.
fields.byline: Richard Disney, Jonathan Haskel and Ylva Heden
fields.body:
The fate of the Rover plant at Longbridge is a graphic illustration of one of the big dilemmas in a modern economy. For a government committed to high employment, plant closures are a potential disaster. But, for a government committed to high productivity, closing poorly performing plants is precisely what is required. How realistic is this dilemma and what should the government do about it?

If the market worked well then poor firms would disappear. Unable to produce the goods that customers want, the exit of inefficient firms would raise the average productivity of those remaining. Well functioning markets give you a double whammy. Innovative new firms will enter and prosper, replacing the older ones, again raising the batting average.

The market then does nothing more than boost the average of the side by leaving the poor performers out and bringing the good performers in.

However, markets may not work as well as one would like. Speculation, short-termism, and imperfect information might all plague the smooth running of the market place. Firms might exit due to misjudgment, or be sunk by a bank's unreasonable speculative pessimism. Firms, saddled with debt having invested for the long term, might find themselves unable to continue in business. Maybe then governments should be intervening to keep even poorly performing plants alive.

Part of the problem in the debate is the lack of hard evidence. Suppose plant closure contributed little to productivity growth. Then we should not worry too much about keeping such plants open for they would be sacrificing little on the target of raising productivity while perhaps gaining much on the target of raising employment. If governments knew how important plant closure was, they could understand the magnitudes of the trade-offs involved.

In recent work, we have tried to answer exactly this question. Using data from the UK Census of Production, we have calculated the productivity of every manufacturing plant in Britain from 1980-1992. We calculated productivity as output per unit of input, where the inputs are the combined inputs of labour, capital, raw materials and intermediate goods. We then tracked plants through time and separated plants into those that survive, those that are new entrants and those that exit. Since this data has not been available to researchers before the results provide the first hard evidence on the role of plant closures.

The figure summarises what we found. The survivors line shows their productivity grew steadily, while exiting plants had much lower productivity. The impact of the recession in the early 1980s is especially clear, where the line shows that particularly low productivity plants exited. The entrants line shows they were more productive (by about 4% on average) though in the early 1980s their productivity dipped below stayers for a couple of years.

Since exiting plants are less productive than stayers, productivity growth is boosted by their departure. Since new plants are more productive than stayers, productivity growth is boosted by their entry. Some further calculations quantify the various effects. In British manufacturing, about 50% of productivity growth between 1980 and 1992 was due to the high productivity plants entering and low productivity plants exiting (the rest was due to existing plants growing). Furthermore, most of this entry and exit effect was due to the closure of poorly performing plants within larger firms, exactly the Rover story.

Stopping closure would significantly sacrifice productivity by keeping low performing plants. So what is the answer? One option is to make subsidies to firms conditional on improving productivity. The problem with this is what to do when it does not work.

A better option would be try to help the local economy adjust to closure by for example, supporting retraining, labour mobility and new business start-ups. Getting these policies right is hard. But spending large amounts of money trying to keep poor plants open will reduce productivity, and looks increasingly ineffective. The tides of global competition are too strong to order back.

The Rover case also raises deeper questions. Perhaps the most profound change in the trend to a more global economy is the increased mobility of capital. Firms can now quite credibly threaten governments with moving plants overseas. By playing different countries off against each other, they can exact increasingly large subsidies.

The flip side is that governments are tempted to lower taxes to induce firms to locate in their country. Such tax competition is an important issue in Europe with Ireland's low corporation taxes particularly successful in attracting inward investment and the wrath of fellow EU states. The outcome of such tax competition is that firms will not be taxed at all, leaving subsidies to be paid for by taxes on workers. Whether workers will be willing to withstand these burdens remains to be seen.

webTitle: Showdown pits Mugabe against the rule of law

fields.headline: Showdown pits Mugabe against the rule of law
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe on course for constitutional crisis as president defies court order to get squatters off white farms

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe was heading towards a constitutional crisis yesterday as thousands of President Robert Mugabe's supporters disobeyed a high court order to quit the white-owned farms they are occupying.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe was heading towards a constitutional crisis yesterday as thousands of President Robert Mugabe's supporters disobeyed a high court order to quit the white-owned farms they are occupying.

Friday's ruling puts the courts on a collision course with Mr Mugabe and the police. The judgment instructed the police to move the squatters off the farms, to charge anybody who resisted with trespassing, and to ignore any instructions to the contrary from the president.

But as of last night there was still no sign of any big police operation to enforce the court order.

"I don't know what the police will do on this issue, it is a very political matter," said the information minister, Chen Chimutengwende, yesterday. He questioned whether the courts could give orders to Mr Mugabe and the police commissioner, Augustine Chihuri.

Squatters adamantly defied the court order and said they would continue to invade farms. "We are not moving off the farms. If anything we are going to move on to more farms because we are on a mission to reclaim the land of our forefathers," said Joseph Chinotimba, a spokesman for the Zimbabwe Liberation War Veterans' Association; it is based around those who fought white Rhodesian rule in the 1970s.

"We fought for this land and we are getting it now. Anyone who wants to deny us the land of our forefathers will have to fight us and we are ready for that fight."

The invasions of the white-owned farms started a month ago and now an estimated 635 are affected, representing about 15% of the country's large-scale commercial holdings. White farms are key food producers and the source of tobacco, a crucial export crop.

It was the government that organised the large-scale farm occupations to win support from land-hungry rural voters in parliamentary elections due in April.

About 15% of the invaders are actual veterans of the Rhodesian war and the remainder are supporters of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party and unemployed youths. Many are being paid Z$50 (83p) a day to occupy the farms, according to Zimbabwe's Financial Gazette newspaper. Government vehicles are also delivering supplies to the squatters, reported the newspaper.

The surprise ruling by Justice Paddington Garwe directly contradicted recent Mugabe assertions that the farm invasions were legal as long as they were not violent. Mr Justice Garwe previously had a reputation for making judgments favourable to the government. But his uncompromising ruling on the squatters has put the president in a bind.

If Mr Mugabe tells police to remove the squatters, as the court ordered, he risks a backlash from those whose votes he is courting. If he ignores the court he risks worsening his government's reputation overseas - and among opponents at home - as one that is undermining the rule of law.

The betting is that Mr Mugabe will choose to ignore the court order, as winning votes is probably more important to him than legalities.

As well as ordering the invaders to leave the farms within 24 hours and ordering the police to remove them within 72 hours, Mr Justice Garwe said the Commercial Farmers' Union could announce the ruling on state television and radio, and in newspapers. As of yesterday state news media had aired nothing.

President Mugabe, 76, has publicly backed the farm invasions several times in recent weeks. He has also made increasingly intemperate statements against his political opponents. "Those who try to cause disunity among our people must watch out because death will befall them," he said on Friday. His Zanu-PF party recently gave the war veterans Z$20 million (£330,000) to campaign in the parliamentary election.

"I don't believe the government will obey the court order," said Tendai Biti, a lawyer prominent in the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. "Invading farms has always been illegal but they have gone ahead and done it. I don't think a court order will change things. It is a political decision and Zanu-PF sponsored and masterminded the farm invasions. We have come to expect that madness and lack of respect for rule of law by Zanu-PF."

Mr Mugabe is desperate to win the votes of rural Zimbabweans, estimated to be about 65% of the country's 12m people. Last month when his draft constitution was rejected by voters, it was city dwellers who voted solidly against it.

The proposed constitution would have given the authorities power to seize white farms without compensation, but many voters suspected such land would end up going to members of the governing elite rather than being parcelled out to poor peasants.

The state has bought more than 2,000 white farms for resettlement since 1980, but redistribution of this land has been plagued by mismanagement and corruption.

fields.headline: The Sun could teach Haider a thing or two on Gypsies
fields.standfirst:
Vienna would have been drummed out of Europe for less

Refugees in Britain: special report
The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: You're sitting at a cafe table, drinking espresso, reading the Sun you bought from the kiosk across the road. Exciting times and lead stories. "Gypsy spongers are building themselves  palaces with the vast fortune they're making from soft-touch Britain". But nobody in the cafe pauses to peer over your shoulder - for this is a city of palaces. Vienna. Jorg Haider's soft-touch Austria.
fields.body:
You're sitting at a cafe table, drinking espresso, reading the Sun you bought from the kiosk across the road. Exciting times and lead stories. "Gypsy spongers are building themselves palaces with the vast fortune they're making from soft-touch Britain". But nobody in the cafe pauses to peer over your shoulder - for this is a city of palaces. Vienna. Jorg Haider's soft-touch Austria.

Sun readers, it seems, are swamping a special hotline "with fears that we are being taken for a ride and blasts at the government for letting it happen". And their paper has Ten Questions for Jack Straw - such as: "Are pensioners getting just a 75p-a-week rise because so much cash is being spent on refugees?"

Try an 11th question over another coffee. What would we say - what, indeed, would the Sun say - if Haider whipped up such a malignant storm? No need to ponder; it's his stock in trade. We'd call it all of a piece with his neo-Adolf pitch. We would declare Austria and its voters off civilised limits. We would laud the European Union's deep freeze treatment - and go back to the fragrant delights of Britain's biggest selling daily.

Brutal dislocation. Xenophobic hatred is what foreigners stir against other foreigners. Boiling resentment is what good old-fashioned British workers feel when their generosity is exploited by hairy scroungers who ought to be on the first plane home. "How is it," inquires the Sun, "that our European partners can send asylum-seekers on to Britain rather than take them in themselves?"

Well, Austria is still - just about - one of those partners: and how many refugees would we have it take, this small nation with so many borders? Germany, Slovakia and the Czech republic to the north; Hungary to the east (with Romania and the wreckage of Yugoslavia just beyond): Slovenia and Italy to the south and Switzerland to the west. This is the crossroads of our continent. If Sun readers in Cleckheaton and Cambridge feel under threat, how would they cope with Vienna?

Nor, on its refugee record, is Austria any sort of exceptional case. Eight million people; 800,000 foreigners among them. There were years in the 80s when 35,000 asylum-seekers - most of them Poles - came knocking, and years of strain in the 90s when 25,000 fleeing Yugoslavia followed suit. Of course there are laws and restrictions to gag over now, as there are in every country of Europe. But the record holds no particular shame. Final asylum decisions take three to six months. Legislation insists that foreign workers get the going Austrian wage.

So how did this earnest, punctilious society become the sudden pariah of the EU? How did Haider, with roughly a quarter of the votes, emerge as the beast from Carinthia? It is a story of complexity unlikely to interest the Sun: but it should shiver timbers far beyond the cafes of central Europe.

Systems first: the Austrian political and electoral system was designed to nurture partnerships. The socialists weren't in power (and coalition) for 30 years by accident. The moderate conservatives were there to spread consensus and divide the spoils. (They talk of the "red and the black" in Vienna; which is the way that every top public job is carved into two - one socialist, one conservative, one cosy stitch-up).

It sounds claustrophobic and cloying. It was. Austria's economy flourished, the country was smoothly run - but nothing ever changed. Jorg Haider didn't set his suitcase on the portals of power by peddling nostrums about the wonders of the SS or the war crimes of Churchill. He made his way, with the flair of populism, by making swingeing attacks - shrewd, scything onslaughts - on the old pals' act.

And, on the issues, he was often right. The rest is miserable modern history. He polled so well last year that he couldn't be carved out of the action again. Austria's president himself solicited the EU's righteous boycott in order to keep Haider out; but when he was in, it worked in precisely contrary ways. The governor, brooding and waiting in Carinthia, is more, not less popular.

The pantomime of ostracism - Austrian school kids finding their holiday trips to France cancelled and similar nit-pickings - merely infuriates and bemuses the middle ground. The socialists, stripped of their patronage after so long and not relishing it, are much identified with the regular street demos (which have come to be seen as the non-democratic route to giving them back their goody bags). And the country is thoroughly, perilously perplexed.

How, if you belong to the three-quarters who didn't vote for Haider, do you begin to put things right? There has been a full, democratic election. Even the staidest, most serious papers said it was time for change. This was change, duly chosen by the usual means. And the government it has produced has not, as yet, done a single thing outside the normal bounds of politics. The young (Freedom party) finance minister is thought of as a bit of a star. Haider himself sits parked in the wings. All the attention - and thus too much of the blame - switches to Brussels. The rest of Europe (as even sombre liberals say) isn't helping. It is making things worse.

There might be some EU logic in proscribing far-right parties and organisations (dozens of them) before they get a chance to stand for election. But watch the Belgians and the French, among others, duck away from that.

Such logic, though, doesn't operate when the parties, unbanned, collect enough support to claim a hand in government. Then the people who get penalised aren't Haider and his mates; they are laughing. No, the victims of the ban are the majority who want no truck with him. What would happen if the European Commission tried to ban the Sun? Don't answer that: William Hague - and even Jack Straw - would be on their white chargers in 15 seconds flat. And Sun circulation would soar.

You can't have a conversation in Vienna these days which doesn't turn swiftly to politics. Nor can you escape the hurt and the bemusement. "We'll work it out," they say; but they don't know how. And the medium-term things that ought to be happening - such as a profound reappraisal by the socialists of eternal government - are frozen out by short-term gestures.

An ethical foreign policy? Perhaps. But not a remotely practical one - or one that Europe can abandon without unthinkable loss of face. Sanctions - from Iraq to Serbia - are easy to impose, but the very devil to lift.

Meanwhile, two coffees on, there are the Gypsies and their palaces to ponder upon and ordinary Brits to be assuaged. Send them off, send them somewhere. Most roads, after all, lead to Vienna.
fields.bodyText: You're sitting at a cafe table, drinking espresso, reading the Sun you bought from the kiosk across the road. Exciting times and lead stories. "Gypsy spongers are building themselves palaces with the vast fortune they're making from soft-touch Britain". But nobody in the cafe pauses to peer over your shoulder - for this is a city of palaces. Vienna. Jorg Haider's soft-touch Austria. Sun readers, it seems, are swamping a special hotline "with fears that we are being taken for a ride and blasts at the government for letting it happen". And their paper has Ten Questions for Jack Straw - such as: "Are pensioners getting just a 75p-a-week rise because so much cash is being spent on refugees?" Try an 11th question over another coffee. What would we say - what, indeed, would the Sun say - if Haider whipped up such a malignant storm? No need to ponder; it's his stock in trade. We'd call it all of a piece with his neo-Adolf pitch. We would declare Austria and its voters off civilised limits. We would laud the European Union's deep freeze treatment - and go back to the fragrant delights of Britain's biggest selling daily. Brutal dislocation. Xenophobic hatred is what foreigners stir against other foreigners. Boiling resentment is what good old-fashioned British workers feel when their generosity is exploited by hairy scroungers who ought to be on the first plane home. "How is it," inquires the Sun, "that our European partners can send asylum-seekers on to Britain rather than take them in themselves?" Well, Austria is still - just about - one of those partners: and how many refugees would we have it take, this small nation with so many borders? Germany, Slovakia and the Czech republic to the north; Hungary to the east (with Romania and the wreckage of Yugoslavia just beyond): Slovenia and Italy to the south and Switzerland to the west. This is the crossroads of our continent. If Sun readers in Cleckheaton and Cambridge feel under threat, how would they cope with Vienna? Nor, on its refugee record, is Austria any sort of exceptional case. Eight million people; 800,000 foreigners among them. There were years in the 80s when 35,000 asylum-seekers - most of them Poles - came knocking, and years of strain in the 90s when 25,000 fleeing Yugoslavia followed suit. Of course there are laws and restrictions to gag over now, as there are in every country of Europe. But the record holds no particular shame. Final asylum decisions take three to six months. Legislation insists that foreign workers get the going Austrian wage. So how did this earnest, punctilious society become the sudden pariah of the EU? How did Haider, with roughly a quarter of the votes, emerge as the beast from Carinthia? It is a story of complexity unlikely to interest the Sun: but it should shiver timbers far beyond the cafes of central Europe. Systems first: the Austrian political and electoral system was designed to nurture partnerships. The socialists weren't in power (and coalition) for 30 years by accident. The moderate conservatives were there to spread consensus and divide the spoils. (They talk of the "red and the black" in Vienna; which is the way that every top public job is carved into two - one socialist, one conservative, one cosy stitch-up). It sounds claustrophobic and cloying. It was. Austria's economy flourished, the country was smoothly run - but nothing ever changed. Jorg Haider didn't set his suitcase on the portals of power by peddling nostrums about the wonders of the SS or the war crimes of Churchill. He made his way, with the flair of populism, by making swingeing attacks - shrewd, scything onslaughts - on the old pals' act. And, on the issues, he was often right. The rest is miserable modern history. He polled so well last year that he couldn't be carved out of the action again. Austria's president himself solicited the EU's righteous boycott in order to keep Haider out; but when he was in, it worked in precisely contrary ways. The governor, brooding and waiting in Carinthia, is more, not less popular. The pantomime of ostracism - Austrian school kids finding their holiday trips to France cancelled and similar nit-pickings - merely infuriates and bemuses the middle ground. The socialists, stripped of their patronage after so long and not relishing it, are much identified with the regular street demos (which have come to be seen as the non-democratic route to giving them back their goody bags). And the country is thoroughly, perilously perplexed. How, if you belong to the three-quarters who didn't vote for Haider, do you begin to put things right? There has been a full, democratic election. webTitle: Need to know: your guide to the latest clever thinking

fields.headline: Need to know: your guide to the latest clever thinking
fields.standfirst: Marc Lewis
fields.trailText: Marc Lewis
fields.body:
Age: 26

Who's he? Chief executive and founder, WebMarketing (created October 1998). Former copywriter and creative director at Leo Burnett Africa.

What's the clever idea? "We thought if we could get the power of an exciting TV commercial, marry that with the precision of good direct mail, we could be onto a winner. The old-style banner ads don't work. Nobody clicks on them any more. The click-thru rate is about 0.45%, less than one in 200 people. They're dull, flat, scaled-down outdoor hoardings that don't move. We therefore came up with this thing called the video banner - video because it's got video in it.

"The clever idea was sticking TV or TV-style ads through that little rectangular banner on a website. We could give the agencies everything they needed, above and below the line, with the same execution. We said, we'll take your commercial and turn it into a banner, you stick it on Lycos and Excite, and it will end up serving tens of millions.

"Once we launched the video banners - our basic product - we said, how can we make sure we stay number one? We started adding functionality, about a dozen different things we call interactive banners, over the last six months or so. The three that the market knows of so far are: (1) E-commerce banners - click on items within the TV commercial, add them to a shopping trolley, and conduct the entire transaction within that banner space. (2) Printable video banners - watch the TV ad and print out something simultaneously, something tangible that you can own; like car ads - the brochure actually sells the car. (3) Emailable/viral banners - watch the TV ad, click on it, and send it to a friend with a message. The best form of advertising has got to be word of mouth."

What's next? "The ISPs or portals are used to making money off telco rates. If those are scrapped which, looking at recent developments, they will be, advertising seems the main and obvious way of generating decent revenue streams. Hopefully we'll get planners, buyers and clients to shift their offline strategy online (5% of current ad spend goes to online, one part of that to banner ads). TV is still perceived to be far more sexy, although video banner ads can give you a better return on investment. So we face that challenge. Also, so many sites are popping up every day, media planners and buyers need to be helped and educated on deciding which sites to plump for.

"Video banner ads are automatic, stronger, work there and then, easy to use. The click-thru rate at the moment is much higher - 9.3%, nearly one in 10 people. There's a synergy between TV and online because we take those TV commercials and stick them into that banner environment."

webTitle: Tell and sell is the name of the game

fields.headline: Tell and sell is the name of the game
fields.trailText: In the days of yore (pre-internet, that is), news media and corporations had clearly defined boundaries. Ah, life was simple then. The internet has muddled things quite a bit.
fields.body:
In the days of yore (pre-internet, that is), news media and corporations had clearly defined boundaries. Magazines and newspapers gave readers news and objective information. Companies tried to sell goods and services, and placed ads in magazines, newspapers and on TV as a way to sell more. Ah, life was simple then. The internet has muddled things quite a bit.

Online, many companies now act like media entities. Not only do they want to sell you something, but they also want to inform and entertain (as a means to get you to buy more, of course). Cyber-savvy corporations are learning to become media companies, in order to make their websites more than marketing fluff - to make them more "sticky" so online users will come back again and again, not just when they want to buy something.

This trend is most obvious at pure online companies. For example, TheTrip.com is a successful website that helps travellers book trips online, earning its money mostly from commissions. But it also serves as a travel "magazine", in a sense. You can visit the site to get the latest travel industry news from a variety of news sources. It buys the rights to filtered travel-related content from a web syndication company, and hosts articles on its own website. It is travel magazine and travel agent.

Traditional businesses are picking up on this idea, too. The IBM.com site contains a healthy dose of technology news so that a web user could actually rely on the website as a portal for technology information - somewhat usurping the need to rely on traditional business media.

Online booksellers are also media companies these days. Amazon.com, the biggest of them, has a large editorial department that writes its own book and music reviews and author/artist interviews, and buys writing from freelancers and other publishers. The books lover who isn't put off by a commercial entity presenting "objective" articles about books can get it all from Amazon.com - reviews and books industry news and the ability to buy. There's no real need for an independent books magazine.

What of those independent editorial print and online publications, which seek to enlighten and entertain, not sell? What's to become of them? Well, January Magazine (www.janmag.com), a wonderfully written and designed website site about books and the books world, has a solution that works. It doesn't accept advertising and doesn't sell books. What it does is licence its book reviews and other editorial content to others - including Chapters.ca, a Canadian online retailer. Chapters buys content and has a staff writing its own reviews, making its website, again, a magazine of sorts, not just a merchant.

This trend of corporations buying and commissioning "editorial" content is creating a booming new industry: web syndication. Its two dominant players are US-based iSyndicate and Screaming Media. iSyndicate does most of its business selling content to corporations that want to liven up the website sites they present to the public (and to a lesser extent selling content to corporate intranets). According to chief executive Joel Maske, companies are buying such content as weather, horoscopes and lifestyle articles, as well as news stories.

A client like Fidelity Investments even buys sports content for its websites, recognising that its online audience of brokers and financial advisers has interests outside money. Companies are looking at the demographics of their website users and figuring out what content to publish to serve their needs and desires - just as a newspaper or magazine would.

Some companies are trying to set their website sites up as industry or vertical portals. Database giant Oracle last month launched what it calls the "E-Business Network" an attempt to make Oracle.com a "destination" site for business professionals. This "news network" will buy content from Reuters and ON24, offer live webcasts of business events, and publish company profiles, how-to shows, panel discussions, and even entertainment.

Is this a danger to traditional media outlets or their website sites? I doubt it. Oracle's E-Business Network surely won't kill off BusinessWeek.com. But it might take a few web users away from other business sites, just as Amazon.com's magazine-like features mean fewer visits to the New York Times website's books section.

It's an interesting phenomenon to watch. The internet results in corporations becoming more like media while some media companies start to look like pseudo-retailers, as they engage in online commerce and begin selling merchandise around their content. It's a strange (new) media world we're seeing evolve before our eyes.

 Steve Outing is a Colorado-based columnist and analyst who covers internet media trends for Editor & Publisher and Writer's Digest. He is also chief executive and founder of Content Exchange (www.content-exchange.com). steve@content-exchange.com
