fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top anayists are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.trailText: Missed what the top anayists are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.body:
Max Rust
www.mndaily.com

The idea that the internet is a place where ideas can be discussed and anyone can be a publisher or author is slowly dying as the web becomes more commercialised, according to TV journalist Ray Suarez. "The perfection of the internet as a medium will bring with it some terrors and some possibilities," Suarez told students. "On one hand, if you write to be read, there will be more places to write for and more readers to go there to find it. On the downside, there is no dependable revenue stream for places to publish on the web so far."

But this revenue stream is slowly widening, he said, changing an internet that initially seemed set to be "a very heavily text medium. It was thought of as a library. Now, the internet is a television, shopping mall and porn theatre all in one building. It's that net that's going to carry us into the coming decades. Words are going to lose to pictures. Words are going to lose to sound. Sound is going to lose to pictures. What this means for the news maker is hard to tell."

Suarez also talked about the "digital divide" theory that people are being split into two groups: those with modern information technology and those without. This leads news makers to cover subjects relevant to the "haves", leaving the "have-nots" out of the picture - "The news business in America is based on middle class people following trends of people richer than themselves."

David Butcher, Revolution magazine
www.revolutionmagazine.com

Ten things you can do to exploit the fact that increasing numbers of people now interact with TVs and PCs simultaneously:

1. Feed viewer response back into a live broadcast.

2. Offer viewers the live option of different perspectives on an event, eg a backstage webcam at a concert.

3. Run streaming video online that complements a sitcom or drama.

4. Let viewers access info online relevant to a show, video or sports event.

5. Run banner ads to coincide with on-air ads for the same brands.

6. Run TV ads that involve viewers in online activity, eg choosing endings online for "incomplete" Nike ads.

7. Allow viewers a synchronous forum for text chat related to TV shows.

8. Learn about TV audiences via online registration, polls etc.

9. Test-drive formats for when interactive TV becomes widespread.

10. Sell stuff: eg an ad pops up for a Dr Evil T-shirt on one screen just as he appears in an Austin Powers screening on the other.

fields.headline: Queen nets £m from dot.com
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: An internet photo-map company backed by the Queen and former Conservative trade minister Tim Eggar is planning a £40m stock market debut.
fields.body:
An internet photo-map company backed by the Queen and former Conservative trade minister Tim Eggar is planning a £40m stock market debut.

The company, Getmapping.com, is digitally photographing all of Britain from the air and web browsers will be able to zoom in to their neighbourhood and see pictures of everything on the ground more than 25cm long. The high-resolution images will then be marketed to consumers and businesses.

The Queen and Mr Eggar, along with the Queen's former private secretary Sir Robert Fellowes are among 30 private investors who raised nearly £2m to get the company started. The company plans to raise £7m for expansion from an Aim listing.

The Queen invested £100,000 at the outset and her 1.5% stake in the company should be valued at some £600,000.

webTitle: NHS advice line to handle some 999 calls

fields.headline: NHS advice line to handle some 999 calls
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Sweeping changes to the ambulance service will be announced today as the government intensifies its efforts to improve one of the most hard-pressed areas of the NHS, which faced intense pressure during the recent winter fuel crisis.
fields.body:
Sweeping changes to the ambulance service will be announced today as the government intensifies its efforts to improve one of the most hard-pressed areas of the NHS, which faced intense pressure during the recent winter fuel crisis.

Operators will be allowed to refer 999 callers with minor illnesses to the government's flagship NHS Direct telephone service, which is staffed by nurses and gives medical advice to callers, under plans unveiled by the health minister Gisela Stuart.

Ministers, who have come under fire for slow ambulance response times, believe the service could be transformed by ending the anomaly that prevents 999 operators from passing callers to NHS Direct.

Critics will claim that the move could jeopardise the safety of patients, who expect an ambulance when they dial 999. However, Ms Stuart will argue that her initiative will strengthen the ambulance service by allowing crews and operators to concentrate on urgent patients.

Ms Stuart's announcement comes on the eve of the Budget, in which Gordon Brown is expected to signal extra resources for the health service. There is speculation that the chancellor could pump an extra £500m into the NHS ahead of his next spending round in July. An extra £21m for the ambulance service was secured several weeks ago.

A series of pilot schemes has shown that there is "major scope" for NHS Direct to take the pressure off the ambulance service, Ms Stuart will tell the Royal College of Nursing conference.

"I am keen that, in the light of these pilots, we can move forward to develop a robust approach to allow NHS Direct to take on this area of work," she will say.

The winter flu crisis, in which emergency calls soared by up to 40%, provided a powerful example of the dangers of overloading the 999 system with non-urgent cases. Despite warnings that the public should only call 999 in emergencies, many of the calls came from flu sufferers who wrongly believed they were suffering from something more serious.

During the crisis, 999 operators were powerless to refer such patients to NHS Direct, which meant the genuinely sick and injured were forced to wait for ambulances. In one case over Christmas, a 74-year-old woman had to wait two hours for an ambulance because its crew answered a call from a man who had started sneezing in the rain.

Ministers believe the change to the ambulance service is an example of how inexpensive structural reforms can improve the NHS.

Ms Stuart will reinforce this message today when she leads the celebrations to mark the second anniversary of NHS Direct. Under the system, which will cover the whole of Britain by October, patients describe their symptoms over the telephone to a nurse who advises them either to stay at home, see a GP or go to hospital.

In her speech, Ms Stuart will unveil details of a survey that showed how the £250m NHS Direct service has relieved the burden on the health service. The survey of several hundred callers found that 48%, many of whom would have gone to their local GP, were advised to stay at home.

As Ms Stuart prepared for to day's announcement, Labour clashed with the Tories after Michael Portillo suggested that a Conservative government would encourage employers to finance the NHS through insurance schemes.

Andrew Smith, the treasury chief secretary, immediately hit back, saying that Mr Portillo's "latest gaffe" showed that the Tories' spending plans did not add up. The government is strongly opposed to employer insurance schemes for the NHS because it believes they would add disproportionately to business costs and set up a two-tier NHS.

A series of pilot schemes has shown that there is "major scope" for NHS Direct to take the pressure off the ambulance service, Ms Stuart will tell the Royal College of Nursing conference. "I am keen that, in the light of these pilots, we can move forward to develop a robust approach to allow NHS Direct to take on this area of work," she will say. The winter flu crisis, in which emergency calls soared by up to 40%, provided a powerful example of the dangers of overloading the 999 system with non-urgent cases. Despite warnings that the public should only call 999 in emergencies, many of the calls came from flu sufferers who wrongly believed they were suffering from something more serious. During the crisis, 999 operators were powerless to refer such patients to NHS Direct, which meant the genuinely sick and injured were forced to wait for ambulances. In one case over Christmas, a 74-year-old woman had to wait two hours for an ambulance because its crew answered a call from a man who had started sneezing in the rain. Ministers believe the change to the ambulance service is an example of how inexpensive structural reforms can improve the NHS. Ms Stuart will reinforce this message today when she leads the celebrations to mark the second anniversary of NHS Direct. Under the system, which will cover the whole of Britain by October, patients describe their symptoms over the telephone to a nurse who advises them either to stay at home, see a GP or go to hospital. In her speech, Ms Stuart will unveil details of a survey that showed how the £250m NHS Direct service has relieved the burden on the health service. The survey of several hundred callers found that 48%, many of whom would have gone to their local GP, were advised to stay at home. As Ms Stuart prepared for to day's announcement, Labour clashed with the Tories after Michael Portillo suggested that a Conservative government would encourage employers to finance the NHS through insurance schemes. Andrew Smith, the treasury chief secretary, immediately hit back, saying that Mr Portillo's "latest gaffe" showed that the Tories' spending plans did not add up. The government is strongly opposed to employer insurance schemes for the NHS because it believes they would add disproportionately to business costs and set up a two-tier NHS.

webTitle: Nationalists run riot after Taiwan vote

fields.headline: Nationalists run riot after Taiwan vote
fields.standfirst:
The victory of a pro-independence candidate for the presidency brings uproar in party which ruled for 50 years

Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang party was on the brink of collapse yesterday as furious supporters protested over its humiliating defeat in Saturday's presidential election.
fields.body:
Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang party was on the brink of collapse yesterday as furious supporters protested over its humiliating defeat in Saturday's presidential election.

Taiwanese voters defied Chinese warnings on Saturday by narrowly electing Chen Shui-bian, candidate for the pro-independence Democratic Progressive party (DPP), with 39.3% of the vote.

The headquarters of the Kuomintang (KMT) came under siege by hundreds of party members who claimed that the outgoing president, Lee Teng-hui, had conspired to ensure victory for Mr Chen.

Demonstrators hurled eggs and stones and shifted barbed wire barricades to block riot police and water cannons. "Lee has plotted to destroy us," shouted one demonstrator. "We are so angry with this pig, we have fury in our hearts. Lee must resign as party chairman!"

Last night Mr Lee was still refusing to step down immediately. However, pressure grew on him after a party spokesman, Huang Huei-chen, said Mr Lee would hand over in September and the mayor of Taipei, Ma Ying-jeou, told demonstrators he would urge him to go now.

Mr Lee has gone further than any other KMT leader in saying that Taiwan is a separate state from China. The demonstrators accuse him of lukewarm support for Lien Chan, the KMT candidate who came third with only 23.1%.

KMT members claim Mr Lee deliberately split it by ousting James Soong, a former party leader who ran a close second to Mr Chen, winning 36.8%.

Mr Soong stands to profit from the KMT's collapse and has indicated that he may form a new party.

Fears of military action eased after Beijing made it clear that it will wait at least until after Mr Chen and the new vice-president, the veteran feminist Annette Lu, are inaugurated in May.

A statement said: "We should listen to what the new leader in Taiwan says and watch what he does. We will observe where he will lead cross-straits relations."

But Beijing also publicised a mainland poll which allegedly showed that 95% of the people "will shed blood for their country if the Taiwan leader wants to secede".

In his acceptance speech on Saturday night, Mr Chen said that he would defend Taiwan's "sovereignty", but avoided using the more provocative word, "independence."

He repeated his offer to visit Beijing before the inauguration: "We would like to immediately negotiate with China on the issues of direct transport links, direct commerce, investment and military confidence-building measures".

Aides say they are encouraged because China has not dismissed the possibility of negotiations with Mr Chen.

webTitle: Chiang Kai-shek's legacy dies as pressure for freedom wins

fields.headline: Chiang Kai-shek's legacy dies as pressure for freedom wins
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: The death warrant of the Kuomintang (KMT) - the Chinese Nationalist Party which ruled the mainland for more than three decades and then Taiwan for another five - was signed at the weekend, when Chen Shui-bian won the presidency.
fields.body:
The death warrant of the Kuomintang (KMT) - the Chinese Nationalist Party which ruled the mainland for more than three decades and then Taiwan for another five - was signed at the weekend, when Chen Shui-bian won the presidency.

This militaristic machine, modelled on the Soviet Communist Party in the 1920s, has been forced to yield ground to the opposition over 15-20 years to the point where Taiwan is a free society with free elections. But it failed to reform its own political practice while becoming mired in corruption.

The key issue in the election was not relations with Beijing but "black gold politics". The KMT is said to be the world's richest political party, with assets totalling more than $6bn (£3.75bn).

Official KMT propaganda presents the growth of democracy as a natural process. Improvements in literacy, economic growth and social mobility all created rising expectations. The turning point was the lifting of martial law and of the ban of political parties in 1986. Two rounds of constitutional reform culminated 10 years later when Lee Teng-hui won the first presidential election.

But this version ignores years of struggle and repression. Taiwanese had learnt to hate the KMT even before Chiang Kai-shek's flight from the mainland. In February 1948 a mass protest led to bloody suppression.

Human rights campaigners were jailed and brutalised. Taiwan's democracy movement emerged in 1979-80 in response to mass arrests and the banning of the pro-independence Formosa magazine. Mr Chen's wife was the victim of a motor "accident", which has left her confined to a wheelchair.

With the death of President Chiang Ching-kuo in 1988, who had succeeded his father Chiang Kai-shek, the dominance of mainlanders in the KMT began to wane.

Under Mr Lee, 'Taiwan's first native-born leader, much of the party ideology brought from China was jettisoned, but the party machinery ground on. From the early 1990s, several reform-minded figures were evicted from the KMT elite by Mr Lee, who called them "trash-fish who cannot survive in the party's clear waters".

The mismatch between the new economy and old politics has become starker. Taiwan is a world leader in producing computer chips yet millions live cramped in drab, urban areas, and key public bodies, such as television and the labour federation, still await reform.

Democracy sets island off from Beijing

1927-28 Under Chiang Kai-shek, the Nationalist party (Kuomintang, or KMT) unifies much of China, after vanquishing regional warlords

1945 China, a war victor, takes back Taiwan after 50 years of colonial rule by Japan

1946-49 Chinese civil war between the Nationalist KMT government and the rising Communists

1947 The Nationalist government's army kills hundreds - perhaps thousands - in Taiwan after February 28 protest by islanders at the mainland regime's dictatorial rule in Taiwan, and its economic exploitation

1949 His government collapsing before the Communists, Chiang Kai-shek flees from the mainland and establishes his KMT government in Taiwan

1971 Beijing ousts Taipei as China's UN representative

1991 Taiwan ends state of war with China

1992 First Taiwan elections for legislature. China is upset

1996 First election for president. China upset again

1999 President Lee Teng-hui says China and Taiwan are "two states". Beijing is furious

2000 In the presidential election, KMT loses power for first time in more than 50 years

fields.headline: Hysteria and hate
fields.standfirst:
Refugees need protection not persecution

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: In the wake of a jingoistic press and populist politicians banging their anti-foreigner drums, standing up for refugee rights requires bold political leadership. Alas, currently there is not much of that on show.
fields.body:
It was Winston Churchill who suggested the best judge of a civilised nation was the state of its prisons. If he was alive today, he would almost certainly have to select asylum policy. In the wake of a jingoistic press and populist politicians banging their anti-foreigner drums, standing up for refugee rights requires bold political leadership. Alas, currently there is not much of that on show. An opposition, which still lags far behind in the polls, has not forgotten how many votes Margaret Thatcher won with her anti-immigrant policies. A right-wing tabloid press is only too happy to help, fanning fear of asylum seekers, and pouring contempt on politicians and pressure groups who attempt to defend their rights. Most miserable of all, ministers appear to be buckling now that the party's dreaded focus groups are suggesting the current asylum alarm is eroding support for the government. Since when were civil rights decided by pollsters? Few rights are more fundamental than the right to be free from persecution. That right should include freedom from being misrepresented by a rabid media.

Yesterday's Sunday Telegraph, a paper not noted for its staunch support of refugees, was fed some raw meat by someone within Whitehall who was seeking to appease the blood-lust. The front-page headline summed it up: "Immigrants who beg will be kicked out of the country". Radio interviews were filled by the ever-present Ann Widdecombe, who wanted asylum-seekers caught begging, locked up until their applications were resolved. Has it ever occurred to her that one reason they may be begging is because their benefits fall 30% below an already inadequate subsistence allowance? If she really had the taxpayers' interests at heart, she'd be calling for them to be paid a bit more and save on the £200 plus a week it costs to keep just one asylum applicant in custody. And she might have the humility to remember, that under her time at the Home Office, thousands of asylum seekers were waiting over five years for a decision.

Ministers should stop panicking. Increasing the speed at which asylum applications are processed is urgently needed, but not as a penalty against begging but as a basic humanitarian need to reduce the time applicants remain in limbo. Average waits have been cut to 13 months, but that is still far too long. More calmness, composure and compassion is needed at the top.

fields.headline: Fast-track curb on beggars
fields.standfirst:
Asylum seekers convicted of demanding cash could be deported more speedily

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The processing of asylum seekers who are convicted of aggressive begging, particularly if they exploit children, is to be fast-tracked and those who fail to qualify for refugee status removed from the country, under plans being considered by the Home Office.
fields.body:
The processing of asylum seekers who are convicted of aggressive begging, particularly if they exploit children, is to be fast-tracked and those who fail to qualify for refugee status removed from the country, under plans being considered by the Home Office.

The immigration minister, Barbara Roche, is considering the scheme as one way of relieving the increasing pressure that the government faces over the asylum issue. It comes in the face of warnings from Labour's polling guru, Philip Gould, of focus group evidence showing that asylum lies only just behind the state of the health service and education in the list of issues that are damaging the government's standing in the country.

The asylum system is beginning to recover from a complete breakdown in the past year. More than 8,000 decisions were made in the last four weeks and for the first time since 1996 outstripped the number of applications during the same period.

Ministers are hoping to maintain this performance and begin to eat away at the backlog of more than 102,000 cases awaiting a decision. The current average waiting time to determine whether an asylum claim that has not been fast-tracked is genuine or not is 13 months.

In an attempt to restore public faith in this ramshackle system for dealing with asylum applications, the first privately run "internment" camp will open at Oakington, near Cambridge, today with the aim of deciding initial applications from 13,000 asylum seekers within seven days and so saving £30m a year in costs of housing and education.

Men and women arriving at the Group 4-run "processing centre" housed in a former RAF base will be separated and families broken up while their applications are considered. Those whose applications are turned down will have three weeks to appeal before facing removal from the country.

The decision of ministers to use a fast-track system for those convicted of begging as well as those suspected of making abusive claims indicates that Labour is deter mined that its asylum reforms, including a system of vouchers and dispersal, are seen as an effective deterrent abroad to those thinking of coming to Britain and to answer claims that the country is a "soft touch" compared with other European destinations.

It is already a criminal offence to beg on the streets in Britain and it is expected that an immigration and asylum appeal tribunal would be unlikely to look sympathetically at the claim for refugee status from a woman who had been convicted of a criminal offence while she was here.

A Home Office spokesman said yesterday: "There is absolutely no reason for any asylum seeker to be begging on the streets, they are provided with enough to live on. The Home Office is looking at ways of addressing what appears to be increasing numbers of asylum seekers who are begging. One of the options is a fast-tracking of the asylum claims of those caught begging."

Small groups of women with children collecting money has become a familiar sight on the London tube in recent months. Many come from eastern Europe. British Transport police have received reports of 27 incidents in January and February so far this year.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said yesterday that asylum seekers who beg should be jailed immediately before being automatically deported. "It is a criminal offence to demand money with menaces and people like that should be in prison."

Refugee welfare groups said yesterday that 2,500 children of asylum seekers in Britain were being denied their legal right to a school place. The Refugee Council said headteachers had rejected them because they feared damaging their schools' position in the league tables.

Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the council, said: "In our view it is completely unacceptable to beg with children. We have consistently called for the decision-making process to be speeded up. We think this can be done without compromising the fairness of the decision-making process."

webTitle: Not only doomed, but dotty too

fields.headline: Not only doomed, but dotty too
fields.standfirst:
William Hague's espousal of Hayek's theories is bizarre

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague's speech to Politera, a free-market thinktank, received far less attention than it deserved. I accept that the leader of the opposition's opinions are usually irrelevant to the contemporary political debate. His destiny is to lose the next general election. And the style he has chosen with which to embrace defeat - absurdities expressed in the language of the Oxford Union, circa 1910 - make him sound slightly dotty as well as totally doomed. But last Monday's lecturette on tax policy was important. It illustrated how far to the right the Conservatives have drifted in their search for clear blue water with which to separate themselves from the Labour party.
fields.body:
William Hague's speech to Politera, a free-market thinktank, received far less attention than it deserved. I accept that the leader of the opposition's opinions are usually irrelevant to the contemporary political debate. His destiny is to lose the next general election. And the style he has chosen with which to embrace defeat - absurdities expressed in the language of the Oxford Union, circa 1910 - make him sound slightly dotty as well as totally doomed. But last Monday's lecturette on tax policy was important. It illustrated how far to the right the Conservatives have drifted in their search for clear blue water with which to separate themselves from the Labour party.

The idea that low taxes enable private citizens to give their life "a moral shape", and the consequent conclusion that high taxation inhibits personal morality, is a significant rejection of traditional Tory pragmatism. Conservatives were always in favour of low taxation. But they have only recently felt the need to support that prejudice by pretending that it has an ethical justification. Harold Macmillan believed that "morality is best left to the bishops". William Hague, without his predecessor's self-confidence, thinks it necessary to hide his party's usual appeal to avarice behind a bogus philosophy.

Only William Hague, when the mood of the country is passionately in favour of spending more on public services, could believe that there are votes to be won by claiming that there is virtue in spending less. Nevertheless, that is what he did - resuscitating Margaret Thatcher's old ideas in a more extreme form. Lady Thatcher was the apostle of the bar-room version of the same theory, arguing: "It's your money and you are entitled to keep it."

William Hague's church-youth-club variation on the same theme ("It's your money and you have a duty to keep it"), takes the notion a further step down the path which Friedrich von Hayek trod in The Road to Serfdom.

So, he was allowed to set out, without a word of ridicule, his nursery version of an idea which is normally only associated with American free-market ayatollahs who believe that the right to buy and sell body parts is the mark of a liberal society. If you doubt the provenance of Hague's new theory, compare the texts "Taxation is agreement by the majority on sharing the booty gathered by overwhelming a minority of citizens and deciding how much is taken from them . . . Taxes lie at the heart of state interference in our lives". The first of those sentences comes from Hayek, the second from Hague. But I defy anyone to notice the join.

Being a clever and well-read chap, William Hague must know the depth of absurdity to which Hayek's theory leads. The most interesting is the contention that high taxes are the result of something which Hayek calls "unlimited democracy", a condition which his followers are always determined to remedy. That is why they supported the downfall of high-tax Allende and his replacement with low-tax Pinochet.

Since Hague echoes Hayek's basic principle that a tax policy that helps some citizens at the expense of others is "not only incompatible with personal freedom but highly immoral", he has to accept what Hayek was honest enough to admit are the consequences of the look-after-yourself society. The manner in which the benefits and burdens are apportioned would, in many instances, have been regarded as very unjust if it were the result of deliberate allocation. But this is not the case. To demand justice from such a process is absurd.

So there is nothing to worry about. According to Hayek, so long as we neither intentionally starve pensioners to death nor wilfully refuse treatment to the sick, we bear no guilt from their inadvertent deaths by neglect. Indeed if we did begin to concern ourselves about their prospects, we might be tempted to raise taxes in order to meet their needs. And that would be highly immoral. Ask Friedrich von Hayek or William Hague.

Which leaves us with a perplexing question. Why on earth has William Hague sought to associate himself and his party with all this squalid nonsense? Margaret Thatcher's more vulgar interpretation of the same theory can be attributed to her capacity for skating along on the surface of serious thought. She declared herself a disciple of Hayek and then announced that she had never read him. But Hague is supposed to understand these things. So he cannot enter such a defence. He must have realised that nibbling at Hayek's notions would maroon him on the wilder shores of free-market politics. Perhaps it was a sudden lapse of understanding. Or he may have been driven half-demented by the certainty of defeat. Then there is the possibility that he actually believes all this rubbish. It is a mark of William Hague's political importance that no one has noticed.

So, he was allowed to set out, without a word of ridicule, his nursery version of an idea which is normally only associated with American free-market ayatollahs who believe that the right to buy and sell body parts is the mark of a liberal society. If you doubt the provenance of Hague's new theory, compare the texts "Taxation is agreement by the majority on sharing the booty gathered by overwhelming a minority of citizens and deciding how much is taken from them . . . Taxes lie at the heart of state interference in our lives". The first of those sentences comes from Hayek, the second from Hague. But I defy anyone to notice the join. Being a clever and well-read chap, William Hague must know the depth of absurdity to which Hayek's theory leads. The most interesting is the contention that high taxes are the result of something which Hayek calls "unlimited democracy", a condition which his followers are always determined to remedy. That is why they supported the downfall of high-tax Allende and his replacement with low-tax Pinochet. Since Hague echoes Hayek's basic principle that a tax policy that helps some citizens at the expense of others is "not only incompatible with personal freedom but highly immoral", he has to accept what Hayek was honest enough to admit are the consequences of the look-after-yourself society. The manner in which the benefits and burdens are apportioned would, in many instances, have been regarded as very unjust if it were the result of deliberate allocation. But this is not the case. To demand justice from such a process is absurd. So there is nothing to worry about. According to Hayek, so long as we neither intentionally starve pensioners to death nor wilfully refuse treatment to the sick, we bear no guilt from their inadvertent deaths by neglect. Indeed if we did begin to concern ourselves about their prospects, we might be tempted to raise taxes in order to meet their needs. And that would be highly immoral. Ask Friedrich von Hayek or William Hague. Which leaves us with a perplexing question. Why on earth has William Hague sought to associate himself and his party with all this squalid nonsense? Margaret Thatcher's more vulgar interpretation of the same theory can be attributed to her capacity for skating along on the surface of serious thought. She declared herself a disciple of Hayek and then announced that she had never read him. But Hague is supposed to understand these things. So he cannot enter such a defence. He must have realised that nibbling at Hayek's notions would maroon him on the wilder shores of free-market politics. Perhaps it was a sudden lapse of understanding. Or he may have been driven half-demented by the certainty of defeat. Then there is the possibility that he actually believes all this rubbish. It is a mark of William Hague's political importance that no one has noticed.

fields.headline: Rover: the sound and fury
fields.trailText: So Mr Blair is angered by BMW's treatment of Rover (Blair fury at BMW tactics, March 18). Had he launched the policies necessary for building a proper stakeholders' economy in Britain - as he seemed to promise before the election - his anger would have been unnecessary.
fields.body:
So Mr Blair is angered by BMW's treatment of Rover (Blair fury at BMW tactics, March 18). Had he launched the policies necessary for building a proper stakeholders' economy in Britain - as he seemed to promise before the election - his anger would have been unnecessary.

BMW could not have acted this way in Germany. Germany has a stakeholders' economy; it has an institutional and legislative framework which requires big companies to act as good corporate citizens. If companies operate in an environment where they are allowed to work in the interests of their shareholders alone, then even those that are the best of corporate citizens in their home countries, tend to go on the rampage.

Mr Blair appeared to presage a programme to modernise the British economy along stakeholder lines. But he was not prepared to countenance the constraints on business and shareholder rights evident in the notion.
Prof Jeffrey Henderson
Manchester Business School
J.henderson@fs2.mbs.ac.uk

 Until late last year the German Bundesbank's website showed a monthly update of the over-valuation or under-valuation of the German Mark. When I pressed the Bank of England to consider this last year they declined. However it is clear that Germany's transparency coincides with German car producers rarely suffering the effects of overvaluation.

With an article by Edmond Warner (Euro doesn't figure in these sweet dreams, January 29) you published a chart illustrating the real over-valuation of sterling against the Deutschmark since 1980. I have since sent a copy of this to the Bank of England and asked them whether this illustration is a true and fair representation of the position of sterling.

A region like ours desperately needs the Bank to come clean so that the dynamics of the Longbridge debacle are exposed.
Andrew Lydon
Vice Chair, West Midlands new economics group

 As BMW's decision to sell off its loss-making Rover subsidiary is presumably an example of pure global commerce in action, isn't it funny that we haven't seen all those free-market supporting members of the former Tory government cheering from the opposition benches? Or do they only support the philosophy when it's developing countries that suffer at the hands of US or European companies and the WTO?
Don Keller
Londondon.keller@nationwideisp.net

 The debacle at Longbridge must serve as a wake-up call for centre-left parties and unions to stop prostrating themselves before the free market. BMW made their priorities clear; when will Vodaphone return the compliment to German workers?
Colin Hines
Twickenham, Middlesex
chines@dial.pipex.com

 The Alchemy transmutation deal is a dud based on dreams for a name that once existed and cars that are yet to be designed. The answer is obvious; the government matches the venture capitalists and buys Rover. That is what Labour governments do in situations like this.
Mic L Porter
Monkseaton, Tyne and Wear

 I see (We knew from the beginning that they would eventually close us down, March 18) that a Longbridge worker who entered the factory as a scab is now complaining that he would still have a job, "if the unions had taken some old-style tough action last year". Ain't it the truth!
Myrna Shaw
London

 Does my boycott of BMW cars count, even though I can't afford one?
John Morrison
Hebden Bridge, West Yorks
john@trunorth.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Dots before the spies
fields.trailText: If the spooks at MI5 and their police accomplices haven't yet figured out how to hack into the Guardian's system and read David Shayler's email for themselves (Secrets, lies and David Shayler, March 17), what on earth are we paying them for?
fields.body:
If the spooks at MI5 and their police accomplices haven't yet figured out how to hack into the Guardian's system and read David Shayler's email for themselves (Secrets, lies and David Shayler, March 17), what on earth are we paying them for?
Tom Willis
Woking, Surrey
tom@marinedata.co.uk

 A sign of the times: Alison, my four-year-old grandaughter, signed of her prayers the other night with "amen dot.uk"!
Peter Hobson
Chester
peter.hobson@virgin.net

 Surely it should be written "dotcom" or ".com" (Guardian, every day last week). "dot.com" reads "dot dot com".
Sarah Kenning
Hull
sarah_kenning@hotmail.com

 The fifth cloned piglet (The genetics debate, March 15) was called Dotcom because she was pharmed on the lastminute.
John Hamlett
Manchester
johnhamlett@mac.com

 Despite what John Ezard (March 17), Pass Notes, Jeremy Paxman and sundry correspondents think, Grigory Rasputin neither was, nor claimed to be, a monk.
Prof Robin Milner-Gulland
School of European studies, University of Sussex

 I must protest strongly at your continuing collusion in the use of cats in publicity photographs. These are usually striving to create a cuddly image for some deeply unpleasant person with whom no decent cat would be seen dead. First it was Cherie Blair, then Jeffrey Archer, and now (Saturday Review, March 18) Ann Widdecombe. These animals are obviously suffering. Please do not encourage these awful people.
Elmo Jones
London

fields.headline: The wrong chemistry
fields.trailText: In a classic venture capital operation, Alchemy (Asset-stripper? Not me, says the man who will scrap Rover, March 17) bought out Cresta Care in September 1999, making them the sole owners through a holding company, Four Seasons, of the three residential care homes sold off by Wandsworth's Tories in 1996.
fields.body:
In a classic venture capital operation, Alchemy (Asset-stripper? Not me, says the man who will scrap Rover, March 17) bought out Cresta Care in September 1999, making them the sole owners through a holding company, Four Seasons, of the three residential care homes sold off by Wandsworth's Tories in 1996.

By November, notices of closure had been issued to residents and staff at one home, Holybourne, deemed by Alchemy not to be profitable. One elderly man was so confused by the manner in which residents were told, that he was found putting his possessions into a bin liner.

Under court action based on a weak agreement struck by the Tories to deflect criticism of their 1996 sell-off and which was supposed to guarantee residency and care for life, Alchemy have confirmed that Holybourne will close as soon as reasonably practicable. Displaced residents will be allowed first access to places in their other homes in the borough: small comfort to relatives who feel that their loved ones have been disgracefully treated. There are less vacancies than potential residents in the two homes which remain open and are in Alchemy's possession.

Notwithstanding this disaster, Tory councillors voted on Wednesday to award without competition a five year extension of contract to Alchemy to run day centres in the borough as part of their continuing quest to maintain as a council the lowest possible council tax.

One can only hope for the sake of the workers at Longbridge that Alchemy are somewhat better at making cars than they have been at looking after elderly people and the staff who have dedicated themselves to caring for the same in Wandsworth.
Cllr Pam Tatlow
Wandsworth Town Hall

fields.headline: What planet is he from?
fields.trailText: It's somewhat disingenuous of Colin Matthews to claim (Letters, March 18) that his addition to Holst's masterpiece was only front-page news because your reporter phoned him on the subject. A performance of The Planets that does not end with Neptune as originally conceived is news in itself in my view.
fields.body:
It's somewhat disingenuous of Colin Matthews to claim (Letters, March 18) that his addition to Holst's masterpiece was only front-page news because your reporter phoned him on the subject. A performance of The Planets that does not end with Neptune as originally conceived is news in itself in my view.

Whether Holst was wrong or not to add a "Pluto" movement is debatable, as indeed is the issue of whether Mr Matthews should be prepared to contribute to various other updated masterpieces such as Mahler's Song of the Friends of the Earth or a politically correct version of Prokofiev's Person and the Wolf.
John Anderson
London
 Mr Matthews has not only commited a musical error he has also commited a physical one; viz placing Pluto after Neptune "fades away". My understanding is that as of now it should be before Neptune, as its orbit is elliptical and it is closer to the sun at present. I also believe that there is an ongoing discussion to downgrade it to an asteroid anyway, so perhaps old Gustav was years ahead of us.
DS Haseldine
Burgess Hill, West Sussex
deltyaar.5@virgin.net

 Your leader on the Holst controversy (March 17) asks why Beethoven wrote only 33 Diabelli Variations. He ran out of keys; there are 34 and Diabelli had already used one of them.
George Kitchin
Penrith, Cumbria
george@gkphoto.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: More poison in the well
fields.trailText: Some of the correspondence (Letters, March 16) in response to Ed Vulliamy's article (Poison in the well of history, March 15) unwittingly endorses Vulliamy's point about the "unholy alliance of Serb apologists and misguided intellectuals" in Britain.
fields.body:
Some of the correspondence (Letters, March 16) in response to Ed Vulliamy's article (Poison in the well of history, March 15) unwittingly endorses Vulliamy's point about the "unholy alliance of Serb apologists and misguided intellectuals" in Britain.

Serbian infiltration into Britain's academia takes many forms. In 1997, LM activists attempted to disrupt an international conference at Glasgow University to launch their "new-look" magazine, which included the photos at the heart of the ITN libel trial. After the war many British academics sought to undermine the success of the Nato campaign, even using university website links to advertise Serbian propaganda material.

Academic freedom is one thing. Revisionist reasoning based on fallacious analysis and presented as serious scholarship is another.
Carole Hodge
South east European research unit, University of Glasgow
 Alfred Sherman (Letters, March 16) puts forward the tired old myth that the break-up of Yugoslavia was the fault of the Croats and the Germans. The EU recognised Croatia only after Serbia had annexed and ethnically cleansed a third of Croatia. Who can blame the Croats for going for independence? If England declared it's intention to create a "Greater England" at the expense of Scotland, I'm sure the Scots would declare independence pretty damn fast.
Brian Gallagher
London

fields.headline: Playing happy families
fields.trailText: The government preaches the primacy of marriage in school teaching on the day Shelter reports on frighteningly high levels of domestic violence (Violence driving women from their homes, March 16). Ironic, or what?
fields.body:
The government preaches the primacy of marriage in school teaching on the day Shelter reports on frighteningly high levels of domestic violence (Violence driving women from their homes, March 16). Ironic, or what?

It is time we realised that happy children come from happy parents, regardless of the status imposed on them by antiquated religious laws, or the disapproval of right-wing moralists.
Simon Lawton-Smith
London
 Now that heterosexuals are to have their own equivalent (Section 28 deal faces new attack, March 17), maybe there will be some resistance to the mad clamour of religious fundamentalists. The proposed new guidelines cobbled together by the churches and Mr Blunkett are an insult to the divorced and the single-parent household as well as to gay men and lesbians. They insult teachers but, above all, they insult the children themselves who are supposedly so simple-minded that they will believe anything anyone tells them.
George Broadhead
Secretary, Gay and Lesbian Humanist Association
GALHA@bigfoot.com

 Lady Blatch is mistaken in saying that the government's new guidelines present marriage as morally equivalent to other stable relationships. An agreement to differ, which is what the guidelines offer, is the only possible solution.
Earl Russell
House of Lords

fields.headline: Maggie's nice little earner
fields.trailText: So Margaret Thatcher can get about £35,000 a time on the speakers' circuits (No such thing as a free speech, March 17). And she gets it of course, largely on the strength of the fame we gave her by allowing her to be our prime minister. One is reminded that when she left our employ, we gave her a nice little handshake to finance a private office and staff.
fields.body:
So Margaret Thatcher can get about £35,000 a time on the speakers' circuits (No such thing as a free speech, March 17). And she gets it of course, largely on the strength of the fame we gave her by allowing her to be our prime minister. One is reminded that when she left our employ, we gave her a nice little handshake to finance a private office and staff.

The lady herself created this allowance, rather shrewdly some might think, to be called the "former prime ministers' public duties costs allowance". It didn't exist before she announced it in 1991; and she was the first ex-PM to receive it when she left office in 1994. Since the old dear is now visibly on her feet and earning her own living, isn't it time our annual state hand-out should be withdrawn? After all, it's peanuts to her on £35K a night but it's a lot to us: £55,300 in the current year and rising annually. Since she and her dubious foundation are clearly now profiting from her years in our employment, a withdrawal of benefit would certainly accord with her stern principles regarding public spending.
Stanley Walinets
Barnard Castle, Co Durham
 So, how many people asked Frank Dobson to speak after dinner?
Chris Abbott
Harlow
cabbott@netcomuk.co.uk

fields.headline: No need for revision
fields.standfirst:
A year after Nato went to war for Kosovo

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: It was hardly surprising that, when Nato launched the first hot war in its history by bombing Yugoslavia a year ago, it aroused as much passion as reasoned debate across Britain's political spectrum. Heated arguments over the conflict transcended ideological lines, with members of the Conservative right coming down on opposite sides of the fence just as much as luminaries of the left.
fields.body:
It was hardly surprising that, when Nato launched the first hot war in its history by bombing Yugoslavia a year ago, it aroused as much passion as reasoned debate across Britain's political spectrum. Heated arguments over the conflict transcended ideological lines, with members of the Conservative right coming down on opposite sides of the fence just as much as luminaries of the left.

In the fluidity of the post-cold war world the war for Kosovo fitted no easy matrix. It was not fought for oil, or against communism. The code name "humanitarian intervention" which its proponents gave it was not, of course, the whole truth. No countries go to war on the basis of altruism. Nevertheless, the strategic and political interests which prompted the west to act, after considerable hesitation, were not clear cut at the time, and have not become much clearer since. Uncertainty over what the United States and the European Union consider to be their strategy in the Balkans, and whether they agree, is still pronounced.

In this confused continuity, the main questions which divided opinion at the start of the war remain just as contested today. Was it necessary? Was it legitimate? We would still say yes to both. By the time of the bombing, 200,000 Albanian civilians were displaced within Kosovo and another 50,000 were refugees outside. Repeated demands by the six-nation contact group, of which Russia was a full member, for Yugoslav security forces to stop their repression in Kosovo had been flouted, as had several resolutions of the United Nations security council. Some form of external restraint was needed. A major difficulty was that the council frequently wills a goal but not the method for reaching it. The west's failure to seek authorisation from the council for military action was understandable but serious, though, paradoxically, the bombing acquired greater legal cover three days after it started when the Russians asked the council to demand an immediate end and were outvoted by 12 to three. But if this meant that Nato's intervention was neither legal nor illegal, it was legitimate in that Yugoslavia's defiance of the UN had launched a humanitarian catastrophe.

The questions, which could only be answered after the military action was over, are whether the war was efficient and successful. This paper repeatedly criticised the bombing strategy and its wide range of non-military targets. We argued for a ground operation. But the civilian casualties caused by the air strikes were relatively low - around 500 deaths according to Human Rights Watch, of which most were not in Belgrade or other Serbian cities but in Kosovo itself. Although this toll will rise because of Nato's unjustifiable reluctance to defuse its own unexploded cluster bombs, the record is not so horrendous as some imply.

The most troubling issue is whether Nato's bombing made things worse. In the short term it did, because Milosevic used it to intensify his ethnic cleansing, resulting in several thousand murders and a huge outpouring of refugees. In the long term it did not, because after 78 days he withdrew his forces and let international peacekeepers come in and restore freedom from fear to the majority of Kosovo's people. That Serbs now feel under pressure, if they have not fled altogether, and that Kosovo faces major problems in rebuilding are issues to which western governments must respond with greater urgency. But they are not a result of the bombing. The man primarily responsible is still in Belgrade.

The west's failure to seek authorisation from the council for military action was understandable but serious, though, paradoxically, the bombing acquired greater legal cover three days after it started when the Russians asked the council to demand an immediate end and were outvoted by 12 to three. But if this meant that Nato's intervention was neither legal nor illegal, it was legitimate in that Yugoslavia's defiance of the UN had launched a humanitarian catastrophe. The questions, which could only be answered after the military action was over, are whether the war was efficient and successful. This paper repeatedly criticised the bombing strategy and its wide range of non-military targets. We argued for a ground operation. But the civilian casualties caused by the air strikes were relatively low - around 500 deaths according to Human Rights Watch, of which most were not in Belgrade or other Serbian cities but in Kosovo itself. Although this toll will rise because of Nato's unjustifiable reluctance to defuse its own unexploded cluster bombs, the record is not so horrendous as some imply. The most troubling issue is whether Nato's bombing made things worse. In the short term it did, because Milosevic used it to intensify his ethnic cleansing, resulting in several thousand murders and a huge outpouring of refugees. In the long term it did not, because after 78 days he withdrew his forces and let international peacekeepers come in and restore freedom from fear to the majority of Kosovo's people. That Serbs now feel under pressure, if they have not fled altogether, and that Kosovo faces major problems in rebuilding are issues to which western governments must respond with greater urgency. But they are not a result of the bombing. The man primarily responsible is still in Belgrade.

fields.headline: When red tape is right
fields.standfirst: A chance for peers to turn official faces red
fields.trailText: Ministerial shilly-shallying over long-term care should haunt this government. First it was kicked into the long grass with the appointment of a royal commission. Then when it reported a year ago calling for the introduction of free nursing and personal care for all with means tests restricted to living and housing costs, it was put on hold again. Yet the issue is not going to go away.
fields.body:
Ministerial shilly-shallying over long-term care should haunt this government. First it was kicked into the long grass with the appointment of a royal commission. Then when it reported a year ago calling for the introduction of free nursing and personal care for all with means tests restricted to living and housing costs, it was put on hold again. Yet the issue is not going to go away. About 30% of the 500,000 people in long-term care are currently paying for their care. Thousands of homes have been sold to pay for that care. Yet still there has been no decision. Worse still, ministers are still refusing to accept a related recommendation from the royal commission of the need for proper regulation of long-term care insurance. Peers have a chance to force a decision in the Lords today.

Long-term care insurance is usually bought by older people, frequently when they are on the point of going into care as a means of protecting their assets should they live for a long time. The present market is small - about 30,000 policies - but is expected to expand rapidly. In the wake of the pension mis-selling scandal, the royal commission was unanimous in its call for proper regulation of these policies. Most of the clients being frail and elderly are even more vulnerable than the people who bought dud pension schemes. A responsible government would introduce regulations to ensure any such policies are sold responsibly. The royal commission's proposal is supported by the personal investment authority, the Burns committee which scrutinised the bill before its introduction, the industry itself and the new financial services authority. The only opposition - apart from cowboy salesmen - has come from ministers, who seem petrified of being tagged as lovers of red tape. An amendment to be moved today to the financial services and markets bill would ensure proper regulation. Peers should step in where pusillanimous ministers fear to tread.

webTitle: It's a whole new Bahl game

fields.headline: It's a whole new Bahl game
fields.trailText: It was only because of Kamlesh Bahl, suspended bully and alleged victim of sex and race discrimination (the two are not incompatible) that the Law Society had to abandon its traditional October annual conference in Birmingham. The dates, she pointed out, clashed with Diwali, which meant she wouldn't be able to be there for the lawyers' bash.
fields.body:
It was only because of Kamlesh Bahl, suspended bully and alleged victim of sex and race discrimination (the two are not incompatible) that the Law Society had to abandon its traditional October annual conference in Birmingham. The dates, she pointed out, clashed with Diwali, which meant she wouldn't be able to be there for the lawyers' bash.

Seeing that she would, by then, have become the society's top honcho, and that a presidentless event was unthinkable, the whole extravaganza was moved (it now won't happen until October 2001, though a makeshift small London do is planned for this November) and lots of bookings, functions and arrangements had to be undone.

Now that Bahl is unlikely to be present at all, the whole expensive conference fiasco will have been for naught. Diwali 2000 will cleverly have been avoided - for a white, probably male president who, for sure, won't be a Hindu.

I've learned not to describe anything legal as unprecedented but I'm sure that this has been the first lawsuit against a prime minister arising from the failure of a newspaper-owner to be in the House of Lords. You'll remember that last year Tory leader William Hague recommended Telegraph proprietor Conrad Black for a life peerage. But because Black is Canadian, he had to get the consent of his own government to be allowed to accept the honour.

It should have been a courteous formality. To his rage, Canadian prime minister Jean Chrétien refused. Black sued, claiming Chrétien had no right to block his peerage. The Ontario Superior Court has now ruled otherwise. Chrétien was merely exercising his crown prerogative in the conduct of foreign affairs. But Black is entitled to sue the federal government, the judge ruled, so we may still one day see Lord Black of Canary Wharf at Westminster.

Barristers, contrary to their image, do a great deal of voluntary work for free. Almost every barrister I know helps out with bits of legal advice, or drafting of documents, on behalf of causes from small local appeals to nationwide campaigns. Indeed, the bar often draws atten tion to all the unsung, unpublicised work barristers do for nothing - which makes the Bar Council's attitude towards Peter Marsh all the more perplexing.

He used to give free legal guidance at clinics run by the organisation Families Need Fathers, a registered charity which seeks better rights for fathers following marriage breakdown. The Bar Council heard about it and told him to stop - the rules say a barrister can only supply legal services, even for free, if briefed by a professional client (usually a solicitor). There is a scheme by which organisations could be "designated" as advice centres, but FNF was refused such designation, on what criteria is uncertain.

So either hundreds of barristers are acting unprofessionally when they give of their time for good causes which can't afford to pay, and the Bar Council will presumably be taking stiff action against all of them, as they did with Peter Marsh, or they've picked out Marsh and FNF for special attention. Which?

Portraying living people in Hollywood films, except heroically, is jolly difficult. If you out them in a bad light they sue you for millions, and then you have to prove that they're as awful as you've shown them. In The Insider, just opened in Britain, a whistleblower, Jeffrey Wigand, reveals the sinister secrets of the tobacco company for which he's worked, only to be betrayed by the television company who'd persuaded him to go public.

His wife, called Liane in the film, is shown as a wimpish uncomprehending figure who, far from standing by her man through thick and thin, scarpers at the first sign of trouble. The real wife - called Lucretia - has now emerged and started legal proceedings against Disney, alleging that they used her life without her permission and portrayed her disparagingly. I see lots of money changing hands, much of it veering towards her lawyer's pocket.

The most unpleasant character in the film, though, is a young, ultra-confident patronising woman lawyer at CBS who advises her bosses not to show the programme featuring Wigand. So far, I've heard nothing about a lawsuit from her. Which could mean a) the real one is just like that b) she's not like that, but is chuffed with her portrayal or c) she's fictional, and the real nasty lawyer was an elderly smiling male.

In a certain sense I didn't give you as much guidance as you might have wished, but I expect you noted the omission and acted accordingly. For reasons of limited space - OK, let's be honest, for reasons of my forgetting - the following sentence didn't find its way into the final item last week: "The horse may not win, but it should come second, so put on an each way bet." Hors la Loi III finished an excellent runner-up in the Champion Hurdle at better odds than expected, so I was able to buy at a least half a dot.com share on the winnings. More importantly, it means that my policy of investing in the velocity and stamina of horses with legal names is once again showing profit.

fields.headline: Youngsters who suffer twice
fields.standfirst: Clare Dyer on how young victims of sex crimes lose out on compensation
fields.trailText: Clare Dyer on how young victims of sex crimes lose out on compensation.
fields.body:
Taken into care at the age of six, S had a turbulent childhood and adolescence. He was adopted by his foster parents, but rejected at 13 and sent back into care. He went to a foster family but was moved after an army cadet made allegations of sexual assault at a training camp against the foster father.

S stayed with other foster families before asking to be moved to a children's home because he couldn't cope with being in a family. When he came out of care, he moved from place to place, never finding a proper job but supporting himself by stealing. He took an overdose of paracetamol and spent time in young offender institutions for stealing.

Eventually he disclosed that his foster father, who was convicted of sexual assaults on other children, had frequently buggered him. A psychiatrist said he showed typical features of post-traumatic stress disorder.

L's childhood and teenage years were just as grossly disturbed. When she was four, her parents put her and her younger brother into care. Her parents told social services they were freelance photographers who had to go to the Caribbean to produce a book. For nearly two years, the children lived with foster parents. Soon after she was reunited with her parents, L disclosed that her foster father had sexually abused her. Years later he was convicted of sexual assaults on a number of children, including L, and sentenced to 10 years in prison. A psychiatrist who saw L at 21 found evidence of a personality disorder throughout her teens with multiple pregnancies, truanting, shoplifting, fraud and a suicide attempt. She failed at school and had a poor work record.

S and L were both awarded compensation by the Criminal Injuries Compensation Authority, the state body which compensates victims of violent crime. But in each case the award was reduced - because of their own criminal records. The assaults on S were judged to be worth £12,000, but the award was reduced to £9,000. L received £7,500.

Yet surely their offending is part of the whole picture of disturbed behaviour, just as much as the suicide attempts and truanting. Many of the survivors of sex abuse at children's homes in North Wales and elsewhere have criminal records.

Not all the after-effects, including criminal behaviour, can be blamed entirely on the abuse: many children who go into care have suffered harm from poor parenting in their early years. But the abuse is likely to have damaged further their chances of becoming functioning adults, as the criminal injuries scheme recognises. Why penalise them twice?

Even more unfairly, the scheme refuses to award compensation for sex assaults on youngsters below the age of consent who appear to have participated willingly. If the child did not resist, the reasoning goes, the crime is not violent and therefore not covered by the scheme.

Last week the High Court rejected a challenge to the authority's refusal to compensate a girl who, aged 12, was plied with drink and induced to have sex with an adult in a wood. He was convicted of unlawful sexual intercourse but she was refused compensation because the authority decided it was not a crime of violence. This interpretation is now to be challenged in the Appeal Court by Carl August, who was buggered by a 53-year-old when he was a 13-year-old rent boy. His lawyers argue that since a 13-year-old's consent is not a defence to a charge of buggery, he should not be held to have consented.

They also contend that he was unable to give a valid consent anyway: a psychiatrist's report at the time describes him as a "grossly psychologically disturbed and damaged 13-year-old boy, living in the care system, who was incapable of giving consent." Too many children who go into the care system end up as victims of abuse. The crime compensation scheme should not turn them into double victims.

webTitle: Extra British troops to watch over Albanian extremists

fields.headline: Extra British troops to watch over Albanian extremists
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Britain is to send 170 troops and two helicopters to Kosovo to help in surveillance work amid growing concern within Nato about attempts by ethnic Albanian hardliners to extend the conflict in the region.
fields.body:
Britain is to send 170 troops and two helicopters to Kosovo to help in surveillance work amid growing concern within Nato about attempts by ethnic Albanian hardliners to extend the conflict in the region.

Geoffrey Hoon, the defence secretary, announced yesterday that two Gazelle helicopters would be deployed to the province, along with men from the Phoenix battalion of the Royal Artillery.

The Ministry of Defence said that the Phoenix - an unmanned surveillance vehicle - and the Gazelles would be used to survey the activities of armed Albanians who have been infiltrating the Presevo valley area of southern Serbia, over the border from Kosovo.

They would also be used over the Kosovan town of Mitrovice where groups of Serbs and ethnic Albanians have been attacking K-For peacekeeping troops as well as each other.

"A number of countries are looking at how they can increase their commitment," Mr Hoon told the BBC. "Our contribution will be in this specialist role. Getting more information and intelligence about what is going on is vital to our job there."

He said he was unable to predict how long British troops would be involved in Kosovo, saying that they would have to stay "as long as it takes" to stabilise the security situation. Nato commanders have said K-For troops are likely to be needed in the province for at least four years.

Mr Hoon also admitted that unexploded Nato cluster bombs left over from last year's air campaign had being triggered by Kosovans as they returned to their homes, though he could not confirm numbers of dead or injured. The bombs are considered to be more deadly than landmines.

The independent monitoring group, Human Rights Watch, last month reported that the RAF continued to drop the cluster bombs after the White House issued an executive order stopping US pilots using them. The order followed a raid on the Serbian town of Nis which killed 14 civilians, the New York-based group disclosed.

The Guardian reported last week that Washington was refusing to allow US troops to remove the thousands of unexploded cluster bombs dropped by Nato on Kosovo. As well as falling wide, about 28,000 of the canisters failed to explode.

Each cluster bomb unit, containing up to 200 weapons, opens up at about 2,000ft, unleashing a hail of the bomb canisters that swamp an area the size of four football pitches with lethal shrapnel.

Mr Hoon said yesterday that the MoD was investigating the use of alternative weapons to replace indiscriminate cluster bombs.

webTitle: Talks to reopen as Israel hands over land

fields.headline: Talks to reopen as Israel hands over land
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Israeli cabinet yesterday approved the handover of 6.1% of the West Bank to full Palestinian control, paving the way for the renewal of talks outside Washington tomorrow.
fields.body:
The Israeli cabinet yesterday approved the handover of 6.1% of the West Bank to full Palestinian control, paving the way for the renewal of talks outside Washington tomorrow.

The handover will bring a total of 39.8% of West Bank land under full or partial Palestinian control, said the deputy defence minister, Ephraim Sneh. He added: "Sixty percent of the [West Bank Palestinian] population and all the major cities, from this week, will be under full Palestinian authority."

The handover had been planned for January 20, but was delayed due to disagreements over the areas to be transferred.

Tomorrow's renewed Israeli-Palestinian talks, expected to last a fortnight, are aimed at sealing a permanent peace treaty by September. A dispute over the handover map had held up talks on all aspects of a treaty, which had been meant to address such key issues as Palestinian refugees, the fate of Jerusalem and Jewish settlements.

Palestinians had demanded that the handover include areas near Arab east Jerusalem, which they claim as the capital of a state they hope to establish in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel captured east Jerusalem in 1967 and regards all of Jerusalem as its capital.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the president of the Palestinian Authority, Yasser Arafat, smoothed over the land transfer issue earlier this month in a summit that gave rise to the resumption of talks. But Mr Barak, bowing to pressure last week, decided against including the village of Abu Dis, next to Jerusalem, in the 6.1% transfer.

Mr Sneh said decisions over handovers affecting Jerusalem would be made in talks on a permanent peace accord.

Israel also released five Palestinian prisoners jailed for anti-Israel activity and promised to release 10 more today as a goodwill gesture.

fields.headline: Girl talk
fields.standfirst: Does the way a woman speaks say more about her than the way she looks?  Anita Chaudhuri listens in to what the experts have to say
fields.trailText: Does the way a woman speaks say more about her than the way she looks?  Anita Chaudhuri listens in to what the experts have to say.
fields.body:
Which part of a woman is routinely scrutinised for signs of sex, power and money? Sadly it's not her brain; nor is it any asset with greater pulchritudinous allure. According to the latest findings from the feminist linguistics frontline, it is her voice.

The current speculation over whether Sue MacGregor, stalwart of Radio 4's Today programme, is about to retire and which female presenter might fill her shoes tends to suggest that women's voices are judged in a different way from the dulcet tones of men, particularly in public life. Unofficially, the Today contest is rumoured to be between two candidates: Sarah Montague, who speaks with clipped southern vowels, and Winifred Robinson, whose accent still betrays a Mersey childhood. Robinson is a seasoned Radio 4 broadcaster, while Montague works for Sky and made her debut on Today only two weeks ago.

Media coverage has made much of the women's accents, although, strangely, no one made such a big deal about the Scottish and Welsh brogues of co-presenters Jim Naughtie and John Humphrys when they were appointed. Frankly, I'm not that surprised. Any woman with a strongly identifiable accent will be all too familiar with the social stereotyping that comes from not sounding like Celia Johnson in Brief Encounter.

If, like me, you have a Scottish accent, then you will regularly have to suffer cracks about sounding like Kirsty Wark (frosty), the girl from the Spirito di Punto car ad (up for it) or, worst of all, Muriel Gray (scary). Regardless of gender, accents breed stereotypes. We all know that if you sound Scottish, you must be a tight-fisted drunk who's spoiling for a fight. But for women, those judgments are more personal, even if for no other reason than that we take such comments more personally.

"Women's voices are judged in a different way from men's," asserts Deborah Cameron, linguistics professor and author of Good to Talk? (published by Sage this week) which examines the fetish of communication in our working and private lives. "Research has shown that a woman with an accent will be judged in terms of her sexual availability and relative femininity. A man with a rough accent will merely be perceived as being lower class; a woman with the same accent will be regarded as being of a lower sexual class. This was found to be particularly true of women with strong cockney and scouse accents who were judged to have 'rough mouths' and be sexually available."

Cameron points out that the female broadcasting voice in vogue is what she terms "the voice of perceived androgyny. That's probably why there are so many neutral female Scottish accents on TV - they have authority without exploiting their femininity."

Lucy Rouse, editor of Broadcast magazine, believes there's a wider issue at stake. "Women in broadcasting and in public life can get away with less and that's why they are often derided for the way they speak. Yes, certain accents are perceived as sexy on a woman - Scottish, Irish and French, for example - and others - like Scouse and Welsh - are not. At the end of the day, particularly in broadcasting, the voice is about establishing authority. That's going to be harder for a woman to begin with and that's really why they are judged so harshly."

Certainly there have been dozens of high-profile women who have been vilified for the way they speak. Janet Street-Porter, for example, was dubbed "the talking Tannoy", while Margaret Thatcher had voice training to drop hers to a lower pitch.

"Women make more effort than men to change their voices; they are more driven to adapt," explains Philippa Davies who runs VoiceWorks, a voice training consultancy that was part of the Labour campaign taskforce at the last election. "Research from one Australian university recently revealed that women's speaking voices have been getting progressively lower in pitch since the 40s. That change isn't biological, it's about social conditioning."

She points out that, regardless of accent, women with lower pitch are taken far more seriously in public life. "Thatcher went through the most rigorous training to get that deep voice. And it's no surprise that Annie Nightingale, with her low growl, was one of the first female radio stars. A low pitch suggests confidence and authority, probably because that's how men sound. Many women, especially when they are emotional, speak in a higher range."

Davies witnessed first-hand the extent to which women's voices are judged when she trained 110 of the last intake of Labour MPs. "Gisela Stuart, now junior health minister, had a terrible time because she had a slight German accent. The male Tory candidate in her constituency went to town about that in a way I don't think anyone would have done to a man."

Davies points out politics reflects the general trend that women are more likely than men to adopt "high-status" accents. It's a good point. For men, having a strong working-class or regional accent carries a suggestion of honesty and virility. Thus in politics we have an endless drone of Scottish blokes, with the odd Welshman thrown in, and of course William Hague's eagerness to assert his Yorkshire roots.

But there are few strong female accents in politics. There's Clare Short with her watered-down Brummie tones, but Mo Mowlam's voice is pure Mother Courage and Edwina Currie famously altered her scouse accent to become more socially acceptable.

Linguistic theorists are keen to draw parallels between accent and sexuality, but for some at least this idea is absurd. "When it comes to employing girls to work on our phone sex lines, accent is the last thing we judge them on," says Mary, who works for IAS, a company that runs adult chatlines. "I have never come across a man who has complained about a particular accent or requested to talk to someone with, say, an Irish accent. That's the last thing on their minds. And when it comes to employing people, the biggest talent is keeping the caller on the line - not necessarily the same thing as having a sexy accent."

Sex workers aside, there is a whole new segment of the workforce whose earning power relies on their voices. In her book, Deborah Cameron examines how far talking has become the basis for many professions. She conducted substantial research into call centres, traditionally major employers of women. There, accents count for a great deal, with many choosing to base their offices in Scotland and the north-east.

"Call centres are the reverse of mass media," she says. "They don't want women to sound authoritative, they want people with soothing, slightly socially subordinate accents. The last thing they want is anyone who sounds RP."

Cameron predicts that in future, all public talk will become increasingly feminised: "That means having very expressive intonations, asking lots of questions and encouraging the other person to do all the talking." She reports that male call-centre workers have already begun rebelling against the perceived loss of their masculinity. "They don't realise it," she points out, "but soon everyone will be talking like that."
