fields.headline: That drinking feeling
fields.standfirst: How's a girl to get served at the bar these days?  Emma Warren reveals all
fields.trailText: It is Friday night and it's your turn to go to the bar. You skim the five-deep, 15-wide scrum of suited and booted weekenders and sum up the options. Is now a good time to try out the elbow barge, or would a money-waving "Oi!" get a V&T in double-quick time? Alternatively, do you stand by the till, lean in at 45 degrees and mould your features into a rabbit-in-the-headlights panic?
fields.body:
It is Friday night and it's your turn to go to the bar. You skim the five-deep, 15-wide scrum of suited and booted weekenders and sum up the options. Is now a good time to try out the elbow barge, or would a money-waving "Oi!" get a V&T in double-quick time? Alternatively, do you stand by the till, lean in at 45 degrees and mould your features into a rabbit-in-the-headlights panic?

Choose the latter, reckons a recent survey by Guinness, and you'll be walking away, beverage in hand, long before the pushers and shouters. And while you're at it, see if the bloke to your left is trying to flirt: the same survey found female bar staff were likely to ignore flirtatious male customers for the entire evening. "Girls often serve girls first," agrees 24-year-old Lulie, who has worked in bars in London, Sydney and Bath, "especially if they are surrounded by guys on the pick-up. But if they think girls are flirting with them, they'll ignore them, too. Harassed bar staff are temperamental creatures."

"I think women are smarter than guys about getting a drink," suggests Nathalie, a 26-year-old with five years' experience in the industry. "Guys'll just go up and check out the women, or annoy the bar staff by being pushy. Women seem to plan it better, go back to the same part of the bar they were served at before and go for the same bartender."

Londoner Sophie, 29, agrees. "I think men try to project themselves at the bar by being aggressive. Women do it more subtly, using body language and eye contact."

Working behind a bar now demands new levels of what Nathalie calls "combat bartending". "Girls who work behind the bar have to be, not defeminised, but harder. You're dealing with leery guys all the time, using lines like 'Remember, darling, I like a lot of head ... on my beer'."

Lulie agrees. "You have to be quick with the ones suffering testosterone overload. I find sarky quips go a long way. And I always ignore the really lecherous ones."

Even though it has been 30-odd years since pubs were democratised (a note to those under 30: ask your mum if she ever went to the pub), some things have not changed. Through Friday night beer-tinted glasses, misplaced ideas about customer service, female bartenders and the residual sexism of a male-dominated arena can sometimes turn a simple financial transaction into a hotbed of sexual politics.

"I think the bar is a horrible place to be," Sophie says. "I normally send my boyfriend. If you try to assert yourself, you end up with aggressive men pushing you away and generally being very unpleasant."

Being sober while everyone else is drunk can be extremely revealing. Not only do you witness what drunk people really look like (all downwards sloping eyes and bendy mouths), you also get to watch regulars acting out different roles. One man at a pub I worked in for two summers would morph from attentive boyfriend to slathering sex-machine within one nanosecond of girlfriend leaving the pub. My sister, who works at a salsa bar, says within seconds of pulling up a seat at the bar after working a shift, she'll have 10 men pulling her arm for a "dance". "They think that once you've been working behind the bar, you're available. It's like, er, no. Some people have very odd ideas about customer service."

But let's face it. Waiting for a drink, you are more likely to encounter a mildly annoying (or mildly ego-boosting, depending on your mood) flirt than serious harassment. "The bar is actually quite a safe environment," Nathalie says, "and you only spend a minute interacting with the person behind it."

The same goes for the two blokes you are squashed up next to. You are in close, potentially sexual proximity, but not for too long. You queue, you buy, you return to your friends. So remember, gender politics are bringing a whole new meaning to the phrase: "Are you being served?" Get a cob on while you're waiting for a drink, flirt too hard with the lady in charge, and your local watering hole might well get a touch dry. And you certainly won't get served.

fields.headline: Parking mad
fields.trailText: It is bad for my mother to be stuck too long in her broiling bedroom with the fan-heater and telly roaring on, so we planned a thrilling outing into town. What luck that we have an orange disabled badge but what a shock to find a ticket stuck on the car. Whatever for? There is the warden, only yards away. I demand an explanation.
fields.body:
It is bad for my mother to be stuck too long in her broiling bedroom with the fan-heater and telly roaring on, so we planned a thrilling outing into town. What luck that we have an orange disabled badge but what a shock to find a ticket stuck on the car. Whatever for? There is the warden, only yards away. I demand an explanation.

"You've been there more than an hour," lies the warden. I have not. I can prove it. There is the orange badge, indicating our time of arrival.

"Did you put money in first?" he asks, just managing not to smirk. It is difficult, when one is in a raging temper, to spot a trick question. No, I answer. That was my big mistake. I had forgotten we were in Westminster where normal rules do not apply. Here you must pay the minimum fee, then you can stay for an hour. Be warned. This is a secret until you get caught and punished, or unless you've read your disabled parking booklet carefully, phoned up the Westminster Disabled Parking number and found out what the rules are. But you can't because this number is only for paying fines or having clamps removed. Otherwise all the operators are busy, please try later.

I have a scream at the warden. He has ruined our outing. My mother stands pale and trembling, clutching her zimmer. And she has forgotten her angina spray.

We drive round the corner to Cousin's flat. But dare we park on a yellow line with our useless badge? I jump out, ring Cousin's bell, screech at her to come downstairs because here comes the warden again, searching for cripples to persecute. I run and ask him if I may park on a yellow line."No, park in a bay," says he. There isn't one.

What am I meant to do with my collapsing 93-year-old mother? She did want to visit Cousin for a cup of tea, but she can't. I have another scream and drive round in circles waiting for Cousin. Warden couldn't care diddly-squat. He's on a roll. Last week I heard Westminster raked in £39m from parking fines, more than any other borough. Now we know how they do it.

fields.headline: Metal exchange story 'treated fairly'
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's independent ombudsman, John Willis, deals with substantial complaints against the paper or matters where its integrity is called into question.
fields.trailText: Complaint
fields.body:
Complaint

The London Metal Exchange complained about an article written on July 1 1999 by Alex Brummer, Guardian financial editor. This followed the fine imposed upon Merrill Lynch of £6.5m for breaches of London Metal Exchange rules in relation to copper trading on behalf of the Sumitomo Corporation.

The London Metal Exchange believes that Mr Brummer "made assertions which were simply wrong in fact", and that the Guardian then refused to publish a letter which set the record straight.

Background

The London Metal Exchange's concern was Mr Brummer's assertion in his article that "it is clear from LME's own account of events that it was the draconian powers possessed by US authorities which unlocked the intricacies of the copper scandal".

The LME, on the other hand, says that by the time the US authorities issued an order against Sumitomo in May 1998 the case against them was very well advanced.

Indeed the LME and the UK Securities and Investment Board began work in 1995 and the actions of the US authorities were based upon the exhaustive investigative work from the UK. The British investigators cooperated with their counterparts throughout.

Conclusions

I read all the relevant documentation and interviewed both parties at length. In the context I believe the Guardian handled the story fairly and was within its rights not to publish the letter from the LME.

Mr Brummer's piece was clearly an opinion column, and as such was "fair comment".

The piece could perhaps have made more of the role of the British investigation and the improvements in regulatory practices at the LME over the recent period. However, given the nature of a five-day-a-week comment column, this incompleteness was not surprising.

Even if the LME is correct in saying that the Americans did not actually "unlock" the scandal in 1998, it is clear that the US's stronger regulatory powers were crucial in the conclusion of this affair.

Any incompleteness or what the LME calls inaccuracy in Mr Brummer's column was balanced by a long news report in the same edition by Dan Atkinson. This report quoted the LME press release at length and made readers aware that the LME had played a major role in this investigation.

Taken together on the day the Guardian treated this story fairly.

The letter sent to the letters editor claims that "Alex Brummer's commentary is factually wrong".

I am sure that if the LME had confined itself to clarifying its important role in this investigation the letter would have been published.

However, to accuse a journalist of getting his/her facts wrong is a serious matter, particularly as the Guardian had led the way on the copper scandal, devoting time and resources to a major investigation over a year.

Not unreasonably, it believed that the article was justified comment and fair on the LME, particularly when Dan Atkinson's sister article was taken into account. In this overall context, to have expected the Guardian to have published a letter was not unfair, but to expect it to have published a charge of "factual inaccuracy" was, under all the circumstances, not reasonable.

In my view, the Guardian behaved reasonably in not publishing the letter.

fields.headline: Farmers seek newpastures in Canada
fields.standfirst: More head west for the prairies' wide open spaces at bargain prices
fields.trailText: Farmers fed up with red tape, depleted bank accounts and leaden skies are quitting Britain for the vast prairies of central Canada.
fields.body:
Farmers fed up with red tape, depleted bank accounts and leaden skies are quitting Britain for the vast prairies of central Canada.

Wooed by real estate managers who cross the Atlantic to tell in village halls up and down the country of rich land at bargain prices, owners and tenants are selling up, leaving farms their families have often worked for generations.

The traffic west is a reminder of the great 19th century migrations, particularly from Scotland, to the wide open spaces in the new world. Interest is growing as confidence in the future of farming wavers. "I don't paint a picture of paradise but I tell them they are likely to win better rewards for the same effort," said Maurice Torr of the Century 21 corporation in Brandon, Manitoba.

"I visit Britain once a year, usually during February when farms are quiet, and advertise in local papers. This year I held about 30 meetings and met about 650 people."

British farmers complained to him of bureaucracy gone mad, plunging cattle prices and negative incomes. He told them of the fine land by the Red River for sale at just £450 an acre: the price of Canadian land is a fraction of the rates in Britain.

"Farmers want freedom and Canada is a country where farmers can farm," added Mr Torr, who emigrated from Staffordshire seven years ago.

James Sykes, 37, who grazes sheep on Pennine moors owned by the National Trust above Marsden, West Yorkshire, heard Mr Torr's message and glimpsed the promised land.

With his wife Joanne, he flies to Winnipeg in June to search for 2,000 acres on which to raise cattle and grow grain. "We first went to Manitoba in 1997 and my first impression was of how vast the countryside is. There are very few regulations and you can do what you want.

"When we were getting on the plane to come home, I had tears in my eyes and a lump in my throat. There are great opportunities out there."

Mr Sykes took over the farm from his father in 1983 and until 1996 made a decent profit. "Since then, everything has gone down hill. Britain doesn't want farmers any more. This government would rather import food than have farmers produce it here."

And then there's the weather: "You get summer and winter there. Here we get only wind and rain."

webTitle: Hunting complaint rejected by Guardian ombudsman

fields.headline: Hunting complaint rejected by Guardian ombudsman
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's independent ombudsman, John Willis, deals with substantial complaints against the paper or matters where its integrity is called into question.
fields.trailText: Background
fields.body:
Background

Alasdair Mitchell complained that on October 18 1999 the paper ignored a huge protest march in Newcastle upon Tyne in support of hunting. Two days after the Guardian failed to carry a news report of the Newcastle march it published a front page story by Peter Hetherington titled Hunt job losses claims are rebutted. "This news story," said Mr Mitchell, "lacked proper journalistic objectivity and was presented without sufficient scrutiny, with the result that some readers may have been misled." The response to his initial complaint was "more of a dismissal than an explanation, being unduly defensive and somewhat hostile".

Ignoring the demonstration and publishing an anti-hunting story within two days, said Mr Mitchell, "raises questions about the paper's reputation for straight reporting."

Findings

The decision not to publish the story of the demonstration was a matter of news judgment. It was the largest ever protest in Newcastle, on the other hand on a national scale bigger protests have not been reported by the Guardian and other newspapers. The decisions of those running the news pages on the Guardian, or any other newspaper, are fine ones and some readers will not agree with all news judgments that are made but this judgment was defensible.

I can find no evidence to support Mr Mitchell's serious allegation that the Guardian's anti-hunting stance influenced its decision not to report the Newcastle protest march.

A search of the Guardian's leading articles for nearly two years prior to the demonstration reveals no clear statement against hunting.

It was only on November 12, after both the demonstration and Mr Mitchell's initial complaint, that the paper ran a leader headed Time for hunting to disappear into history.

Both the Guardian newsdesk and Peter Hetherington assert that their decisions were in no way influenced by the paper's policy on hunting.

Given that there is absolutely no evidence to the contrary it is reasonable that they should be believed.

Mr Mitchell claims that Peter Hetherington's article of October 20 was "distorted" because "he failed to take into account a number of salient facts he either knew or should have known".

This allegation centres on the figures in Mr Hetherington's news report which came from a report by Dr Neil Ward of Newcastle University. Mr Mitchell states that (a) Dr Ward's report was not new and (b) Dr Ward has associations with a relevant pressure group and close links with the Labour party.

Mr Mitchell is right in saying that the report was first published in March 1998, not September 1999, and that some work on the figures had previously been undertaken by Dr Ward for a television programme in 1997.

However, the September publication was the first time that publication had been peer reviewed, giving the study additional credibility, before publication in the Journal of Rural Studies.

Dr Ward says that he did some additional work on the study before academic scrutiny and that it could legitimately be regarded as new.

Whether the Guardian was justified in using the word "today" in Peter Hetherington's report of October 20 is a moot point. In my view, they were not. This may have given the article a sense of up-to-the-minute topicality. However, it did not diminish the basic value or integrity of the information in the paper's report.

The report by Dr Ward, on behalf of Newcastle University, was partly funded by the International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW), the anti-hunting group. This was not mentioned in the original Guardian report.

However, Dr Ward's study has been reviewed by his academic peers and he is clear that funding sources had no impact upon the figures contained in the report. Indeed, he is unhappy about Mr Mitchell's attack on his integrity and independence as an academic.

Dr Ward has confirmed that he was not a member of the Labour party or any other political party and that his period in the Cabinet Office was as a civil servant, not as a political appointee.

Mr Mitchell also alleges that the RSPCA, which is opposed to hunting, "cleared" the use of this data with Dr Ward. Dr Ward says he in fact rang the RSPCA to complain about its behaviour.

Ideally, the Guardian should not have used the word "today" and also referred to the partial funding source of Dr Ward's study. However, those two minor points do not impinge upon the basic accuracy of Dr Ward's figures, nor amount to "distorted" news reporting.

On November 18, a month after the Newcastle march, Peter Hetherington wrote a balanced analysis article which carefully gave space to both sides of the debate, including the impact on rural jobs.

Mr Mitchell complains that the Guardian's response to his complaint was a disgrace. Within 10 days he received a detailed and robust reply to his lengthy complaint from the readers' editor, Ian Mayes.

After this reply Mr Mitchell withdrew his original allegation that Peter Hetherington had been a conduit, willing or otherwise, of anti-hunting propaganda. He rang Mr Hetherington to apologise, but Mr Hetherington said he found the complaint offensive and put the phone down.

In my view Mr Mayes dealt conscientiously and quickly with a serious and detailed complaint. Given the vehemence of Mr Mitchell's allegations, Mr Hetherington's behaviour on the telephone was unsurprising, if impatient.

Conclusion

This is a serious complaint going right to the heart of the paper's journalistic integrity.

It is a complaint that I reject.

webTitle: Food industry rises to the demand for non-GM food

fields.headline: Food industry rises to the demand for non-GM food
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The food industry is to advise supermarkets and processing companies how to secure supplies of conventionally grown crops in response to the consumer demand for products without genetically modified ingredients.
fields.body:
The food industry is to advise supermarkets and processing companies how to secure supplies of conventionally grown crops in response to the consumer demand for products without genetically modified ingredients.

It hopes to encourage new deals with soya and maize growers in the US who have resisted pressure to switch to GM production, in order to ensure a broad range of products remains free of GM material.

The proposals for new standards on sourcing from non-GM crops comes days after the government decided to press ahead with farm-scale trials of GM crops in England and Scotland.

It represents a massive shift in attitude for the industry which two years ago claimed it was virtually impossible to segregate non-GM soya from the new strains during stor age, transport and processing.

Soya is in about 60% of all processed foods, including biscuits, soft drinks, ready-made meals, bread, chocolate and baby food while maize is found in baby food, crisps, confectionery and a variety of snacks.

Many supermarkets such as Iceland have already moved to protect some non-GM supplies but the British Retail Consortium and the Food and Drink Federation are to consult members on measures to stop contamination of conventionally prepared ingredients.

These will cover use of separate storage and transportation, cleaning and inspection of equipment, and documentary proof of non-GM status.

An industry insider said: "During the last year it has become clear consumers do not see any benefit in having GM soya or maize in their food and it is becoming the task of UK manufacturers to source from conventional crops. Even if some 60%-plus of the American harvest was GM, there is still a hell of a lot of non-GM."

Last year Britain probably imported about 2m tonnes of US soya, only a small part of the 78m tonne American harvest, but the industry does not know how much of this was non-GM. It now plans to discriminate between GM and non-GM supplies from the US and countries such as Brazil and Argentina.

The industry bodies say their job has been made easier by the European Union allowing 1% accidental contamination before manufacturers are compelled to label their food as containing GM material. The new standards under the voluntary code will not allow companies to call their products GM-free since some emulsifiers and processed oils used in food production are derived from GM sources but are refined to such a degree that GM material is undetectable.

fields.headline: Lindisfarne gospels going home
fields.trailText: The priceless Lindisfarne gospels, one of the oldest surviving works in the English language, are to be returned to the north-east after Tony Blair bowed to pressure from MPs, business and church leaders in the region.
fields.body:
The priceless Lindisfarne gospels, one of the oldest surviving works in the English language, are to be returned to the north-east after Tony Blair bowed to pressure from MPs, business and church leaders in the region.

The manuscripts, written and lavishly illustrated by monks on Northumberland's Holy Island in the 7th century, will be sent on loan from the British Museum to Newcastle's Laing art gallery, the prime minister will announce next month.

From there, it is expected that the gospels, 253 pages of exquisitely preserved calf skin dedicated to St Cuthbert, will leave for a permanent exhibition in Durham Cathedral, close to a choristers' school once attended by Mr Blair and a few miles from his Sedgefield constituency. But other sites being considered as a permanent home for the gospels, which are seen seen as an important tourist attraction, include the Laing gallery and an exhibition dedicated to St Bede at Jarrow, as well as Holy Island - although it can only be reached from the mainland by a causeway, which is impassable during high tides.

Siezed from the cathedral by Henry VIII's commissioners during the Reformation, the gospels now form the centrepiece of an exhibition at the new British Library at King's Cross, London.

Until recently, library officials had been determined to hang on to them, unless ordered otherwise by an act of parliament.

Claims that the gospels were stolen from the north during Henry's dissolution of the monasteries cut little ice on the grounds that the manuscripts were a British masterpiece rather than a north-east treasure.

But Fraser Kemp, MP for Houghton and Washington and a key figure in a cross-party campaign to have the manuscripts returned, revealed yesterday that the prime minister had personally intervened. "They are more important to this area than the Elgin marbles are to the average Greek. They belong in the north-east, not in some horrendous shed in London."

Two years' ago scores of campaigners, including the former Tory MP for Langbaurgh, Michael Bates, and a leading north-east folk musician, Kathryn Tickell, raised a "stand up for the north-east" banner outside the British Library and presented a petition to Downing Street.

Written between 687 and 698AD by Eadfrith, who became successor to St Cuthbert as bishop of Lindisfarne, the gospels represent the best British example of the transcription and illumination process.

The manuscripts, said to have required the skins of 130 calves, contain the four gospels, each opening with three highly ornate pages. They were removed from Holy Island by monks fleeing Viking invaders in 876 and eventually found safety in Durham Cathedral.

Pressure for their return to the north-east grew after they were brought to Newcastle in 1996 - for the first time since being siezed in the 16th century - for an exhibition at the Laing gallery.

fields.headline: 'Untouchables'of the Met drop corrupt supergrass
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police's secretive anti-corruption squad has dropped one of its top supergrasses after two years.
fields.byline: Michael Sean Gillard and Laurie Flynn
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police's secretive anti-corruption squad has dropped one of its top supergrasses after two years.

The surprise move means the supergrass, the convicted former Met detective, Terry McGuinness, will now be sentenced for his own corrupt activities spanning six years.

The decision last week that Mr McGuinness is no longer considered a reliable witness against serving and former officers is an embarrassment for the Met's much-vaunted drive to root out bent coppers.

The complaints investigation branch (CIB3) hoped Mr McGuinness's evidence against his flying squad colleagues would bolster its faltering anti-corruption drive which has so far secured only seven convictions for major corruption in six years.

Earlier this month a Guardian investigation revealed that CIB3, dubbed the untouchables, was using discredited practices and is now the subject of three internal inquiries.

Of great concern is the return of the controversial supergrass system where corrupt officers and criminals are offered inducements such as a reduction in sentence to be served in a safe house, a new identity and financial assistance when freed, to turn Queen's evidence and implicate others in return.

The loss of Mr McGuinness means CIB3 is now relying on two main supergrasses to underpin the anti-corruption drive.

Mr McGuiness, 41, has spent 27 months as a CIB3 supergrass with special privileges. Most of this time will be taken off the heavily reduced sentence he is likely to receive at the Old Bailey in 10 days' time.

He will earn two thirds off his sentence for pleading guilty in September, 1998, to seven counts of corruption, including conspiracy to steal and perverting the course of justice.

Mr McGuinness served at the Rigg Approach flying squad office in east London from 1990 to 1997. He cultivated senior officers and before joining the flying squad served with detectives who are now in senior positions at CIB3.

According to a former CIB3 officer, Mr McGuinness and a fellow officer, Detective Constable Kevin Garner, were put under surveillance in 1995 following a tip-off from an informant inside the Met.

Both officers were finally arrested during a CIB3 drugs sting in December, 1997. They were secretly videoed stealing £500,000 of cannabis placed by CIB3 officers in an east London flat.

McGuinness and Mr Garner decided to "roll over", and became CIB3's first and most important supergrasses.

They made self-incriminating allegations against more than 80 officers for various crimes, including the theft of recovered proceeds from a £300,000 robbery. CIB3 mounted a huge clandestine operation codenamed Ethiopia and suspended a large number of detectives.

But last year the crown prosecution service decided not to proceeded against them, thereby raising the first serious doubts about the value of Mr McGuiness and Mr Garner as witnesses.

A defence solicitor in a big CIB3 corruption case said: "The supergrass-informant system is completely flawed. The police try to clean up people who are mainly criminals and dishonest by presenting them as witnesses of truth in return for large sentence reductions and time in a safe house not prison.

"The lesson is if you are going to commit offences do so on a large scale otherwise you are not in a position to trade when you are caught. That is unacceptable."

The third CIB3 supergrass is an even more controversial figure than the two flying squad officers.

Hector Harvey is a professional criminal linked to various organised crime groups in London.

Commander Andy Hayman, the CIB3 commander, told the Guardian that Mr Harvey was assisting in forthcoming trials against Rigg officers, adding that he had pleaded guilty to 85 counts of armed robbery and related offences. But Mr Hayman will not disclose how many of these robberies were committed while Mr Harvey was a protected witness living in a safe house under a new identity provided by the Met. The figure is believed to be about 30.

CIB Chief Superintendent David Wood said there had been no investigation into the handling of Harvey and he described him as a reliable witness of truth who had been "cleansed of his criminality".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Briton held over heroin find
fields.body:
Briton held over heroin find

A British woman, Alison McKinnon, 37, was yesterday being held by police in Turkey in connection with the seizure of three kilograms of heroin.

She is alleged to have had the drug concealed round her waist when she was arrested at Istanbul airport. Three Turkish men were also arrested. The Foreign Office said: "We will offer any assistance we can."

Miscarriage research

Scientists have launched a two-year investigation into the possible link between miscarriages and lifestyle factors such as drinking, smoking and stress.

The launch of the lottery-funded enterprise, by researchers from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, coincides with the start of Miscarriage Awareness Week.

Krays' jail reunion

Former London gangster Reggie Kray has been transferred from Wayland jail in Norfolk to Parkhurst prison on the Isle of Wight so he can visit his brother Charlie in hospital.

Charlie, 73, is serving 12 years for a drugs conspiracy. The pair have not seen each other since they attended the funeral of Reggie's twin brother, Ronnie, five years ago.

Three die in house fire

A woman and two children died yesterday when fire swept through their semi-detached home in Hale, Greater Manchester.

Three other adults were taken to hospital suffering from smoke inhalation.

Geri's chart hat-trick

Geri Halliwell bagged her third solo number one today - and her hat-trick means she has now fea tured on more chart-toppers than any of her former Spice Girls colleagues.

fields.headline: 'Give Bulger killers 15 years'
fields.trailText: The mother of James Bulger yesterday urged the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, to uphold the 15-year sentences imposed on her son's killers.
fields.body:
The mother of James Bulger yesterday urged the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, to uphold the 15-year sentences imposed on her son's killers.

Lord Bingham is reviewing the sentences after a European court ruled that politicians should not decide how long criminals spend in detention. The sentence was set seven years ago by the then home secretary, Michael Howard, when James's killers, Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, were 10.

James's mother, Denise Fergus, told Sky News: "They should be given a proper sentence, not something stupid like 10 or eight years."

Since they had been detained in a children's home they had been given the best of everything, she said. "They won't realise what they have done until they go to a proper jail. I don't think they can be rehabilitated. How can you rehabilitate two evil little monsters?"

Mr Howard set the 15-year tariff after the then lord chief justice, Lord Taylor, said the two should serve 10 years for murdering James, two, in Bootle, Merseyside, in 1993.

webTitle: British army women to run Sahara marathon

fields.headline: British army women to run Sahara marathon
fields.standfirst: Team faces six-day, 150-mile run over mountains and sand dunes
fields.trailText: Around 3,000 runners will arrive in Morocco next month to take part in the Marathon des Sables, or sands marathon, which has become the ultimate challenge for endurance sports enthusiasts.
fields.body:
It is one of the most arduous races in world sport, an epic test of mind and body that involves tackling the inhospitable terrain and searing temperatures of the Sahara desert.

Around 3,000 runners will arrive in Morocco next month to take part in the Marathon des Sables, or sands marathon, which has become the ultimate challenge for endurance sports enthusiasts.

For the first time, an all British women's team is set to take part in the mega-marathon, which lasts six days and involves tackling desert mountains, giant sand dunes and stony plateaux.

The entire course is almost 150 miles long and some stages of the race involve running the equivalent of two marathons in one day in temperatures topping 38C (100F).

Britain's first women's team is made up of soldiers Kathryn Macphee, Katie Unsworth and Tessa Loyd who are all lieutenants in the Royal Engineers.

They have spent three months undergoing rigorous training that included 30-mile runs each day, often wearing woolly hats and thermal underwear so that they could become accustomed to sweating profusely.

The training schedule involved taking running machines into heat chambers and endurance training in Wales, where they ran daily marathons across giant sand dunes to familiarise themselves with the Sahara's terrain.

"We are in good physical shape but are getting quite nervous," said Lt Macphee. "No amount of preparation in Britain can prepare us for the types of temperatures we are about to face."

The Marathon des Sables, which is now in its 15th year, begins on April 9 and com petitors from 30 countries will take part. Only 12% of racers are female and competitors pay an entry fee of over £2,000.

Runners are given a map and using a compass they have to negotiate their way across the various stages of the race. Water is provided only at the start of each day and competitors have to bring their own rations and medicines and carry their own equipment.

The British women will be running across the Sahara each carrying backpacks weighing almost 7kg (16lb) containing freeze-dry food rations, similar to those used by mountaineers and soldiers in the jungle, energy foods and drinks, most of which have been donated by sponsors.

Runners must prove they are carrying rations amounting to 3,000 calories a day. Many lose up to a stone in weight by the end of the race but the biggest danger is dehydration.

Competitors sleep in bedouin tents provided by organisers but must bring their own sleeping bags.

Lt Macphee said: "More important than physical stamina is mental stamina. We have been on army endurance exercises before but nothing like this."

Race organisers provide a back-up medical team but the most common complaints have been blisters caused by sand getting into trainers.

The British women's team will use special nylon stretched over their trainers to prevent sand from entering.

The women have been given time off from army duties for training and part of their travel costs to Morocco are being met by the army, which insists that if they succeed it will be a great advertisement for women in the forces.

Captain Andy Phipps, media officer for the runners, said: "The army likes to encourage arduous activity overseas. It's very character building."

fields.headline: Parents in work 'good for children'
fields.trailText: Parents are spending more quality time with their children than previous generations, despite having high-pressured and time-consuming jobs, research revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Parents are spending more quality time with their children than previous generations, despite having high-pressured and time-consuming jobs, research revealed yesterday.

A study for Abbey National found the amount of time invested by parents in their children's upbringing had more than trebled over the past three decades. Parents devote an average of 85 minutes a day to each child compared with 25 minutes a day in the mid-1970s.

By 2010, the figure is predicted to leap to 100 minutes, destroying the myth that family life is being damaged as both parents go out to work.

Researchers questioned three generations of families on their attitudes to parenting. When asked to compare their practices with what their parents did, the majority of men and women said they took parenting more seriously.

In every key aspect of parenting and family life explored by researchers, fewer than one in 10 respondents spent less time with their children than their parents did.

Two-thirds of parents claimed they spent more time every day reading with or helping their children with homework.

Full-time working parents were found to spend more time than their part-time and non-working counterparts talking to their children and enjoying leisure activities.

The study - by the Future Foundation - also showed that men were now more involved in their children's lives.

webTitle: Cooker fan hits on cast iron answer

fields.headline: Cooker fan hits on cast iron answer
fields.trailText: A man's passion for collecting cookers has cost him girlfriends and drawn ridicule from his family.
fields.body:
A man's passion for collecting cookers has cost him girlfriends and drawn ridicule from his family.

But James Bunce has hit upon a cast iron scheme to deal with his growing collection of 251 cookers. He is renting storage space to make room in his Gloucestershire home which, despite two garages, is full with a collection that dates from the 1900s.

Mr Bunce, from Cirencester, has had family members make fun of his hobby while relationships have burned out after girlfriends became fed-up with the attention he paid to his cookers.

But he has vowed to keep collecting the pre-1970s stoves, for which he pays anything up to £300 before trying to restore them to working condition.

Mr Bunce said: "I have had mixed reactions from my family, who thought it was ridiculous at first. It has interfered with relationships before because I put a lot of time into my hobby."

fields.headline: Tribute to Lord Grade
fields.trailText: Slapstick legend Norman Wisdom lived up to his reputation yesterday when he unveiled a plaque at the London Palladium to honour one of the greatest names in showbusiness, Lord Grade.
fields.body:
Slapstick legend Norman Wisdom lived up to his reputation yesterday when he unveiled a plaque at the London Palladium to honour one of the greatest names in showbusiness, Lord Grade.

The 85-year-old performer larked around with fellow entertainer Tom O'Connor, 60, who lifted 5ft 4in Sir Norman up for a better view of the plaque.

The ceremony was to mark the contribution to British comedy and entertainment of mogul Lew Grade, who died in 1998. His nephew, TV executive Michael Grade, took part in the unveiling, which was organised by the comedy group Comic Heritage.

A performer, film and stage producer, and the founder of Sunday Night At The Palladium, Lord Grade and his brothers Leslie and Bernie created a showbusiness dynasty.

fields.headline: Stormy waters
fields.standfirst: Lewes swimmers fight to keep lido
fields.trailText: Britain's oldest open-air swimming pool (above) is facing closure after 140 years.
fields.body:
Britain's oldest open-air swimming pool (above) is facing closure after 140 years.

The historic lido was built by public subscription in 1860 in Lewes, East Sussex. But now councillors want it closed to make way for a skateboard park. They vote on the cost-cutting plan tomorrow.

Local people, many of whom were taught to swim in the pool, are angry. Valmai Goodyear, of the Save the Pells Pool Campaign, said: "It is the oldest outdoor pool in the country and was left to the people of Lewes. They have no right to close it in this way.

"We have called a special town meeting about it and that could lead to a vote of no-confidence in the town council. In 1991 there was another attempt to close the pool and 4,000 people signed a petition to keep it open. That is more than vote in local elections."

Although it was built by public subscription, Lewes borough council is the current guardian of the pool, acting as trustees for Town Brook, the charity that holds the land for the community. The council points out that over the past five years more than £150,000 has been spent on keeping the pool open for four months a year. Cracks on the floor of the pool will cost another £100,000 to repair.

At tomorrow's meeting, councillors are expected to vote to close the pool "while alternative plans to secure the long-term future of the site" are investigated. The designs so far include a skateboard park, a water feature and a podium for community events.

David Neighbour, a councillor, said: "We hoped that a trust or someone in the private sector would come forward to offer a working alternative but sadly that has not happened."

fields.headline: Warrington remembers bombing
fields.trailText: Today, exactly seven years after the IRA bombed Warrington, killing two young boys, a peace centre will open in the Cheshire town.
fields.body:
Today, exactly seven years after the IRA bombed Warrington, killing two young boys, a peace centre will open in the Cheshire town.

The Tim Parry Johnathan Ball young people's centre cost £2.6m to build and is a joint venture between the NSPCC and the Tim Parry Johnathan Ball Trust, named after the boys who died in 1993.

It is the first regional centre in Britain specifically for young people and has a dual role as a residential facility for visitors attending courses and a drop-in centre where local children can meet and socialise. Children will visit from Northern Ireland, Britain and the Republic of Ireland to attend courses specifically about resolving conflict through dialogue.

The building's curved shape aims to represent the raised wings of a dove symbolising peace. Inside, the facilities include a residential centre with 40 beds, a cyber cafe, arts centre, library and an IT suite.

It will be opened today by the Duchess of Kent and other guests include the Duke of Westminster, Albert Reynolds and John Major.

Young people have had a say in the design of the building. Colin Parry, Tim's father, who has been instrumental in campaigning for the peace centre, said he hoped to see young people enjoying themselves there.

webTitle: Boy critical after road race crash

fields.headline: Boy critical after road race crash
fields.trailText: A 14-year-old boy was in a critical condition in hospital yesterday after a car in a suspected illegal town centre road race ploughed into spectators.
fields.body:
A 14-year-old boy was in a critical condition in hospital yesterday after a car in a suspected illegal town centre road race ploughed into spectators.

About 500 people were watching 50 cars race at high speed in Northampton when the accident happened on Saturday night.

Witnesses said the cars appeared to be racing round a section of dual carriageway as ordinary motorists found themselves caught up in the drama.

The boy, one of four spectators on the central reservation, was hit by a Ford Escort GTI as it ploughed across the carriageway and hit a car travelling the other way. He was trapped under the car.

He was taken to Northampton general hospital and transferred to John Radcliffe hospital, in Oxford, where his condition was described yesterday as "critical".

The Escort driver, a 20-year-old man from Northampton, was arrested in connection with the accident and was due to be interviewed by police yesterday.

The event, which police said was unofficial and had taken place without their prior knowledge, was broken up after nearly an hour by the crash.

Police are investigating whether the cars were taking part in an illegal race meeting. Inspector Peter Hanford said: "There was obviously some unusual driving going on."

Another spectator, aged 31, remained in hospital yesterday with serious leg injuries while the passenger of the Escort was treated for serious internal injuries not believed to be life-threatening. Neither of the drivers involved in the accident was injured.

fields.headline: Chris Evans pledges £100,000 for Livingstone
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's mayoral coffers received a much-needed boost with news yesterday that Chris Evans had pledged £100,000 to his election fighting fund.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's mayoral coffers received a much-needed boost with news yesterday that Chris Evans had pledged £100,000 to his election fighting fund.

Since deciding to stand as an independent candidate for May's London elections, Mr Livingstone has been appealing to Londoners to back his campaign.

Evans, who has been a vocal Tony Blair supporter in the past, had no qualms about backing Mr Livingstone over Labour's official candidate, Frank Dobson, who narrowly beat Mr Livingstone to win Labour's nomination.

"As a core London voter, I can say that the 'Legendary Livingstone' against Frank is no competition," said Evans. "Ken's got charisma. He is London. He's a leader. I like Frank Dobson a lot but he is not a leader."

He added: "I'm a massive Labour supporter, but I think they've made a mistake not giving Ken the ticket. Frank will never be the real mayor of London. To make that appointment was silly, not so much how they did it but to do it at all."

Whether the arrival of Evans in the Livingstone camp will bring with it votes as well as cash remains to be seen but having a friend with a radio station and a TV show will no doubt prove useful to a seasoned media campaigner such as Mr Livingstone.

Evans is just one of many Labour supporting celebrities who have come out in favour of the former GLC leader. Damon Albarn of Blur, Fatboy Slim and the Chemical Brothers, have already pledge support.

Mr Livingstone declined to discuss the fiscal generosity of Evans yesterday and instead limited himself to saying how "delighted" he was by Evans' public support.

The offer was made after Mr Livingstone appeared on Evans' TV show.

webTitle: £4,000 is too much for life-saving drug

fields.headline: £4,000 is too much for life-saving drug
fields.trailText: A woman infected with hepatitis C has been refused life-saving treatment by the health authority that gave her the potentially fatal virus.
fields.body:
A woman infected with hepatitis C has been refused life-saving treatment by the health authority that gave her the potentially fatal virus.

Patricia Greed, 49, contracted the virus from a blood transfusion almost 20 years ago, years before hepatitis C in blood supplies was identified as a health risk.

Avon health authority, which has accepted responsibility for her illness, says it cannot afford the £4,300 cost of the treatment needed to save her.

But without drug therapy to protect her liver from further damage she risks developing liver cancer, which would make a transplant her only hope of survival.

Mrs Greed, of Worle, near Weston-super-Mare in Somerset, cannot afford to pay for the treatment and has launched a fund-raising effort to save her own life.

If she lived five miles further south in the Somerset health area she would eligible for free treatment.

Her case is the latest to highlight the problem of the "postcode lottery of care", which critics claim is failing patients with serious illnesses because costly drugs are prescribed according to where they live instead of on the basis of clinical need.

Mrs Greed said yesterday: "It makes me so angry. Avon has given me this condition and they are now refusing to treat me.

"I would not be in this situation if it wasn't for them.

"I find it hard to believe they can put a price on my life and that I'm not even worth £4,000. I think sometimes I'm just in a bad dream."

Mrs Greed, who suffers from arthritis, underwent a hip replacement operation in 1981, before doctors were aware of the existence of the strain of the disease.

She was taken back into surgery when complications set in and suffered such severe bleeding that she needed a transfusion. Hepatitis C was not diagnosed until 1995 when she had a second hip replacement at the Bristol Royal Infirmary.

Mrs Greed was told that treatment was possible with a six-month course of a newly developed drug, Ribavirin, at a cost of £4,300. But she was devastated when Avon health authority told her that it did not fund the drugs because they were too expensive.

The authority is one of only three in the country that does not provide the treatment.

More than 600,000 people in Britain are estimated to be infected with hepatitis C, commonly as a result of intravenous drug use with dirty needles. Donated blood is now routinely screened for the virus.

If left untreated, hepatitis C can cause liver cancer, cirrhosis and eventual liver failure. Ribavirin, which is used alongside the antiviral drug Recombinant Interferon Alpha, protects the undamaged part of the liver from further harm but the later the treatment is left, the less chance there is of the patient responding and surviving.

Ralph Barry, Mrs Greed's consultant, said: "This is a lethal disease. Hepatitis C is the biggest public health problem in the Avon area and it could be cured by a simple six-month course of treatment.

"The combined treatment which we have been trialling for two years has proved to be highly effective in anything from 50% to 80% of cases. But the health authority is not facing up to the problem at the moment."

Mrs Greed's MP, Brian Cotter, a Liberal Democrat, said her situation was "totally unacceptable" and argued that drug treatment now could save the authority the £70,000 cost of a liver transplant.

A spokesman for the authority said: "We do not currently fund either of the drugs in question but the situation will be looked at again in April. Ribavirin has only just been licensed and is not a cure for the disease, although it has been shown to prolong life."

The Department of Health said the national institute for clinical excellence, set up by the government to address the "postcode lottery", was due to report on the drug in October and would provide national advice on its use. But it was up to individual health authorities to decide which drugs they funded.
fields.bodyText: A woman infected with hepatitis C has been refused life-saving treatment by the health authority that gave her the potentially fatal virus. Patricia Greed, 49, contracted the virus from a blood transfusion almost 20 years ago, years before hepatitis C in blood supplies was identified as a health risk. Avon health authority, which has accepted responsibility for her illness, says it cannot afford the £4,300 cost of the treatment needed to save her. But without drug therapy to protect her liver from further damage she risks developing liver cancer, which would make a transplant her only hope of survival. Mrs Greed, of Worle, near Weston-super-Mare in Somerset, cannot afford to pay for the treatment and has launched a fund-raising effort to save her own life. If she lived five miles further south in the Somerset health area she would eligible for free treatment. Her case is the latest to highlight the problem of the "postcode lottery of care", which critics claim is failing patients with serious illnesses because costly drugs are prescribed according to where they live instead of on the basis of clinical need. Mrs Greed said yesterday: "It makes me so angry. Avon has given me this condition and they are now refusing to treat me. "I would not be in this situation if it wasn't for them. "I find it hard to believe they can put a price on my life and that I'm not even worth £4,000. I think sometimes I'm just in a bad dream." Mrs Greed, who suffers from arthritis, underwent a hip replacement operation in 1981, before doctors were aware of the existence of the strain of the disease. She was taken back into surgery when complications set in and suffered such severe bleeding that she needed a transfusion. Hepatitis C was not diagnosed until 1995 when she had a second hip replacement at the Bristol Royal Infirmary. Mrs Greed was told that treatment was possible with a six-month course of a newly developed drug, Ribavirin, at a cost of £4,300. But she was devastated when Avon health authority told her that it did not fund the drugs because they were too expensive. The authority is one of only three in the country that does not provide the treatment. More than 600,000 people in Britain are estimated to be infected with hepatitis C, commonly as a result of intravenous drug use with dirty needles. Donated blood is now routinely screened for the virus. If left untreated, hepatitis C can cause liver cancer, cirrhosis and eventual liver failure. Ribavirin, which is used alongside the antiviral drug Recombinant Interferon Alpha, protects the undamaged part of the liver from further harm but the later the treatment is left, the less chance there is of the patient responding and surviving. Ralph Barry, Mrs Greed's consultant, said: "This is a lethal disease. Hepatitis C is the biggest public health problem in the Avon area and it could be cured by a simple six-month course of treatment. "The combined treatment which we have been trialling for two years has proved to be highly effective in anything from 50% to 80% of cases. But the health authority is not facing up to the problem at the moment." Mrs Greed's MP, Brian Cotter, a Liberal Democrat, said her situation was "totally unacceptable" and argued that drug treatment now could save the authority the £70,000 cost of a liver transplant. A spokesman for the authority said: "We do not currently fund either of the drugs in question but the situation will be looked at again in April. Ribavirin has only just been licensed and is not a cure for the disease, although it has been shown to prolong life." The Department of Health said the national institute for clinical excellence, set up by the government to address the "postcode lottery", was due to report on the drug in October and would provide national advice on its use. But it was up to individual health authorities to decide which drugs they funded.

webTitle: Labour begins arming its battalions of spin doctors for election assaults

fields.headline: Labour begins arming its battalions of spin doctors for election assaults
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A network of budding Alastair Campbells is to fan out across Britain as Labour prepares to browbeat every media outlet, however large or small, into running positive stories about the government in the run-up to the election.
fields.body:
A network of budding Alastair Campbells is to fan out across Britain as Labour prepares to browbeat every media outlet, however large or small, into running positive stories about the government in the run-up to the election.

In a rare glimpse of Millbank's private thoughts on the media, a pamphlet has been published to provide local party activists with handy tips on how to emulate the heavy-handed tactics of the party's finest spinmeisters.

Titled Using the Media, Ammunition for Activists, the pamphlet advises activists to steer clear of dreary stories about party meetings and to concentrate instead on endlessly ramming home the government's achievements.

Labour's network of new spinners should also appreciate that newspapers and radio stations stations are suckers for superlatives. "Journalists love the oldest, youngest, biggest, smallest and so on," the pamphlet says. "They also love milestones. Try to play to these preferences. Who is the oldest member of the local party?"

Do not be afraid, the pamphlet advises, to repeat your message again and again. "Even if your local Labour campaigner says something a thousand times, someone is hearing it for the very first time," it says. "That means sticking to the script - or staying on message." Local activists should not shy away from adopting Downing Street's tactics: always keep a note, complain, write letters and, above all, remember "you can be friendly with journalists but they are never your friends".

Local spinners are warned to be on guard against canny journalists. These include: "the Pinter Pause" in which journalists exploit the sort of silences which are characteristic of Harold Pinter's plays.

"If, during the course of a normal conversation there is a pause, most of us say something to fill the gap," the pamphlet warns. "Journalists play on this natural inclination and hope you will fill [the vacuum] with something you didn't mean to say."

Then there is the "Columbo Killer Question" in which journalists adopt the "amiable but shambolic approach" of the US TV detective to lull a suspect into a false sense of security. "If a conversation seems pleasant and untaxing, beware the killer question designed to throw you off your guard," it warns. The pamphlet, which was written by the former Labour candidate, Paul Richards, provides a telling illustration of New Labour's obsession with the media.

However, opponents were scathing. Sir Bernard Ingham, Margaret Thatcher's former press secretary, said: "This shows that Labour really is getting desperate. This government believes that the message is everything."

fields.headline: On the case
fields.trailText: The way-we-live-now documentary has long been part of the identity of the BBC's second channel, first with 40 Minutes and now with its successor Modern Times (BBC2, Wednesday, 9.50pm). But, like all successful formulas, this one (a social sub-set anatomised through fussy photography and laconic commentary) has recently seemed threatened by repetition.
fields.body:
The way-we-live-now documentary has long been part of the identity of the BBC's second channel, first with 40 Minutes and now with its successor Modern Times (BBC2, Wednesday, 9.50pm). But, like all successful formulas, this one (a social sub-set anatomised through fussy photography and laconic commentary) has recently seemed threatened by repetition. Success in television depends on format, but format can become habit.

But this week's film, David Hevey's 10,000 Private Eyes, shows that the formula still works when it says something unexpected about the country. Gumshoes might seem to belong to the past - the best scenes in Neil Jordan's war-time movie The End Of The Affair are those featuring a private detective - but Hevey shows that the PI is flourishing in Britain.

The kind of work undertaken in The End Of The Affair - hanging in hotel shadows, collecting evidence for divorce courts - isn't necessary in a time of sexual and marital liberation, but there are still partners with suspicions, parents seeking children and companies suspicious of workers who've gone on the sick.

The film's strong on both professional craft (how to take a surreptitious photo in a nightclub) and anecdote. A wife who found a pair of vast red knickers in her husband's car suspected him of infidelity with an Amazonian woman. The private eye surmised that the size 18s were the husband's size, concluding (correctly) that he was a cross-dresser.

As often in this genre, the only weakness is visual preciousness. 40 Minutes more or less invented the trick of cutting away to a speaker's hands or feet - a device now in use even on the News - and Hevey's film displays a fresh impatience with the convention of a person merely speaking to camera. Rather than the traditional moving mouths, he runs the soundtrack of each witness over footage of them staring silently at camera, spasmodically twitching or scratching. We should hope that impressionable young directors look away.

fields.headline: Chris: the resurrection
fields.standfirst: Chris Morris's antics in Brass Eye should have been enough to banish him from our screens forever. But now he's back - and as subversive as ever.  Mark Lawson on the return of a true original
fields.trailText: Chris Morris's antics in Brass Eye should have been enough to banish him from our screens forever. But now he's back - and as subversive as ever. Mark Lawson on the return of a true original.
fields.body:
On Shepherd's Bush Green in London, I once saw a previously well-known broadcaster trudging stubbled and bleary within a few hundred yards of the BBC studios at which he was now unemployable. His supermarket bags, from their tinkling sound, seemed to contain only bottles. His mistake had been to make a series of remarks judged tasteless by churchmen and politicians. He was also difficult, and a drinker even then, but his downfall was his failure to mind his mouth.

It was hard not to think of that victim of the airwave vigilantes while watching Jam (Thursday, 10.30pm, Channel 4), a new Chris Morris series which proves by its very existence how much more forgiving broadcasting is now. When Morris last had a show on the channel - Brass Eye - he brilliantly humiliated politicians and other public figures by tricking them into condemning an invented drug called "cake". Angered by Michael Grade's decision to postpone and cut the show, he secreted a subliminal obscene message about the then Channel 4 chief executive within the final tape.

Grade later said he would never employ Morris again. Even the comedian's admirers within the industry feared that interference with transmission copy was the final taboo. But living in a culture which no longer believes in consequences brings both good and bad luck. The downside is that we get Jonathan Aitken publicising his memoirs. The upside is that Chris Morris gets a new series rather than ending up on Shepherd's Bush Green with clinking bags. His return also symbolically marks the moment at which Channel 4 ceases to be Grade's and becomes his successor Michael Jackson's.

Morris's career as the magus of bad taste - he recently extended his taboo-busting to newspapers with Time To Go, an Observer spoof of terminal-illness journalism - devel oped in three phases. Radio series On The Hour and its television descendant The Day Today were elegantly rude about the solemn conventions of news broadcasting. The main joke was nonsensical sentences spoken with sinister authority by Morris's Paxmanesque anchorman.

Brass Eye - the show which would make him unemployable in Grade's eyes - again mocked broadcasting, although the satire was more pro-active, tricking celebrities into co-operating with the joke against them. Sending up television and setting up star stunts are now the default mode for graduate gagsters, but in Morris's most recent series he develops a tone we haven't seen before.

Channel 4's Jam - like Radio 1's Blue Jam, Morris's earlier laboratory version - runs surreal sketches against a techno soundtrack. Broadcasting - described by its pioneers as a "friend in the corner of the room" - usually reassures. It's a rule of producers (ever more so as the expansion in channels raises fears about losing viewers) that audiences should "know where they are". Jam extravagantly tears up the map, deliberately leaving you stranded, unnerved and unsure.

The subversion begins with a kind of sub-verse, as Morris recites, over footage of a nightclub dancer, a bleak tone poem about "jazzing to the tone of a life-support machine that marks the steady fading of your day-old baby daughter". And there's an Ortonesque sketch in which a middle-class couple try to employ a family friend as a sexual surrogate, conducting gay relations with the patriarch to leave the matriarch free to sleep with her son.

As in much of Morris's work, the joke is usually the gap between tone and content. The articulate middle-class witness beloved of news programmes describes, with characteristic precision, a suicide attempt at a block of flats. It soon becomes clear that the residents are helping the man to kill himself. A singer stretched across a tree-trunk croons Minnie Ripperton's Loving You, but the camera pulls back to show a semi-naked man flagellating her with a Space Hopper.

Apart from television, the most frequent target for Morris (who won't give interviews) is the medical profession. The Radio 1 shows included a doctor who seriously believed he could kiss it better, and Jam features a hospital consultant who diagnoses the "symptomless coma" and ends the lives of numerous healthy patients.

The point has sometimes been made - most forcibly against Emma Thompson's 80s TV sketch show which forced her to seek an alternative career in the movies - that surrealism can be an excuse for not bothering with structure or punchlines, sweat-work of the best comedy. Morris generally avoids this objection because his pieces don't feel aimless. The aim is to unsettle and trouble.

The taste-testing which made Morris's name and led him to take Grade's in vain is less in evidence than elsewhere, although you suspect that Channel 4's Right To Reply may be hearing about a scene in which a husband accused by his wife of having an affair is bizarrely forgiven when he reveals that the infidelity was rape.

The preview cassette, however, contained one black screen marked "Scene Missing". Michael Jackson may yet find himself having to decide whether to publish or be subliminally insulted.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: From Doodlebugs to DIY | Helmut's Party
fields.body:
Francis Wheen casts a bleary eye at the way Whitehall has tried down the years to get its message across. If you think we're living in the nanny state now you should hear the propaganda of the early days of the war, recalled in From Doodlebugs to DIY (11am, Radio 4). One plummy-voiced twit suggested our 1940 New Year's resolution should be to eat potatoes instead of bread. However, following four ministers in two years, Brendan Bracken realised that condescension didn't play at all well.

There can sometimes be a touching naivete among German voters. Easterners were scandalised to discover that their Communist leadership had been living high on the hog for decades. Now the unified electorate is astounded that secret subsidies helped keep its principal capitalist party in business. The fall-out from the German slush fund scandal is examined by Caroline Wyatt in Helmut's Party (8pm, Radio 4).

fields.headline: A ghost in the machine
fields.trailText: Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased) | Correspondent | Seeing Red
fields.body:
'Discussion is my maiden name," said sleuth Marty Hopkirk, when his nervous client urged him to be discreet. Cheesy lines of this sort lay thick on the ground in the Reeves and Mortimer re-make of Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased) (ITV, Saturday). Scripted by The Fast Show's Charlie Higson, the first episode saw Hopkirk (Reeves) tumble over a cliff and die, thereby jilting feisty fiancee Jeannie (Emilia Fox) at the altar. Not to worry. He returned, white-suited and ectoplasmic, just in time to save Randall (Mortimer) from being set in resin by a snarling Charles Dance.

Being composed of pure spirit, this was a quite a feat for Randall. "I can... blow on things," he declared triumphantly, after a few hapless encounters with solid matter. For those who feared that this remake of a 70s original might just be cashing in on the craze for retro, this first showing was a relief. The plot (iconoclast-artist-conspires-with-agent-to-murder-more-talented-wife) was taking an unabashed pop at the world of Shoreditch loftspaces and frozen urine sculptures, and there wasn't a platform heel or wing collar in sight. Mr Dance turned in a self-ribbing performance redolent of the Scooby Doo baddies, and to see Vic and Bob keeping to a script was a treat well worth a second visit.

Traditionally, they've been an acquired taste - in-jokes and impenetrable surrealisms appreciated by the grateful few. But the Randall and Hopkirk concept is bizarre enough to soak up their excesses and let us see the Tyneside Two in a new light. The term "family viewing" springs to mind - enough, surely, to turn Vic and Bob a ghostly pale.

Less of a shock were the revelations from Channel 4's Correspondent (Saturday), which told us that the USA is up to no good in Central America. It would be tough to imagine a world where this were not the case. Apparently, there are some Marxists controlling the jungle of southern Columbia. They call themselves FARC, but they are still to be taken seriously. We saw them in action - a T-shirted judge, complete with Che Guevara badge and beard, was presiding over a murder trial. Presumably after careful perusal of Das Kapital, he told the victim's mum and the murderer's mum to go away and sort it out themselves. They returned, best buddies, having agreed on £1,000 compensation.

Perhaps it's this nutty concept of law and order, rather than the Marxists' control over the cocaine trade, which has provoked Uncle Sam into funding a bloody war.

Blood and war featured sporadically in ITV's schmaltzy Sunday night offering, Seeing Red , starring Sarah Lancashire. Still fighting off the doe-eyed, dappy cow legacy of her stint as Corrie's Raquel, Ms Lancashire grappled with the role of 70s actress Coral Atkins, who chucked in stardom to run her own children's home. A heartening and fascinating true story was rendered glib when the heroine, after a two-minute trip to a children's home (where she saw, of all things, a child crying), decided that "all you need is love" and resolved to convince Social Services of that blinding insight.

A few phone calls, some fund-raising montage, and bingo! Coral had her own home. But she couldn't cope (not least because she still couldn't decide which accent to use). Then she glanced out of the window and on the lawn she saw guitar-strumming hippie Chris, who could charm disturbed children with a few Dylan chords. But she still couldn't afford shoes for the kids. Then who should wander into the shoe-shop? One of her old acting chums, loaded with dosh, of course...

The story groaned with quick fixes like this until the writer whacked in a bizarre sub-plot, in which Coral relived her traumatic past as a wartime evacuee. A past dominated not by bombs or by the pain of separation, but by persistent visions of a butchered rabbit. (Seeing Red? Geddit?). A benevolent shrink then proceeded to rid her of this obsession in less time than it takes to skin a hare, and everyone enjoyed a slap-up tea.

In a final touch, reeking of Dickensian sentiment, a little mite spoke her first words and everyone hallelujah'd. Except that the writer forgot to point out that this was the little mite who'd never spoken before. Sympathies rested less with the nippers and more with Sarah Lancashire, who should be in a position to turn down scripts as abysmal as this.

Except that the writer forgot to point out that this was the little mite who'd never spoken before. Sympathies rested less with the nippers and more with Sarah Lancashire, who should be in a position to turn down scripts as abysmal as this.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: LA Confidential | Presumed Innocent | White Men Can't Jump | Deconstructing Harry
fields.body:
LA Confidential

(Curtis Hanson, 1997)

10pm, Sky Premier

Superb, dense and dark thriller in which a trio of oddly assorted cops - speccy Guy Pearce, plus two of this year's Oscar contenders, beefy Russell Crowe and smoothy Kevin Spacey - join forces to root out crime and corruption. It's adapted from James Ellroy's long, intricate novel, and the murky underworld of 50s LA is brilliantly realised. Kim Basinger is impressive as a nearly fatal femme, but the biggest surprise, after his kindly farmer in Babe, is James Cromwell's calculating police captain.

Presumed Innocent

(Alan J Pakula, 1990)

10pm, Sky Cinema

Pakula, of All The President's Men and The Parallax View, is just the man to follow the twists and turns of Scott Turow's courtroom bestseller. Harrison Ford plays a convincingly horror-struck Rusty Sabich, a public prosecutor who, after a brief affair with colleague Greta Scacchi, is number one suspect when she is raped and murdered. Raul Julia as his hired counsel and Bonnie Bedelia as his frazzled wife are excellent - and there's a shocking but plausible final twist.

White Men Can't Jump

(Ron Shelton, 1992)

11.50pm, FilmFour

Director Shelton, who created an excellent romantic comedy around baseball in Bull Durham, plays a mean game of basketball here. Wesley Snipes and Woody Harrelson are ace backstreet players in Venice, CA who develop a hustling double-act. Loaded with funny, fancy street insults and a sharp eye on modern American urban realities.

Deconstructing Harry

(Woody Allen, 1997)

12.25am, Sky Premier

Allen stars as a self-centred, self-pitying novelist whose practice of basing his characters on his friends and family has caught up with him. As he and a good-natured prostitute kidnap his son to accompany them on a trip to his alma mater, both his characters and the people they were based on come back to haunt him.

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous. This week, Robert Downey Junior in Weird Science.
fields.body:
Robert Downey Junior in Weird Science

Who? Incredibly gifted actor whose talents are frequently overshadowed by his prodigious alcohol and narcotics problems. His big break came, prophetically enough, playing a wealthy drug addict in the screen adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis's Less Than Zero (1987). He's since turned in great performances in One Night Stand and Short Cuts, but sadly also cropped up in US Marshals and In Dreams. Unsurprisingly, these roles came at the height of his battle with addiction. His latest incarceration led to a "Free Robert Downey Junior" campaign, which got him transferred to a treatment centre.

The role: Ian, highschool jock and tormentor of nerdish heroes Gary (Anthony Michael Hall) and Wyatt (Ilan Mitchell-Smith). His antics extend to giving them wedgies and dropping slurpees on them in the mall.

Best Line: "I'm shitting in my pants!" (delivered while wearing a bra on his head - it's a long story).

Cringe factor: Pretty high. Mostly for the none-more-80s attire, which includes a white dress shirt and black suit jacket teamed with khaki shorts and boots. And don't even mention the eyeliner.

Other wannabes: Wallace Langham, of Veronica's Closet and The Larry Sanders Show, pops up as a party guest.

Critical judgement: "Weird Science," remarked Roger Ebert, "combines two great traditions in popular entertainment - inflamed male teenage fantasies and Frankenstein's monster."

Also not starring in: Mad Magazine's Up The Academy in 1980, and as Bruno Mussolini in the 1985 TV biopic Mussolini: The Untold Story.

 Weird Science (John Hughes, 1985) Tuesday 21 March, 10pm, Sci-Fi Channel.

webTitle: Kennedy warns Blair on electoral reform

fields.headline: Kennedy warns Blair on electoral reform
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy yesterday warned Tony Blair that his party will abandon Lib-Lab cooperation without a commitment to a referendum on voting reform as he sought to stake out distinctive Liberal Democrat electoral ground as the party of the environment.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy yesterday warned Tony Blair that his party will abandon Lib-Lab cooperation without a commitment to a referendum on voting reform as he sought to stake out distinctive Liberal Democrat electoral ground as the party of the environment.

The Liberal Democrat leader made clear he is ready to cool formal links with Labour, leaving Mr Blair to decide on cooperation. The prime minister is preparing for a struggle with dissenters in his own party over support for proportional representation (PR).

After telling delegates at his party's spring conference in Plymouth that the Lib-Lab joint cabinet committee (JCC) set up after the last election is "by no means the be all and end all of influencing government", Mr Kennedy yesterday warned on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost that, without a firm Labour manifesto commitment to hold a referendum on PR for Westminster, he could not see "much basis for further meaningful cooperation" between the two parties.

The JCC, which discussed devolution and Lords reform, is now scheduled to examine only electoral changes such as weekend polls and reform of the United Nations.

The threat to break off links comes as Mr Kennedy is seeking to counter accusations that he is failing to make a distinctive mark, six months after taking over leadership of his party from Paddy Ashdown.

He acknowledged yesterday that he had failed to make an impact with 59% of voters according to a recent poll but insisted that he could develop the positive ratings he scored with those who did recognise him.

Liberal Democrat strategists point to yesterday's conference speech - which broke with tradition by focusing primarily on the single policy theme of green issues - as defining a stronger political identity for both the party and its leader.

In a 25 minute speech Mr Kennedy branded the government's record on the environment "absolutely pathetic", telling delegates "there is no joined up thinking on the environment".

Accepting that he and his own party had "ducked some tough questions" on the environment, Mr Kennedy urged a five year moratorium on the commercial growth of GM crops, and ridiculed the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, for failing to push through green transport measures. "I want our party to turn the phrase 'on your bike' into a compliment," he said.

Mr Kennedy's team hopes the well-received speech will provide its leader with a distinctive "cause" in the way Mr Ashdown made international conflicts, particularly the war in the Balkans, his special subject.

The emphasis on the environment is intended to extend well beyond doorstop recycling schemes, attempting to link in social justice issues and core Liberal Democratic themes of freedom and liberty. Poorly insulated homes led to needless deaths among the elderly, while inner-city pollution denied children health and freedom, Mr Kennedy argued.

"Protecting the environment is the most fundamental liberation politics" he told delegates, adding "it is vital that we start persuading the British people that the environment is one of the biggest issues in politics".

Nevertheless it was for his assaults on the chancellor, Gordon Brown, for failing adequately to fund health and education that he received his warmest applause.

Mr Kennedy now faces the difficult task of developing a genuinely populist green agenda and carving out an identity distinct from Labour's while also quelling the fears of some in his party that he is allowing Lib-Lab relations to cool too far. Some senior figures, including those close to Mr Ashdown, are concerned that Mr Kennedy is "too passive" in relations with Mr Blair, and appears to be too ready to "park" the joint committee in favour of bilateral talks on single issues such as freedom of information.

Mr Ashdown is understood to want to see Mr Kennedy abandon talk of taking the Tories' place as the main party of opposition and concentrate on developing a half-dozen distinctive policies which would form the basis of negotiations in the event of a post-election Lib-Lab coalition.
