webTitle: Ministers 'horrified' by attack on press over Shayler

fields.headline: Ministers 'horrified' by attack on press over Shayler
fields.trailText: Senior ministers are to be summoned to a crisis meeting over Whitehall's heavy-handed attacks on the media for reporting allegations made by the former MI5 officer, David Shayler.
fields.body:
Senior ministers are to be summoned to a crisis meeting over Whitehall's heavy-handed attacks on the media for reporting allegations made by the former MI5 officer, David Shayler.

The move follows a bitter dispute at the highest levels of government over attempts by the Home Office to force the Guardian and Observer newspapers to hand over any documents they may have relating to Mr Shayler.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, and Peter Hain, the foreign office minister, are furious at what they believe to be a serious attack on press freedom.

Mr Hain is said to be "horrified" about the actions by the Home Office, prompted by increasingly desperate attempts by the security and intelligence services to isolate Mr Shayler and prevent further al legations about wrongdoing being disclosed.

An Old Bailey judge on Friday ordered the two newspapers to hand over to the police special branch any document or emails relating to Mr Shayler, and in particular his allegation that MI6 was involved in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy, in 1996.

Judge Martin Stephens made the order even though he admitted that a letter to the Guardian - the object of the order - contained nothing that had not already been printed.

He ordered the Observer to give up material even though he acknowledged that Mr Shayler had already sent the same information to Jack Straw, the home secretary.

The newspapers are challenging the orders and intend, if necessary, to take the case all the way to the European court of human rights.

Evidence of MI6's involvement appeared in a top secret report placed on the internet last month. Sir Malcolm Rifkind, foreign secretary at the time, is understood to have insisted he knew nothing about MI6's involvement in the Gadafy plot.

Mr Cook, who described the allegations as "pure fantasy" is believed to be less than happy about assurances he was given by MI6 which allowed him to dismiss them in this way.

However opposed they are to leaks from MI5 and MI6, the foreign secretary and Mr Hain strongly believe that the problem will not go away - indeed, will be exacerbated - by the Home Office picking a war with the press.

The court action has served to provoke further media interest in Mr Shayler's allegations. One Sunday newspaper yesterday repeated his earlier allegation that the IRA was able to carry out two mainland bombings because of a breakdown in communications between MI5 and the police special branch.

MI6 will be further annoyed by a book on its activities to be published later this month. MI6, Fifty Years of Special Operations, names intelligence officers - including some still serving - whose names have appeared on the internet.

Meanwhile the government wants to prosecute a former member of the army's force research unit - a covert arm of military intelligence - who has made allegations about attempts to sabotage an inquiry by Sir John Stevens, the metropolitan police commissioner, into collaboration between the army and loyalists in Northern Ireland.

Geoffrey Hoon, the defence secretary, has obtained an in junction preventing newspapers from reporting further revelations by Martin Ingram.

Sir John was reported yesterday to have ordered an investigation into allegations that the unit burgled and burnt down his offices to destroy incriminating evidence.

John Wadham, Mr Ingram's solicitor, said yesterday: "Once the authorities take the law into their own hands, they undermine the very democracy they purport to be protecting."

Jane Winter, director of British Irish Rights Watch, said that if the allegation were true "then that is more reminiscent of a banana republic than a civilised democracy".

Sir John is also heading an investigation into the murder of Pat Finucane, a Belfast lawyer murdered by loyalists in 1989.

fields.headline: Hayward Cirker
fields.standfirst: Publisher behind the rescue of lost classics
fields.trailText: Hayward Cirker, who has died aged 82, was the founder of Dover Publications, the American paperback imprint, and one of the great individualists in contemporary publishing.
fields.body:
Hayward Cirker, who has died aged 82, was the founder of Dover Publications, the American paperback imprint, and one of the great individualists in contemporary publishing.

His reputation for publishing cheap, but beautifully produced and mainly out-of-print, books came from his early experiences in the trade. He had written to a number of well-known authors, asking if they had anything put away which their regular publishers were not interested in. He received a surprising number of typescripts but, when it came to the royalties, there was no money to pay them - with remarkable understanding, the authors accepted his apologies.

Nevertheless, Cirker was determined not to get into that position again, and decided that henceforth most of the books he published would be out-of-copyright reprints, where royalties would not apply.

The Dover titles, built up over the years, ranged from beautifully-produced paperback editions of Rembrandt etchings and Palladio's I Quattri Libri to quirky titles such as The History Of Underclothes and the Nancy Reagan Cutout Book. Classics of art, children's literature, photography and craft books, many of which had been out of print for years, were also reprinted. Dover became the first publisher to build an extensive list of reprints of classical music scores. Dover covers are still known for their style and design.

Born and brought up in New York - he had an encylopedic knowledge of the city - Cirker began his working life as a sales representative for Crown Publishing, but soon felt the urge to spread his wings. In 1941, he and his wife Blanche launched Dover (named after the block of flats in which they lived in Queens) as a mail-order business for remaindered books. A few years later, he decided to publish his own titles, the first being an out-of-print and somewhat arcane German scientific text, Tables Of Functions, recommended by a physicist friend - it did well and sold 2,000 copies in six months. From these small beginnings Dover grew and flourished, and the business now has some 7,000 titles and employs more than 200 staff.

Hayward Cirker was a child of the depression, the horrors of which had made a deep impression on him. He observed that, in those harsh times, street traders who priced their goods as cheaply as possible were more likely to survive than their competitors. It was a lesson Cirker bore in mind; when he came to pricing book titles, he would insist on the lowest viable cover price. Hayward Cirker was a most congenial companion, and a man of quick wit and insatiable curiosity. The latter was perhaps his chief characteristic; without it he would not have built up such a wide and varied list. He loved his business and seemed as happy walking through the warehouse at Mineola, outside New York, chatting to his packers, as he was arguing with his editors on the merits or otherwise of a book.

He continued to work in his office three days a week until his death; Blanche went in on the other two days. She survives him, together with a son and a daughter.

 Hayward Francis Cirker, publisher, born June 1 1917; died March 8 2000

fields.headline: Blair email virtually ignored
fields.trailText: He may be the first prime minister to address the nation from his own website, but Tony Blair still has a long way to go to find his feet in cyberspace.
fields.body:
He may be the first prime minister to address the nation from his own website, but Tony Blair still has a long way to go to find his feet in cyberspace.

The prime minister's bumbling efforts to make virtual contact with his friend, the former Liberal Democrat leader Paddy Ashdown, saw the joint architect of Lib/Lab cooperation dismissed as "another of those email nutters" by the Yeovil MP's staff.

Mr Ashdown, who remains close to the prime minister despite stepping down as party leader, received a letter last week from Mr Blair expressing thanks for his speech on the challenges of globalisation. "I hope you got my email," the prime minister added.

Mystified, Mr Ashdown - a computer whiz, equally at home in cyberspace as on a Kosovan peace mission - searched his personal email in-tray, but found no evidence of the communication.

Finally, his staff, instructed to trawl his constituency email books, recovered an electronic note with an undistinctive address reading "HIGH PAT! You will be amazed that I have now come into the modern world. Tony."

"I asked my staff why they hadn't responded to the message and they said they just presumed it was from some loony emailer," an amused Mr Ashdown said yesterday.

Mr Blair, who devoted part of his first internet webcast to confessing his own unfamiliarity with new technology, readily admits he trails far behind his wife Cherie and three children in web proficiency.

However, the prime minister is anxious that others should not similarly fall by the wayside, recently making a speech warning against an e-divide between those with access to new technology and those without.

fields.headline: Thomas Ferebee
fields.standfirst: The man who dropped the Bomb and changed the world
fields.trailText: On July 21 1945, the physicist William Penney, a guiding light of the later British nuclear weapons programme, held a seminar at Los Alamos, New Mexico, where the first atomic bombs were being assembled, to anounce the results of his calculations on the impact of an A-bomb. fields.body:
On July 21 1945, the physicist William Penney, a guiding light of the later British nuclear weapons programme, held a seminar at Los Alamos, New Mexico, where the first atomic bombs were being assembled, to anounce the results of his calculations on the impact of an A-bomb. A city of 300,000- 400,000 people, he said, would be reduced to a sink for disaster relief, bandages and hospitals.

One of the people listening to Penney was Philip Morrison, then a 27-year-old senior physicist engineering the construction of A-bombs. In the 1980s, Morrison, by then an astronomer, told the writer Studs Terkel about the meeting. Penney had been clear about numbers of casualties. "It was reality," said Morrison. "We knew it, but we didn't see it."

Some 17 days after Penney's seminar, Thomas Ferebee, who has died aged 81, was one of the handpicked crew on the "Enola Gay", a US Army Air Force B29 superfortress, flying 5 miles above the Japanese city of Hiroshima. It was a clear, sunny day, just 17 seconds after 8.15am, when Ferebee, Enola Gay's bomb-aimer - and then only 26 years old - released the first A-bomb towards the Ota river bridge.

The Hiroshima bomb had the explosive power of 12,500 tons of TNT. Of a population of 350,000, between 60,000 and 70,000 people died outright. More than 50% of the area simply vanished. It was not the greatest bombing devastation wreaked on a single city, but, the world had turned.

The crew watched as the radioactive cloud over Hiroshima ascended to the B29's altitude of 33,000ft. The cloud's surface was "nothing but a black boiling", recalled the aircraft commander Colonel Paul Tibbets, "like a barrel of tar."

The Japanese were initially uncertain what had happened. So was Ferebee. It was only when he returned to his base at Tinian, in the Northern Mariana Islands, that he was told he had dropped an atomic bomb. Nagasaki was similarly attacked on August 9. Six days later, Japan surrendered, finally ending the second world war.

Announcing that the Hiroshima attack had taken place, US President Harry Truman explained that the A-bomb was the "harmonising of the basic power of the universe". The Manchester Guardian editorialised that the bombing was legitimate, but that humanity had turned one of history's corners. The publisher and writer Victor Gollancz described the attacks as "a blasphemous presumption". Later critics suggested that the raids had been primarily a demonstration of US power directed at the Soviet Union. Ferebee himself did not regret the bombing; he argued it had saved the million lives that an invasion of Japan would have cost.

The bomb-aimer had provided the United States with its punctuation mark on the 20th century; confirming its monoply both of global reach - no other country had an intercontinental bomber like the B29 - and briefly, of nuclear weapons. The A-bomb had been developed by scientists from many nations, but the funds and direction came from the US.

Ferebee was a farmer's son, one of 11 children, born outside the small town of Mocksville, near Winston-Salem, North Carolina. Educated at the local Lees-McRae college, he excelled at sports, trained with the Boston Red Sox and had early hopes of a baseball career. A knee injury precluded him from army service, and in 1940 he joined the USAAF.

From 1942-44, he was based in England, flying 63 missions. These included the first USAAF daylight raid on France; later, he was part of the attack on the Nazi-controlled oil fields at Ploesti, in Romania. His pilot on those missions was Paul Tibbets, who chose him when the 509th Composite Group was formed for the A-bomb mission late in 1944.

After the war, Ferebee stayed on in the military. As deputy wing-commander for maintenance, he worked with the US Air Force on B47 bombers, and during the Vietnam war flew on B52s. He retired in 1970 and became an estate agent in Florida. The world he inadvertently summoned into being persists - in nuclear arsenals, and 747 jumbo jets and B52s, the direct descendants of the Boeing B29.

In retirement, Ferebee enjoyed cultivating roses. He is survived by his second wife, Mary-Ann, whom he married 19 years ago, by four sons from his first marriage, and five grandchildren.

 Thomas Wilson Ferebee, airman, born November 9 1918; died March 16 2000

fields.headline: Baden Hickman
fields.standfirst: Guardian correspondent who brought church affairs to life
fields.trailText: Baden Hickman, who has died aged 68, was the respected churches correspondent of the Guardian for many years, and one of a small band of journalists who managed to persuade editors that church affairs merited a place on the news pages, rather than in the dustier corners of their papers.
fields.body:
Baden Hickman, who has died aged 68, was the respected churches correspondent of the Guardian for many years, and one of a small band of journalists who managed to persuade editors that church affairs merited a place on the news pages, rather than in the dustier corners of their papers.

He was himself a practising Christian, but made no great issue of it. Instead, he did good by stealth. If the books editor had review copies to give away, he would bag a suitable collection for the Salvation Army, for prisoners at Strangeways prison in Manchester, for his local hospice, or to distribute to down-and-outs under the railway arches.

The only son of a steel worker in Aston, Birmingham, Hickman joined the Manchester Evening News in 1954, where he covered church affairs along with news reporting. A natural organiser, he helped to form the Guild of Christian Journalists. Much moved by World Refugee Year in 1955, he took sabbatical leave to work for the World Refugee Council. The job took him to many parts of the world, from where he produced a series of harrowing reports. This seemed to ignite a sense of missionary zeal, which led him to the Far East Broadcasting Association (Feba), to produce religious-based programmes.

Hickman returned to Britain worn out and, after a spell in hospital, joined the Guardian in Manchester in 1961. He loved churches, church people and, most of all, church politics, producing a stream of stories which the sub-editors used to call "Baden's unholy rows" - though it pained him to write anything which, however true, might upset anyone. He turned in many good exclusives - about the private musings of archbishops (Archbishop Ramsey was one of his favourites), the row over the Catholic church's abandonment of the tridentine mass, and priestly defiance in the campaign to secure the ordination of women.

Hickman's imposing height and air of gravitas inspired the trust of those who would otherwise prefer to keep journalists at arm's length. Burdened with little theological baggage, he could get away with innocently asking the hard question because he genuinely wanted to know the answer.

He was an assiduous clerk of the Guardian chapel of the National Union of Journalists in difficult times, and once led a walkout from the press gallery at the general synod, when it seemed to him that a bishop had mounted an unfair attack on Clifford Longley, his opposite number at the Times.

Back in the office, he could and did turn his hand to most things, and was the self-appointed office organiser of collections for whatever causes seemed to him to deserve support. He would mark his colleagues down for contributions in their absence and, on their return, would humbly explain that "I took the liberty..." We thought that would have made a good title for his autobiography had he ever got round to writing it.

In 1980, the missionary in him reasserted itself and Hickman uprooted himself and his family to do more religious broadcasting for Feba in the Seychelles. But the job failed to live up to expectations, and he was soon back in Manchester with the Central Office of Information, where he did radio work for overseas listeners and escorted royalty and other distinguished visitors around the region - a role that appealed to his sense of decorum.

Hickman was awarded the MBE and, on retirement, found a new role creating a press office for the then Bishop of Manchester, Stanley Booth-Clibborn. An abstemious man who kept a well-stocked drinks cabinet, Baden was persuaded by Shirley, his wife of 33 years, that a small sherry on special occasions was not inadmissible. She died suddenly last year and Baden, by then badly disabled by Parkinson's disease, moved into a nursing home. He is survived by two sons, Matthew and Paul.

 Baden Herbert William Hickman, journalist, born March 26 1931; died March 16 2000

fields.headline: Mary Bodne
fields.trailText: Mary Bodne, who has died aged 93, fell in love with New York's famous Algonquin hotel when she and her husband lunched there while on honeymoon in the roaring 20s. They were awed by their fellow-diners: Will Rogers, Douglas Fairbanks, Eddie Cantor, Gertrude Lawrence and Beatrice Lillie. In 1946, the Bodnes bought the hotel for about $1m.
fields.body:
Mary Bodne, who has died aged 93, fell in love with New York's famous Algonquin hotel when she and her husband lunched there while on honeymoon in the roaring 20s. They were awed by their fellow-diners: Will Rogers, Douglas Fairbanks, Eddie Cantor, Gertrude Lawrence and Beatrice Lillie. In 1946, the Bodnes bought the hotel for about $1m.

Located at 59 West 40 Street, close enough to the Broadway theatres to attract show-business people, the Algonquin was also near Times Square and so drew newspaper and magazine writers and editors as well. In 1919, a group of them started gathering regularly for lunch at a round table in the hotel's Rose Room.

The Algonquin round table included newspapermen like Franklin Adams, Alexander Woollcott and Heywood Broun; playwrights-to-be like George S Kaufman, Charles MacArthur and Robert Sherwood; the novelist Edna Ferber and satirist Dorothy Parker, among many other luminaries-to-be of the jazz age. The round table has usually been associated with the New Yorker magazine (its office being only a block north on West 45th Street) but the group antedated the magazine, which was founded in 1925.

Mary Bodne greeted generations of guests from her armchair in the lobby. She played the Jewish mother on an epic scale, cooking chicken soup for Laurence Olivier when he was sick, babysitting for Simone Signoret and displaying an ability to acquire seats for sold-out Broadway shows. Regulars as different as Ella Fitzgerald and Brendan Behan sang her praises.

She had never expected to reign over the great institution - as a young bride from Charleston, South Carolina, she had merely teased her husband Ben about someday buying her the Algonquin as a wedding present. Born Mary Mazo, her parents were Russian Jews who had fled the pogroms that ravaged their hometown, Odessa. Her father settled in Charleston, where he opened the city's first Jewish delicatessen.

The story goes that George Gershwin and DuBose Heyward were regulars at the restaurant in the 1930s, when they were working on Porgy And Bess, their folk opera about African-Americans in the south. The pair also showed up frequently for dinner at the home of Mary's parents.

From the time of their purchase in 1946, Mary and Ben Bodne lived in a suite among the Algonquin's 200 rooms. Nowadays, Mary's personal touch has given way to marketing; a guest at the hotel can buy a mug with a round-table logo and contemplate wallpaper with James Thurber cartoons. Ben Bodne died in 1992; Mary is survived by two daughters.

 Mary Mazo Bodne, hotelier, born October 25 1906; died February 28 2000

webTitle: Iran at war over use of violence to defend Islam

fields.headline: Iran at war over use of violence to defend Islam
fields.standfirst:
Reformers blame ayatollahs for inciting attacks from the pulpit

More about Iran
fields.trailText: The attempted assassination of a key Iranian reformer has prompted an explosive debate over whether violence is justified in Islam if the faith is perceived to be under threat.
fields.body:
The attempted assassination of a key Iranian reformer has prompted an explosive debate over whether violence is justified in Islam if the faith is perceived to be under threat.

Saeed Hajjarian, the architect of the reformers' victory in last month's parliamentary polls, was gunned down on March 12. The assailants are suspected of carrying out a hardline plot to extinguish political and social reform.

Reformers and moderate clerics blame Ayatollah Mohammad Taqi Mesbah-Yazdi and like-minded theologians for encouraging extremists within the intelligence service, the Islamic basij militia, and the Revolutionary Guards for the attempted assassination and recent violence.

Mr Hajjarian is now clinging to life in a Tehran hospital, where he underwent surgery yesterday for the first time since the shooting, doctors said, to enable him to eat normally.

Many Iranians are demanding that the spiritual messengers behind the shooting be silenced.

"When the Friday prayers are used officially to advocate violence and justify it, and state television broadcasts these sermons, then this is the official position of the state," said Akbar Ganji, a journalist and leading intellectual.

"When it is said by officials that there will be a crisis in the country as long as Hajjarian lives, do you not expect them to assassinate him?" Mr Ganji added.

Ayatollah Mesbah-Yazdi, the leading ideologue of the right, routinely encourages violence from his pulpit and in lectures to religious students in the Shi'ite holy city of Qom.

"I am not a theoretician of violence, but I emphasise that in cases in which things go out of the government's control, and Islam is jeopardised, there is no way but using violence. Applying violence in these cases is a necessity," he told students a few months ago.

In the parliamentary election on February 18, fewer clerics than ever before were elected MPs, but the roots of the latest war of words lie with the 1997 election campaign of President Mohammad Khatami, a moderate, mid-ranking cleric.

His landslide victory strengthened the hands of progressive theologians and forced divisions within the clerical elite into the political realm.

Mr Khatami's power enabled reformist theologians and Iranian society to openly challenge the hardline clerical establishment, which insists on imposing its views on how Islam should be applied in Iran.

This fundamental dispute has surfaced in periodic eruptions of political violence, including a raid on the dormitories of pro-democracy students last July, and the murders in 1998 of dissident intellectuals by rogue agents in the intelligence service.

The use of violence to defend Islam has long been debated, but the shooting of Mr Hajjarian has polarised Iranian society.

"How do you justify these terrorist activities?" asked pro-reform Ayatollah Abdolkarim Moussavi-Ardebili during a lecture to religious students in Qom last week.

"Not one drop of Muslim blood must be shed. It is against the sharia (Islamic law)."

fields.headline: President-wallah
fields.standfirst: India is the jewel in US leader's Asia trip
fields.trailText: US President Bill Clinton opened the first visit by an American president to south Asia in 22 years last night, hoping to curb the nuclear-weapons rivalry between India and Pakistan and cool territorial tensions in what he describes as "perhaps the most dangerous place in the world today".
fields.body:
US President Bill Clinton opened the first visit by an American president to south Asia in 22 years last night, hoping to curb the nuclear-weapons rivalry between India and Pakistan and cool territorial tensions in what he describes as "perhaps the most dangerous place in the world today".

Most Indians welcomed the visit but in New Delhi a group of protesters chanted: "Death to Bill Clinton. Death to the imperialism of multinationals." In the northern region of Kashmir, police lobbed teargas and beat back separatists seeking to draw attention to their cause.

Mr Clinton stepped off Air Force One with his daughter Chelsea on his arm. Hillary Clinton stayed home to campaign for a senate seat in New York.

The six-day journey will take Mr Clinton briefly to Bangladesh and military-ruled Pakistan. Ostensibly, the stop in Dhaka is to endorse Bangladesh's democracy - which contrasts with Pakistan's return to military rule. But probably the driving interest is the deal Mr Clinton is due to sign giving US companies the right to exploit three of the most lucrative new Bangladeshi gas fields.

Most of the president's time, however, will be spent in India. He will cover five cities in five days, seeking a new relationship to replace the cold war era of suspicion when India was close to the Soviet Union and kept up national barriers that gave its economy a socialist patina.

India and Pakistan tested nuclear devices in 1998, dramatically raising the stakes of their long rivalry, which includes who should have the Indian-ruled state of Kashmir.

The president's national security adviser, Sandy Berger, noted that neither has deployed nuclear weapons. "That's an important step not taken," he said. But neither is willing to sign a nuclear test ban treaty. Mr Clinton has pledged to press for nuclear restraint, but the goals for his trip are modest. The main one, Mr Berger said, was for the US and India, the world's largest democracy, to "place their relationship on a sounder footing".

Washington officials say Mr Clinton might stop in Geneva for talks with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria on March 26, but the White House chief of staff, John Podesta, refused comment.

 AP

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Kohl blames old battle for outcry
Former Chancellor Helmut Kohl says the "old left" still hasn't forgiven him for allowing US missiles into Germany in the 1980s, and said it was part of the reason for the present uproar over his party's illegal donations scandal, a newspaper said yesterday.
fields.body:
Kohl blames old battle for outcry
Former Chancellor Helmut Kohl says the "old left" still hasn't forgiven him for allowing US missiles into Germany in the 1980s, and said it was part of the reason for the present uproar over his party's illegal donations scandal, a newspaper said yesterday.

Mr Kohl told Welt am Sonntag that leftwing parties and media harboured resentment over the missiles, which were brought to Germany to guard against the threat of Soviet attack.
Reuters, Berlin

Greeks protest at US marines
Demonstrators hurled sticks and stones at a convoy of US marines yesterday, after the first troops landed in northern Greece on their way to a Nato exercise in nearby Kosovo.

More than 100 protesters briefly blocked a convoy of US military vehicles carrying marines in the port city of Thessaloniki before riot police intervened. Many Greeks condemned last year's US-led Nato bombing of Yugoslavia.
AP, Thessaloniki

Thousands answer plea
People queued at hospitals across Cyprus yesterday, willing to donate bone marrow that could save the life of a six-year-old boy who has leukaemia. Their blood was being tested to see if they were compatible for a bone-marrow transplant for Andreas Vassiliou.

Christos Andreou, in charge of the Karaiskakion clinic in Nicosia, said more than 9,500 people had been tested since a television appeal on Friday. One person in 30,000 is compatible, he said.
AP, Nicosia

Senegal votes for president
Senegal's president, Abdou Diouf, said he was confident of winning yesterday's presidential election runoff. Mr Diouf, president since 1981, won 41.30% of the vote in the first round on February 27 while his challenger Abdoulaye Wade won 31.01%.
Reuters, Dakar

fields.headline: Murder suspect holds three hostages
fields.trailText: A heavily armed murder suspect shot at police officers yesterday as they surrounded the suburban home where he is holding three members of his ex-girlfriend's family.
fields.body:
A heavily armed murder suspect shot at police officers yesterday as they surrounded the suburban home where he is holding three members of his ex-girlfriend's family.

Joseph Palczynski, 31, has been holding captive his former girlfriend's mother, her mother's partner and the partner's 12-year-old son since Friday night, when he forced his way into their home in Dundalk, near Baltimore, Maryland.

Mr Palczynski is suspected of killing four people in two shooting sprees which took place earlier this month after his girlfriend, Tracy Whitehead, left their shared home.

Mr Palczynski was believed to have fired between five and 15 bullets in the direction of the police officers surrounding the house yesterday morning. No one was injured by the burst of gunfire, apparently intended to make police, who have sealed off the area, fall back, which they did.

People living near the scene of the siege were being told to stay indoors yesterday while residents away when the siege began were not allowed to return to their homes.

The gunfire came amid concerns that Mr Palczynski, who is believed to be a manic depressive, is becoming increasingly dangerous.

He is understood to have armed himself with two high-powered rifles and a handgun.

Ms Whitehead, who is 22, accused Mr Palczynski of trying to kill her before she moved out of their Maryland home at the beginning of March. He was arrested but released on $7,500 (£4,760) bail put up by his mother.

Ms Whitehead, who works in a local discount store, went to stay with the family of an older colleague. Mr Palczynski then turned up at the house on March 7 and is thought to have killed the friend and her husband as well as a neighbour who came to help. During the incident he is also said to have kidnapped his ex-girlfriend.

Ms Whitehead escaped unharmed, but not before Mr Palczynski allegedly shot and killed a woman the following day during a bloody car-jacking in which a mother and her two-year-old child were also wounded.

Police believe Mr Palczynski travelled to Virginia last week and stole two guns and cash, then forced a man to drive him back to eastern Maryland.

Since the siege began on Friday, Mr Palczynski, who has a history of domestic violence and has spent time in prison, is understood to have talked to police by telephone, demanding that food to sent into the home via a robot.

The condition of the three captives is not known. Corporal Vickie Warehime said that the authorities wanted to keep talking to Mr Palczynski. "We have been in constant contact with Mr Palczynski throughout the night. Our main focus is to have this come to a peaceful end."

She added that a psychiatrist was also helping negotiators.

Lynn Whitehead, Ms Whitehead's mother, had apparently been staying with relatives during the hunt for Mr Palczynski which was launched following the earlier deaths. She only returned home on Friday night and the 31-year-old electrician immediately shot his way into her home.

Mr Palczynski is understood to have been involved in a similar siege in 1992 when he kept police at bay for 16 hours following a domestic violence complaint by a girlfriend. He was finally forced out with tear gas.

In the latest siege, Mr Palczynski has repeatedly asked for Ms Whitehead in telephone conversations with police officers and the psychiatrist. He reportedly told her sister-in-law: "I only want Tracy."

Ms Whitehead is now being kept in a secret location by police.

Relatives and friends, who have made appeals on local television to Mr Palczynski during the weekend siege, have said in the past that he would shoot himself or make police shoot him rather than go back to prison.

webTitle: Parents use book to deny killing JonBenet

fields.headline: Parents use book to deny killing JonBenet
fields.standfirst: Couple say six-year-old beauty queen was killed by a paedophile
fields.trailText: More than three years after their six-year-old beauty queen daughter was found dead in their basement, John and Patsy Ramsey have reopened the case in the court of public opinion by denying that they were to blame.
fields.body:
More than three years after their six-year-old beauty queen daughter was found dead in their basement, John and Patsy Ramsey have reopened the case in the court of public opinion by denying that they were to blame.

In a series of high-profile interviews timed to coincide with the publication of their book about the case, the couple suggest that the killer of JonBenet Ramsey was a paedophile who may have known the family.

The book, The Death of Innocence: The Untold Story of JonBenet's Murder and how its Exploitation Compromised the Pursuit of Truth - appeared on Amazon.com's bestseller list as soon as it was published on Friday.

Although a grand jury failed after 13 months' deliberation to indict the couple in October, they are still under an official "umbrella of suspicion". The local police force in Boulder, Colorado, has publicly criticised them for their failure to cooperate and most opinion polls show that the American public believe they are guilty of strangling and sexually abusing their daughter during the 1996 Christmas holiday.

The couple have used several television interviews and a lengthy article in Newsweek, to be published today, to claim that such suspicions are allowing the police to stop looking for the real murderer.

They accuse the police of simply trying to "trip them up" rather than find the murderer. Although largely positive, the interviews are likely to raise further questions about the murder that made the little girl with candy-floss hair and a heavily made-up face into what writer Joyce Carol Oates called "the most famous little girl of our time".

The Ramseys tell Newsweek that they would now be willing to take a lie detector test, having previously declined to do so. John Ramsey says that the authorities once asked him to take a test but that he said such a request would "offend" him as a grieving parent.

The couple set out to disprove alleged inconsistencies in their evidence. The most oft-quoted theory about the murder to date is that one of the parents bludgeoned JonBenet over something as minor as wetting the bed and then covered it up with a phoney ransom note. The ransom note found by the Ramseys demanded $118,000 (£73,750), the exact amount Mr Ramsey was expecting to receive as his annual bonus that year.

In trying to explain such a coincidence, Mr Ramsey said: "Only the killer knows that. Why didn't they ask for a million dollars? What you have to think about, though, is that the person who did this is a madman."

Mrs Ramsey, a former child beauty queen, has been accused of forcing her daughter to dress in inappropriate ways to win local pageants. She denies that she capped JonBenet's milk teeth, but she does admit to dyeing her daughter's hair to "blend it" with her sun-bleached summertime tresses.

The Ramseys now admit to doubts about the wisdom of JonBenet's position as a beauty queen as she could have attracted her killer by behaving in what others have described as sexually provocative ways.

In a book that provides little fresh evidence, the Ramseys raise seven facts which they believe back their claims of innocence. In particular, they point to an unidentified palm print on the door to the room where her body was found, unidentified DNA under the girl's fingernails and on her underwear, and an unmatched boot print near her body.

The Ramseys use of the proceeds to the book is likely to be controversial, as most of it will be used to hefty pay legal expenses. Anything left is going to the children's' foundation they set up in their daughter's name. They have been criticised in the US press for setting up such a charity.

Mr Ramsey said in one interview that the family was largely living on his retirement account.

"We will not profit a single dime from this book. I don't know exactly [how much we have spent] because we have spent money on lawyers and a lot of money on the investigation... What I do know is what I had in savings and what I don't have now."

Other interviews, carried out without lawyers present, suggest that the Ramseys believe that they may have known the killer. Mrs Ramsey says: "The more I learn, the more I think we must have crossed paths somewhere."

A retired homicide detective who resigned from the case spoke out last week about his belief that someone other than the Ramseys was involved in the killing.

The police department in Boulder has refused to comment on the case since the publication of the book.

webTitle: A party, prayers, then mass suicide

fields.headline: A party, prayers, then mass suicide
fields.standfirst: Up to 470 dead as worshippers lock themselves in blazing church
fields.trailText: A mass of tangled bodies lay sprawled on the floor of the makeshift church. The corrugated tin roof had fallen in from the pressure of the flames, and rain spattered down on the corpses, some of which were still smouldering.
fields.body:
A mass of tangled bodies lay sprawled on the floor of the makeshift church. The corrugated tin roof had fallen in from the pressure of the flames, and rain spattered down on the corpses, some of which were still smouldering.

Several looked as if they had died in terror. Their blackened bodies were curled towards the wall, as if shielding themselves from the flames. One man lay on his back, his legs spreadeagled and his arms thrown above his head. The body of a baby - its arm partly missing - lay just outside the main door to the church.

Police estimate that more than 235 men, women and children died in an apparent mass suicide on Friday morning at the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God church in Kanungu trading centre, in the western Ugandan district of Rukungiri. There were unconfirmed reports last night that the death toll may be as high as 470.

The followers locked themselves into their church, doused themselves in petrol and then reportedly set themselves ablaze.

"All indications are that we have a mass suicide. We know that the leaders of that sect must have planned it. But we can only really make our final analysis when the pathologists make their report," said Uganda's inspector general of police, John Kisembo.

The Restoration of the Ten Commandments cult has been operating in western Uganda since the late 1980s and had a following drawn mainly from the south and central regions, as well as from across the border in neighbouring Rwanda.

Police have a copy of the cult's membership list, but do not yet know whether they were all in the church when it was set alight. What is known, however, is that the cult was a live-in community - and that no one who was in the area at the time of the blaze survived.

Gruesome task

A steady stream of relatives and friends made their way along the muddy path to the cult headquarters yesterday to begin the gruesome task of identifying their dead.

Two women, their heads draped in shawls, wailed as they looked at the charred remains. Another woman, who had lost 10 family members in the fire, wandered around with a fixed smile on her face as if she could not absorb what was happening.

"The scene is horror," a police spokesman, Asuman Mugenyi, said. "It is only about two or three bodies which you can say that these are men or women. The rest of the bodies are beyond human shape."

"I've come here because we had our relatives here. I had an elder brother and his children who were members of this cult. All five have died here. I had no idea that this would happen," said Isaac Mugenyi, a dazed young man from western Uganda, as he walked around the site.

The exact circumstances surrounding the death of the followers is still not known. However, police and people living in the area tend to believe the followers chose to kill themselves.

"I was at Kanungu police station when someone came to tell us that these people had locked themselves into a church and set themselves on fire. We went there running, but we found heavy fire and we could do nothing - although we tried our level best," said Stephen Mujenyi, a security officer from the nearby trading centre.

The cult members appeared to have nailed down the doors and windows from the outside. Then they went inside and set themselves alight.

The windows of the church still have large tin nails hammered into the charred wood frame. A large drum which police believe contained fuel, sits at one end of the church, along with the remains of several jerry cans.

There had been signs in the week before the deaths that something unusual was going on. The followers had reportedly started selling off their possessions - in readiness for entering heaven.

On March 14, they also held a big party, for which they bought crate-loads of Coca-Cola. The long palm fronds, put up for decoration, are now withered and standing outside the new church.

Local people had heard members of the cult talk in biblical terms about their community. "All along they had said that this [church] is the boat of Noah," said Florence, a local villager. "This is the ark and they were told that at the time of calamity they would come here.

"They were told that at a certain time this year the world would end and so the leaders made it happen and perhaps the people there believed it had happened," she said.

Police still do not know whether the cult leader, Joseph Kibwetere, and his principal aides - two former Roman Catholic priests - were among those who died in the fire. "We are still checking our leads. But we believe that he could have also died along with his followers," Mr Kisembo said.

Among Uganda's plethora of religious cults, the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God had been considered fairly innocuous. The group was established in the late 1980s by Mr Kibwetere and registered as a charity with the aim of carrying out observance of the ten commandments and preaching the word of Jesus.

The cult still shows its Roman Catholic links; the leaders modest office has three small statues of Jesus. A crucifix also lay on a chair, covered with a stretch of green cloth.

By the late 1990s, the church had grown into a thriving community. The cult members lived communally on land bought by pooling the profits from their property - which they sold when they joined the cult.

The church buildings were set in plantations of pineapples and bananas. Cows grazed on the hilly land. The followers had their own primary school, as well as dormitories where they slept together on simple rush mats. They had recently completed a new church and decorated it with coloured bunting.

Local people described the cult followers as disciplined and polite and said they never gave any trouble. Their only oddity was their habit - on certain days - to converse entirely in hand signals.

"It was properly registered and they were behaving absolutely normally. They were even about to hold a reception for the new resident district commissioner. They did everything in the most sensible way," the internal affairs minister, Professor Edward Rugamayo, said.

There were perhaps some hints that everything was not as normal as it seemed. In 1998, the cult was closed down for its insanitary conditions and using children as labourers, but then allowed to reopen.

The state-owned New Vision newspaper last year ran an interview with a 19-year-old cult member.

"The world ends next year. There is no time to waste. Some of our leaders talk directly to god. Any minute from now, when the end comes, every believer who will be at an as yet undisclosed spot will be saved," he said.

The death toll of devotion

November 1978

In the largest cult-inspired mass suicide of recent times, 914 followers of the reverend Jim Jones's People's Temple died at Jonestown, Guyana.

Most drank a grape punch that was laced with cyanide. Those who refused to drink it were shot.

A sign over Jones's altar read: "Those who forget the past are doomed to repeat it".

The paranoid pastor and his followers had moved to Guyana from the US amid allegations of abuse of power and funds.

April 1993

A 51-day siege of a compound run by the Branch Davidian cult, led by David Koresh, at Waco, Texas, ended with the deaths of 70 cult members.

A fire consumed the compound, which was surrounded by police and federal agents. Koresh, who believed he was Jesus Christ, died of a shot to the head.

The end of the siege was re-enacted yesterday to see if gunshots from the military caused the blaze - a theory denied by the US government.

October 1993

Fifty-three hill tribe villagers in a remote Vietnamese hamlet committed suicide using flintlocks and other primitive weapons after they were tricked out of money by a blind local leader who had promised to get them to heaven.

Nineteen children were among the villagers who died in the hamlet of Ta He, about 200 miles north-west of Hanoi.

The mass suicide was inspired by a man named Ca Van Liem who had proclaimed himself king.

October 1994

The charred bodies of 48 members of the Solar Temple cult were found in a farmhouse and three chalets in Switzerland.

At the same time five bodies, including one of a child, were discovered in a chalet near Montreal, in Canada.

The cult, founded in 1980 by Luc Jouret, believes that sacrificial suicide leads to rebirth on a planet called Sirius.

March 1997

Thirty-nine members of the Higher Source cult committed suicide at a mansion in Santa Fe, California.

Police found the bodies of 21 women and 18 men lying face up with their arms by their sides. They were all dressed in black trousers and black tennis shoes and had purple triangular shrouds covering their faces and chests.

The group are believed to have killed themselves by swallowing phenobarbital dissolved in apple sauce and vodka.

The sect's leader, Marshall Applewhite, also died. The deaths were believed to have coincided with the arrival of the Hale-Bopp comet, which the cult members believed contained a space ship that would deliver them to a "higher evolutionary level" after they had shed their bodies.

December 1991

A minister and 29 worshippers suffocated after toxic fumes filled a church in San Luis Potosi, Mexico.

The minister, Ramon Morales Almazan, urged people to stay calm and keep praying as they began to choke on the fumes and vomit or faint.

The minister is reported to have told his dying congregation that God was drawing near and that he could feel the presence of the Lord.

March 1995

The Aum Shinri Kyo (Way of Divine Truth) cult killed 12 people and injured over 3,700 after releasing sarin nerve gas on the Tokyo subway.

The cult, estimated at one time to have 30,000 members in Japan, believed it would help lead Japan into a military empire that would last 1,000 years.

Its members venerated Shiva, the Hindu god of destruction and renewal, but also took inspiration from Buddhism.

December 1995

Solar Temple members were found dead in a burned house outside Grenoble, in the French Alps.

Sixteen corpses were discovered lying in a circle. The victims were killed by two cult members, who were policemen, after first being lured to an outdoor mass.

March 1997

The burned bodies of five Solar Temple members were found in a house in Quebec, Canada.

 Vikram Dodd

They did everything in the most sensible way," the internal affairs minister, Professor Edward Rugamayo, said. There were perhaps some hints that everything was not as normal as it seemed. In 1998, the cult was closed down for its insanitary conditions and using children as labourers, but then allowed to reopen. The state-owned New Vision newspaper last year ran an interview with a 19-year-old cult member. "The world ends next year. There is no time to waste. Some of our leaders talk directly to god. Any minute from now, when the end comes, every believer who will be at an as yet undisclosed spot will be saved," he said. The death toll of devotion November 1978 In the largest cult-inspired mass suicide of recent times, 914 followers of the reverend Jim Jones's People's Temple died at Jonestown, Guyana. Most drank a grape punch that was laced with cyanide. Those who refused to drink it were shot. A sign over Jones's altar read: "Those who forget the past are doomed to repeat it". The paranoid pastor and his followers had moved to Guyana from the US amid allegations of abuse of power and funds. April 1993 A 51-day siege of a compound run by the Branch Davidian cult, led by David Koresh, at Waco, Texas, ended with the deaths of 70 cult members. A fire consumed the compound, which was surrounded by police and federal agents. Koresh, who believed he was Jesus Christ, died of a shot to the head. The end of the siege was re-enacted yesterday to see if gunshots from the military caused the blaze - a theory denied by the US government. October 1993 Fifty-three hill tribe villagers in a remote Vietnamese hamlet committed suicide using flintlocks and other primitive weapons after they were tricked out of money by a blind local leader who had promised to get them to heaven. Nineteen children were among the villagers who died in the hamlet of Ta He, about 200 miles north-west of Hanoi. The mass suicide was inspired by a man named Ca Van Liem who had proclaimed himself king. October 1994 The charred bodies of 48 members of the Solar Temple cult were found in a farmhouse and three chalets in Switzerland. At the same time five bodies, including one of a child, were discovered in a chalet near Montreal, in Canada. The cult, founded in 1980 by Luc Jouret, believes that sacrificial suicide leads to rebirth on a planet called Sirius. March 1997 Thirty-nine members of the Higher Source cult committed suicide at a mansion in Santa Fe, California. Police found the bodies of 21 women and 18 men lying face up with their arms by their sides. They were all dressed in black trousers and black tennis shoes and had purple triangular shrouds covering their faces and chests. The group are believed to have killed themselves by swallowing phenobarbital dissolved in apple sauce and vodka. The sect's leader, Marshall Applewhite, also died. The deaths were believed to have coincided with the arrival of the Hale-Bopp comet, which the cult members believed contained a space ship that would deliver them to a "higher evolutionary level" after they had shed their bodies. December 1991 A minister and 29 worshippers suffocated after toxic fumes filled a church in San Luis Potosi, Mexico. The minister, Ramon Morales Almazan, urged people to stay calm and keep praying as they began to choke on the fumes and vomit or faint. The minister is reported to have told his dying congregation that God was drawing near and that he could feel the presence of the Lord. March 1995 The Aum Shinri Kyo (Way of Divine Truth) cult killed 12 people and injured over 3,700 after releasing sarin nerve gas on the Tokyo subway. The cult, estimated at one time to have 30,000 members in Japan, believed it would help lead Japan into a military empire that would last 1,000 years. Its members venerated Shiva, the Hindu god of destruction and renewal, but also took inspiration from Buddhism. December 1995 Solar Temple members were found dead in a burned house outside Grenoble, in the French Alps. Sixteen corpses were discovered lying in a circle. The victims were killed by two cult members, who were policemen, after first being lured to an outdoor mass. March 1997 The burned bodies of five Solar Temple members were found in a house in Quebec, Canada.  Vikram Dodd

fields.headline: No: 1597
fields.standfirst: Andy Kaufman
fields.trailText: Andy Kaufman.
fields.body:
Age: No longer with us, I'm afraid. He died in 1984 aged 35.

Appearance: A clown without make-up. Chevy Chase meets John Belushi on speed.

Status: Legendary US comic, erstwhile host of Saturday Night Live.

Most famous role: Latka Gravas in Taxi (opposite Danny DeVito).

Go on, tell us his best joke then: He wasn't really that kind of comic.

You mean he wasn't funny. I didn't say that. What I mean is his humour was "dadaistic".

Exactly. Not funny. More that he "explored the borderline between reality and imagination".

I rest my case. Go on then. He was being hired to perform at children's parties by the age of eight, and had soon honed his infamous Elvis Presley impression.

Which was? Chevy Chase-lookalike-Elvis who couldn't sing.

Then what? During a spell as a professional wrestler, Kaufman became the world's first inter-gender wrestling champion. "Having wrestled over 400 women," reads his official website, "Andy retired undefeated."

Too knackered to go on? Well, he had carved out a rather successful comedy career by this point.

Tell me more. His "routines" included reciting the Great Gatsby for three hours, singing One Hundred Bottles of Beer (all 101 verses), and appearing in a sleeping bag and sleeping throughout the show.

Bet that went down well. Still, unfortunate that he died. Yes. Especially since when he announced he had terminal cancer, people thought it was one of his surreal jokes.

And when he did kick it... Ditto. Die-hard fans believe he faked his own death, and that somewhere wandering around America is an ageing Elvis accompanied by a Chevy Chase lookalike who can't sing.

Many fans, has he? Enough for Hollywood to have made a Kaufman biopic, Man on the Moon, which opens here this week and has won its star, Jim Carrey, a Golden Globe.

Do say: "I bet he's wrestling Marilyn Monroe as we speak."

Don't say: "I wonder how it ends."

fields.trailText: In a short profile of the unit director, Wessex Archaeology, page 13, March 11, we got his name wrong throughout the piece, calling him Andrew Jennings. He is Andrew Lawson. Profuse apologies.
fields.body:
In a short profile of the unit director, Wessex Archaeology, page 13, March 11, we got his name wrong throughout the piece, calling him Andrew Jennings. He is Andrew Lawson. Profuse apologies.

In a piece headed Shark suits give swimmers speed, page 8, March 17, we said it was claimed that swimmers using the suits - which mimic the qualities of a shark's skin - had "increased their overall times by 3%". Their speed was increased, and their overall times reduced.

Our reference to the Royal Society of Artists in our report about the new sculpture for Trafalgar Square, page 8, March 16, should have been to the Royal Society of Arts.

In a column, page 5, G2, March 16, we referred to Sebastian Coe as a former sprinter. In fact, he won four Olympic medals and set eight world records in middle-distance running.

Homophone corner, from a column, page 23, March 16, "There is no finer example of the way that the north of London lauds it over the south."

fields.headline: £113m windfall for five SKB directors
fields.standfirst: Chief executive Leschly cleans up in triple-chance winnings after drugs company merges with Glaxo Wellcome
fields.trailText: Five directors of SmithKline Beecham are set to bank a £113m share windfall as the drugs company merges with Glaxo Wellcome.
fields.body:
Five directors of SmithKline Beecham are set to bank a £113m share windfall as the drugs company merges with Glaxo Wellcome.

The huge payout triggered by the takeover will hand £77m worth of shares to SmithKline's chief executive, Jan Leschly, on top of the £11.8m worth of shares in the company he already owns and the £2.2m he was paid in salary, bonuses and perks last year.

The generosity of the SmithKline executive rewards scheme has been known for some time, but the company has always pointed out the fortunes being amassed were only potential profits - and the real payouts related to performance and share price. But the three schemes which offer free and cheap shares to top executives will be automatically triggered by the company's merger with Glaxo Wellcome.

The scale of the executive share bonanza is revealed in SmithKline's annual report and accounts, posted to shareholders over the weekend.

Aside from Mr Leschly, who is to retire from the company next month, the other big winner is Jean-Pierre Garnier, the man set to become chief executive of the enlarged Glaxo SmithKline, which with annual sales of £16bn will be the world's biggest drugs company. Mr Garnier has shares schemes worth £26m.

The other beneficiaries will be finance director Andrew Bonfield, chief science and technology officer George Poste, who retired last December, and Tadataka Yamada, chairman of research and development.

The rewards also include a golden going-away present of more than £500,000 for Dr Poste, in the form of an extra year's salary paid just before his retirement, and a pension of £285,000 a year for Mr Leschly's wife, payable when her husband steps down in April.

Mrs Leschly's pension is in addition to the £570,000 a year pension the chief executive will be entitled to, and both will be linked to inflation. But should this prove insufficient the couple may also be awarded extra discretionary increases.

Another chunk of cash has been paid to former director William Grant, who retired in 1998. He has been handed £891,000 under a "deferred fees plan", which relates to a time when he was a director SmithKline Beckman - the US company which merged with the UK's Beecham group eleven years ago.

The SmithKline pay and perks packages - which are generated through a complex transatlantic web of performance schemes - are the most generous awarded by a UK quoted company, but they are starting to appear almost derisory in comparison with the fortunes amassed in just a few months by dot.com entrepreneurs.

Mr Leschly's son Stig, for instance, set up a rare-record and books website with £50,000 of family money and sold it just seven months later to Amazon.com for £125m.

The SmithKline chief has also had his own success with web ventures, generating millions out of start-ups he and his wife have privately backed.

Now he is planning to go into the e-commerce business with his four sons in the US, selling drugs and linking healthcare professionals.

fields.headline: Qwest merger 'a done deal'
fields.trailText: A planned merger between phone companies Qwest Communications and US West will go ahead as planned despite reports that a big European telecoms company was ready to crash the deal.
fields.body:
A planned merger between phone companies Qwest Communications and US West will go ahead as planned despite reports that a big European telecoms company was ready to crash the deal.

"We're very committed to get the US West deal done. If we could get it done by Monday, we would," said Qwest's chief executive Joe Nacchio.

Relations between the two telecoms firms have been strained since March 1, when reports started of a third party - believed to have been Deutsche Telekom - entering into the $36bn (£23bn) merger talks. Another suitor frequently mentioned was Britain's Cable & Wireless.

Deutsche Telekom's bid, which reportedly offered more than $100bn for the two companies, has since been taken off the table. Qwest this month had to placate its intended US merger partner after admitting that it was also flirting with someone else. The company said that it was talking to a "major telecommunications company" about the "possible acquisition of both Qwest and US West".

Asked about the withdrawal of the third party suitor, Mr Nacchio, who had originally supported its bid, said: "The deal's done. I don't think it is going to get resurrected. I'm off to the next thing. We're on the way to get this merger [with US West] done."

Both sides felt the other did not handle the acquisition talks well, playing out their disagreements in the media. Mr Nacchio said that the two companies were now waiting for six of the states where US West does business, to give regulatory approval.

"The federal side is done," he said. "We've got to wait for the states, but we'd like to get the deal done as fast as we can."

Mr Nacchio and US West's chief executive Sol Trujillo said that they believed that the two companies would be merged this year. The pair will meet today at a previously scheduled meeting in Denver. The meeting was expected to be "routine", a US West spokesman said.

fields.headline: Worm's eye
fields.trailText: Should the top brass at the Treasury have an extra string in its collective step this week, this may not be entirely a result of the bigwigs' self-congratulation at their budgetary brilliance. It might rather be related to the happy sight of an old rival being carted out of the ring.
fields.body:
Should the top brass at the Treasury have an extra string in its collective step this week, this may not be entirely a result of the bigwigs' self-congratulation at their budgetary brilliance. It might rather be related to the happy sight of an old rival being carted out of the ring.

On its 30th birthday, the Department of Trade and Industry is in disarray. One of its central concerns from 1970 onwards - the maintenance of a volume car business with a British name - has ended in failure. All around are calls for this hapless ministry to be disbanded.

Orthodox thinking has it that once the Treasury managed to see off Labour's growth-orientated Department of Economic Affairs in the 1960s all its problems were over.

Nothing could be further from the truth. On the Algeria principle, Edward Heath's DTI posed a potentially much greater threat to the Treasury and the financial interests it represents.

Indeed, with the 1972 Industry Act - which provided for widescale government intervention in the economy - the mandarins of Great George Street seemed to be on the run. That same year they even lost control of the budget, the expansionary framework of which was deliberately created in opposition to the Treasury.

That, however, was probably the DTI's premature high-water mark. It had always effectively been two departments with two philosophies, the "trade" half lobbying for international laissez-faire and the struggling "industry" bit bringing up the rear as a cut-price version of Japan's powerful industry ministry. From 1974 to 1983 they were in fact separated, and all the indications are that the DTI was allowed to reform itself only after mass unemployment had effectively smashed up the "I" part.

It is likely that, sooner rather than later, the status quo ante will be restored, with a slimmed-down Board of Trade upholding unfettered free trade and a minuscule Ministry of Technology dutifully handing out fact sheets to businessmen on trading estates informing them of available government help (none).

This will suit the Treasury view just fine; it never objected to the trade but merely to the industry. With the DTI razed to the ground and its field strewn with salt the Treasury can concentrate unhindered on the serious business of fronting for the City.

The demise of Rover is a jolly omen for the DTI's old enemies with the role played by a high pound making victory all the sweeter. All's right with the world once more.

Or perhaps not. Ten years ago Noel Annan reminded us that at the moment of victory for any idea - liberalism, the Victorian religious revival, imperialism - the reaction sets in.

This reaction ultimately undoes the dominance of the idea in question.

It would be pleasing to report such a reaction against the "Treasury idea". Such movements have to begin sometime and now is as good a time as any.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

The government is close to agreeing a £60m emergency aid package that could throw a lifeline to the 8,000 workers still employed in the British coal mining industry.

A German travel agent has started legal proceedings against Lastminute.com, which floated last week for more than £500m, alleging that the company's name is misleading and breaches trade laws.

Sunday Business

Transport group Stagecoach will sell its Porterbrook train leasing operation to Abbey National for £1.3bn in an attempt to boost its flagging share price. The deal will be announced in a fortnight.

Charles Allen, chief executive of media and leisure company Granada, has decided to spend each Friday at home to "think" and avoid hustle and bustle of his office.

The US utility that owns Britain's Eastern Electricity - TXU - is believed to be lining up a £350m bid for Norweb, the electricity supply business put on the auction block by parent company United Utilities this month.

Sunday Times

Phil White, chief executive of National Express, the coaches and airports company, has made a merger approach to First Group, a rival company. If successful, the deal would create the world's biggest private-sector transport combine, with a £1.4 bn market value.

Autonomy, one of Britain's most successful software companies, is planning to list a portion of its equity on Nasdaq, America's high-technology stock market, and raise a further £100m.

The company behind Ben Sherman, the shirtmaker favoured by pop stars such as Noel Gallagher of Oasis and Damon Albarn of Blur, is about to be sold. Trade and financial bidders are close to finalising what is thought to be a £100m deal to snap up the once-struggling company.

Sunday Telegraph

Britain's high street banks face a full competition commission investigation into the heart of their business in the wake of an explosive 400-page report from Don Cruickshank, the former telecommunications regulator, which will be published today.

British Telecom is considering a bid for Telefonica, Spain's largest telecommunications carrier, in a move which could create a company worth £160bn.

CCF Charterhouse, the City merchant bank, is working on a management buyout that is thought to value the business at more than £100m.

Vin & Sprit, Sweden's state-owned producer of Absolut Vodka, has appointed NM Rothschild as its financial adviser to work on a possible trade sale or flotation, which could value the business at more than £1bn.

Mail on Sunday

German motor group BMW is giving financier Jon Moulton a £500m cash pile to take over its crippled Rover cars operation. As the government steps up attempts to woo rival bidders, Mr Moulton will use the revelation as evidence that he has the financial muscle to turn Rover's Longbridge plant into a manufacturer of world-beating cars.

Sunday Express

Whitbread is carrying out a wide-ranging review of its strategic options, including a plan to take the brewing and leisure group private in the biggest deal of its kind in British corporate history.

Major shareholders in BT want the telecoms company to remove a clause in its constitution designed to prevent a hostile bid.

IoS

IBM alleges that Microsoft is "milking customers" with its software designed for mobile internet use. It claims that some add-ons to Microsoft products lock customers into using software designed by Bill Gates's company.

Finals: Broadcastle, Cox Insurance Holdings, French Connection Group, Furlong Homes Group, Future Network, Nestor Healthcare, Prestbury Group, Taylor Nelson Sofres, Wellington Holdings, Wolstenholm Rink. AGMs: Dobbies Garden Centres, Warrants & Value Investment Trust. EGMs: Redstone Telecom.

Tuesday

Interims: Scottish Metropolitan Properties. Finals: Chime Communications, Dawsongroup, Delta, Glynwed International, Johnston Press, Peterhouse Group. AGMs: Hill Samuel Emerging, Xaar. EGMs: None scheduled.

Wednesday

Interims: Barratt Developments, Sirdar. Finals: Alliance UniChem, Amey, Charles Baynes, Celltech Group, Chelsfield, Horace Clarkson, Flying Flowers, Kingfisher, Bernard Matthews, Quality Software, Senior, St James's Place Capital, Swan Hill Group. AGMs: London & Scottish Bank, Mercury World Mining, Nokia Corp, RDL Group. EGMs: Corporate Executive, Dmatek, Huntingdon Life.

Thursday

Friday

Interims: NetBenefit. Finals: ATA Group, Fortnum & Mason. AGMs: Trust of Property. EGMs: Antisoma, Gladstone.

UK: Public sector finances (February). UK: Provisional M4, M4 lending (February). UK: BBA bank lending (February). UK: BSA building society lending (February). UK: CML mortgage lending (February). US: Treasury budget statement.

Tuesday

UK: The Budget (3.30 pm). UK: CPI (February). US: Trade deficit (January). US: FOMC meeting.

Wednesday

UK: BoE Minutes of March 8/9th Monetary policy committee meeting. UK: Land Registry annual property price review.

webTitle: When I was young in Blackburn people said, 'Have 'em all out lad.' And I did

fields.headline: When I was young in Blackburn people said, 'Have 'em all out lad.' And I did
fields.standfirst: David Ross, Britain's best-kept acting secret, tells  Chris Arnot why toothlessness can be an advantage in the theatre world
fields.trailText: David Ross, Britain's best-kept acting secret, tells Chris Arnot why toothlessness can be an advantage in the theatre world.
fields.body:
Alan Bleasdale describes David Ross as "the Scarlet Pimpernel of British theatre, our industry's best-kept secret." He has written 11 parts for him. "That's more than anyone else," he says. "And the role I'm writing for him now is as big as any anything I've done for him before." That role is a suicidal accountant in a six-part TV drama, loosely based on Bleasdale's stage play On the Ledge.

Another Bleasdale stalwart, Julie Walters, says of Ross: "Whatever role he's in, he always hits the central truth of it." And Michael Billington, Guardian theatre critic, described his Archie Rice in John Osborne's The Entertainer at the Birmingham Rep in 1996 as "easily the best I've seen since Olivier's".

Yet Ross is hardly a household name. Bleasdale puts this anonymity down to his ability to "change like a chameleon with every role" - his parts have included Ratty in Wind in the Willows at the National, Gloucester in King Lear at the Manchester Royal Exchange, and Vera Duckworth's Blackpool fancy man in Coronation Street. The actor himself accepts that a low profile is the consequence of immersing himself so deeply in his characters. "I played a horse thief in Heartbeat the other night and my own mother didn't recognise me," he admits cheerfully.

We're talking in the bar of the Birmingham Rep where he's rehearsing Willy Loman in Arthur Miller's Death of a Salesman. "It's the first time I've played it in 14 years, and I'd forgotten how demanding it is vocally. Everything's on the top note."

The New York accent, though, is no problem to him. Indeed, the only city whose speech pattern he can't master is Liverpool, which makes his professional relationship with Bleasdale all the more remarkable. "We just had an affinity from the beginning," he says. "With Alan's work, you have to play your emotions on the line rather than thinking about it and then doing it. You have to keep running with it and don't let it drop. But I still think my Liverpool accent sounds false. So in GBH I was the retired headteacher who spoke with received pronunciation, in Jake's progress I was a Yorkshire farmer, and in The Boys From the Black Stuff I was the DSS snooper from Blackburn."

Ross was born in Blackburn at the end of the war and lived there with his first wife and two daughters until 10 years ago, when he finally moved to London. He still goes back to Lancashire at regular intervals to see friends and family, including his 90-year-old mother. His father died at 78, but not before he'd seen his son on television and managed to recognise him. Jack Ross was a bit of a performer himself. He ran the dance band at Oswaldtwistle Town Hall where entrance was a shilling, or sixpence after the interval. But he never gave up the day job at the mill. And when young David left school at 15, he went to work in a factory that manufactured industrial washing machines.

"I used to have to sit inside this big steel drum with a metal 'dolly' rammed into my shoulder," he recalls, "while a bloke on the outside kept whacking in rivets with a two-pound hammer. No wonder I'm going deaf. It was a nightmare." One from which he escaped after eight months to take a job in a gentlemen's outfitters. He was already displaying signs of exhibitionism at 16 by sporting a bowler hat about town - not exactly conventional headgear in Blackburn then or now. "I used to like to run the gauntlet a bit," he grins. By then he was already treading the boards at the Blackburn Arts Club. "I only joined because I fancied a girl there called Julie Heath. Eventually she married a doctor and had seven children."

Ross himself could well have remained a shop worker had his talent on stage not been spotted by a local worthy with a brother who was in rep in Barrow-in-Furness. "I went up there with my mother when I was 17 or 18," he says. "After three auditions and one day's rehearsal, I was playing a black homosexual boxer called Princess Grace in The Hostage by Brendan Behan. I had to black up with burnt cork."

Not politically correct, he concedes, but then black actors weren't exactly queuing up for parts in early-60s Barrow. From there he moved on to Harrogate Rep and, in 1969, to drama school at Manchester Polytechnic where his contemporaries included Bernard Hill, Richard Griffiths and Julie Walters. "David was two years above me," Walters recalls, "but he seemed about 40 years older. He had big Victorian sideboards and smoked a long, curly pipe, so he looked like an extra in Sherlock Holmes. But I remember being very impressed by his eccentricity and the fact he'd been acting in the big world outside."

Thirty years on, she remains impressed. "His Mr Bumble [in Bleasdale's adaptation of Oliver Twist] was so brilliant it deserves a Bafta. I didn't think we'd get through the scenes because he was so funny in the character. He used four different sets of teeth in various stages of decay... You must ask him about his teeth."

There's no need because he volunteers the subject himself. "They're false," he says, beaming brightly over his mineral water. "When I was a young man in Blackburn, people used to say: 'Have 'em all out, lad. You'll never regret it.' So I did, when I was 20."

And, no, he hasn't regretted it. Not professionally, anyway. For an actor, the ability to remove teeth is a particularly advantageous when playing grotesques, like Mr Bumble, or comic modern characters like Baz, the dim part-time driver in John Sullivan's TV mini-cab saga, Roger, Roger. "When I told John about the teeth, he wrote in a scene in a restaurant whereby the full set finished up embedded in a flambé of oriental beef," Ross reveals.

He was just 28 when he appeared in The Canterbury Tales as the miller, completely toothless. "That's when I first saw him," Bleasdale recalls. "I remember thinking at the time: who is this man?" Audiences have been asking the same question ever since.

 Death of a Salesman runs till April 1 at the Birmingham Rep. Box office: 0121-236 4455.

webTitle: West Indies top order wiped out

fields.headline: West Indies top order wiped out
fields.trailText:
West Indies 187 and 95-3
Zimbabwe 236
fields.byline: B C Pires in Port of Spain
fields.body:
West Indies 187 and 95-3
Zimbabwe 236

At tea yesterday, West Indies were batting to save the first Test against Zimbabwe here in Trinidad; mind you, they have been doing that since the first ball of the game last Thursday.

In fact, any of six million severely depressed West Indian fans could tell you it has been a long, long time since West Indies were batting to do anything other than save the match - even if they were to bat first against a Greater Dublin Special Olympics second XI. And, with nine defeats in the past 11 Tests, the West Indies nowadays, it might be more accurate to say, are almost always batting to lose the match.

Already 49 runs behind Zimbabwe's first-innings score, the West Indies made their worst start ever at the Queen's Park Oval, nose-diving to two for none in the first over.

The opener Adrian Griffith's second innings lasted nearly twice as long as his first: he was out for a duck on the third ball he faced first time around, but managed to get to ball five before being out for a duck yesterday, lbw to Heath Streak.

Chris Gayle, the first innings' second top scorer, was out next ball, clean bowled, and only the (relatively speaking) rock-solid Shivnarine Chanderpaul denied Streak his hat-trick.

The impatient Zimbabweans had to wait until the score got all the way to 37 for their third wicket, that of Sherwin Campbell, run out by Murray Goodwin for 23, one less than his first-innings score but made in only 91 minutes, almost two hours shorter.

The captain Jimmy Adams and Chanderpaul steadied an innings about to capsize with a patient 58-run partnership for a West Indies lead of 46.

The umpire George Sharp appeared to have returned his colleague Steve Bucknor's favour - he gave Andy Flower not out caught behind when he was on a duck - by not giving Adams out when he may just have been lbw on four. Flower went on to make 113; at tea, Adams was on 19 and looking more steady than he has in months.

But it would be a West Indian patriot or optimist who was not concerned. West Indies have lost 13 of their past 19 Tests, including 10 consecutive away matches.

Their five victories have all been at home and include the two against Australia last year that are probably attributable to Brian Lara personally, and one in 1998 that would have gone to England had Carl Hooper not played the most important innings of his or any West Indian's life, until Brian Lara's 153 against Australia at Bridgetown last year.

Since Australia in 1996, West Indies have scored totals of over 400 only three times, all at home, 300-400 nine times and under 200 a staggering 18 times. It is enough to make anyone pause, and may soon make the West Indian batsmen themselves halt.
