webTitle: Jon Courtenay Grimwood's top 10 cult SF novels

fields.headline: Jon Courtenay Grimwood's top 10 cult SF novels
fields.trailText: Jon Courtenay Grimwood's latest book is redRobe, published by Simon and Schuster
fields.body:
Jon Courtenay Grimwood's latest book is redRobe, published by Simon and Schuster
Buy redRobe at Amazon.co.uk
Extracts from his previous novels can be found at www.j-cg.co.uk

"These range from cult classics to straight imposters which aren't really science fiction, cult or otherwise. But what they all have in common is the fact that their authors took a good look at this world and then wrote about some place different, or not..."

1. Mona Lisa Overdrive by William Gibson
It's got everything a Gibson novel needs: Japanese gang bosses,double-dealing corporations, intelligent computers, reclusive billionaires and a ghost that is literally in the machine. His later books may be better written, but for me this one punches the buttons.

2. The Master and Margarita by Mikhail Bulgakov
Is it SF? Definitely not, but it still features regular time slips between Soviet Russia and Biblical Palestine, a large talking cat and Satan in Mosow. Not to mention Jesus as Pontius Pilate's alternative health practitioner.

3. Vurt by Jeff Noon
God, I love this book. Robo-crusties, a gnomic Game Cat and narcotics so real I'm suprised Jack Straw hasn't had his drug tsar slap government warnings all over Jeff Noon's work. A real walk on the dub side.

4. The Diamond Age by Neal Stephenson
Less flashy than Snow Crash and a perfect example of what cyberpunk should be like now it's all grown up. Besides, how can anyone pass up a novel where one of main characters goes by the moniker 'A Young Lady's Illustrated Primer'?'

5. The Good Fairies of New York by Martin Millar
Two punk fairies hit East Fourth Street via a Cornish rave in a field full of magic mushrooms after being thrown out of Scotland for doing something obscene with a clan banner. Quite why MM isn't one of the UK's best-known novelists, God knows (maybe).

6. Schismatrix by Bruce Sterling
Philosophy, astute historical analysis, heart-felt moral statement, whatever... This novel is Sterling's claim to be, along with Gibson, more than just a founding father of the mirrorshades movement.

7. The Hard-Boiled Wonderland and the End Of The World by Haruki Murakami
Somewhere in the near future our hero shuffles numbers from the right to the left side of his brain, laundering data. Unicorn skulls bring dreams. Weird shit happens.

8. Red Shift by Alan Garner
This is what you get when you set Vietnam in Roman-age Britain, throw in the English Civil War and add a desolate modern-day teenage love story. A book that's too hard for adults, in every sense of those words.

9. Death: the High cost of Living by Neil Gaiman/Chris Bachalo/Mark Bukingham
OK, so it's a graphic novel, but the writing is tight and so is the pencil and ink work. And the fact that I've got a model of Death sat next to my computer has nothing to do with it...

10. A Canticle For Leibowitz by Walter M. Miller
In 1944 the allies reduced the monastery at Monte Cassino to rubble and the 20-year-old WM Millar helped. Ten years later he wrote a novella that became Canticle, as good a trashing of war, organised religion and politics as you'll find anywhere.

webTitle: Rush to try fraud cases ahead of Human Rights Act

fields.headline: Rush to try fraud cases ahead of Human Rights Act
fields.trailText: Fraud investigators and police are believed to be taking action to speed up the prosecution of alleged white-collar criminals before the Human Rights Act comes into force in October, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
Fraud investigators and police are believed to be taking action to speed up the prosecution of alleged white-collar criminals before the Human Rights Act comes into force in October, the Guardian has learned. There are fears cases could be thrown out simply because they have taken too long to come to court.

One immediate beneficiary may be fugitive tycoon Asil Nadir, who fled Britain in 1993, escaping arraignment on fraud charges relating to the collapse of his Polly Peck trading empire. Mr Nadir may be able to argue that any trial now, 10 years after Polly Peck disintegrated, would violate his human rights.

The act, which enshrines the European Convention on Human Rights in British law, may be interpreted not only as reducing delays between charge and trial, but also to cutting the length of investigations.

This could seriously hobble long-running fraud inquiries, because people could claim the length of an investigation had prejudiced their chances of a fair hearing.

Such interpretations by judges may create problems for departments including the Department of Trade and Industry, the Serious Fraud Of fice and the Scotland Yard fraud squad.

Already the convention's article six - which guarantees a fair trial to all people in Council of Europe countries - has been used to strike down the use of evidence obtained under "talk-or-else" powers available to the DTI, the SFO and the official receiver. In the wake of the December 1996 judgment that former Guinness chairman Ernest Saunders' rights had been violated by the use of such evidence during his 1990 trial for share-support operations, the government prohibited use in court of such material.

But the Human Rights Act - which may at first be interpreted by relatively junior circuit judges - would allow for on-the-spot rulings against fraud prosecutors. Already fraud prosecutors are seeking to cut delays in bringing suspects to trial, although they are thought to be more concerned at the prospect of the entire inquiry period being taken into account for the purposes of article six.

One consolation is that an informal study of the amount of time taken in other convention countries has found no noticeable improvement in terms of speed and no apparent problem with the convention.

webTitle: Former Tesco chief joining team in assault on Storehouse

fields.headline: Former Tesco chief joining team in assault on Storehouse
fields.trailText: Former Tesco boss Lord MacLaurin, one of the most respected elder statesmen of British retailing, has been signed up to join one of the teams attempting to take over Storehouse, the ailing Bhs and Mothercare group.
fields.body:
Former Tesco boss Lord MacLaurin, one of the most respected elder statesmen of British retailing, has been signed up to join one of the teams attempting to take over Storehouse, the ailing Bhs and Mothercare group.

Lord MacLaurin, who is chairman of the English Cricket Board, and John Manser, a leading City banker and chairman of Robert Fleming, have been recruited by Nigel Whittaker and Stephen Tucker to lend authority to their no-bid takeover plan.

Former Kingfisher director Mr Whittaker and Mr Tucker, a Monaco-based car parks millionaire, want to persuade disgruntled Storehouse investors that they can install new management and extract more value from the loss-making company than a cash bidder.

Storehouse has admitted it has had several approaches from potential bidders. Iceland, the food retailer, has shown an interest and discounter Brown & Jackson is also thought to be interested. The struggling company's share price has slumped to just 45p, valuing the group at less than £200m.

"I would become non-executive chairman and Stephen Tucker would be a major shareholder", said Mr Whittaker last night. "If we are successful than we will have Lord MacLaurin and John Manser as non-executive directors.

"At this moment we have no intention of making a bid. We just want to manage it. The value of the business has to be got back to shareholders, because at the moment it is just dribbling away."

The proposed management team would have a big incentive to succeed, but Mr Whittaker says shareholders could get a bigger return than from a bidder who would have to pay £20m in fees to bankers and other advisers. He would not rule out mounting a full takeover if the group's overtures were unsuccessful.

He said the team's plans involved selling Mothercare and around 60 of the best-positioned Bhs stores. The remaining one hundred, he said, "are in secondary locations and could become an effective value business, with the emphasis on sharp pricing".

Mr Whittaker said he was unsure whether his team would stick by the deal put together last year by Storehouse chairman Alan Smith which would put 100 Iceland foodhalls inside Bhs stores.

"I'm not that keen on the food business, but we would need to look at the numbers before deciding ," he said.

Mr Whittaker met the Storehouse chairman last week but has so far been denied access to Storehouse's financial information. One major Storehouse shareholder, Templeton, is understood to have asked Mr Smith if he will hand the group's books to the Tucker/Whittaker team.

Mr Whittaker says he has already contacted several Storehouse investors and found a lot of support for his scheme. He is now planning a round of meetings with other Storehouse investors.

fields.headline: Quandts consider BMW stake sale
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The Quandt family will sell their controlling stake in BMW unless the luxury car makers' top management come up with a new strategy following advances from other top motor marques.
fields.body:
The Quandt family will sell their controlling stake in BMW unless the luxury car makers' top management come up with a new strategy following advances from other top motor marques.

Today's edition of Die Welt newspaper quotes the head of BMW's workers' council, Manfred Schoch, as saying the company needed a plan "that will preserve BMW's independence. Only then will a sale of Quandt family shares not be possible".

The Quandt family, which owns 48% of BMW, had been losing patience with Rover - but it appears the rising cost of its disposal has also irritated the secretive clan.

Reports in the German press point out that BMW's decision to sell off Rover has cost DM6bn (£1.9bn), whereas a plan by former development chief Wofgang Retzle to close factories would have added only DM3bn to the cost of withdrawal.

According to some reports Stefan Quandt, a big shareholder within the Quandt's holding, was in talks with parties interested in linking up. One German paper, Welt am Sonntag, claimed that US car maker Ford is interested in taking over BMW.

The newspaper, citing BMW sources, said the two firms had been discussing through third parties a possible takeover over the past three months.

It said General Motors and Volkswagen had also shown renewed interest in BMW after it had agreed earlier this week to sell its loss-making Rover subsidiary.

BMW chief executive Joachim Milberg and the Quandt family both denied this week the Munich company was for sale.

Ford agreed last week to buy BMW's sport utility vehicle manufacturer Land Rover.

To make matters worse the German regulatory authorities have launched an investigation into whether strict transparency rules were broken in the way that the news of Land Rover's sale dribbled out of BMW.

A spokesman for the federal stock exchange supervisory authority confirmed that regulations on transparency in BMW's sale of Land Rover to Ford were to be investigated. The spokesman said the authority would be checking "very carefully" the order of announcements about the transaction.

The spokesman could not offer a further evaluation of the situation.

BMW did not issue a formal communication, known as adhoc message, about its sale of Land Rover. This is in apparent breach of section 15 of the regulations on share trades, which stipulate that companies must release information "which could strongly influence the share price" into the public domain.

Richard Gaul, a spokesman for BMW said that the company had already publicised the sale of Land Rover through "various media", including British trade union leader Tony Woodley and trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers.

Mr Gaul said that Mr Byers and Mr Woodley confirmed BMW's intention to sell Land Rover on Thursday evening.

fields.headline: Screen on the green
fields.standfirst: You are where you work, as companies redesign their workspaces to reflect their corporate philosophy. So  Dolly Dhingra  finds swings, a lawn, palm trees and a stream - in the office
fields.trailText: You are where you work, as companies redesign their workspaces to reflect their corporate philosophy. So Dolly Dhingra finds swings, a lawn, palm trees and a stream - in the office
fields.body:
Stop reading for a moment and take a look around your office. What does your work environment say about your company and employer? Does the long walk to the toilets through the huge open plan office give you stage fright? Does the lighting cause you psychic distress? And whose idea were the fake plants and windows that nobody can open?

If feng shui devotees are right, the workplace, like any other space, has an aura of its own - and often it seems actively malevolent. Any employers worth their salt will realise that an oppressive environment makes an unhappy - and unproductive - workforce. But a new breed of bosses is beginning to think beyond a fresh lick of paint and a poster or two to "smarten the place up a bit". Office design is becoming increasingly conceptual as employers attempt to express corporate psychology through the very space in which they work. In business these days, you are where you work.

Take another.com, a new internet company that offers tailor-made email addresses through its website. Based in Highgate Studios in London's hip Kentish Town, the company believes a tailor-made office space is every bit as important. Which is why it installed a lawn in the middle of the office - a truly organic work space.

Founder Graham Goodkind recalls his vision when he first set eyes on the unprepossessing site. "I was looking for a really nice space that would hopefully sum up what we were about - which was fun and an expression of personality and individuality. I saw this space when it was basically rubble. It was horrendous: it had concrete floors, no windows and about 50 pigeons loose in it. But it was a fantastic space, I fell in love with it. It was bright, light, reasonably well located and cheap."

Love, however, wasn't enough. Goodkind called in designers Nowicka Sterns for some bright ideas. "It became obvious that we needed a concept to make it work, to bring it to life. Nowicka Sterns loved the space and came back with this idea which they likened to a New York cityscape where you have row upon row of office blocks separated by Central Park, which is an oasis of peace and calm," says Goodkind.

He then realised they meant "park" literally. For £12,000 the designers installed a boxed rectangle of grass that lives in the middle of the office, complete with irrigation system beneath and specialised lighting above. "OK, it's quite a lot of money, but some companies might pay that for a boardroom table or a bit of art. You've got to remember that it's a functioning bit of space. We don't have a meeting room - the grass is our meeting space and people also sit and have their lunch on it," explains Goodkind. "What we are trying to do is to break down inhibitions as well as create a relaxed atmosphere. An internet business is a pretty high-pressured, quick-moving environment."

Elsewhere in the office, assistant Kally Wilson is charged with offering visitors a seat on the set of chrome swings in the lobby. It creates a lighthearted, playful atmosphere from the moment they enter the office. "I just say, 'Would you like to take a seat?' and point towards the swings. A few people have said, 'No thank you, I'd rather stand,' but most people are OK about it. There was talk of getting a sofa in the reception area but as most people are fine with the swings, we decided against it."

But are these designs just faddish and gimmicky? "We don't mean to be gimmicky or controversial," says design director Oded Stern-Meiraz. "We are concept-led and try to find the right angle for our client. We began this job with the idea around the internet and we came up with the notion of surf and turf."

It's not just the flash arriviste dot.com companies that are interested in concept-driven office design. Consulting giants Arthur Andersen recently relaunched its brand identity in an eager attempt to appear more casual than corporate. Having already introduced a "dress dow" policy at its offices in London's Strand, it contracted architectural and interior design consultancy BDG McColl to redesign its entire workspace.

Referring to "office design as space-craft", BDG McColl treats space as being "task-orientated" rather than traditionally "status- orientated". Picking apart the jargon, what this means in practice is that there are no senior managers' offices at the company: at best they get a desk near a window. No longer does each employee have a desk - there is little point if consultants are spending most of the day working with clients outside the office. Instead, they have "touchdown points" where they can plug in laptops and phones while sitting on tall stools with a view of the world going by on the Strand.

Those working in creative teams are sent to the "chaos room" where all desks are on wheels and can be rearranged as required. Meeting rooms have colours rather than names or numbers - the green, blue, red and white spaces are based on psychologist Edward de Bono's "thinking hats" theory, which asserts that certain colours aid particular modes of thinking. The salesman's favourite, the flip chart, is gone, replaced with a high-tech whiteboard which when written on reproduces the text on to a linked-in computer. "Zen zones", with fish tanks and notices on the walls reading "no interruptions, no calls, no bookings", are a haven of tranquillity and productivity.

Movement within the offices is minimal - there are no traditional corridors, for instance. And almost everything has changed - instead of going to the canteen for a cup of coffee, you now head for the "breakout zone". With the new concept of office design comes a new vocabulary.

Brian Bentley head of the strategic analysis team at BDG McColl, says: "We pride ourselves on listening to our clients' needs and how we can serve them. There is no all-encompassing solution to business design. We have to understand the organisation so that the design team can interpret that into the creative design we offer them."

For Thomas Cook's call centre in Falkirk, Bentley and his team designed a stream running through the office, complete with real palm trees, tropical sounds and smells. "Everyone says that it always rains in Falkirk - and it's very difficult to go into an office environment where it's raining all day and sell holidays. So what we tried to do was to make the staff feel different. Using all these designs and using bright colours, we managed to make them feel up, and up for selling holidays," says Bentley.

At BDG McColl's own headquarters, the chief executive's office, although cellular (having walls) has no door and the venetian blinds set between two panes of glass cannot be closed. It is always commendable, after all, to lead by example.

webTitle: Can an outsider do an insider's job?

fields.headline: Can an outsider do an insider's job?
fields.standfirst: Replacing full-time staff with temps can save money. But it might not make sense for British Airways to do it, warns  Bill Saunders
fields.trailText: Replacing full-time staff with temps can save money. But it might not make sense for British Airways to do it, warns Bill Saunders
fields.body:
Rumours were circulating last week that after a less than rosy financial showing of late, British Airways is to contract out tiers of its administrative structure, getting rid of many permanent PAs and replacing them with external temps.

Outsourcing, as this practice is known, has been a significant business strategy over the past 10 years for keeping down payrolls. But not everyone is convinced it is the best way to run a company. At its most extreme, the principle is very simple: decide which people are essential to an enterprise, and get rid of the rest. Administrative staff are supplied, sometimes in bulk, by outside agencies and are generally employed as temps or on short-term contracts. Virtually nobody directly employs cleaners, so why not tackle the basic tasks of office administration the same way?

Many sociologists have been unhappy about outsourcing, predicting a grey "age of anxiety" in which nobody really works for anybody. But studies have tended to show that short-term contract workers are less anxious than their fully employed peers. Temps acquire a broad range of skills and experience, while those who stay put may have limited opportunities for learning anything new. Much of it is a question of mindset, of course. Temps are used to flexible working, but the thought that any Friday they might be replaced by outsourced staff does not do much for fully employed workers' peace of mind.

But what of the employers? While nobody disputes that outsourcing can be a valuable strategy, some are beginning to move against the trend. "There is a time to outsource and a time to insource," says David Hagan, a director at M&G Investment Management. "It is a question of getting the balance right." In his case, one of the factors in the balance is communication. As investment managers strive to become more accountable to their clients, they must have support staff who understand the business. "Nothing must be lost in communication," says Hagan, arguing that this can best be achieved if the individuals work permanently together.

Miranda Smyth, head of marketing at specialist legal recruiters ZMB, says that the need for good understanding makes outsourcing an entire operation very difficult. There are jobs that are best tackled by outsiders - strategic analysis, for example, which obviously benefits from a fresh set of eyes with no emotional attachment. But even apparently straightforward functions, such as typing, can be difficult for an outsider. All ZMB's documents conform to a house style, and unless the person entering it into the system understands it, the job will have to be done again. "The fact is that an employee using their knowledge of the structure and the politics of an organisation will get the end product signed off more quickly," says Smyth.

There are advantages for employees too. Keeping staff in-house, says Hagan, "gives people a chance to develop themselves". Properly managed, the stability of a regular job can be as dynamic as the hurly-burly of the short-term contract. "People have the opportunity to work in several areas, and to test the waters in something which may not immediately appeal." The opportunity to develop new skills is, he says "the essence of a happy workforce". It goes without saying that well-trained and happy employers are more likely to "add value" beyond their basic job description.

As yet the trend towards outsourcing shows no sign of abating. Perhaps David Hagan and Miranda Smyth take a more independent view because they have both had varied careers themselves. She qualified as a solicitor, and he was a research physicist. One does not have to be a rocket scientist to see the sense in their arguments.

There are jobs that are best tackled by outsiders - strategic analysis, for example, which obviously benefits from a fresh set of eyes with no emotional attachment. But even apparently straightforward functions, such as typing, can be difficult for an outsider. All ZMB's documents conform to a house style, and unless the person entering it into the system understands it, the job will have to be done again. "The fact is that an employee using their knowledge of the structure and the politics of an organisation will get the end product signed off more quickly," says Smyth. There are advantages for employees too. Keeping staff in-house, says Hagan, "gives people a chance to develop themselves". Properly managed, the stability of a regular job can be as dynamic as the hurly-burly of the short-term contract. "People have the opportunity to work in several areas, and to test the waters in something which may not immediately appeal." The opportunity to develop new skills is, he says "the essence of a happy workforce". It goes without saying that well-trained and happy employers are more likely to "add value" beyond their basic job description. As yet the trend towards outsourcing shows no sign of abating. Perhaps David Hagan and Miranda Smyth take a more independent view because they have both had varied careers themselves. She qualified as a solicitor, and he was a research physicist. One does not have to be a rocket scientist to see the sense in their arguments.

fields.headline: A mixed menu
fields.standfirst:
Meals on Wheels of Steel
The Cockpit, Leeds
****
fields.trailText: This isn't New Labour's latest vote-winning attempt to help the homeless, but a showcase-cum-state-of-the-union report by the Ninja Tunes label into the art of the turntable. The "wheels of steel" aren't as revolutionary as they were, but spin masters Fink, DJ Food and Kid Koala attempt to prove that vital scratching and mixing didn't end with the 80s masters turned Ninja record company bosses, Coldcut. A shame, then, that there's so much conservatism around.
fields.body:
This isn't New Labour's latest vote-winning attempt to help the homeless, but a showcase-cum-state-of-the-union report by the Ninja Tunes label into the art of the turntable. The "wheels of steel" aren't as revolutionary as they were, but spin masters Fink, DJ Food and Kid Koala attempt to prove that vital scratching and mixing didn't end with the 80s masters turned Ninja record company bosses, Coldcut. A shame, then, that there's so much conservatism around.

Fink mixes up hip hop and funk. It's nice, but when people from suburban white estates in south Leeds start throwing fingers, it's disturbingly close to The Fast Show's withering spoof, Jazz Club.

Praise, then, for Kid Koala. He isn't a bear, but the equally rare pop presence of a Canadian Chinaman. Eric to his Mum, the Kid (who's 24, but looks about 12) is both a showman and a real enthusiast. He winks at the crowd, mercilessly sends himself up and makes a welcome change from the bowel-churning egomania rife in DJ culture. More importantly, Koala is musically brilliant. His record collection is obviously highly desirable but it's what he does with it that counts, mixing all manner of fragments so that they don't sound quite like anything before. Occasionally he's joined by doppelganger DJ P-Love and at one point brings a full band, Bullfrog, and their congas, into the show. The irony of Koala's track Nerdball is obviously lost on the chin-stroking DJ Food, but maybe there's some sly mischief in that title, Meals On Wheels. One appetiser, a fabulous main course and one total pudding.

 Meals on Wheels of Steel plays at Sheffield University Student's Union (0114-222 8777) tomorrow, then tours

fields.headline: British pair join rich list
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Mike Lynch, chief executive of internet software group Autonomy, and David Potter of Psion have joined an elite band of dollar billionaires outside of the US who have built their wealth in the hi-tech sector.
fields.body:
Mike Lynch, chief executive of internet software group Autonomy, and David Potter of Psion have joined an elite band of dollar billionaires outside of the US who have built their wealth in the hi-tech sector.

The pair sneak in at the bottom of a list of 39 entrepreneurs. The list, published today in Global Forbes magazine, is dominated by businessmen from Japan, India and Germany.

Number one on the rankings is Masayoshi Son, the Japanese businessman who built Softbank, the software group and investor in internet firms, who is personally worth about $33bn. His value has soared in the past year from a paltry $6.4bn.

Despite Mr Son's impressive rise, his worth is dwarfed by Bill Gates's total wealth - his 16% stake in Microsoft tops $78bn. Softbank started life in 1981 as a software and hardware distribution business. But from 1995, under the guidance of its 42-year-old chief executive, it has invested in more than 120 internet companies with high-growth potential.

The list demonstrates how the technology-based explosion in wealth that began in the United States has spread elsewhere in recent years. Mr Son is followed by Azim Hasham Premji, the Indian who turned his family business Wipro from a cooking oil firm into a software and PC powerhouse. He is worth $21.4bn.

Yasumitsu Shigeta, who runs Japanese internet service provider and mobile phone group Hikari Tshushin, is in third and is valued at $16.8bn.

Another wealth generator is software powerhouse Infosys. Based in India's Silicon Plateau, the company's rise has seen two of its founders pass the billion dollar mark.

The highest ranking European is Germany's Dietmar Hopp who runs software business SAP and is worth £12.3bn. Mr Hopp is number four in the list.

Mike Lynch, who makes it in at 36 with a $1bn, has seen the value of Autonomy, his Cambridgeshire company, soar on the Easdaq stock exchange. The company makes software which has the ability to understand written concepts rather keywords in web pages or word processing documents. Mr Lynch holds 20% of the company which is now worth $5bn.

David Potter, at number 38, gained fame after a leaked memo from Bill Gates identified Psion as the chief emerging threat to Microsoft. Psion's Epoc operating system for mobile phones has become standard for accessing the internet.

webTitle: If the cap, t-shirt and trainers fit

fields.headline: If the cap, t-shirt and trainers fit
fields.standfirst: Do you dress down for work and go to ridiculous lengths to avoid wearing a suit? Then you could be one of a growing breed of Clobber Snobs
fields.trailText: Status symbols have died a death in the workplace. Executive dining rooms have vanished, the company car has been replaced by the bus pass. But when the Armani suit is traded in for leisurewear and trainers, you know you've entered a new era in the workplacethe Age of the Clobber Snob.
fields.body:
Status symbols have died a death in the workplace. Executive dining rooms have vanished, the company car has been replaced by the bus pass. But when the Armani suit is traded in for leisurewear and trainers, you know you've entered a new era in the workplacethe Age of the Clobber Snob.

The rules

To play the game you need to be aware of the rules. Flashiness is out and subtlety's the order of the day. Clobber Snobs eschew the gym 'n' gin and laugh in the face of the company Jag. They revel in looking scruffy as hell and will only apologise if you catch a glimpse of the well-hidden designer label.

How to be a Clobber Snob

Hair: Choose your hairdresser with care. Anyone with a six-month waiting list and prices to make you vomit violently will do. Then you refer to him as your barber to colleagues, as in: "Nicky Clarke? Oh yeah, I know him, he's my barber." Once you've had your hair styled by the maestro, do not wash or comb it yourself between visits. Only visit the salon twice a year.

Clothes: Dress down for work and think dark. The new net millionaires all look like swotty teenagers, so think nerd when you're shopping at Prada or Gucci. The trick is to dress expensive but look as though you paid peanuts. Sleeves should be long enough to cover knuckles. Some underwear must be showing somewhere.

Drinks: Clobber Snobs walk in each morning carrying their paper cup of couture latte or capuccino and a skinny muffin. They select their coffee 'to go' as carefully as a wine buff sniffing through a cellar full of chardonnay. Only the best will do. They will never pay less than two pounds a cup and will be delighted when the price goes up. To them the office coffee machine might as well dispense rat poison.

Eye-wear: With business dress decidedly downwardly-mobile, one of the few ways the Clobber Snob can express him or herself is through their specs. Contacts are a thing of the past and designer frames are de rigeur. Shapes need to be as weird and unflattering as possible. As a general rule of thumb, the fatter the head the tinier the frames, giving the wearer that Goebbels/Dr Crippen look.

Gadgets: Laptops and mobiles are still the thing to flaunt, although less is more in terms of size. If it can't fit into your palm then you shouldn't be seen dead with it. A phone the size of a nesting hamster should be capable of every chore imaginable, from faxing and emailing, to reading your tarot and wiping your bottom.

Away days: A good firm is currently judged more by its imaginative training courses than the quality of the job itself. Clobber Snobs will discuss their team-building methods with colleagues from other departments and rivalry is fierce. Paint-balling and go-karting are out. Grizzly-wrestling in the Rockies or fire-walking on the edge of Mount Etna are what you should be aiming for. Ditto the office Christmas party location, which should be as off-the-wall and happening as possible. The biggest put-down a Clobber Snob can employ is: "Oh, we held a bash there three years ago."

Job title: Whatever your job, it will need the right title. Clobber Snobs prefer them as long and indecipherable as possible. Forget income and perks, the title is all. Anything that fits on to one line of a business card just will not do. Start with the words "Head of.." and add your own departments, being as creative as possible en route. Try to get some initials and the word "domain" in there somewhere. Translate into three languages on the business card for added kudos.

fields.headline: No 11: Sticky tack
fields.trailText: The 1970s will be remembered for many things, but - while lots of them are tacky - tack itself seems unlikely to be one of them. Yet the launch of Blu Tack, the first blob-like stuff designed to hold paper on walls, belongs to that decade too.
fields.body:
The 1970s will be remembered for many things, but - while lots of them are tacky - tack itself seems unlikely to be one of them. Yet the launch of Blu Tack, the first blob-like stuff designed to hold paper on walls, belongs to that decade too.

The notion of reusable putty-like adhesives seemed weird at first. People didn't want to know that it was made from masticated synthetic rubber combined with synthetic mineral fillers, pigments and oils coated in wax. All they knew was that it grew softer when heated and harder when cooled, and it was unlike anything they had seen before.

This, incidentally, is why the most famous brand of sticky tack - and there are many others, in white and pink and green - ended up blue. Market research revealed that consumers were worried children might mistake the moulded bars for confectionery so, as there were no blue sweets on the market at the time, blue it became.

Hostility to sticky tack hasn't vanished. Today, the war is waged primarily by universities across the country, fearful that students will disfigure the paintwork of their halls of residence by displaying that enduringly hilarious poster of the Mona Lisa with a spliff.

If only they knew of another attempted use for Blu Tack, they'd have more cause to be worried for the youngsters in their care: manufacturer Bostik claims, improbably, to have been contacted by a psychiatric nurse concerned that patients were drying the stuff out in the airing cupboard, wrapping it in cigarette paper and smoking it.

For the rest of us, though, sticky tack is still about the most versatile tool of office life and, indeed, life in general: for cleaning dirt from typewriters, erasing pencil marks, or preventing car windscreen sprays from icing over in winter. Or, if you want to be really boring, for attaching bits of paper to the wall.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: T here are few things more glamorous than a charity dinner or awards ceremony at the Dorchester hotel. Champagne, chandeliers and cut glass tableware, everything has to be perfect - and no one knows that better than Connie Okonta. As PA to Charlotte Vickers, the hotel's banqueting manager, she oversees everything from weddings to bar mitzvahs to the Bafta awards.
fields.body:
T here are few things more glamorous than a charity dinner or awards ceremony at the Dorchester hotel. Champagne, chandeliers and cut glass tableware, everything has to be perfect - and no one knows that better than Connie Okonta. As PA to Charlotte Vickers, the hotel's banqueting manager, she oversees everything from weddings to bar mitzvahs to the Bafta awards.

"My job is to be on the phone," says Okonta, "liaising with everyone from the clients to the caterer, and ensuring each person knows their role. Every function has different requirements - a corporate dinner needs a very different type of entertainer from a charity lunch, wedding parties may request a particular type of linen or china, an awards ceremony will need complicated table plans and settings."

Each event has a separate file, which is passed to Okonta from her boss. On a busy day, she may receive 20 files, although there is not necessarily something to do on each one. "I've been doing this job for three years now and I've learnt that the only way to keep on top of it is to make lists," she says. "It would be so easy to forget to book the caterer, or give the wrong date to a florist. Each morning I make a list and tick things off as I go. At least that way I feel I'm in control."

Although some clients come armed with a clear idea of the sort of function they want, others need guidance. "In a hotel such as the Dorchester you have to make the client feel special. Sometimes you have to guide them as to what would work - what kind of band or meal - and show them the available rooms. Invariably you're helping to arrange a special occasion, so you have to think about what will work best for them."

Even with the best organisation, things can go wrong and that, according to Okonta, is when interpersonal skills come into play. "Sometimes you can't get the particular linen they ordered, or an after-dinner speaker may fall ill and cancel at the last minute. In that case it's important not to go to the client armed only with bad news - I would always line up at least two alternatives so that they felt they still had options."

In spite of the sometimes manic nature of her job, she admits the pressures are nothing compared to those her boss experiences. "Part of my role is to take some of the responsibility off her shoulders, to field calls and answer queries so she doesn't get bogged down in the details. It can be frenetic, but it is hugely rewarding. If there's a wedding reception and you see that the bride is thrilled, it feels great to have been a part of that."

Okonta offers these tips:

* Make lists. Write everything down and tick it off only when it is totally organised.

* Try to remain cheerful - everyone reacts better to someone who sounds upbeat and positive.

* However pressurised things feel, take regular breaks to make sure you get away from your desk.

* A couple of days before the event, get out the file and double-check that every single aspect has been dealt with.

fields.headline: Criminal acts
fields.standfirst:
Blagger
Clore Studio, Royal Opera House, London
*
fields.trailText: It's a long journey from HMP Wayland to the Royal Opera House, where Escape Artists - a company which aims to rehabilitate serving and ex-prisoners - present their latest work. Blagger is an earnest, arduous account of the travails of one Billy Dobbs, a sensitive youth from the wrong side of the tracks, who falls in with bad company to the whiny soundtrack of a girlfriend's complaints. It's a hectoring affair, which may struggle to attract the audience it seeks to influence.
fields.body:
It's a long journey from HMP Wayland to the Royal Opera House, where Escape Artists - a company which aims to rehabilitate serving and ex-prisoners - present their latest work. Blagger is an earnest, arduous account of the travails of one Billy Dobbs, a sensitive youth from the wrong side of the tracks, who falls in with bad company to the whiny soundtrack of a girlfriend's complaints. It's a hectoring affair, which may struggle to attract the audience it seeks to influence.

The numerous problems with Blagger begin with Matthew Taylor's script, which plays as if transcribed, with minimal editing, from improvisations. The dialogue is lifeless; the play is bereft of subtext and dramatic impetus.

Its by-numbers account of a young man's descent into Class A's and crime begins discouragingly, with Billy (a committed Jamie Harden) shouting a lot about how miserable he is. Billy, we know the feeling.

Shuffling spinelessly from one crisis to the next, the character is terminally weak-willed: a trait which - Hamlet notwithstanding - tends to pre-empt great drama. We're given nothing to like about the character, so it's hard to care when his life goes belly-up. The resulting piece has little more to say than that crime doesn't pay, a moral frequently stifled by over-insistent incidental music and the Clore Studio's cavernous acoustic.

Billy's supporting cast can't animate the affair. Paul Malcolm is effectively repulsive as an off-the-shelf sociopath who peddles homophobic innuendo and pills. Katarina Olsson has the rawest deal as the lachrymose bit of posh doomed to nag her wayward beau and crave domesticity. Only Simon Hyde as dim-witted wideboy Frank raises a flicker of interest in a production which seeks to counsel against crime and ends up, in theatrical terms at least, perpetrating one.

fields.headline: Toby Litt's top 10 crime novels
fields.trailText: Toby Litt is the author of several books, including Beatniks, Corpsing and deadkidsongs
fields.body:
Toby Litt is the author of several books, including Beatniks, Corpsing and deadkidsongs.
Read an extract from Corpsing at the Penguin site

Giving away plots is something I never do, so these may be a tad gnomic. Also, I have problems with the ultra-ultra-hardboiled - case in point: James Ellroy. Now, I got, and digged, Dick Contino's Blues. But reading White Jazz is like decoding telegrams from the compiler of a dictionary of 50s cop slang; for the moment at least, it's got me beat. Here, however, is a wide selection of recent, decent reads.

1. A Study In Scarlet by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
Holmes meets Watson. Holmes mainlines some cocaine. Holmes and Watson go off to solve not particularly foxing crimes. You know the rest. Or maybe you don't...

2. Dead Clever by Scarlett Thomas
The first Lily Pascale novel - feisty heroine, or what? If there's a dark, scary corridor, Lily will go down it. (Don't!) If there's a killer on the road, Lily will make him squirm like a toad. (Do!) And the little darling lives in deepest, darkest Devon. Emmets (or is it grockles?) beware.

3. The Killer Inside Me by Jim Thompson
Everybody knows Thompson is weird. But if you get to the end of this - and I guarantee that if you start it, you will - you'll find he's outweirded even himself. Rule-breaking is what he does - sometimes you wonder if he even knows there are rules.

4. The Big Lebowski by Ethan and Joel Coen
A bit of a cheat this one, but the screenplay just about edges in as a book. One of the most recent takes on Chandler/LA noir, and the use of Dylan's 'The Man In Me' on the soundtrack was inspired.

5. A Philosophical Investigation by Philip Kerr
A really interesting attempt to do high and low in one go (compare my new novel, Corpsing.) A super-literate villain with a weakness for Wittgenstein (the title's no accident) thinks he can easily outplot the plods.

6. Double Indemnity by James M. Cain
Extraordinary plotting, and the storytelling voice is just exquisite: "All I saw was a living room like every living room in California, maybe a little more expensive than some, but nothing that any department store wouldn't deliver on one truck, lay out in the morning, and have the credit OK ready the same afternoon."

7. Cruel and Unusual by Patricia Cornwell
Before the decadence of overproduction set in. This, I think, is the best of the Scarpetta novels - the last one, I couldn't even get started with.

8. Brighton Rock by Graham Greene
The opening is about as thrilling as Greene ever got - but then, it's about as thrilling as almost any English writer ever got. Razor boys in Brighton, a meditation on the nature of Divine Grace - what more could you want? (Footnote: Inspired Morrissey's last decent song, 'Now My Heart Is Full'.)

9. The Ipcress File by Len Deighton
Harry Palmer's first Burberryed and bespectacled outing. The self-conscious cool of Deighton's writing has dated in the best way possible; bear in mind that the man was almost single-handedly responsible for bringing coffee culture to the British Isles. Stone-cold Cold War classic.

10. The Driver's Seat by Muriel Spark
Short and very, very sweet. Spark is wonderful on the little details of a woman's perversion. Read this and foreign travel will never seem quite the same again.

fields.headline: Kate Atkinson's top 10 books
fields.trailText: Winner of the 1995 Whitbread Book of the Year award with Behind the Scenes at the Museum, Kate Atkinson's latest book, Emotionally Weird, is published by Doubleday
fields.body:
Winner of the 1995 Whitbread Book of the Year award with Behind the Scenes at the Museum, Kate Atkinson's latest book, Emotionally Weird, is published by Doubleday.
Buy Emotionally Weird at Amazon.co.uk

1. The Great Gatsby by F Scott Fitzgerald
Perhaps the best American novel (although see '10') or the best novel about America and the hollowness at the heart of the dream. The closing paragraphs of 'Gatsby' are surely some of the most poignant and powerful ever written.

2. Slaughterhouse Five by Kurt Vonnegut
The individuality of Vonnegut's style is a curious yet perfect match for the pain of the emotional content. A humane, human book that always remains a work of art rather than biography, no matter how apparent the author's presence.

3. Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen
The Mozart opera of novels and again a transcendent union of structure and content in which unhappy marriage is the reward for those who show a weakness of character and lifelong happiness is a province reserved only for those "who truly know themselves."

4. Just William by Richmal Crompton
The funniest English novels ever written?

5. What Maisie Knew by Henry James
The other side of childhood and James' finest working of his preoccupation with the theme of innocence corrupted. James is the master of making what is not said the most important thing on the page.

6. Pricksongs and Descants by Robert Coover/Collected Stories by Donald Barthelme
Two of the most innovative of all American short story writers. Recklessly imaginative, they are both remarkable for the playfulness and sheer brio of their writing. Coover's ingenuity and Barthelme's absurdity made me look at writing in a different way. More than anyone else these are the writers who made me want to be a writer myself.

7. Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass by Lewis Carroll
And without these two books in my childhood I doubt whether my imagination would have developed at all.

8. Lolita by Vladimir Nabokov
The finest American novel not written by an American. Perhaps the finest American novel ever (but see '1'. And don't forget '10'.) No one can emulate Nabokov's dizzyingly vertiginous prose and his command of the text.

9. Middlemarch by George Eliot
Eliot could write bad books (Romola) and half-brilliant books (Daniel Deronda - the first half) but in Middlemarch her serious intelligence produced a novel that no one else could have been capable of - a picture of society as an organic, living, breathing synthesis - order and disorder, hope and hopelessness, pride and humility, charity and greed. If only she had seen fit to marry Dorothea to Lydgate.

10. Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain
The perfect novel.

... And I can't believe there wasn't room for 11. The Good Soldier by Ford Madox Ford, a novel about the wanton destruction caused by passion and bad behaviour, written with the greatest delicacy and precision.
